webTitle: Kalms shrugs off fears over Freeserve's future

fields.headline: Kalms shrugs off fears over Freeserve's future
fields.trailText: Sir Stanley Kalms, chairman of Dixons, yesterday brushed aside anxieties about the electrical retailer's volatile share price as he outlined plans for further expansion in Europe and hinted at new ownership arrangements for Freeserve, the internet service provider.
fields.body:
Sir Stanley Kalms, chairman of Dixons, yesterday brushed aside anxieties about the electrical retailer's volatile share price as he outlined plans for further expansion in Europe and hinted at new ownership arrangements for Freeserve, the internet service provider.

A strong opponent of Britain adopting the euro, Sir Stanley said the group would look for "more acquisitions and more opportunities" in Europe, where it already has operations in 11 countries.

He reiterated his opposition to "giving up sterling" but said this did not mean he was against going into business on the continent.

In Britain, competition has forced Dixons - along with its subsidiaries Currys, PC World and The Link - to cut the price of many products. The company is planning a new style of store, aimed at offering a wider range of "off-the-shelf" products rather than relying on staff to bring out goods to customers.

The company admitted that many older "mature market" goods - such as television sets and video recorders -were falling in price. But it expected that newer products will eventually replace the lost income.

While investors are struggling with Dixon's see-saw share price, Sir Stanley appeared unconcerned. The shares closed at 274p, down 6p yesterday, suffering from the absence of news about the retailer's plans for Freeserve following the failure of talks with the German company T-Online.

Sixty-nine-year-old Sir Stanley would only say yes terday that Dixons was "looking to see if we can have a better arrangement" so that it can expand Freeserve's operations. This might involve a sale - Dixons is said to have talked with BT and NTL - or even an acquisition.

Dixons reported a better than expected profits of £264m for the year to end-April - surprising since its margins had been hit by competition on the high street and the falls in prod uct prices. The final dividend is 3.55p, taking the total to 4.6p, up 20%.

 Comet, a close rival to Dixons, is to create hundreds of new jobs by opening 18 new superstores. Each of the new stores will employ up to 50 people, the retailer said.

The new stores will offer kitchen and home appliances at low prices all year round rather than having seasonal sales.

fields.headline: Little dabs of colour
fields.standfirst:
Endymion Ensemble/ Paul Silverthorne and David Le Page
Hoxton Hall, London
***
fields.trailText:
Endymion Ensemble/ Paul Silverthorne and David Le Page
Hoxton Hall, London
***
fields.body:
The Endymion Ensemble's concert at Hoxton Hall as part of the Hoxton New Music Days was a celebration of the musical miniature. Not surprisingly, the perfectly formed shards of Gyorgy Kurtag's music featured prominently. In SK Remembrance Noise, soprano Sarah Leonard was joined by violinist Marshall Marcus in settings of haiku-like lines by Dezso Tandori. In conventional terms, each 30-second piece is a musical fragment, no more complete than a page ripped out from a larger structure. But Kurtag creates self-sufficient poetic experiences within this ultra-compressed time frame.

Road to Damascus was a gradual - a relative term in Kurtag's music - increase in intensity and volume in both voice and violin parts. After the climax, the violin reached a point of stasis, and quietly intoned the limits of the journey just undertaken. A contrast between two kinds of musical time, and a resonant suggestion of a Damascene transformation from darkness to light - all in less time than it takes to describe what happened.

Kurtag's music is a touchstone for creating drama and conflict in small-scale pieces. Works by Kaija Saariaho and Per Norgard took a different approach, luxuriating in the textures of particular instrumental combinations. Saariaho's Oi Kuu fused a bass clarinet and cello together, creating a virtual instrument in the intersection between the bass clarinet's breathiness and the cello's half-formed bow-strokes. Norgard's Lark Song was a playful meditation on a simple, tonal melody for flute, violin and cello.

Andrew Hamilton's soprano + horn =, a first performance, cut up a text by Jasper Johns and set it to a similarly scarified music of rhythmic insistence. Music by Oliver Knussen and Harrison Birtwistle framed the concert - Knussen's expressive, keening settings of poems by Rilke for solo soprano, and Birtwistle's Monody, for soprano and ensemble. At around 10 minutes long, this piece sounded extravagantly large-scale in comparison with the rest of the concert.

A late-night recital of solo works for violin and viola continued the Hoxton New Music Days' Bach and Today series, with three works of enormous difficulty and ambition. Robin Holloway's solo viola sonata, another world premiere, defined an idiomatic world of melancholy invention that Paul Silverthorne communicated with conviction. David Le Page's performances of Bach and Luciano Berio were impressive feats of stamina and technique. After the tortuous complexities of the Adagio and Fugue from Bach's C major sonata, Le Page followed with Berio's Sequenza VIII. Hearing the pieces in succession, it was the Bach that sounded the more impossible and labyrinthine; Berio's music was positively accessible by comparison.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Pension open to 8m more
fields.trailText: Eight million more people will be able to buy stakeholder pensions following a new government ruling.
fields.body:
Eight million more people will be able to buy stakeholder pensions following a new government ruling.

Under "concurrency" - the technical name for membership of more than one scheme at the same time - most occupational pension members will also be able to invest up to £3,600 a year into a stakeholder plan when the low cost schemes come on line next April, irrespective of other pension payments.

Stakeholder schemes - designed by the government as a low cost alternative pension to encourage low to middle income workers to save for their retirement - previously only applied to those outside final salary pension schemes. The exceptions to the rule relaxation are employees earning more than £30,000 a year and controlling directors.

But once lower paid employees qualify, they can continue to pay into a stakeholder plan for a further four years even if their earnings go through the £30,000 ceiling.

Treasury economic secretary Melanie Johnson said the £30,000 line had been chosen because "it was nice and easy round number. We shall not be index-linking this or raising it annually in other ways so it will remain a simple-to-remember figure. Allowing stakeholders to stay in for five years is intended to help people plan ahead.

"Stakeholder will be valuable for those who frequently move jobs but we don't want people quitting occupational schemes," she said.

Concurrency is the result of lobbying by life insurance companies who intend selling stakeholder plans next year. However, some firms and the Conservative party want "full concurrency" before allowing everyone to join stakeholder.

Shadow social security secretary David Willetts yesterday attacked the £30,000 limit as "another unnecessary complication in a regime that is already far too complex".

Inland revenue calculates that the £30,000 ceiling involves a £150m a year tax relief cost by 2010, while full concurrency would cost the Treasury £400m a year.

webTitle: A Date with the Devil: Samuel Ramey

fields.headline: A Date with the Devil: Samuel Ramey
fields.standfirst:
Barbican, London
***
fields.trailText:
Barbican, London
***
fields.body:
Most of us, asked to imagine the Devil, wouldn't automatically come up with the idea of a handsome, nattily coiffed Texan in a black silk suit. Cult performer Samuel Ramey has been specialising in operatic incarnations of Old Nick for some time, eventually coming up with the idea of what one might call a "themed recital". A Date with the Devil was a hit in the US when first performed in 1996. It has only now reached London, and it played to a predictably packed Barbican Hall.

The format is simple: diabolical arias are interspersed with a series of orchestral "pops" that carry with them a whiff of wickedness. Since the latter include the Can-Can from Orpheus in the Underworld (called Galop Infernale in the score), we're not exactly in Exorcist territory.

An atmosphere of salacious naughtiness reigns. Taking their cue from Goethe's Faust (the original source of over half of Ramey's material), 19th-century writers and composers brought the Devil on stage to give prurient voice to the hidden agendas of the times. Berlioz's Mephistopheles gleefully portrays flea-ridden royalty made politically redundant by ceaseless scratching. Gounod's version of the same character encourages the monetary free-for-all of capitalism. Illicit sex is omnipresent. Meyerbeer's Robert le Diable was a big hit in its day, and when you hear its demonic invocation to randy nuns who sniff "the lewd incense of pleasure", you understand what got the Victorians going.

Nineteenth-century composers often worked on the assumption that the higher the voice, the more moral the character, so the Devil got all the low notes, whence Ramey. Not everything suits him. Once a bass, he's pushed his voice up to bass-baritone status, with the result that Arrigo Boito's Mefistofele now lies a bit low for him. Gounod's Mephistopheles finds him at his best, his voice flickering like demonic fire, then turning velvety, sexy and snide as he goads Faust into taking Marguerite's virginity. Some of the music is samey. The diabolical bass was given a lot of scherzos to sing.

Ramey isn't always helped by his conductor, Hal France, whose contribution was lacklustre at best. Some of the orchestral excerpts dragged unmercifully and the RPO weren't, by any means, at their best.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Caught in the middle
fields.trailText: 6 July: My work is split between two teams. One team leader maliciously spreads gossip about me to keep himself top dog.
fields.body:
The problem

I have worked in a small manufacturing company for only 4 weeks. I am 28 years old. The job is relaxed, the pay is not fabulous but I cannot complain. The problem is that the team is divided in two groups, and I have to work with both teams.

One team leader keeps himself top dog with a ruthless use of company gossip. He is aggressive but he had done it like that for the past 25 years. Luckily the other is quite the opposite but the problem is that I am caught in the middle. Gossip has started already so I really need to know how to handle my co-workers?

The solution

OK, you need to tread quite carefully since you have only been with the company for four weeks. You are not in any position to make waves by confronting the Bad Guy leader. All you can do is protect your back and try and get in with both teams.

I suggest that you take three tacks in your attempts to stay in with everyone. The first involves ingratiating yourself with Mr Bad Guy, the second concerns coping with the gossip, whilst the third tack involves getting on with your co-workers. I'll go through each in turn:

Dealing with Mr Bad Guy: Sorry to be the bearer of bad news, but you are going to have to suck up to this guy a bit. Not too much - but just enough to encourage him to cut the gossip a bit. Forget his numerous character flaws, and try to find something to relate to with him. Talk to him, agree with him (not all the time!), flatter him occasionally, do favours for him - anything to get him on your side. But, don't overdo it since he will probably twig what your game is whilst really cheesing off your co-workers.

Coping with the gossip: There are several approaches to countering gossip that depend on what is being said. One way is to spread rumours about yourself that contradict the gossip. Another is to deny it. A third approach is to simply ignore it. But, the best approach in your case could be to tackle the source of the gossip-mongering - Mr Bad Guy - and tell him how the rumours are getting you down. If you have followed

Step 1 and won him over a little, he may be more inclined to stop.

Getting on with co-workers: Your final strategy involves you being everyone's buddy. Harder said than done, but you really need to cultivate an image of being a likeable, harmless chap/chapess who fits in with both camps. Try and socialise with both teams where possible, but avoid any gossip about the opposing team. Resist being drawn into the us and them competition by making non-committal remarks.

What you are hoping to achieve is hard, but, with some tact and diplomacy, you might achieve it. Of course, if you do succeed, you might then wish to consider a career change to the diplomatic service!

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

fields.headline: Retailers feel the pinch
fields.standfirst: Slow sales growth and static housing market prompt calls for no change on interest rates
fields.trailText: Sales growth in Britain's shops fell last month, acording to the Confederation of British Industry. Together with figures indicating that the boom in house prices is over, the survey prompted renewed calls from industry and homeowners for the Bank of England to leave interest rates on hold.
fields.body:
Sales growth in Britain's shops fell last month, acording to the Confederation of British Industry. Together with figures indicating that the boom in house prices is over, the survey prompted renewed calls from industry and homeowners for the Bank of England to leave interest rates on hold.

As the Bank's monetary policy committee began its deliberations yesterday morning, the latest snapshot of the retail sector published by the CBI showed that sales growth in June was at its lowest for more than a year. The balance of retailers reporting increased sales volumes last month dropped to +15% from +45% the previous month -the second largest fall in the survey's 17-year history.

"The message from retailers to the Bank of England is clear," said Alastair Eperon, chairman of the CBI's distributive trades panel. "There is no sign of a consumer boom, so interest rates can be safely left on hold."

The news of a slowdown on the high streets came as sepa rate data showed that the growth in the services sector, of which retailing is part, had eased to a five-month low. Over the past four years the services sector has been the main engine of growth in the economy, outpacing the flagging manufacturing sector.

All the main sub-sectors of service economy reported slower growth, according to figures published by the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply. Firms also reported a marked downturn in plans to take on new workers.

"These [CIPS] figures could not have been designed better to allow the MPC to leave interest rates on hold," said Trevor Williams, economist at Lloyds TSB.

If the Bank leaves interest rates on hold today at 6%, as is widely expected, it will be the fifth consecutive month that it has made no change. As each month passes, commentators are becoming increasingly confident in their prediction that the next move by the MPC will be downwards.

Expectations that interest rates have peaked helped to send sterling sliding against other major currencies yester day. The pound fell to $1.5105, after having peaked at $1.5166, while against the euro it slipped to 0.6327p from 0.6278p earlier.

But some analysts cautioned that the Bank has surprised borrowers before with an unexpected rise in rates after sitting on its hands for months. The minutes of the June meeting revealed that three of the nine MPC members favoured higher borrowing costs.

Since the June meeting, however, various data have pointed to a slowdown in the economy. Wage inflation has fallen back to 4.4%, just below the level which the Bank believes is consistent with its inflation target. Domestic de mand growth in the first quarter has been revised down to 0.2% and house prices have fallen for the fourth time in five months, leaving the average property worth £1,300 less than it was in January, according to new figures which confirm the housing boom is over.

The cost of a typical home fell 0.4% in June and now stands at £83,903, said the Halifax, Britain's largest mortgage lender. In January the figure was £85,244. This latest fall pushes the annual rate of house price growth down to 9.2% - the lowest figure since September 1999.

The figures are at odds, however, with the latest data from Nationwide building society, which said on Monday that the cost of an average home rose by 0.4% in June.

The Halifax said: "Last month's modest decline in house prices provides further evidence that the housing market is slowing down. Annual house price inflation is now well below the 16% peak attained in January."

But the bank dispelled suggestions that the slowdown could turn into a slump, saying that the favourable economic background should ensure a "relatively robust" housing market over the remainder of the year.

Prices fell by between 0.4% and 0.9% in February, March, May and June, compared with the sharp rises in excess of 2% seen in December and January, according to the Halifax.

fields.headline: Scraps of great talent
fields.standfirst:
George Benson
Royal Concert Hall, Glasgow
**
fields.trailText:
George Benson
Royal Concert Hall, Glasgow
**
fields.body:
Maybe it was the heady mix of perfumes clogging the air, maybe it was the dressed-up, predominantly female audience, or maybe the programmed perfection of a show made up of soft soul, light funk and ballads, but Ally McBeal kept popping into my mind during the opening night of the reinvigorated Glasgow Jazz Festival.

With a wide smile curving under a perfectly trimmed pencil moustache, George Benson sauntered on stage dressed in soft silks and a sparkly waistcoat, looking almost as glossily perfect as his latest air-brushed album-cover portrait for Absolute Benson. He is 57, looks 37, and used to play pure jazz guitar. Once upon a time he sat in with and hung out with Miles Davis and John Coltrane, and he was a protege of Wes Montgomery, in the 70s recalling his speedy delicacy and rhythmic command. Then, as he tells us, his father advised him: "Don't get too serious." And he didn't, deliberately taking the crossover path away from musical exploration into the 80s disco heartland.

And it's all very 80s, with a pre-clubbing, debonair disco feel, which it has to be said - Ally McBeal again - is making a comeback, with Benson poised as the master of an easy, smooth style. This was a big pyrotechnic smooch of a show.

When Benson does pick up the guitar, he is in flight, the light, zipping melody lines and cross-cutting chops fabulous and fluid. He gets vaguely funky with Donny Hathaway's classic The Ghetto. But it is pious funk, never touching in the libido and the dirty sweat of the music.

Near the end he leaves his platinum cover song book to play an instrumental version of Danny Boy. That may sound mawkish but Benson introduced a breathtaking chordal complexity that broke down and somehow re-formed the melody while skimming improvisations over the surface. Then he led an army of arm-swinging fans into The Greatest Love of All, the audience in raptures.

He plays Give Me the Night, with those zinging guitar lines and solid dance-floor beats, and strolls off, teeth twinkling, not a hair nor a cufflink disturbed. I sense that he will be packed away with his guitar for transportation to another gleaming, hermetically sealed performance. For the real guitar aficionado all that was left were the scraps of a great talent. Jazz, but only just.

The Glasgow Jazz Festival continues until July 9. Box office: 0141-287 5511

fields.headline: The Swingle Singers
fields.standfirst:
City of London Festival
***
fields.trailText:
City of London Festival
***
fields.body:
The Swingle Singers have built their reputation on the works of JS Bach but are not afraid to embrace new work. Like the pianist Jacques Loussier, who also played in this year's City of London Festival, the group's founder, Ward Swingle, recognised in the 60s that the distance between baroque music and jazz was not so great and transcribed Bach's greatest hits for an octet of wordless jazz voices.

In the context of the baroque transcriptions that had dominated the first half, it was interesting to hear Balancing the Books, a new commission from Michael Nyman. This is one of seven new works commissioned by the Swingle Singers for the 250th anniversary of Bach's death, and is based loosely around ideas gleaned from the two volumes of Bach's 48 preludes and fugues.

Whereas the previous pieces had been originally written for instruments and usurped by voices, the punchy accents, semiquaver figuration and sustained notes on which this work for voices is built could easily have been written with strings in mind.

If the singers had demonstrated how close baroque can come to jazz, then Nyman's piece showed that minimalism also grew up in the same neighbourhood. The work is built on minimalist techniques of repetition and episodic, gradually accumulating textures, with melodies cutting chorale-like through established patterns of notes. Balancing the Books didn't push back any boundaries, but was aptly written for the group that commissioned it.

There are limits on what the Swingle Singers can do as a group - and a few of them are to do with their constant use of microphones. Their unplugged voices could probably have filled the cavernous, ornate Gibson Hall, a mid-19th century banking hall, with relative ease. The microphones mean that the sopranos in particular sing in a very light jazz voice all the time; the sound is pretty but there's not much room for expression.

More sedate baroque pieces worked better on the whole than faster and more complex ones. CPE Bach's Solfeggietto had the singers passing the swiftly-flowing melody between them as if playing musical tennis, but the breakneck speed meant that the harmonies lacked clarity.

Once the novelty has worn off, they keep the show going with choreography, some inventive Beatles arrangements and some fairly ridiculous encores, dashed off with panache. They look the part, play to the audience and smile like mad - but at least they look like they're genuinely enjoying themselves.

fields.headline: Cordiant in £390m American takeover
fields.trailText: Cordiant Communications, the advertising agency, is moving into branding and corporate communications with a £392m takeover of the American Lighthouse Global Network.
fields.body:
Cordiant Communications, the advertising agency, is moving into branding and corporate communications with a £392m takeover of the American Lighthouse Global Network.

The all-share deal reflects Cordiant's strategy of building a one-stop shop for all its clients' promotional and marketing needs. It also furthers the group's ambition to build a big presence on both sides of the Atlantic.

Cordiant's chief executive, Michael Bungey, said: "Lighthouse has some extremely good businesses - they're fast growing and they have high margins. We were essentially an advertising agency with some services on the side. Now we really are truly a marketing and communications group."

Lighthouse's businesses include the London public relations firm Financial Dynamics, which handles communications in the City for a number of leading companies - including Glaxo Wellcome, Kingfisher, Tesco and Cadbury Schweppes.

Other subsidiaries include the design consultancy Fitch, - on its third revamp of the Debenhams department store chain - and the brand agency Primo Angeli, which has made the Green Giant on sweetcorn tins look more cheerful.

Cordiant, which owns the Bates Worldwide advertising network, has been anxious to expand since its creation through a demerger from Saatchi & Saatchi in 1997.

Under the terms of the deal, Cordiant will issue 75m new shares - worth £258m at yesterday's closing price - to the venture capital firms which own Lighthouse. The British group will also take on Lighthouse's debts.

Cordiant's share price slipped 27.5p to 344.5p, which analysts attributed to concerns about shares being diluted in the issue, and to declining hopes of a takeover.

Mr Bungey said the acquisition made Cordiant more attractive to bidders: "We've got the spotlight on us. People might well be coming up with interesting ideas to put to us."

The marketing industry has recently been shaken up by a spate of big deals: WPP bought Young & Rubicam, and the French Publicis group acquired Saatchi & Saatchi.

Consolidation has been driven by the need to provide a service to multinational clients, which increasingly want to project a uniform image throughout the world. Lighthouse clients include the BBC, Warner Brothers, Ben & Jerry's and Vodafone AirTouch.

Mr Bungey said: "Consolidation has just gathered pace and if you look around you, it suddenly looks as if there aren't many other independent groups around."

The two companies had been talking for more than four months before reaching agreement. The deal means that 35% of Cordiant's revenues will be generated in the US, up from 27%.

One analyst said: "Cordiant are not exactly buying a premium player - Lighthouse is something that has been bolted together by venture capitalists over the last couple of years. But they are paying a fair price and it is certainly in line with their strategy."

webTitle: Egg shares drop below float price

fields.headline: Egg shares drop below float price
fields.trailText: Egg got its first taste of the vagaries of the stock market yesterday when its recently floated shares closed below their offer price for the first time. The telephone-cum-internet bank, 80% owned by Prudential, became the latest victim of predictions that that an all-out price war is about to break out in mortgage lending.
fields.body:
Egg got its first taste of the vagaries of the stock market yesterday when its recently floated shares closed below their offer price for the first time.

The telephone-cum-internet bank, 80% owned by Prudential, became the latest victim of predictions that that an all-out price war is about to break out in mortgage lending.

The 8% decline came during another bad day for banking shares, bruised since the decision earlier in the week by HSBC to cut its standard variable rate for home loans by almost a full percentage point.

In addition to competitive pressures in home loan markets, the traditional mortgage banks - such as Halifax and Abbey National - are attempting to lure lucrative current account business from the big clearing banks, such as Barclays and Lloyds TSB, through new ventures such as Intelligent Finance and Cahoot.

Egg's shares, which were sold to investors last month at 160p, ended yesterday at 149.5p, 14p lower, as 38m shares had changed hands.

"The whole sector is down and Egg is stuck in that sector. It's not a surprise that it's fallen," one analyst said.

The retreat in the share price of Egg follows predictions by analysts, such as those at Deutsche Bank, that a price war among the big banks will make life more difficult for new upstarts to undercut established players.

Egg was one of the first "new entrants" and at its launch in 1998 was a thorn in the side of the traditional players, with its trendy advertising campaign and market beating interest rates on savings and mortgages.

Egg's slide was greater than the traditional banks yesterday, but they too were sharply lower. For instance, Barclays fell 90p to £15, while Alliance & Leicester slipped 30p to 527p and Halifax lost 23.5p on the day to 564.5p.

The malaise among the banking stocks has been building for a number of weeks during which leading analysts have been turning more negative against the sector ahead of the interim results reporting season later this month.

Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, the German stock broker, was yesterday the latest the line of brokers turn against the banking sector as whole.

Even the banks which have been long-standing favourites of analysts have been feeling the pain. Lloyds TSB, for example, yesterday gave up 14.5p to 590p.

webTitle: Banks and brays set for just deserts in Zurich

fields.headline: Banks and brays set for just deserts in Zurich
fields.trailText: The high priests of England's latest cult gather in Zurich today to hear the last rites to the ideology that brought them together in the first place.
fields.body:
The high priests of England's latest cult gather in Zurich today to hear the last rites to the ideology that brought them together in the first place.

Barring a last-minute comeback of French proportions Fifa's executive committee is expected finally to lay to rest England's ambitions to host the 2006 World Cup. South Africa are favourites, particularly now Brazil have pulled out and declared support for them, with Germany second, though virtually conceding to South Africa yesterday, and England struggling to make the second round of voting and seemingly set for another early return home.

From the moment the Football Association announced its intention to bid, following the success of Euro 96, the entire operation has been run with such myopic adherence to the cause that the Moonies look open-minded.

"The cult of the bid", as it has been dubbed, has involved anyone mildly critical being marginalised, vilified by organisers and, in some cases, openly abused.

Anyone who has questioned the sense behind the £10m campaign - England have spent almost twice as much as any other bidding nation - has been accused of being unpatriotic, cynical and even pro-German. Anyone backing the South Africans (as I have) stands accused of being naive and emotional.

Tony Banks, the former minister of sport and England's special envoy for the World Cup bid, once said he was keeping all the critical articles on the campaign and planned to approach those who had written them once England had got the World Cup (his words) and he would stick them in a place they were unlikely to forget but might find discomforting.

How Banks must regret his words, given the way the bid seems to be heading. It appeared doomed even before a group of English thugs smashed up an Irish bar in Brussels during Euro 2000.

England went into the bidding process on dodgy moral ground and without the backing of Fifa and Uefa. From the outset they were playing catch-up with South Africa and Germany who threw their hats into the ring earlier. For a start Uefa, which has eight votes on the Fifa executive, had backed Germany, so England started without the support of their own continental federation.

The Germans and Uefa claimed a gentleman's agreement had been drawn up between Sir Bert Millichip, then chairman of the FA, and Lennart Johansson, Uefa's president. In return for getting Euro '96 England would not stand in Germany's way for the 2006 World Cup.

The Germans cried foul, the English claimed that no such agreement existed. Privately government and football officials will say there was such an agreement but, whatever the truth, the damage had been done.

England persuaded Scotland's David Will to back their bid but have spent the past few years campaigning in an election where they know they will miss out on seven votes in a contest where only 13 are needed to win.

Ungentlemanly conduct aside, the writing has also been on the wall since Fifa's president Sepp Blatter stepped out of Downing Street last year after a meeting with Tony Blair. "Nice country," he said. "Great footballing history." But, when asked about the World Cup bid, he replied: "I think it should go to an African country. It's Africa's turn."

England's campaigners have not let that stand in their way. The lavish trips around the world continued, the palm pressing, parties and promotions have been of the highest order. There has been no shortage of enthusiasm, generosity and energy, just a distinct shortage of common sense combined with a load of arrogance.

Meeting Hugh Grant or dining with Prince Charles does not guarantee votes. Banks's lack of diplomacy has not helped. The direct style of England's campaign leader Alec McGivan has done little to charm Fifa delegates. So farewell England 2006? Probably - and properly, too.

webTitle: Luton's new broom sweeps out Lawrence

fields.headline: Luton's new broom sweeps out Lawrence
fields.trailText: Luton Town yesterday opted to clear the decks and pay off Lennie Lawrence after more than four seasons as their manager.
fields.body:
Luton Town yesterday opted to clear the decks and pay off Lennie Lawrence after more than four seasons as their manager.

The 52-year-old former Charlton and Middlesbrough manager, who officially departs Kenilworth Road by mutual consent, has accepted a severance deal put together by the club's new chairman Mike Watson-Challis.

Lawrence said: "Although the time of my departure has taken me by surprise, I believe the new owners will take the club forward.

"I am proud to have steered Luton through one of the most difficult periods of its history."

Lawrence took over in December 1995 but could not save the club from relegation to the Second Division that season, where they have remained despite the turmoil of being placed in administration for more than a year.

Luton have two candidates in mind for the post, one of them likely to be Iain Dowie, a former Town forward who is out of contract as a QPR player. Talk that Wimbledon's coach Mick Harford has been approached is wide of the mark.

Bradford's captain Stuart McCall has become the club's assistant manager, taking on the role vacated by Chris Hutchings, who moved up to become manager on the departure of Paul Jewell.

"I am delighted to say agreement has been reached with Stuart," said Geoffrey Richmond, Bradford's chairman. "He was more than happy to become Chris's assistant."

Birmingham, who yesterday completed the £3m sale of Gary Rowett to Leicester City, have signed Nicky Eaden from Barnsley on a free transfer. The 27-year-old has agreed a three-year contract. "He's my second signing of the summer after David Burrows. That's two new full-backs, both of whom have arrived under the Bosman ruling," said Birmingham's manager Trevor Francis.

Gillingham, preparing for life in the First Division, have signed Millwall's highly rated striker Paul Shaw for £450,000 and will pay Scunthorpe £250,000 for the defender Chris Hope. Both have signed four-year contracts.

John Scales, 34, a free agent since his contract expired at Spurs, has had a medical at Ipswich, who are also weighing up a £2m move for the Sunderland defender Jody Craddock.

Sunderland are hoping to conclude a £250,000 deal with Mechelen for Tom Peeters, a 21-year-old midfielder. "I didn't think I would get a chance to play in the Premiership so quickly," the Belgian said. "I'm looking forward to showing the fans what I can do."

fields.headline: Zoff throws in his hand
fields.trailText: Recriminations over Italy's Euro 2000 final defeat disintegrated into a political bloodsport yesterday when the coach Dino Zoff resigned in response to criticism by the opposition leader Silvio Berlusconi.
fields.body:
Recriminations over Italy's Euro 2000 final defeat disintegrated into a political bloodsport yesterday when the coach Dino Zoff resigned in response to criticism by the opposition leader Silvio Berlusconi.

Zoff, shaking with anger, declared he could not continue after being "offended as a man" by the accusation of incompetence. "I am not taking lessons in dignity from Berlusconi," he said. "I don't understand why someone has to undermine the work of someone else. I will reply to Berlusconi personally."

The 1982 World Cup-winning captain added that he had not slept since being labelled "an amateur". Players and fans, converted to the dour former goalkeeper by Italy's unexpectedly strong showing in the tournament, begged him to reconsider.

There had been no calls for Zoff to quit. Berlusconi, a media tycoon and also president of the Serie A club Milan, was almost a lone voice when he said that France's Zinedine Zidane should have been man-marked in the final, even though the defence appeared to have coped with the midfielder. "All it took was to understand this thing, and we would have won the game. It was unworthy," was Berlusconi's comment.

fields.headline: Ball bounces out hapless Worcester
fields.standfirst:
Gloucestershire 163
Worcestershire 158
Gloucestershire win by five runs
Scoreboard
fields.trailText:
Gloucestershire 163
Worcestershire 158
Gloucestershire win by five runs.
fields.body:
Gloucestershire's ambition to win an unprecedented four successive one-day finals was rekindled in the most contentious circumstances yesterday when they overcame Worcestershire in a NatWest third-round replay ordered because their opponents had fielded an ineligible player in the original tie.

The replay, held 13 days after Worcestershire's disallowed three-wicket win, possessed surprisingly little acrimony but much tension. Gloucestershire eventually squeezed a five-run win - and a fourth-round tie away to Leicestershire today - when the off-spinner Martyn Ball bowled Steve Rhodes with three balls left.

Paul Pollard's 55 had kept Worcestershire in touch with their target of 164, a demanding proposition considering a soft outfield and scowling skies, until he ran himself out attempting a second run to third man. Rhodes batted with enormous gumption for 43, striking 10 runs from the penultimate over by Jamie Averis, before Ball intervened.

That Worcestershire breached the regulations is indisputable, but the regulations could hardly be more obtuse. They basically state that Kabir Ali could not play for Worcestershire because, when he had previously played in the same competition for the Worcestershire Board XI, he had already played for Worcestershire.

The fact is the involvement of county board teams merely confuses everybody. If the England and Wales Cricket Board really wants the NatWest Trophy to become "an FA Cup of cricket" then the invitation of Premier Leagues or top club sides is the only option.

Worcestershire's septuagenarian stewards on the main gate were in a prickly mood yesterday, and there were no tea and cakes in the Ladies Pavilion - presumably because the tea ladies had inadvertently made a treacle tart for the Board XI after first making a jam sponge for Worcestershire and had therefore been ruled ineligible.

Gloucestershire's batsmen struggled. "We've stuffed 'em once and we can stuff 'em again," bawled one Worcestershire loyalist when Glenn McGrath snaffled the valuable wicket of Ian Harvey for an enterprising 32 from 29 balls.

But Worcestershire found it no easier. When Ryan Driver fell they had lost half their side for 61, with Averis chiefly responsible. He had Graeme Hick brilliantly caught at slip in his first over by Ball, the man of the match, and then claimed Vikram Solanki in his next when the batsman hauled a long hop to mid-on.

Just how latent can a talent be? Solanki has now made 10 single-figure scores in 12 one-day innings this season, suggesting his reputation could hardly be more insubstantial.

fields.headline: Ferguson moves for Barmby
fields.trailText: Manchester United have joined the hunt for the Everton midfielder Nick Barmby, 26, who last week enraged the blue half of Merseyside by announcing that he wanted to join Liverpool.
fields.body:
Manchester United have joined the hunt for the Everton midfielder Nick Barmby, 26, who last week enraged the blue half of Merseyside by announcing that he wanted to join Liverpool.

United's manager Sir Alex Ferguson has contacted Walter Smith to express interest. "He has asked to be kept informed about the situation but understandably he is reluctant to become involved in any auction," said the Everton manager, who may ask for another England midfielder, Nicky Butt, in exchange. Butt, 25, was not a first-team regular with United last season.

Barmby, who played in Euro 2000, wants a move to a club who will meet his demand of about £40,000 a week. Liverpool offered £3.5m for him last week but Everton want £8m and would probably do business at £5.75m, the price they paid Boro four years ago.

Steve Watson has joined Everton from Aston Villa for £2.5m but John Collins has been to London for talks with Fulham. Everton have informed the First Division club that the price is £3m.

fields.headline: The town hall Tories
fields.standfirst: A new brand of municipal Conservatism is taking hold
fields.trailText: A new brand of municipal Conservatism is taking hold
fields.body:
A new political force is emerging in town and county halls. It's called municipal Conservatism. Away from Westminster, a party once dedicated to squeezing the life-blood from local government has, in effect, turned full circle to become the champion of local democracy and defender of community action. Some progressive Tory counties, such as Kent, have even been labelled more New Labour than the party in power, with their commitment to the theme of tackling the causes and effects of social problems, from poverty to drug abuse.

Last week's annual conference in Bournemouth of the Local Government Association (LGA) was notable not for Labour ministers' set-piece contributions, but the emergence of Tories as social innovators as well as managers who have long believed that the much-vaunted party of business can run things better than Labour or the Lib-Dems.

With Tories controlling much of south-east England once again, along with familiar shires and big councils from Bradford to Plymouth, the party has now gained key positions within the LGA. It even chairs the key Improvement and Development Agency, a local authority-led self-policing body which is having some success with a special "councillors' academy", while improving town hall efficiency by sending in trouble-shooting squads to sort out collapsing boroughs like Hackney.

Sandy Bruce-Lockhart, a fruit farmer who leads Kent county council, is widely admired across the political spectrum for his pragmatic brand of Toryism. "I'm a strong believer in tackling the root cause of social problems through preventative work and not just by treating the effects," he says. "But I also feel very strongly about traditional Christian values. I do not know how you balance that between left and right. I would not put a label on it."

His five-year plan, produced after the Tories regained Kent three years ago, speaks of enhancing the quality of life for all residents and improving the accessibility, cost- effectiveness and quality of services while protecting the environment and building up the economy. This has meant not only pushing forward the vast Thames Gateway regeneration project - houses, new businesses and all - east from Dartford but also, at a more parochial level, restoring library opening hours and developing libraries as access centres for learning and business support.

In the old royal county of Berkshire, Paul Bettison, leader of Bracknell Forest district, a new unitary authority, is well on the way to making his council the first electronic borough.

Bettison, who will shortly become the LGA's housing spokesman, is a man in a hurry. He speaks of municipal Tories having a "degree of pragmatism which might not always have been there". His council will shortly give every resident the country's first "multi-application" smart card, which will provide access to swimming pools, libraries and many council services - while acting as a school attendance record for children and providing school meals payments through a "charge it up" facility. Soon this will be incorporated into a special, free mobile phone.

He is also planning to give every child a computer at school, as well as at home. "I am fairly middle of the road," he insists. "I believe in giving people the freedom to succeed . . . but you also have to give people freedom to fail. They need a safety net."

Conservatives, in short, are relishing their new-found commitment to local democracy. Lord (Paul) Hanningfield, leader of Essex county council, who heads the Tories on the LGA, says he is prepared to take party leader William Hague on his word that a future Tory government will hand back powers to town and county halls, giving them the freedom to set budgets without Whitehall interference.

Others, however, are not so sure. Will the Treasury, under whatever government, tolerate town halls having financial independence, free of the capping threat?

But Hanningfield is insistent. "Although the shadow Treasury team weren't so keen, we will not go back. I have that promise."

fields.headline: Estate of flux
fields.standfirst: From a flagship of the 1960s to its partial demolition and rebirth, Wembley's Chalkhill mirrors housing policy of three decades.  John Cunningham  reports
fields.trailText: From a flagship of the 1960s to its partial demolition and rebirth, Wembley's Chalkhill mirrors housing policy of three decades. John Cunningham reports
fields.body:
Classes in cookery, computers and gardening; advice on energy-saving and DIY - these are all activities run by many big estates for residents. But on the Chalkhill development in Wembley, north-west London, these summer events are not about leisure. Their purpose is more serious: to help rebuild a community fractured by the massive reconstruction of the estate and the consequent disruption for hundreds of families.

The programme was put on to mark completion of the first 30 of a batch of 450 new, low-rise homes. These are replacing huge, system-built slabs of flats that were at the cutting edge of municipal housing in the late 1960s, but gradually became problem blocks.

With its mix of accommodation, from bedsits to five-bedroom houses, sheltered housing, lock-up shops, a health centre and a police station -along with those system-built blocks - Chalkhill was a classy showplace, 30 years ago, of just how good local authority housing projects could be. No wonder the newly formed borough of Brent was proud of it - a flag to wave for Harold Wilson's vision of a Labour Britain.

In 1971, Senator Edward Kennedy was impressed on his visit to what was billed as one of Britain's finest housing projects. But by 1992, local MP Ken Livingstone was commiserating with a harassed resident with these words: "Nobody in their right mind wants to live [there]. It's a riot just waiting to explode."

Chalkhill encapsulates virtually every phase of public housing policy - and the mixed experience of tenants - over the past three decades. From high-density, high-tech, high-speed construction mopping up London's housing crisis in the 1960s, through right to buy, to the government's latest notion that councils surrender control to other social landlords.

On Chalkhill, Brent council is bowing out in line with a tenants' referendum which produced an 88% vote for a change of control. Richard Harrod, a councillor and leader of housing services, insists that the authority will monitor how well the new operator - New Horizons, a partnership between developer Wimpey and the Metropolitan Housing Trust - fulfills its duties.

The estate was built for 1,400 families, but about 700 have been decanted to other estates. Density will be much lower on the slimline Chalkhill. "About 1,100 people have gone, and the majority won't be coming back. It's like a bereavement," says Chris Mullan, who chairs one of two residents' associations, and lives in a one-person flat. Gloria Travers, who chairs the other group, and whose family has grown up in her three-bedroom town house, says: "We've got to put the community together again, but I don't think the lower density will make any difference."

What they, and everyone else agrees, is that the Chalkhill used to be a marvellous place to live. "The dream was a road to the sky; whole communities would move to the area; it would be car free," recalls Harrod, "It didn't work totally, but it didn't fail, totally, either."

It certainly began on a high note. Between the wars, the northern strip of land which eventually became the estate was occupied by a line of detached houses with large gardens. By the 1950s, the owners had died or moved; commercial developers bought the properties and proposed a private estate. In the end, a joint deal between the developers and the fledgling Brent council won the day. Chalkhill was designed and built by the council's planning and architecture departments - then in their heyday.

It's true that the system-built blocks had unappealing concrete exteriors, but inside the rooms were spacious; there was a ducted heating system and a novel rubbish disposal system. A unit in every kitchen chewed up all items of waste and so avoided the need for traditional refuse collection. There was none of the trauma of high-rise - the blocks were five storeys, arranged in crab-claw configurations, with decks running their length. These were designed so milk floats could make door to door deliveries.

Years later, Livingstone complained that the Conservatives were dumping homeless families on the estate. But it was very different early on. Chalkhill was choosy about its dwellers. "You had to have a reference from an employer and from a bank so you could become a tenant," recalls Travers, who moved with her husband, an electrician, and her then young family from rented accommodation in Kensal Rise.

However, controversy struck. First it was the empty flats. Many remained vacant for long periods in the late 1960s and early 1970s because rents at £6 for one bedroom and £11 for five bedrooms were beyond the means of many would be-tenants - scandalous in a London with a big shortage of council accommodation. Subsidies eventually helped, but when the Tories came to power, their policy of cost rents again excluded many potential residents.

Later, the endless decks became the haunts of muggers, vandals and drugtakers. "They could escape by running along the walkways and nobody could catch them," says Harrod. Resident porters with security cameras were introduced, but with mixed success. And an old fashioned idea - a small permanent police station - was tried, but gradually the hours have been cut back to the point where there's now no resident bobby.

As Chalkhill goes through its latest makeover, it is pertinent to ask why so much went wrong. There's wide agreement, among councillors and residents, that Brent underestimated the massive maintenance that the high-tech estate needed. This was aggravated by central government cuts, limiting spending during Labour's long (and the Tories' short) control of Brent. And Labour maintains that the Tories deliberately ran down the estate, from the late 1980s, because they wanted it razed and rebuilt.

But it's a complicated picture. On the land occupied by several demolished blocks, there's a shiny supermarket. "It's our new social club," quips Mullan. He may be joking, but it is open all hours, has a cafe, and a manager savvy enough to foster links with the community.

There's also a new, much smaller attraction on Chalkhill. It's a showhouse: one of the new, low-rise homes. It's very nice, visitors say. But then again they have said the same of other new homes through the years.

For now, the view has improved for the Travers family. From her first floor lounge, Gloria Travers looks across at a cleared site where Bison blocks once loomed. And all is peace for Mullan, as he helps his neighbours and the regeneration team turn a shabby corner of the estate into a fragment of garden.

With services functioning properly, all the Chalkhill folk have to do is plug in neighbourliness, turn on the switch - and show that it's still working.

35 years of housing law

1965 Fair rents introduced.

1972 Housing Finance Act brings in fair rents for council tenants.

1975 Fair rents abandoned in council sector.

1977 Councils must accommodate homeless families in specified priority needs groups.

1980 Right to buy introduced.

1982 Housing benefits established.

1986 Right to buy discounts increased; block sale of estates facilitated by law.

1988 New financial arrangements for housing associations. Housing action trusts start in England.

1996 New regulatory framework for registered social landlords. Amendments to housing benefit, tenants' rights and homelessness provisions.

2000 Green paper review of housing. Covers social and private rented sectors; also owner occupation.

Source: Chartered Institute of Housing.

"About 1,100 people have gone, and the majority won't be coming back. It's like a bereavement," says Chris Mullan, who chairs one of two residents' associations, and lives in a one-person flat. Gloria Travers, who chairs the other group, and whose family has grown up in her three-bedroom town house, says: "We've got to put the community together again, but I don't think the lower density will make any difference." What they, and everyone else agrees, is that the Chalkhill used to be a marvellous place to live. "The dream was a road to the sky; whole communities would move to the area; it would be car free," recalls Harrod, "It didn't work totally, but it didn't fail, totally, either." It certainly began on a high note. Between the wars, the northern strip of land which eventually became the estate was occupied by a line of detached houses with large gardens. By the 1950s, the owners had died or moved; commercial developers bought the properties and proposed a private estate. In the end, a joint deal between the developers and the fledgling Brent council won the day. Chalkhill was designed and built by the council's planning and architecture departments - then in their heyday. It's true that the system-built blocks had unappealing concrete exteriors, but inside the rooms were spacious; there was a ducted heating system and a novel rubbish disposal system. A unit in every kitchen chewed up all items of waste and so avoided the need for traditional refuse collection. There was none of the trauma of high-rise - the blocks were five storeys, arranged in crab-claw configurations, with decks running their length. These were designed so milk floats could make door to door deliveries. Years later, Livingstone complained that the Conservatives were dumping homeless families on the estate. But it was very different early on. Chalkhill was choosy about its dwellers. "You had to have a reference from an employer and from a bank so you could become a tenant," recalls Travers, who moved with her husband, an electrician, and her then young family from rented accommodation in Kensal Rise. However, controversy struck. First it was the empty flats. Many remained vacant for long periods in the late 1960s and early 1970s because rents at £6 for one bedroom and £11 for five bedrooms were beyond the means of many would be-tenants - scandalous in a London with a big shortage of council accommodation. Subsidies eventually helped, but when the Tories came to power, their policy of cost rents again excluded many potential residents. Later, the endless decks became the haunts of muggers, vandals and drugtakers. "They could escape by running along the walkways and nobody could catch them," says Harrod. Resident porters with security cameras were introduced, but with mixed success. And an old fashioned idea - a small permanent police station - was tried, but gradually the hours have been cut back to the point where there's now no resident bobby. As Chalkhill goes through its latest makeover, it is pertinent to ask why so much went wrong. There's wide agreement, among councillors and residents, that Brent underestimated the massive maintenance that the high-tech estate needed. This was aggravated by central government cuts, limiting spending during Labour's long (and the Tories' short) control of Brent. And Labour maintains that the Tories deliberately ran down the estate, from the late 1980s, because they wanted it razed and rebuilt. But it's a complicated picture. On the land occupied by several demolished blocks, there's a shiny supermarket. "It's our new social club," quips Mullan. He may be joking, but it is open all hours, has a cafe, and a manager savvy enough to foster links with the community. There's also a new, much smaller attraction on Chalkhill. It's a showhouse: one of the new, low-rise homes. It's very nice, visitors say. But then again they have said the same of other new homes through the years. For now, the view has improved for the Travers family. From her first floor lounge, Gloria Travers looks across at a cleared site where Bison blocks once loomed. And all is peace for Mullan, as he helps his neighbours and the regeneration team turn a shabby corner of the estate into a fragment of garden. With services functioning properly, all the Chalkhill folk have to do is plug in neighbourliness, turn on the switch - and show that it's still working. 35 years of housing law 1965 Fair rents introduced. 1972 Housing Finance Act brings in fair rents for council tenants. 1975 Fair rents abandoned in council sector. 1977 Councils must accommodate homeless families in specified priority needs groups. 1980 Right to buy introduced. 1982 Housing benefits established. 1986 Right to buy discounts increased; block sale of estates facilitated by law. 1988 New financial arrangements for housing associations. Housing action trusts start in England. 1996 New regulatory framework for registered social landlords. Amendments to housing benefit, tenants' rights and homelessness provisions. 2000 Green paper review of housing. Covers social and private rented sectors; also owner occupation. Source: Chartered Institute of Housing.

fields.standfirst: More on the extracts
fields.trailText:
The principal characters
Damien Dean, narrator, is a washed-up twentysomething intelligence officer, hard drinker and dedicated fan of Ironopolis FC, his home-town club. He works for the Organisation, a highly shadowy intelligence service which does the Establishment's dirty work. Dolores Gallagher is Damien's fiery and unpredictable ex-girlfriend. She has returned to his life apparently set on revenge for his treatment of her at college. Part of the book is told from her point of view. Charlotte (Charlie) Preston, Damien's much-younger, on-off girlfriend. Just graduated, she is a supremely confident and ambitious journalist. She is also very dear to her brother, Syd. Syd Preston is Damien's best friend and drinking partner at college. The two have since fallen out and Syd has gone on to become a lawyer. Imogen Bowler-Clous is a former society girl and airline hostess who becomes Damien's girlfriend.

The principal characters
Damien Dean, narrator, is a washed-up twentysomething intelligence officer, hard drinker and dedicated fan of Ironopolis FC, his home-town club. He works for the Organisation, a highly shadowy intelligence service which does the Establishment's dirty work. Dolores Gallagher is Damien's fiery and unpredictable ex-girlfriend. She has returned to his life apparently set on revenge for his treatment of her at college. Part of the book is told from her point of view. Charlotte (Charlie) Preston, Damien's much-younger, on-off girlfriend. Just graduated, she is a supremely confident and ambitious journalist. She is also very dear to her brother, Syd. Syd Preston is Damien's best friend and drinking partner at college. The two have since fallen out and Syd has gone on to become a lawyer. Imogen Bowler-Clous is a former society girl and airline hostess who becomes Damien's girlfriend.

Blurb
The Organisation is a shadowy, behind-the-scenes intelligence set-up. When the Establishment doesn't want to get its hands dirty, in goes the Organisation. It is answerable only to its head of operations. Damien Dean is a late twentysomething oddball who likes his beer and his football. To avoid a four year sentence for computer fraud four years earlier, he secretly joined The Organisation. His working-class background, his fondness for the bottle and his love of football mark him out as not "one of us" in the Organisation. One drunken week in September 1994, there are a series of apparently unrelated murders. They have only one thing common: Damien Dean is always there or thereabouts and dead drunk when they happen. Just when he suspects they may be the work of a serial killer, he is assigned to The Organisation's investigation of a government minister.

But as Damien follows up the leads in both investigations, he realises they are connected by more than just his presence. But is the Organisation trying to frame him for the murders? Or is his off-the-wall ex-girlfriend Dolores Gallagher responsible? Or is it really Damien himself?

Synopsis
One morning in late September 1994, Damien Dean wakes up in a strange hotel room. The last five days of his life have been a drink-induced haze, which began with a celebration in Ironopolis, Damien's home town, and finished in a London hotel room. As he wakes up, Damien tries to piece together his circumstances. Some memories flood back, others are less clear. Either way, he remembers he has been to an autopsy where he recognised the body; then met Dolores in a bar, got drunk, narrowly avoided being killed and finished up witnessing two murders. He also remembers unwittingly throwing up over Imogen Bowler-Clous, a former society girl, but takes comfort from the fact that he has somehow got her telephone number. Damien has also picked up a note, delivered by hand to his home address and signed only The Ratcatcher. It threatens to expose something from Damien's murky past. As Damien speculates on the Ratcatcher's identity, he begins to suspect that it may be one of his good friends or his long-term, on-off girlfriend, Charlie Preston.

Genre and style
The novel is written in the framework of a conventional, "page-turner" thriller but seeks to avoid the cliches of this genre through:

the highly personalised voice of the first person narrator. the complex histories of the characters which are explored in flashback through the narrator's eyes. The use of the present historic to recount significant or cliffhanger moments in the plot. Damien Dean is a highly fallible hero who gives the book a comic dimension through his wayward exploits and his satirical commentary on the work of the intelligence services. He is also an unreliable narrator which sets up another tension in the narrative - is he telling the truth? He is more Bernard Samson than George Smiley or James Bond. As a twentysomething in London, his life and its attendant problems of career, money and relationships mean he will find an audience who can identify with him.

Much of the novel takes place in the fashionable areas of London, such as Soho, and mixes fictional bars, restaurants and clubs with real ones. As such, it shares some qualities with the London genre of novels. As Damien comes from the north-east of England, he is an outsider to the beau monde of London but it is through the eyes of this outsider that we see the action of the novel. Coming from Ironopolis (which is loosely based on Middlesbrough) Damien is also football daft, supporting his hometown club as they struggle to escape division one and a century of obscurity. As such, football adds to the comedy and the pathos of the novel.

fields.headline: 'Vindicated': David Shayler
fields.standfirst:
Hear David Shayler talk about his new book (1mins 50)
More on the extracts
fields.trailText: Renegade former MI5 officer David Shayler has spoken to Guardian Unlimited about his new thriller, approved for publication just yesterday by the Home Office.
fields.body:
Renegade former MI5 officer David Shayler has spoken to Guardian Unlimited about his new thriller, approved for publication just yesterday by the Home Office.

Talking from his home in exile in Paris, Mr Shayler described the novel as an 'off the wall thriller'. "It's about the bungling bureaucracy that I knew", rather than the power games of George Smiley.

He added that the book is a "vindication that I'm always responsible towards national security".

Mr Shayler, 34, wrote The Organisation, also described as "a gritty thriller about spies, sex and football", while exiled in France.

Under the terms of a High Court injunction obtained by the Attorney General in 1997, Mr Shayler is prevented from disclosing any information he gained while working for the intelligence services, whether presented as fact or fiction.

To comply with the injunction, his agent Chris Joseph ostentatiously submitted the book's manuscript to the Treasury Solicitor last month as a professional dancer performed the cancan on the Home Office steps and six "special agents" dressed in sunglasses and dark suits played football.

The application came as the former head of MI5 Dame Stella Rimington submitted a draft of her memoirs for vetting. Mr Joseph's solicitor Barney Monahan of David Price and Co said he received written confirmation from the Treasury Solicitors' Office on Monday that the book had been cleared.

The letter, signed Roland Phillips, Head of the Public Law Group, said: "I write to let you know that the Crown will not seek to restrain publication of the information in the book in the form in which it was submitted on June 1."

The Organisation has not been sold to a publisher yet but Mr Shayler said he is hopeful a deal will be forthcoming now the book has been passed by the censors.

The Guardian and Observer newspapers are currently applying to the High Court for a judicial review to challenge an order granted by an Old Bailey judge forcing them to hand over documents and e-mails relating to Shayler.

The three judges yesterday reserved judgment to a later date following a two-day hearing.

The Home Office confirmed that Government censors had cleared Mr Shayler's book for publication. A spokeswoman said: "Mr Shayler put forward a text which he said was a work of fiction. "The Government saw no reason to restrain this publication." The book got through without a word being cut, Home Office sources said.

fields.headline: Chapter 11: The Organisation
fields.standfirst: More on the extracts
fields.trailText: The great strengths of the Organisation are its security, secrecy and its disciplined culture.  No one except the CG and his deputy knows its total budget, due to the secrecy which surrounds the work of the intelligence services, even in Whitehall itself. fields.body:
The great strengths of the Organisation are its security, secrecy and its disciplined culture. No one except the CG and his deputy knows its total budget, due to the secrecy which surrounds the work of the intelligence services, even in Whitehall itself. Only the Cabinet Office knows the total budget - or vote, as it is mysteriously called - of the intelligence agencies combined. It does not, however, know the individual vote for each service. Conversely, the individual services know their own vote but do not know the aggregate intelligence vote or that of the other agencies.

These circumstances make it very easy for the Organisation to cream off its vote without Whitehall, the government or parliament knowing (although the recent round of cuts has eaten into the Organisation's budget as there is simply less pie to go around).

Similarly, no one knows exactly how many people work here. Officers only know colleagues in their section or those who work on the same operations; if they go to the subsidised canteen, they are obliged to go in certain pre-arranged shifts so their exposure to each other is kept to the minimum. They clock in each morning in a strict rota of fifteen minute slots which vary according to the time of year to minimise the risk of exposure to other officers in the surrounding streets.

There are still, even in the mid-1990s, the odd few support staff, mostly older folk, who do not actually know they work in the Organisation but believe themselves to be in a Spec Ops unit of naval intelligence (which was once misspelt on pay slips as "navel intelligence"). But, by the time that I joined in the early 1990s, the Organisation had abandoned its policy of touring schools and offering the malleable potential recruits jobs in the Civil Service, only to tell them later they were working in "security". Many staff recruited in this way believed they worked for Securicor, Group 4 or one of the many neo-Nazi, pseudo-paramilitary organisations which now offer these services.

The select few Special Branch officers (rank of detective inspector or above, or of 15 years service or more in the Branch), who meet the Organisation officers trusted to liaise, think all these officers are in a super-secret section of MI6. So the Branch officers never mention them to visiting MI5 officers while real MI6 officers consider visiting local Branches beneath them. And Organisation officers attend meetings of Whitehall officials, like the ad hoc CIGs or weekly JIC, under the cover of the National Audit Office or the Treasury checking that the intelligence agencies are spending the public's money with discrimination and wisdom.

But security is also the weakness of the Organisation. Great OpSy and SyCom sections have evolved from the ranks of the older officers, who should have been sacked long ago, to advise the busy desk officer about the risks inherent in any operation they undertake. Most of this is common sense - "Don't tell members of the public you work for the Organisation"; "If you are caught on ops, just deny it. Claim to be a common-or-garden criminal"; "Never carry material which reveals your real identity when operational". They're-issue endless tomes which have hardly been updated since the Second World War and are at best irrelevant and contradictory, if not actually dangerous. And, of course, each of the OpSy and SyCom sections needs its own, dedicated support - battalions of secretaries, clerks, electricians and photocopier engineers - for undefined "security" reasons, which are, of course, assessed by OpSy and SyCom. Officers elsewhere in the Organisation never question any of these assessments as they know that being seen as "not one of us" in the field of security is tantamount to professional suicide in the Organisation.

Of course, the Organisation has many other sections which thrive on disseminating rulebooks, handbooks, guidance pamphlets, regular circulars, bulletins, tomes and volumes to a controlled (and captive) audience. All of these papers notionally go to make up the Manual of Investigations and Operations. I say notionally because no one has bothered to comprehensively update the original manual held in Department R - "the Registry" or "the Bunker", as it is known to officers - for as long as anyone can remember. Essentially this means you can do what you like - including blackmailing or exposing "political renegades" and assassination, although I am told the latter rarely happens, anymore - as long as you jump through the right bureaucratic hoops. Bureaucracy must not only be done but be seen to be done. And that can sometimes count in favour of the hapless intelligence officer or IO, as we are known.

fields.headline: Chapter 10: At the office
fields.standfirst: More on the extracts
fields.trailText: After being thrown around for another quarter of an hour or so, I arrive at the station near the Organisation's secret building, but I cannot tell you where.  As I climb the steps to the outside world, I'm assaulted by the habitual nonsense of the post-industrial society:
fields.body:
After being thrown around for another quarter of an hour or so, I arrive at the station near the Organisation's secret building, but I cannot tell you where. As I climb the steps to the outside world, I'm assaulted by the habitual nonsense of the post-industrial society:

 You're two minutes from a tasty Big Wonga
 Gonad. Black and Blue (from lovin you) The new album, out now
 Marcie Tarnish Temptress Her new blockbuster Out 5 October
 Speak Softly But Carry a Big Stick
 Smear. Don't tell Your Mates. Be there or be a round peg in a square hole

Outside, I briefly dry-clean myself to ensure I haven't been followed before I make my way to the anonymous office block where we now work. I don't walk into the back of a tailor's shop in the West End. I don't mutter conspiratorially "the swallow is silent when it migrates but only in the spring" to a besuited but discreet lackey. I don't step through a panel in the wall. I don't climb into a lift without buttons. I don't descend into the bowels of the earth. I do, though, enter an anonymous grey 1950s building which has enough style to frighten the inquisitive, but remains unremarkable to the passer-by.

We have only been in Nation House XVI since July 1993, just over a year - the Organisation has to be able to move around at short notice in case its existence is compromised. We moved the last time because the 1960s hairdressers we used on Grosvenor Street was blown after some pink-rinse old dear went in search of the toilet. Somehow, at odds of billions to one, she pressed the correct eight-digit, alphanumeric combination in the lift and finished up in the Department Y - Technical Support section, the closest thing the Organisation has to Q's department in James Bond. Rumour has it she is still on sedatives, even after the Temazepan the Organisation gave her (without her knowledge) ran out.

Before that, the Organisation was based in the 1960s Sovbloc-style Ministry of Truth, a dirty concrete affair just off the Euston Road. And up till then - going back before my time - it was split between the 1930s BBC-style Ministry of Information at Curzon Street and the black Lubiyanka which runs the length of nearby Bolton Street. As office space in Central London has become more expensive, the Organisation has been shoehorned into ever cheaper and smaller accommodation over the years. The current offices are cramped, dirty and either too hot or too cold, even though we've only been here just over a year.

I swipe in and step into the booth to be X-rayed and scanned, before I am allowed to go on my way. 09:57, it prints off. I tear off the print-out and put it in my pocket, just in case of any bureaucratic dispute later on. I'll be leaving at 18:12 today, not a minute later - unless Wendy Probit tackles me around six, in which case I could be ensconced here to gone ten for "security reasons". When we first came to the new building, the newly emulsioned walls gleamed in the July sun like snow as we trudged through the thick carpets to our modern, ice-grey desks in offices which were divided by frosted glass rather than the crumbling, moth-eaten plasterboard of Bolton Street. It was fairyland compared to what we had grown used to.

But no one had budgeted for the upkeep of this new wonder so it soon began to chip and peel and, before long, the carpets became worn and frayed like old tennis balls. For some inexplicable reason, the walls were then painted standard issue Government green, the pale and sickly hue seen in a hundred Monty Python sketches satirising Whitehall. Surrounded by all this, I feel paler and sicklier as I walk down the interminable corridors, listening to the radiators clanking their monotonous, irregular beat, like death-row prisoners banging on their cell bars.

As I get closer to the CP/3 section room, I shudder once again, first at the thought of justifying my absence to Wendy, then at the thought of yesterday. Once I'd seen the blood, I leapt out of bed, put a foot in Sunday night's unfinished pizza, stretched out a hand to steady my balance and electrocuted myself on the barren bulb socket protruding from an old lamp on the bedside table. I then vomited into the bin before finally forcing myself to look down in the same way I have to force myself to watch a last minute Ironopolis penalty. My genitals were still there but retracted and covered with an oily slick of semen. Blood was running down my leg like lubricant down a Castrol can.

I smelt her cigarettes again, the cool menthol. I searched to recognise her but couldn't. Then, I realised she was no longer wearing that dark-red wig. I stared at her short, spiky dark hair. She looked just like she did when I first met her at the Freshers' Fair at Cally, when she stood there in her innocence and her dungarees not far from the Lesbian Action Group stall watching a rugger bugger facetiously trying to book some "hot lesbian action".

It is strange to think that at that moment - that precise moment, the one before I said: "Just ignore them, they're rugger buggers" and she spun round to look at me with those eyes like sin - we felt nothing for each other but indifference. If I'd never have whispered those words, we'd never have spoken and we'd never have had the opportunity to cut each other to the emotional quick as we have done over the last few years. It is better, they say, to have love and lost than never to have loved at all. But they never saw Dolores and me at our worst.

Then, just as I realised there were a hundred questions I had to ask her, she looked at her pink translucent Swatch and declared: "Duty calls. I'm off. See you in Ronaldo's at eight," before daintily stepping out of my cramped bedroom and clicking shut the front door behind her. I belatedly went to scamper after her, only to realise I was naked, my penis retracted like a snail in its shell, shy and embarrassed. I picked up her red wig and threw it on the floor in frustration. I knew then, I would have to make that date, that evening, last night in fact.

webTitle: Cort signs for Newcastle in £7m deal

fields.headline: Cort signs for Newcastle in £7m deal
fields.trailText: Newcastle United have signed Wimbledon's England U-21 striker Carl Cort in a £7m deal.
fields.body:
Newcastle United have signed Wimbledon's England U-21 striker Carl Cort in a £7m deal.

The 22-year-old front man flew to the north-east this morning for talks with chairman Freddy Shepherd and chief executive David Stonehouse. And after a rigorous medical this afternoon he signed a five-year contract.

"I am thrilled to be joining a club as big as Newcastle United," Cort said. "The chairman and chief executive have impressed me with their ambitious plans for the club and I am delighted at the prospect of playing for Bobby Robson. It is a great career move for me."

Meanwhile Derby County have completed the £2m signing of Danny Higginbotham from Manchester United.

The left-back has signed a four-year deal at Pride Park after agreeing personal terms and passing his medical.

Higginbotham, 21, will be officially unveiled tomorrow at a lunchtime press conference at the Rams' training ground along with Finnish international Simo Valakari, who has joined on a free transfer from Motherwell.
