fields.headline: Devolve and thrive
fields.standfirst: The Scottish parliament           and Welsh assembly offer a useful lesson in comparative governance. Now           they need to enthuse the public
fields.trailText: The Scottish parliament           and Welsh assembly offer a useful lesson in comparative governance. Now           they need to enthuse the public.
fields.body:
I didn't see any flags in the streets of Glasgow this week and according to the polls Scottish people are none too impressed by the first year of their new parliament. Its anniversary is worth observing none the less. Forget high-flown stuff about reconvening an institution that shut up shop in 1707 and look at the day to day performance. Coalition has worked (and allowed Scotland to break away on student fees). Backbenchers do a proper job in their committees. The Edinburgh parliament's style (including civilised hours of operation) puts the unmodernised House of Commons to shame. Whatever else gets written in Tony Blair's epitaph, it will say he shifted power away from Westminster. Irreversibly.

The doings at Holyrood and on Cardiff Bay have not exactly set news editors' hearts aflutter, except perhaps for the fight over section 28 (Clause 28, section 2a is the Scottish designation), and the deposition of Alun Michael. But that poses a risk that people in England will not profit from a lesson in comparative governance.

It is worth reading. If law-making is what legislatures are about, Holyrood can claim to have improved productivity. It has passed seven bills (including, finally, the abolition of Scottish feudalism) and has 11 statutes under consideration - not a bad record compared with the one to two specifically Scottish bills that used to be passed by the Westminster parliament each year. Edinburgh committees look at bills in advance. They have made an effort not to dance to the executive's tune, allowing Tommy Sheridan, the sole representative of the Scottish Socialist party, to secure his bill forbidding forced sales of debtors' property. They are holding inquiries on drugs and community care. The Labour-Liberal Democrat executive will find it hard to sideline them over housing stock transfers and council finance (a third of MSPs are former councillors).

In Wales, however, the complaint is that too much time has been spent with lawyers poring over exactly what the assembly's "secondary" powers are. There the relationship between executive and backbenches has not been settled.

Throughout the western world, confidence in public institutions has been sliding so the biggest question to be asked about devolution is whether the new setup has tickled the public's palate. The parliament's leaders have, with the exception of Donald Dewar and Jim Wallace, yet to become household names. But its poor press may not be MSPs' fault. The past year has been marked by atavistic antagonism of two of Scotland's leading papers, the Daily Record, part of the Mirror group, and Andrew Neil's Scotsman - owned by those famous Channel Islanders, the Barclays.

Perhaps press barons, multinationals and (a scandal blew up in Edinburgh earlier this year) lobbyists may find it easier to target small-country politicians. Besides, the parliament scored some own goals. The death this week of Enric Miralles, architect of its proposed new home, has probably not helped public perceptions of mismanagement - the building having started out at £40m but now is likely to cost some £195m. The Welsh assembly's new home will probably cost £30m and that is before a decision is made on physically separating legislature and executive - but Cardiff gets a splendid new building in return.

Yet the new arrangements have their pluses. The chart shows the high proportion of women involved. True, vested interests have been palliated (farmers in Wales for example). They have also been upset - Scottish lawyers do not like MSPs' interest in their appointments and practices. The style in both Edinburgh and Cardiff is participative, so much so that voluntary groups and churches, called in to give evidence, have complained of "fatigue". To make parliament work, says researcher Sue Innes, you need to "build capacity" in civil society, which might entail grants for interest groups so they can attend committee hearings.

The new bodies carry a few Westminster genes. Some 19% of MSPs have been MPs, 15% in Cardiff. But a self- sufficient political class is in formation, not just representatives but lobbyists, aides as well. A question becomes how far the best and brightest begin to see parliament and assembly as the summit of their ambitions, rather than Westminster (or Strasbourg). Cardiff's older guard has been cleared out. Plaid Cymru 's Dafydd Wigley is retiring Tory leader Rod Richard is unlikely to recover. Meanwhile Labour's Rhodri Morgan is carving out a niche for himself at some distance from Millbank. In Edinburgh the race to succeed recuperating Donald Dewar has quietly begun.

Ron Davies, the man destined to lead the new Welsh assembly but for an amble on the common, called devolution a process not an event. Right, the redistribution of power has not ended. The Welsh assembly will, probably after the elections due in 2003, press for more powers. The "B" word (Barnett) hovers over Holyrood, though surprisingly the parliament's allocation has not yet been called into question.

That is because MSPs have focused on practical, do-able politics. Ralf Dahrendorf, the social thinker, recently warned "defenders of democracy do well to remain cautious of regionalism". Small, more homogeneous units might attract authoritarians and become intolerant. So far there have been no signs of such a development. Banality has triumphed in the past 12 months but that is how it should be, in the establishment of an executive and legislature that work. As a result (to borrow Tom Nairn's phrase), Ukanian government looks a lot healthier now than in April 1997.

fields.headline: Blair points to 'substance, not spin'
fields.standfirst: The prime minister hit back at opposition leader William Hague over accusations that Labour's policies on law and order were nothing but gimmicks, writes Alexandra Fouché
fields.trailText: The prime minister hit back at opposition leader William Hague over accusations that Labour's policies on law and order were nothing but gimmicks, writes Alexandra Fouché
fields.body:
The debate on law and order again took centre stage in this week's prime minister's questions, in turn leading to questions on the big issue of the day, Britain's membership of the euro.

Tory leader William Hague kicked off the exchange by asking the prime minister to reveal the name of the government member responsible for the idea of on-the-spot fines to curb disorderly conduct and drunken hooliganism, which were rejected by the police at the end of last week.

In what quickly turned into a game of political ping-pong where the players kept asking questions rather than answering them, Tony Blair demanded to know whether the shadow cabinet was prepared to support the Labour policy of introducing fixed-penalty notices in place of the now discarded on-the-spot fines.

Pointing out that such punishments were "yet another gimmick from a government of gimmicks", Mr Hague asked about measures such as child curfew orders, which had been in force for three years without leading to a single order being issued.

But Mr Blair hit back, pointing to the new hospital-building programme, extra jobs and today's announcement of more cash for science programmes as examples of "substance, not spin".

The debate on law and order eventually gave way to a question from the leader of the opposition on remarks made by Britain's ambassador in Japan, Sir Stephen Gomersall, on the growing urgency for Britain to join the European single currency.

Mr Hague argued that the announcement of the hooliganism-curbing measures had in fact been designed to hide the ambassador's comments - leaked earlier this week. The leaks were a symptom of the prime minister's "weakness and failure of leadership" of his government, the opposition leader jibed.

The question of Europe was picked up on by Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy, who also asked Mr Blair to state the government's position on the European question.

The prime minister explained that the government was sticking to its current policy of "prepare and decide", but that ruling out joining the euro (as the Tories have done) would certainly be "the surest way" he knew to lose jobs.

webTitle: Blair, Barak and their mutual friend

fields.headline: Blair, Barak and their mutual friend
fields.standfirst: Lord Levy, the Labour peer acting as special envoy for Tony Blair in the Middle East peace process, continues to cause controversy, writes  Derek Brown
fields.trailText: Wednesday, 5.30pm: Lord Levy, the Labour peer acting as special envoy for Tony Blair in the Middle East peace process, continues to cause controversy, writes Derek Brown
fields.body:
Tony Blair met his Israeli counterpart Ehud Barak in London today, with his special envoy Lord Michael Levy staying discreetly on the sidelines.

Levy is the focus of scandals in both countries. He is known to have bankrolled the Labour leader, his close friend, to the tune of several million pounds before the 1997 general election.

More recently, he has become the target for Tory gibes about Labour sleaze, when it was disclosed that he paid just £5,000 in income tax last year, despite being a multimillionaire.

In Israel, he has been accused of channelling more millions to Barak's One Nation movement before last year's general election. Israeli politicians are forbidden to seek or take foreign donations.

Levy strongly denies the claim, just as he and Blair deny there is anything improper about key diplomatic missions being entrusted to an untrained, unelected pal of the prime minister.

Downing Street is playing down the significance of Levy's absence from today's talks. A spokesman said that the prime minister had met Barak in the past without Levy being present, and would do so again.

Levy will not have long to wait before he hears details of the discussions. He is hosting a party in London tonight, which the prime minister will attend.

Blair has long coveted a role in the tortuous Middle East peace process, now approaching another of its interminable deadlines.

Israel's key ally and paymaster, the USA, has invited Barak and Palestinian president Yasser Arafat to Washington for a three-way summit next week.

Israel favours a summit, in advance of the highly notional September 13 target date for a final settlement. But with enormous gaps remaining in negotiations with the Palestinians, Arafat is reluctant to submit to certain pressure for concessions.

The sticking points in the negotiations remain the same as they were when Arafat and the late Yitzhak Rabin struck their momentous peace deal in 1993. Israel still occupies most of the West Bank, which it is pledged to evacuate.

There is profound disagreement over the future of some 6m Palestinian refugees scattered throughout the Middle East, and over the final boundaries and degree of autonomy of a Palestinian state. And, most contentious of all, there remains the issue of who should govern Jerusalem, annexed by Israel 33 years ago.

fields.standfirst: Marsh Arab leader whose people and homeland were decimated by Saddam

fields.body:
Shaykh Kadhim Al-Raysan, who has died aged 71, was a prominent tribal leader of the madÕan, the marsh-dwelling Arabs of southern Iraq. His encounter with the modern world was characterised by the calculated destruction of those marshlands by Saddam Hussein and the brutal suppression of the shortlived mass uprisings of March 1991 that followed the Gulf war.

In the uprising, Al-Raysan played a key role in marshalling his tribe. He coordinated with the wider movement in opposition to Saddam's regime, holding the town of Suq ash-Shuyukh. With the crushing of the rebellion, Al-Raysan, like some 40,000 other Iraqi dissidents, fled to the Saudi Arabian refugee camp of Rafha. From there, he continued his struggle, directing some members of his tribe who were still waging guerrilla war in southern Iraq.

The Saudis invited him to move to more comfortable accomodation, but he refused to leave his fellow tribesmen. Saddam, meanwhile, had expressed a personal enmity towards Al-Raysan, and an explicit desire to exterminate him and his tribe. Indeed, a trip across the marshes today would reveal little of the romantic landscape evoked by Wilfred Thesiger in Marsh Arabs, his classic account of life with the mad'an .

Saddam's project to destroy Al-Raysan's people has involved draining the marshes, thereby displacing an unruly populace to more manageable terrain and simultaneously opening up the area for economic exploitation. This environmental destruction is now almost complete, and the land that Al-Raysan loved so much in his youth, and tried so hard to protect throughout his life, is now barely recognisable.

Al-Raysan was born in Nasiriyya, southern Iraq. His father, Raysan Al-Gasad, was shaykh of the Bani Hacham tribe and a defiant figure in the years following Iraq's independence in 1932.

In keeping with tradition - and as training for his future role as tribal leader - the young Al-Raysan joined his father in Ayatollah Shaykh Abdul Hussain Mutar's revolt of 1935. In the marshes today, this episode is still synonymous with Al-Raysan's father and known as Thawrat ibn Raysan, or Raysan's revolt. It was followed by the imposition of martial law in the southern Euphrates region, after which Al-Raysan was again at his father's side during Rashid Ali Gailani's revolt of 1941. On his father's death, Al-Raysan led the Bani Hacham. Along with other Shi'a leaders, he fostered ties with Iraq's Shi'a religious establishment and, after the 1968 Ba'thist coup, worked with it in the face of persecution by the regime.

In 1994, after a stroke, he went to Holland, where he lived out his lonely days as a refugee, and died in hospital. The Iraqi authorities refused him burial in his homeland and banned public or private mourning. He was buried in Damascus.

Al-Raysan's wife, Ameera, died in the Rafha refugee camp in 1994. He is survived by one son and five daughters.

webTitle: Labour and Lib Dems in NHS deal

fields.headline: Labour and Lib Dems in NHS deal
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrats will today clinch their most intimate political deal so far with Tony Blair's government when they confirm their support for the NHS national plan which the health secretary Alan Milburn is devising to modernise British health care.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrats will today clinch their most intimate political deal so far with Tony Blair's government when they confirm their support for the NHS national plan which the health secretary Alan Milburn is devising to modernise British health care.

Since a sharp increase in health spending was announced last March - in line with Lib Dem demands - Charles Kennedy's health spokesman, Nick Harvey, has been negotiating with Mr Milburn's team.

The resulting agreement will be formalised when Mr Harvey joins the six NHS modernisation action teams when they meet in Whitehall today to finalise their reports. The National Plan, still to be written in final draft form, will reflect the talks which have taken place.

It is due to be published after Mr Brown's comprehensive spending review statement due on July 18. Crucial elements in the Liberal Democrat's acquiescence are Labour's acceptance of the need for restructuring of the NHS, the provision of extra funds and the preference for modernisation rather than the Tory option - more private provision.

With Labour fearful of losing seats to the Tories in even a modest swing back in next year's election, tactical voting which ties Labour and Lib Dem voters closer together is crucial.

webTitle: Drumcree loyalists - but loyal to what exactly?

fields.headline: Drumcree loyalists - but loyal to what exactly?
fields.standfirst: Recent history is repeating itself as Orangemen battle with security forces at Drumcree. But they can't simply be written off as hooligans in bowler hats, writes Derek Brown
fields.trailText: Wednesday, 5.15pm: Recent history is repeating itself as Orangemen battle with security forces at Drumcree. But they can't simply be written off as hooligans in bowler hats, writes Derek Brown.
fields.body:
We call them loyalists, for there is as yet no more convenient word for those who are stoning, firebombing and even shooting at Crown forces in Northern Ireland. They say they are loyal to Queen and country, yet they are prepared to fight the British government and defy the will of the majority of the British people to prove it. This is a key paradox in 20th century Anglo-Irish relations, soured for generations by three conflicting majorities: the Irish, the British and the Ulster Protestants.

Now it is the Protestants who are protesting, and it's too easy simply to dismiss them as football hooligans in bowler hats. Certainly, there are sinister elements among them: the Loyalist Volunteer Force (UVF), the Ulster Freedom Fighters (UFF) and all the other tuppenny-ha'penny sets of initials who are chiefly concerned with racket-driven territorial feuds.

The swell of unrest rippling across the province is also fuelled, more mundanely, by adrenalin. From the earliest days of the Troubles, psychologists have pointed out that conflict is in itself a dangerous stimulant. The little boys brandishing petrol bombs and fireworks may only have a dim understanding of the cause, but they are as excited as hell by the action.

There is a third factor in the surge of Orange anger, and it is more important than thuggery and mindless tribalism. It is the fear and frustration of a community that feels in its bones that it is being slowly, inexorably, ground down by the new power-sharing orthodoxy of the Anglo-Irish agreement.

The right of Orangemen to swagger down a short stretch of road where nationalists happen to live may seem from the outside to be the most tawdry and irrelevant of causes. After all, the Lodge leaders who growl about the freedom of the Queen's highway, would not dream of trying to swagger down the Falls Road in Belfast, or through the Bogside estate in Derry.

And yet the parade route along Garvaghy Road in Drumcree is a hugely important symbol to the loyalists. It is not some ancient totem. It was only in 1997 that the authorities were forced by a wave of protests to revoke a ban on the march. Now recent history is repeating itself.

The situation is clearly perilous in the extreme. Shots have been exchanged and security forces have been obliged to bring out all the ugly paraphernalia of riot control. There is careless talk of convicted loyalist paramilitary members, released early under the terms of the Good Friday agreement, being returned to prison.

Though it is invidious to anticipate further violence, there is an appalling risk of further clashes and of sectarian attacks. The usual anodyne appeals for calm have been issued, along with warnings that the government must and will stand firm in the face of naked intimidation.

That is all very well, but surely it is not beyond the wit of the authorities, or for that matter the communities, to come up with an alternative to this week's brutish confrontation. A new parade route, perhaps, or a token escorted march, could satisfy Orange pride without offending nationalist feelings.

Such a solution would also isolate those so-called loyalists who are loyal only to a discredited past.

webTitle: Modest investment, Biggest-ever contract and Free deal

fields.headline: Modest investment, Biggest-ever contract and Free deal
fields.trailText: BID NOW IN SERIOUS TROUBLE
fields.body:
BID NOW IN SERIOUS TROUBLE

Phrases like "dead as a Dodo" and "when hell freezes over" hung uneasily in the Zurich air. Vultures - rare in Switzerland at this time of year - circled overhead. Meanwhile, the organisers of England's World Cup 2006 bid remained defiantly upbeat: with a half-decent final presentation to Fifa's executive committee, tomorrow's vote might just swing their way.

And so campaign director Alec McGivan took the stage to front a slick 30-minute presentation, which included four short films showing positive images of English soccer (no we can't think of that many either) set to a rousing rendition of "I vow to thee my country". McGivan then pledged to invite 12 children from each member country to the World Cup should the decision go our way. Well, when you've already wasted £10.5m...

Then - slightly bizarrely - up popped ex-Spurs striker Garth Crooks, the most earnest man in the world. "Fifa standards are our standards," an overly-serious Crooks began. "You ask for all-seater venues, we have them," he deadpanned. "You ask for stadiums with no fences, we have them," he continued, his words now dripping with gravitas. "None of you will need convincing about our ability to host a World Cup," he sincerely climaxed as the Fifa committee burst into hysterical laughter.

Outside, the vultures flew lower. And the recriminations in England camp began. "You cannot run a bid on the cheap and people are naive if they think otherwise," McGivan spluttered. "Some people will say it is money down the drain. But if you look at it properly, £10m is an amazingly modest investment compared to what the rewards are." And then - like always - realisation finally set in: "Four candidates have made the final vote and there can only be one winner," he admitted as a wildly-cheering South African delegation passed by.

MAINE PAIN

Joe Royle and his assistant Willie Donachie have been rewarded with spanking new contracts for their hard work in setting Manchester City up for a big fall, sorry, for leading the club back to the Premiership. The deals last for four years, which should be long enough for them to take City back down to the Second Division and half the way up again.

"It is the biggest-ever contract offered to a Manchester City management team and puts Joe in the bracket as one of the top Premiership managers," said City's chief operating officer Chris Bird, the only Premiership CEO who is worth twice as much in the hand. "It's just reward for Joe for achieving back-to-back promotions," continued Bird, referring to City's amazing storm up two divisions, a feat which had not been achieved in the game since 1999.

Of course, Joe really does deserve his reward, but he'd probably settle for a little luck in the transfer market instead of improved terms. Because his squad-strengthening £4m bid for Alan Smith is doomed to failure. "I don't care who is interested in Alan Smith, he is not for sale," Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale quietly insisted today. And in any case, the 19-year-old wants to stay at Elland Road to further his career. "Obviously I still have a lot more to learn about the game," he said, ignoring the fact that if he really wants his eyes opening, then City's the very place to be.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Nobody in our campaign team is in any doubt that we have the best bid. That may sound arrogant, but you ask the others whether they think they are the best" - Bobby Charlton. Let it go, man.

HOD BOOSTS HIS SQUAD

Hello everyone, it's Glenn Hoddle here - but don't stand on ceremony, just call me Glenn. I tell you, ever since I got back into a top-flight management situation here at Chel... I mean Eng... er, hold on... Southampton, I've been itchin' to get involved in the transfer market again. So you can imagine how happy I am now that I'm doin' deals left, right and the midfield position David Beckham can't play in because he isn't good enough to do that skill.

Take today. When I was firmly in a this morning situation, I managed to tie up a deal with Tennis Borussia Berlin for German striker Uwe Rosler, who has signed one of them two-year contract things. He didn't even cost me anything, because he's on a free - which is only fair, because I've had to pay pretty heavily for things in the past.

Later on, I did some discussin' with Aston Villa over Mark Draper, who I'm close to signin' for £1.5m. And I've also put my hat in the ring for Jordi Cruyff, who is on a Bosman from Manchester United and will tell me by Friday if he'll join the club I'm currently at. You know, I'm not one to get over excited, but if I land all these players we'll have a half-decent side next season and I'll end up in charge at White Ha... no... we'll win the Cup, that's what I meant. Wish me luck!

THE RUMOUR MILL

Manchester United have launched a £10m bid to sign Italian centre back Fabio Cannavaro from Parma, according to the Sun.

Paris Saint Germain have offered Real Madrid £21m for Nicolas Anelka.

Arsenal are ready to make a move for 21-year old Latvian winger Andrejs Rubins.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Middlesbrough have announced that they have completed the signings of French midfielder Christian Karembeu and Australian skipper Paul Okon. But chairman Steve Gibson has pulled the plug on Chris Sutton. He said: "Chris Sutton won't be coming here. Chris has asked for a week to 10 days to reach his decision, but we have to move on. We have other options."

Dennis Wise will join Chelsea's coaching staff when his playing days are over. The 33-year-old has signed a new-one year extension to his contract that will take him up to 2003; he will then become part of the backroom team.

Chelsea's home ties in Euro-Vase next season will be screened on Sky digital.

Manchester United defender Danny Higginbotham is talking over a move to Derby. The left-back has been at Pride Park to discuss personal terms and the £1.5m transfer is expected to be completed within the next 24 hours.

Birmingham striker Dele Adebola's proposed transfer to Spanish side Las Palmas has been put on hold after the player's medical showed up an Achilles tendon injury.

Newcastle have played down rumours suggesting they are after Wimbledon striker Carl Cort. "There is nothing happening with Carl Cort, but we are still hoping to make a further signing before the start of the new season," a spokesman said.

Louis Van Gaal is to open negotiations with the Dutch Football Association this week over the vacant Holland manager's job.

Ipswich have signed John Scales on a one-year contract. "I'm very honoured the club came in for me. It's an exciting time for me and there's a buzz around the club after they won promotion," he said.

Derby striker Mikkel Beck has agreed a £500,000 deal with French side Lille.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 3: Futbol Mundial (7pm, 12midnight SS1)

If you don't want to watch it at midnight, you can always set the video for the earlier version.

Brian Moore Interviews (11.30pm)

Former Hibernian player Laurie Riley rakes in the viewers.

fields.headline: Fiji military imposes no-go zone
fields.standfirst: Rebels given 48 hours to leave parliament and release hostages
fields.trailText: Rebels in Fiji have been given 48 hours to leave parliament and release their hostages, writes Mark Tran
fields.body:
Fiji's military today issued an ultimatum for rebels to leave parliament and release their hostages, but ruled out the use of force to end a political crisis that began in May.

With its patience wearing thin, the military said it was creating a no-go zone around the sprawling parliament complex and ordered the rebels and residents in the vicinity to leave the area in 48 hours.

"The decree will come into effect from midnight tonight...everyone in the parliamentary complex will be given 48 hours to move out," lieutenant-colonel Filipo Tarakinikini said. "This can be seen as an amnesty period whereby they are allowed to make up their minds and move out."

Under the no-go zone, which will come into force at midnight local time, the military has the power to commandeer land and buildings and restrict water, communications and power to the parliamentary compound. Food will be allowed in, but only a designated driver will have permission to carry it. Rebel supporters who have until now been entering the area freely will be banned.

Similar amnesty offers have been issued during the six-week crisis but Commodore Frank Bainimarama, the military commander, said action would be taken if the rebels did not take up the latest offer, although he said he would not consider "the military option".

Failed businessman George Speight and his gunmen stormed parliament on May 19 calling for rights for indigenous people. They seized Mahendra Chaudhry, Fiji's first ethnic Indian leader, and his entire multi-racial cabinet.

The ultimatum and imposition of an exclusion zone around the parliament complex comes after a shootout between troops and rebels on Tuesday in which three civilians and two armed rebels were wounded. Military officials later said inexperienced troops overreacted to a crowd of rebel supporters who emerged from the parliamentary compound.

The 15-minute gun battle occurred hours after Laisenia Qarasewas, the new indigenous prime minister, was sworn in. Mr Speight has already rejected Mr Qarase and his 19-member civilian administration. The new government, appointed by the military, is comprised entirely of indigenous Fijians - thereby meeting one of Mr Speight's key demands. But his choice for prime minister was ignored.

In further signs of unrest, a mini-mutiny at an army base in Labasa, on the northern island of Vanua Levu, ended today, 24 hours after it began, when a small group of soldiers confiscated arms and ammunition. Colonel Tarakinikini said local chiefs were threatening further disturbances in support of Mr Speight.

"Police have gone around and warned shops that they might have to be closed," he said. Mr Speight had predicted the mutiny would spark a "domino effect" across the country, but there were no signs of other trouble. Meanwhile, the new government has to tackle the economic impact of the coup.

Tourist resorts have been hit hard, with some reporting occupancy rates of just 10%. The Australian government issued a travel advisory late on Tuesday - similar to one the US government made several weeks ago - for its citizens to leave the capital, a move that increases Fiji's isolation.

"There remains a strong possibility of lawlessness throughout Suva, and there also remains the possibility of further civil disturbances affecting travellers," the advisory said.

With its patience wearing thin, the military said it was creating a no-go zone around the sprawling parliament complex and ordered the rebels and residents in the vicinity to leave the area in 48 hours. "The decree will come into effect from midnight tonight...everyone in the parliamentary complex will be given 48 hours to move out," lieutenant-colonel Filipo Tarakinikini said. "This can be seen as an amnesty period whereby they are allowed to make up their minds and move out." Under the no-go zone, which will come into force at midnight local time, the military has the power to commandeer land and buildings and restrict water, communications and power to the parliamentary compound. Food will be allowed in, but only a designated driver will have permission to carry it. Rebel supporters who have until now been entering the area freely will be banned. Similar amnesty offers have been issued during the six-week crisis but Commodore Frank Bainimarama, the military commander, said action would be taken if the rebels did not take up the latest offer, although he said he would not consider "the military option". Failed businessman George Speight and his gunmen stormed parliament on May 19 calling for rights for indigenous people. They seized Mahendra Chaudhry, Fiji's first ethnic Indian leader, and his entire multi-racial cabinet. The ultimatum and imposition of an exclusion zone around the parliament complex comes after a shootout between troops and rebels on Tuesday in which three civilians and two armed rebels were wounded. Military officials later said inexperienced troops overreacted to a crowd of rebel supporters who emerged from the parliamentary compound. The 15-minute gun battle occurred hours after Laisenia Qarasewas, the new indigenous prime minister, was sworn in. Mr Speight has already rejected Mr Qarase and his 19-member civilian administration. The new government, appointed by the military, is comprised entirely of indigenous Fijians - thereby meeting one of Mr Speight's key demands. But his choice for prime minister was ignored. In further signs of unrest, a mini-mutiny at an army base in Labasa, on the northern island of Vanua Levu, ended today, 24 hours after it began, when a small group of soldiers confiscated arms and ammunition. Colonel Tarakinikini said local chiefs were threatening further disturbances in support of Mr Speight. "Police have gone around and warned shops that they might have to be closed," he said. Mr Speight had predicted the mutiny would spark a "domino effect" across the country, but there were no signs of other trouble. Meanwhile, the new government has to tackle the economic impact of the coup. Tourist resorts have been hit hard, with some reporting occupancy rates of just 10%. The Australian government issued a travel advisory late on Tuesday - similar to one the US government made several weeks ago - for its citizens to leave the capital, a move that increases Fiji's isolation. "There remains a strong possibility of lawlessness throughout Suva, and there also remains the possibility of further civil disturbances affecting travellers," the advisory said.

fields.headline: Clinton announces mideast summit
fields.standfirst: President Clinton announces Israeli and Palestinian leaders to meet at Camp David next week in a new effort to bring peace to the Middle East
fields.trailText: President Clinton has announced that Israeli and Palestinian leaders will meet next week at his Camp David presidential retreat in a high-stakes bid to bring peace to the Middle East.
fields.body:
President Clinton has announced that Israeli and Palestinian leaders will meet next week at his Camp David presidential retreat in a high-stakes bid to bring peace to the Middle East.

"Etched in each side's mind are intense fears and emotions and deep-seated commitments to defend their peoples' interests. There are no easy answers and certainly no painless ones and therefore there is clearly no guarantee of success,'' Mr Clinton said in a statement from the White House briefing room. The president said he will attend the summit.

He praised Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat and Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak for agreeing to the summit.

"To delay this gathering, to remain stalled, is simply no longer an option,'' said Mr Clinton .

The announcement followed an intense effort by the President and his advisers to bring the parties together.

Shortly before Clinton appeared in the briefing room, Saeb Erekat, one of the Palestinian negotiators, said he had not been informed that a summit would be convened soon. Mr Barak was in Europe, holding talks with British and French leaders. Mr Barak said in Paris that he hoped to meet a 13 September deadline for a framework agreement on Middle East peace, although those efforts are far behind schedule.

After conferring with French President Jacques Chirac, Mr Barak said the peace process is entering a "crucial period'' of both risks and opportunities

Mr Clinton tried holiday weekend telephone diplomacy to promote the summit, which Israel favours, despite Palestinian reservations.

The objective is to negotiate a framework for peace, with the two sides reported far from agreement on major issues, including the question of Israeli withdrawal from territory it has occupied since the 1967 Six-Day War.

The two sides had earlier agreed that there would be a final status agreement by the deadline, to set the lines for a permanent peace accord. Mr Arafat has said he will declare a Palestinian state on that date unless there are conclusive settlement negotiations before then. He said today that the Palestinians should not make any unilateral moves to declare an independent state, warning that could lead Israel to act unilaterally, too.

The summit is reminiscent of the Camp David talks between Israel and Egypt, brought together by President Jimmy Carter, that led to peace deals.

"I hope the setting leads to inspire them and inspire us,'' said Mr Clinton.

fields.headline: Science funding
fields.standfirst: Following Gordon Brown's announcement that £1bn is to be invested in research to stop the brain drain of scientists, Vikram Dodd explains why good funding is important for British science
fields.trailText: Wednesday, 1.30pm: Following Gordon Brown's announcement that £1bn is to be invested in research to stop the brain drain of scientists, Vikram Dodd explains why good funding is important for British science
fields.body:
Why is science funding in the news?
The chancellor Gordon Brown today announced a billion-pound investment programme for scientific research. The aim is to stem the brain drain of British researchers and scientists overseas, mainly the United States, where salaries, resources and conditions are reputed to be better.

That sounds like a lot of extra money. Is it really?
No, you need to read such government announcements carefully. The statement covers funding starting from 2002-03 and 2003-04. The government will provide £775m over these two years, which it says represents a real-term increase of 55%; so the extra money is considerably less than a billion pounds, more like a couple of hundred million. Last year, the government spent £1.4bn supporting British science.

And the rest of the billion-pound programme?
That comes from the Wellcome Trust, one of the world's biggest research groups, which will provide £225m. The scheme is called the science research investment fund.

What will the money be used for?
It will be invested in buildings, laboratories and equipment. Those who could get the money include universities, government research institutes and large national science facilities. A slice of the scheme will be used to increase the grants given to PhD science and engineering students. They currently get £6,620 a year if they live outside London and £8,265 in the capital. This will rise to £9,000 by 2003. Another slice of £675m has been earmarked for universities, new buildings, refurbishments and equipment. Universities will have to find one pound from a third party, for example a business, for every three they get under this scheme.

So no more moaning scientists?
It looks like the answer is no: academic salaries are still far higher in the US. A Royal Society survey found that, while 20 years ago 18.4% of Britain's top scientists live abroad, that figure is now 26%. The scheme announced today should lessen one pressure on scientists to leave Britain. The government's advisers believe underinvestment in British science's capital base, grotty buildings and antiquated equipment, have contributed to the brain drain. Boosting grants to PhD students is aimed at quelling the fear that there is little point spending money on first-rate buildings if there is no one to work there because grants are so low. Some complain that Britain still has an anti-science culture, and point to what they see as unfounded fears over genetically modified foods as an example.

Does the brain drain matter?
The future wealth of nations will be based on the knowledge economy, and the better a country's scientists and scientific base, the more it will thrive. While there is a long history of scientists swapping countries, losing out in the race in the new frontiers of genetics, fibre optics or environment technologies could be disastrous. British scientists have repeatedly innovated only for the profits to be reaped elsewhere. So while foreign moguls like Bill Gates may invest in British know-how in Cambridge, he will have first call on making money from their inventions, not British companies. The concern over the brain drain is about more than just academic excellence: ultimately, it is about money.

Watch the webcast of Gordon Brown's announcement

Royal Society

fields.headline: Leah Wild's IVF diary
fields.standfirst: Buying a baby? That'll do nicely
fields.trailText: Buying a baby? That'll do nicely
fields.body:
I 'm buying a baby on MasterCard. Well, I hope it will be a baby, but at the moment it's only the faint blistery promise of one. I would have preferred to purchase him or her by American Express, to clock up air miles, but the hospital wouldn't accept it.

At a widely reported international conference on fertility held last week in Bologna, Italy, cost was highlighted as one among many stress factors faced by infertile couples. Unfortunately, this aspect of childlessness seems to be far from a cure. Infertility treatment is a matter of postcode as no other medical procedure. Health authorities are given no extra funding to provide IVF, and it is up to them whether to support treatment from existing budgets. Preimplantation genetic diagnosis (PGD), which I need to sort good eggs from bad, is rarely funded.

I clearly remember the first time cost was broached. My legs were in stirrups and a balloon was being inflated in my womb, into which dye was to be injected. The kindly doctor warned that I was at the starting post in a long, painful and degrading set of pre-tests in my race for a child. Yet here I was going through a fair amount of discomfort and degradation before anyone had bothered to talk to me about the size of the bill.

I was going to have to cough up £2,500. If I couldn't get hold of that amount of money, all those tests would have been pointless. Why hadn't this been mentioned earlier, I asked the doctor with his rubber-gloved hand inside me? "Because we're embarrassed," he said. "We're doctors. We're not used to talking about money."

The quest for a child is costly. IVF drugs alone are an additional £800. My GP agreed to a prescription, for which I cannot thank her enough. But she was under no obligation to do so; each patient must make an individual plea.

But do we have a right to bear children? Do we have a right, as in my case, to have a second child at public expense? Is it the role of the National Health Service to meet these kinds of need? Is infertility an illness? The National Infertility Awareness Campaign (NIAC) argues: "Not all illnesses are visible. Infertility is an unseen illness . . . the infertile suffer emotionally and they suffer physically. You've only got to suffer from it to know."

I'm not so sure. I find it difficult to support the interpretation of infertility as illness. Childlessness is, at least in part, socially defined. In other places, and at other times, children were not always cared for by those who gave them birth. They were considered a shared resource. And I refuse to be labelled as ill. If I did not receive IVF treatment, I would not be less well; I would not pine away. I find it difficult to argue that I should, by right, have PGD paid for.

And yet... in the best of all possible worlds we wouldn't deny people the pleasure of a child when we have the means and money to fulfil their hopes. Surely every society should encourage longed-for children and, when we invest in IVF, we are endorsing the very best of motives and striving for the very best of outcomes. If we have the money we should do it.

Later this year, the department of health will publish a report detailing the huge differences in provision throughout the country. The intention is - eventually - to do something about this inequity. But in the meantime, for your information, just in case you may ever need it (and you never know), I'm reproducing the tiny note taped to the wall of the consulting room in my assisted conception unit:

 IVF £1,250

 PGD £2,500

 Sperm storage £100 per year

 Assisted hatching £200

 Freezing embryos £200 (including two years' storage)

 Freezing Sperm £50

(Note that anything to do with sperm is a bargain. A mere £50 to freeze a whole batch, which could contain millions.)

So far, my money is well spent. My first hurdle in an obstacle-ridden path to conception has been passed. I've responded well to sniffing the sex hormone-reducing drug Buserelin: an ultrasound has shown my womb lining is paper-thin and the follicles in my ovaries minuscule, indicating that my natural cycle has been completely suppressed. I've started injecting myself with FSH, a natural hormone, in the tops of my legs - nice lot of fat there - each morning. This should stimulate egg development. And I've decided to transfer my £2,500 Mastercard debt to a new credit card, as it offers a better interest rate. It happens to be called Egg.

leahwild@cswebmail.com

fields.headline: Born again
fields.standfirst: Writer Susan Johnson longed for a child but motherhood, when it finally came, turned her life inside out. She tells  Sally Weale  how she survived
fields.trailText: Writer Susan Johnson longed for a child but motherhood, when it finally came, turned her life inside out. She tells Sally Weale how she survived
fields.body:
It began with an empty feeling in her arms. A physical sensation that something was missing and a longing to cradle a baby in her arms. Susan Johnson was in her late 30s and after years of making a career for herself as a highly regarded novelist, she found she wanted a child. Her new book, A Better Woman, is an account of the birth of her two sons and its painful aftermath. It is a highly personal story, a confession, one woman's extraordinary tale, but it speaks to many.

Every mother has her own birth story. Johnson's is not for the squeamish - but then neither is life. With the birth of her first son, Caspar, her body was pushed to its very limits and it failed her, humiliatingly, miserably. She developed a recto-vaginal fistula - a small fissure running between her rectum and her vagina - which later resulted in a temporary colostomy. "What an outcome from having one little baby," a therapist commented before surgery.

What happened to Johnson was extreme and rare - the story of her physical collapse is unlikely to be yours. But her narrative is a powerful evocation of the traumatic journey a woman - any woman - makes from non-mother to mother. You are the same, yet different. You are forced to relate to the world and everyone in it differently.

It is about the wonder, the joy, the messiness, the exhaustion, the non-stop screaming, the blood and the guts and the gore. It is about the all-consuming demands of a newborn baby and the dramatic impact on your life of giving life to another. As Johnson writes: "A new baby craves nothing less than the whole of its mother, a mother's arms, a mother's body, a mother's milk, a mother's sleep. A new baby takes the sleep from your eyes, the breath from your lungs, a new baby requires that you lay your body down as the bridge on which he will learn to stand."

When you meet Johnson, what strikes you first is the care she must have taken with her appearance. A 43-year-old Australian, she is orderly, neat. Her long dark hair is carefully blow-dried, her clothes, all polka dots and bold colours, are well chosen. This is a woman who likes to feel in control; a woman who knows what it is like to lose that control.

In an era when we are increasingly filled with a sense of our own omnipotence, a belief that everything is ours for the taking, whenever we like, Johnson's book is a scary reminder that rather than being in control of life we are often at its mercy. "I'm one of that great 'me generation'. We felt we had absolute control over our lives. You could choose when to have a child, when not to have a child," she says.

"What you come up against with questions of reproduction and childbirth is the fact that it's not all about you. I think it's a great lesson in realising that you do not have ultimate control of your destiny. We cannot control life so why do we think we can control birth?

"It's the unexpected, the dramatic. It's about forces beyond our control. It's one of those extreme, primitive passages. I don't think anything can prepare you for that. I've had to learn to my cost that sometimes you can't have everything. Sometimes not everything is risk-free. Sometimes you have to pay for what you get. We're not very fond of that idea - that sometimes there are costs." In some ways childbirth in the western world has become sanitised - or at least has the appearance of being sanitised. Women have elective caesareans, bloody sheets are whisked away, mothers rarely die in childbirth; mortality rates among new-born babies have been dramatically reduced. It is easy to forget how dangerous life and giving life is. "We've got very short memories," says Johnson.

"It's only been a matter of a generation since women and babies were dying in childbirth. It's as if we've collectively forgotten how the possibility for danger is always there in childbirth. "It's still there for women in the third world where women still die regularly in childbirth, or else their babies die. "Fistulas like mine occur regularly in most third world countries."

And even in the sterilised, hygiene-conscious, gowned and masked labour wards of the west, "Life and death will be right in the room with you, you will feel life's breath upon your face and know the throb of life's blood," Johnson writes. "You will sense for a moment the meaning of existence, how fragile the membrane is between life and death, and then the curtains will close again on life's mystery and you will be left with only the vaguest dream."

For after giving birth, you are hurled full-on into life. She gives a graphic description of what it is like to have a child that won't stop screaming. How your heart begins to pound, your temples throb, the spit on your tongue and between your teeth dries; there is sweat on the palms of your hand and the soles of your feet. "You will hear screams in the shower and in your dreams, you will hear screams through walls and through deepest sleep, you will hear screams through the very lining of your head. Your whole body will be one long scream and here is the rub; there is nothing you can do about it."

She tells you about the intimacies of her body and her life; about lactating and defecating; about her failures as a mother; about screaming incoherently at her two toddler sons because she can't bear them fighting; about pushing her elder son down the corridor because he refuses to go to sleep, pushing him so hard that he falls. She tells you about a marriage breaking down; the bickering about who's earning the money, the fears about having sex after a colostomy. "It's as honest as I could make it," says Johnson. "It became much more graphic and revealing than I had intended originally. But I thought, if I'm going to write about this subject I must do it in a way which is as honest as possible."

The marriage is back together, though Johnson's husband has reservations about the book, understandably. Johnson herself has no regrets apart from one brief passage when she talks about the irrational thoughts that go through your head when you're exhausted. In her diary entry for Sunday, November 12 1995, it occurs to her that she hasn't yet heard Caspar stirring and she thinks: "If he's dead, at least I'll be able to sleep."

If nothing else, Johnson's story is a vivid, lurid antidote to the romanticisation of motherhood and the myth of the have-it-all, do-it-all woman. This is someone privileged, educated - she has money and a supportive family - but she's no Nicola Horlick. Her passion is writing, which is squeezed into a few minutes while her children watch Teletubbies. She writes in her head because there isn't time to put it on paper. Babies will not fit into the cracks of life, as she puts it. Small children, she says, are like ink on blotting paper, "seeping out to the very edges of your life, leaving no white space whatsoever". Try to make them squeeze into the tiny spaces between the other parts of your life and it will take its toll: "We've bought the myth of the superwoman. That we can have it all. But perhaps there are costs for our children. Maybe we let them down in some way."

Of course we do, in some small way, every day. Johnson's book reminds us of that. It also reminds us of the terrible, terrifying beauty of having a child. It's life in the raw - blood, tears and BabyGap clothes. But we'd do it all again, wouldn't we?

In Johnson's words: "Yes, yes. A thousand times, yes."

 A Better Woman: A Memoir, by Susan Johnson, is published by Aurum Press, £12.99

"What an outcome from having one little baby," a therapist commented before surgery. What happened to Johnson was extreme and rare - the story of her physical collapse is unlikely to be yours. But her narrative is a powerful evocation of the traumatic journey a woman - any woman - makes from non-mother to mother. You are the same, yet different. You are forced to relate to the world and everyone in it differently. It is about the wonder, the joy, the messiness, the exhaustion, the non-stop screaming, the blood and the guts and the gore. It is about the all-consuming demands of a newborn baby and the dramatic impact on your life of giving life to another. As Johnson writes: "A new baby craves nothing less than the whole of its mother, a mother's arms, a mother's body, a mother's milk, a mother's sleep. A new baby takes the sleep from your eyes, the breath from your lungs, a new baby requires that you lay your body down as the bridge on which he will learn to stand." When you meet Johnson, what strikes you first is the care she must have taken with her appearance. A 43-year-old Australian, she is orderly, neat. Her long dark hair is carefully blow-dried, her clothes, all polka dots and bold colours, are well chosen. This is a woman who likes to feel in control; a woman who knows what it is like to lose that control. In an era when we are increasingly filled with a sense of our own omnipotence, a belief that everything is ours for the taking, whenever we like, Johnson's book is a scary reminder that rather than being in control of life we are often at its mercy. "I'm one of that great 'me generation'. We felt we had absolute control over our lives. You could choose when to have a child, when not to have a child," she says. "What you come up against with questions of reproduction and childbirth is the fact that it's not all about you. I think it's a great lesson in realising that you do not have ultimate control of your destiny. We cannot control life so why do we think we can control birth? "It's the unexpected, the dramatic. It's about forces beyond our control. It's one of those extreme, primitive passages. I don't think anything can prepare you for that. I've had to learn to my cost that sometimes you can't have everything. Sometimes not everything is risk-free. Sometimes you have to pay for what you get. We're not very fond of that idea - that sometimes there are costs." In some ways childbirth in the western world has become sanitised - or at least has the appearance of being sanitised. Women have elective caesareans, bloody sheets are whisked away, mothers rarely die in childbirth; mortality rates among new-born babies have been dramatically reduced. It is easy to forget how dangerous life and giving life is. "We've got very short memories," says Johnson. "It's only been a matter of a generation since women and babies were dying in childbirth. It's as if we've collectively forgotten how the possibility for danger is always there in childbirth. "It's still there for women in the third world where women still die regularly in childbirth, or else their babies die. "Fistulas like mine occur regularly in most third world countries." And even in the sterilised, hygiene-conscious, gowned and masked labour wards of the west, "Life and death will be right in the room with you, you will feel life's breath upon your face and know the throb of life's blood," Johnson writes. "You will sense for a moment the meaning of existence, how fragile the membrane is between life and death, and then the curtains will close again on life's mystery and you will be left with only the vaguest dream." For after giving birth, you are hurled full-on into life. She gives a graphic description of what it is like to have a child that won't stop screaming. How your heart begins to pound, your temples throb, the spit on your tongue and between your teeth dries; there is sweat on the palms of your hand and the soles of your feet. "You will hear screams in the shower and in your dreams, you will hear screams through walls and through deepest sleep, you will hear screams through the very lining of your head. Your whole body will be one long scream and here is the rub; there is nothing you can do about it." She tells you about the intimacies of her body and her life; about lactating and defecating; about her failures as a mother; about screaming incoherently at her two toddler sons because she can't bear them fighting; about pushing her elder son down the corridor because he refuses to go to sleep, pushing him so hard that he falls. She tells you about a marriage breaking down; the bickering about who's earning the money, the fears about having sex after a colostomy. "It's as honest as I could make it," says Johnson. "It became much more graphic and revealing than I had intended originally. But I thought, if I'm going to write about this subject I must do it in a way which is as honest as possible." The marriage is back together, though Johnson's husband has reservations about the book, understandably. Johnson herself has no regrets apart from one brief passage when she talks about the irrational thoughts that go through your head when you're exhausted. In her diary entry for Sunday, November 12 1995, it occurs to her that she hasn't yet heard Caspar stirring and she thinks: "If he's dead, at least I'll be able to sleep." If nothing else, Johnson's story is a vivid, lurid antidote to the romanticisation of motherhood and the myth of the have-it-all, do-it-all woman. This is someone privileged, educated - she has money and a supportive family - but she's no Nicola Horlick. Her passion is writing, which is squeezed into a few minutes while her children watch Teletubbies. She writes in her head because there isn't time to put it on paper. Babies will not fit into the cracks of life, as she puts it. Small children, she says, are like ink on blotting paper, "seeping out to the very edges of your life, leaving no white space whatsoever". Try to make them squeeze into the tiny spaces between the other parts of your life and it will take its toll: "We've bought the myth of the superwoman. That we can have it all. But perhaps there are costs for our children. Maybe we let them down in some way." Of course we do, in some small way, every day. Johnson's book reminds us of that. It also reminds us of the terrible, terrifying beauty of having a child. It's life in the raw - blood, tears and BabyGap clothes. But we'd do it all again, wouldn't we? In Johnson's words: "Yes, yes. A thousand times, yes."  A Better Woman: A Memoir, by Susan Johnson, is published by Aurum Press, £12.99

webTitle: If you go down to the gender ghetto today

fields.headline: If you go down to the gender ghetto today
fields.standfirst:
The way we work

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: You've seen the headlines: "Working Mothers Damage/ Do Not Damage/Improve* Children's Prospects" (*delete as appropriate, taking into account political slant of the publication). A slew of studies - each apparently contradicting the one before - has attempted to track the development of children whose mothers work.
fields.body:
You've seen the headlines: "Working Mothers Damage/ Do Not Damage/Improve* Children's Prospects" (*delete as appropriate, taking into account political slant of the publication). A slew of studies - each apparently contradicting the one before - has attempted to track the development of children whose mothers work. What is striking about these studies and the stories that follow is their complacent sexism. An alien visiting from planet Utopia, where men and women are equals in all spheres, might puzzle for a while over the headlines. "Mmm. Surely there is someone missing from this picture? Who could it be? Oh yes, that's right, my O-level biology is coming back to me - the father!"

Never is the research written up as the impact of working parents. The unshakeable presumption is that children have just two options: paid-for care or mother-care. Fathers are simply discounted. And we wonder why women are at a disadvantage in the labour market. We wonder why the pay gap remains stubbornly open. We wonder why there is only one women CEO in the FTSE-100.

Sadly, this sexism spans the political spectrum. Progressive historian Eric Hobsbawm has this to say in his latest work, The New Century: "I think that successes [for women] in the workplace have been satisfactory ... there is, however, a serious problem: the extraordinary difficulties of combining high professional posts with being mothers. This has nothing to do with discrimination, but with the natural law that women are the ones who give birth."

Actually, Professor, it has everything to do with discrimination. There is a discriminatory view that because women carry children, they are necessarily the prime carers, while men sail on in their careers. Of course, there are some things women can do, in parenting terms, that men cannot. They can:

i) Breastfeed.
ii) Er ...
iii) That's it, actually.

But parenting is a decades-long, complex, multi-skilled job. Fathers can bond as closely as mothers with their children, they can read stories, wipe tears, noses and bums, help with homework, teach swimming, sing songs, advise on first dates, lend cars and write cheques for university tuition fees.

We are a long way from headlines warning that working dads are damaging their children - but some new research takes us at least a step closer to a more balanced view. Christopher Ruhm, in a paper for the National Bureau of Economic Research in the US, has for the first time looked at the impact on child cognitive development of both parents working. First, he finds that children with working mothers - especially in the first year - have slightly lower verbal skills at the age of three and weaker reading ability at the age of five. Ruhm then examines the influence of father's employment and finds almost identical trends.

He concludes: "Time investments of mothers and fathers have qualitatively similar effects on children, raising the possibility of substitution across parents." In other words, all the stories about "working mothers" need to be edited to read "working parents". In other words, fathers can do just as good a job at home as mothers.

The automatic association of femininity with family is, of course, damaging for women. Women are the ones who are made to feel guilty if they work and their child goes to nursery, even though their partner works as well and probably for much longer hours.

Until we rethink our attitudes to childcare - and take it out of the gender ghetto - women will continue to have to fight harder than men to make it to the top of their professions. If, that is, they have children. For many women, a desire to make it to the top makes children a luxury they can ill afford. Nine out of 10 male 40-year-old executives in the US have children; only a third of 40-year-old females at the same level do. These figures are an indictment of our outdated approach to gender and childrearing. For all the talk of a new Britain and a new century, the gendered division of labour remains fixed in concrete, embedded in law and replicated in business practice.

Theodore Zeldin described the 20th century as the first in which women were seeking to find themselves rather than find a husband. This attempt has sometimes been thwarted by 19th-century views of motherhood. Let's ditch the myths and prejudices, and start seeing ourselves as equals at home, as well as at work. Let's drop the attitude.

 Richard Reeves is director of futures at the Industrial Society. You can contact him at rreeves@indsoc.co.uk.
For workplace distractions, visit www.workunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: Holiday season is here again but what's the best way to cope with bored, tired kids if the flight is hit by long delays?
fields.trailText: The Question: Holiday season is here again but what's the best way to cope with bored, tired kids if the flight is hit by long delays?
fields.body:
Kate Calvert Editor of Family Travel magazine

There isn't an ideal solution: what will work for one family won't work for another. So be prepared with something suitable. My four-and-a-half-year-old loves Roald Dahl, so I've got Charlie and the Great Glass Elevator ready to give her. I know she'll enjoy it, but she hasn't heard it before. Crayons and paper are good too, as are Walkmans or hand-held games. I would also suggest taking surprise treats to pull out at moments of boredom. If you're really organised, you'll take enough to have something up your sleeve for the journey home, too.

 Verdict: Be prepared

Caroline Alderson Media relations manager, Gatwick Airport

We understand delays are distressing, although long ones are rare, but we have plenty arranged in case they do occur: for children aged two to six we've got two play areas, and for older children there are arcade games. There are also several internet points for surfing the net. Our spectator viewing gallery is popular and you can also see a sound and light show called Skyview which gives you an idea of what happens at an international airport. There are many shops including a Manchester United FC outlet - something for everyone.

 Verdict: Plan ahead

Peter Stanford Father of two, author and broadcaster

We took our children to Corsica a few weeks ago, and there was a delay on the return trip. My top tip would be, don't go through to the departure lounge until they're calling your flight: in a lot of holiday airports there's not much to do landside, but there's absolutely nothing to do airside. At least you can play outside, have games on the trolleys (don't give those back until you're sure you won't be hit by a delay), even play with the sticky labels our holiday company provided for our suitcases. Travelling with another family helps, too.

 Verdict: Don't rush to gates

Simon Elsey Programme director, Simply Travel specialist agency

For many young children, flying is an adventure in itself - so if you are delayed at the airport you can make plane-spotting seem a lot of fun. Why not buy some postcards of the planes you've seen? They are often available at airport shops. Another good time-filler is to make lists of things you'd like to do on your holiday, if the delay is on the outward-bound flight - or a list of things you've done if you're on your way home. If you've got a guide book which contains useful words and phrases in the language of the country they're visiting, you could teach your kids a few of them.

 Verdict: Language lessons

Jan Parker Co-author, Raising Children, Hodder & Stoughton, £9.99

Don't give kids everything too soon. I once saw a mum negotiate a five-hour airport delay. As her three children reached screaming pitch she pulled personal stereos from her bag, placed one on the head of each grouchy child, switched on their story tapes and then for herself produced a well- thumbed book and a can of Guinness. Quite a survival kit. Games may help. Uno, a colours-and-numbers card game, is my kids' favourite. The Pass the Pig dice game makes them laugh and the dreaded Gameboy can suddenly seem worth every penny.

 Verdict: Pace the treats

Catherine Holmes Mother of Madeleine, aged 14 months

We took Madeleine round the world when she was six months old. Thankfully we didn't experience many flight delays. But I took lots of toys with me - things like her "snuggly", which she likes. It helps if you're breastfeeding: you might feel like a milking machine, but at least your baby is happy and quiet. Now she's older it's more difficult - this summer I'll take board-books to keep her occupied, and lots of snacks - raisins, rice cakes and so on. It's not a good idea to expect too much of small European airports; have your survival kit with you.

 Verdict: Take snacks

fields.headline: Off the shelf
fields.standfirst: Building a library for your child :   Ages 0-4 :   Ages 5-7 :   Ages 8-11 :   Ages 12+
fields.trailText: Building a library for your child : Ages 0-4 : Ages 5-7 : Ages 8-11 : Ages 12+
fields.body:
Book of the month

Frenchtown Summer

by Robert Cormier (Puffin, £4.99; CultureShop price £3.99 )

This is very different. Not just from Cormier's other hard-hitting and often controversial books for teenagers, but from any book for young adults.

For a start, it is written as a prose poem. This might initially be off-putting for some readers but the writing is so unforced and yet so lyrical, the images so startling and the observation so acute that the book carries the reader along like a rushing river.

It is the tale of one summer, 70 years ago, in the life of a paper boy, Eugene. Suffused with Catholic guilt, Eugene walks the streets of the town as a silent witness to its secrets: the suicides and near suicides, the unquiet dead, the crippled, the bullied and bullies. Most of all it chronicles his Eugene's relationship with a father who is "as unknown as a foreign language" but at the crucial moment manages to affirm his love for Eugene in the tiniest of gestures.

A wonderful book that every father and every son should read.

How to buy the books

Off the shelf is a monthly selection of the best new titles. It can be used in conjunction with the Guardian website (www.booksunlimited.co.uk) where you will find reviews of classic books to provide the backbone of a children's library. All the books can be bought directly from the website.

The titles below can also be ordered through the Guardian CultureShop at the discount indicated: freephone 0800 3166 102 or send your order with a UK cheque payable to The Guardian CultureShop, 250 Western Avenue, London W3 6EE. Please add 99p UK p&p per order.

Polar Bolero by Debi Gliori (Scholastic, £10.99; CultureShop price £8.99)

A little polar bear can't get to sleep and so he leaves the house for a frolic with his friends before settling down for the night. The story is not original - the magic is in the execution. Gliori combines a simple rhyming text with bright expressive drawings that evoke both the strange shadowy world of the night and its distorted perspective. It is a familiar world rendered unfamiliar and fantastical.

There is wit at work here, too: Gliori plays delightfully with the fiction of a book within a book suggesting that the tale is a bear or child's dream and also a bedtime story read by the bear's mother. The result is something both wild and adventurous, cosy and safe.

The Lemonade Genie by Adrian Boote (Orchard, £7.99; CultureShop price £5.99)

Colin Crumbly is a walking disaster area, the kind of boy who blows his nose without a handkerchief and demolishes entire buildings when he trips over his own feet.

Things can only get worse when he opens his lunchtime lemonade and unleashes a genie. Not the helpful, Aladdin sort of genie, but one called Keith who unleashes mayhem on Moonwood County primary school. Soon, double-decker buses are falling from the sky, the emergency services are on full alert and the headmaster has to be extracted from up the left nostril of one of several giant Colin clones.

A funny, fizzy read, full of the snotty, banana-skin humour so appreciated by children of this age.

The Boy and the Dog Who Walked to the Moon by Nicholas Cross (Floris, £4.99; CultureShop price £3.99)

Tomas, a young orphan living in Granada, works in conditions of near slavery at a local inn. So when he meets a dog called Don Alfonso, who suggests that Tomas should join him in his attempt to walk to the moon, the boy decides that he has little to lose and much to gain.

Talking dogs, raging bulls and the wild weaver of the Alpujarras who spins rainbows, magic and philosophy remind us that what we so often consider to be facts about the world around us may only be assumptions. After all, as Don Alfonso explains, the only reason dogs bark is because people are too impatient to listen to them.

A distinctly European folktale.

The Power of One by Bryce Courtenay (Puffin, £5.99; CultureShop price, £3.99)

"First with your head and then with your heart," the boxer tells Peekay, a young English boy growing up in a racially divided South Africa.

It is a lesson that Peekay learns as he sets out to fulfil his ambition to become welterweight champion of the world. But first he must overcome the bullies who pick on him, deal with the mother who has a breakdown, and discover the realities of the local prison where the black prisoners endure a savage regime.

Courtenay's David and Goliath story, published here for the first time as a young reader's edition, is a real page-turner. A remarkable book that eloquently persuades of the horrors and evil of racism.

Whiff by Ian Whybrow and Russell Ayto (Corgi, £4.99; CultureShop price £3.99)

Subtitled "How the beautiful big fat smelly baby found a friend", Baby Warthog is sent home in disgrace from other animals' homes because his lingering smell and persistent cloud of flies are not appreciated by their parents. His own folks, of course, think he is just perfect.

There is a vibrant, cartoonish quality to both words and pictures, and there is something wonderfully reassuring in this story for both children and parents as it points to the fact that one person's bad behaviour is another person's good, that we are all different and that making friends isn't half as easy as it's cracked up to be.

A little gem of genuine comic exuberance.

Read Me a Story, Please chosen by Wendy Cooling (Dolphin Giant, £9.99; CultureShop price £7.99)

I know you're not supposed to look at books this way, but this 50-story anthology works out at less than 20p a story. You can introduce your offspring to Francesca Simon's Horrid Henry and Lucy Coates's rewriting of Hans Christian Andersen's The Tinderbox, great original stories such as Anne Fine's How To Read in the Dark, and Vivian French's tale about the wolf who, after seeing how others suffer at the hands of the three little pigs, decides that huffing and puffing is not for him.

Penny Dann's boisterous illustrations give the book a clear identity, and parents will find the labelling of each story, as a two, five or 10 minute read aloud tale, very helpful.

Toad Rage by Morris Gleitzman (Puffin, £3.99; CultureShop price £2.99)

When Uncle Bart tells his nephew Limpy that humans don't hate cane toads, Limpy is disinclined to believe him, not least because seconds later Bart is not Limpy's fattest uncle, but his flattest - squashed beneath the wheels of a truck.

Gleitzman's novel, set against the background of the forthcoming Sydney Olympics, takes a satirical look at mascots and marketing, and asks why we love cuddly koalas but abhor slimy, warty creatures.

This rewarding read is a great introduction to the work of Gleitzman. If they enjoy this one, get some of Gleitzman's other humorous but harder hitting books such as Two Weeks with the Queen and Blabber Mouth.

Raspberries on the Yangtze by Karen Wallace (Simon and Schuster, £7.99; CultureShop price 5.99)

This is not about the Chinese river but a children's hideaway in rural Canada in the 50s. The story turns into a junior version of Kate Atkinson's Behind the Scenes at the Museum as the sunny, innocent world of childhood (in which young Nancy sells the facts of life for 15 cents a throw and spends idyllic summers playing on logs on the river) is invaded by an adult world of sexual scandal and malicious gossip.

Wallace writes perceptively and with a gentle, quizzing humour about the confusion of children confronted with the festering secrets of grown-ups. There is something steely going on beneath the calm surface of this book.
