Polar Bolero by Debi Gliori (Scholastic, £10.99; CultureShop price £8.99) A little polar bear can't get to sleep and so he leaves the house for a frolic with his friends before settling down for the night. The story is not original - the magic is in the execution. Gliori combines a simple rhyming text with bright expressive drawings that evoke both the strange shadowy world of the night and its distorted perspective. It is a familiar world rendered unfamiliar and fantastical. There is wit at work here, too: Gliori plays delightfully with the fiction of a book within a book suggesting that the tale is a bear or child's dream and also a bedtime story read by the bear's mother. The result is something both wild and adventurous, cosy and safe. The Lemonade Genie by Adrian Boote (Orchard, £7.99; CultureShop price £5.99) Colin Crumbly is a walking disaster area, the kind of boy who blows his nose without a handkerchief and demolishes entire buildings when he trips over his own feet. Things can only get worse when he opens his lunchtime lemonade and unleashes a genie. Not the helpful, Aladdin sort of genie, but one called Keith who unleashes mayhem on Moonwood County primary school. Soon, double-decker buses are falling from the sky, the emergency services are on full alert and the headmaster has to be extracted from up the left nostril of one of several giant Colin clones. A funny, fizzy read, full of the snotty, banana-skin humour so appreciated by children of this age. The Boy and the Dog Who Walked to the Moon by Nicholas Cross (Floris, £4.99; CultureShop price £3.99) Tomas, a young orphan living in Granada, works in conditions of near slavery at a local inn. So when he meets a dog called Don Alfonso, who suggests that Tomas should join him in his attempt to walk to the moon, the boy decides that he has little to lose and much to gain. Talking dogs, raging bulls and the wild weaver of the Alpujarras who spins rainbows, magic and philosophy remind us that what we so often consider to be facts about the world around us may only be assumptions. After all, as Don Alfonso explains, the only reason dogs bark is because people are too impatient to listen to them. A distinctly European folktale. The Power of One by Bryce Courtenay (Puffin, £5.99; CultureShop price, £3.99) "First with your head and then with your heart," the boxer tells Peekay, a young English boy growing up in a racially divided South Africa. It is a lesson that Peekay learns as he sets out to fulfil his ambition to become welterweight champion of the world. But first he must overcome the bullies who pick on him, deal with the mother who has a breakdown, and discover the realities of the local prison where the black prisoners endure a savage regime. Courtenay's David and Goliath story, published here for the first time as a young reader's edition, is a real page-turner. A remarkable book that eloquently persuades of the horrors and evil of racism. Whiff by Ian Whybrow and Russell Ayto (Corgi, £4.99; CultureShop price £3.99) Subtitled "How the beautiful big fat smelly baby found a friend", Baby Warthog is sent home in disgrace from other animals' homes because his lingering smell and persistent cloud of flies are not appreciated by their parents. His own folks, of course, think he is just perfect. There is a vibrant, cartoonish quality to both words and pictures, and there is something wonderfully reassuring in this story for both children and parents as it points to the fact that one person's bad behaviour is another person's good, that we are all different and that making friends isn't half as easy as it's cracked up to be. A little gem of genuine comic exuberance. Read Me a Story, Please chosen by Wendy Cooling (Dolphin Giant, £9.99; CultureShop price £7.99) I know you're not supposed to look at books this way, but this 50-story anthology works out at less than 20p a story. You can introduce your offspring to Francesca Simon's Horrid Henry and Lucy Coates's rewriting of Hans Christian Andersen's The Tinderbox, great original stories such as Anne Fine's How To Read in the Dark, and Vivian French's tale about the wolf who, after seeing how others suffer at the hands of the three little pigs, decides that huffing and puffing is not for him. Penny Dann's boisterous illustrations give the book a clear identity, and parents will find the labelling of each story, as a two, five or 10 minute read aloud tale, very helpful. Toad Rage by Morris Gleitzman (Puffin, £3.99; CultureShop price £2.99) When Uncle Bart tells his nephew Limpy that humans don't hate cane toads, Limpy is disinclined to believe him, not least because seconds later Bart is not Limpy's fattest uncle, but his flattest - squashed beneath the wheels of a truck. Gleitzman's novel, set against the background of the forthcoming Sydney Olympics, takes a satirical look at mascots and marketing, and asks why we love cuddly koalas but abhor slimy, warty creatures. This rewarding read is a great introduction to the work of Gleitzman. If they enjoy this one, get some of Gleitzman's other humorous but harder hitting books such as Two Weeks with the Queen and Blabber Mouth. Raspberries on the Yangtze by Karen Wallace (Simon and Schuster, £7.99; CultureShop price 5.99) This is not about the Chinese river but a children's hideaway in rural Canada in the 50s. The story turns into a junior version of Kate Atkinson's Behind the Scenes at the Museum as the sunny, innocent world of childhood (in which young Nancy sells the facts of life for 15 cents a throw and spends idyllic summers playing on logs on the river) is invaded by an adult world of sexual scandal and malicious gossip. Wallace writes perceptively and with a gentle, quizzing humour about the confusion of children confronted with the festering secrets of grown-ups. There is something steely going on beneath the calm surface of this book.

webTitle: Science gets £1bn to halt brain drain

fields.headline: Science gets £1bn to halt brain drain
fields.standfirst: Gordon Brown's press release
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown will today announce a billion-pound investment programme into scientific research to boost hi-tech enterprise and stem the brain drain to the United States.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown will today announce a billion-pound investment programme into scientific research to boost hi-tech enterprise and stem the brain drain to the United States.

Much of the money will be directed at nurturing PhD students in key sciences, the chancellor will tell 20 American and British financiers at a conference in London on enterprise and technology.

The centrepiece of today's announcement will be a joint venture with the Wellcome Trust, one of the world's biggest research groups, that is being described as "bigger and better" than the government's investment in Wellcome's successful programme to crack the human genome.

Mike Dexter, director of the Wellcome Trust, said: "I am delighted that this partnership with government can mean such a massive increase in science research infrastructure throughout the UK. We are delighted to have played our part in this initiative."

The funding could mean that research students currently financed by the government's research councils will see their salaries catch up with the fewer but better-paid students supported by the trust.

Research councils last year announced a £1,000 boost to PhD grant students. As a result minimum grants are currently set at £6,500 a year. But this is still well short of the £12,000 salaries enjoyed by research students backed by Wellcome.

American researchers are much better paid and Bill Gates, the Microsoft computer billionaire, is investing massively in Cambridge to finance research students who might otherwise be without funds.

Academics and ministers have been concerned about the effect of tuition fees on the number of students who take up places, especially in engineering and physical sciences - some of which are longer courses.

Alarm bells were sounded two years ago when rising numbers of unfilled studentships were reported.

In addition, surveys of undergraduates have suggested that increasing debts and small PhD grants are causing many final-year university undergraduates to now think twice about research careers.

The spending announcement today by Mr Brown is the second large tranche of money to be allocated by the Treasury as part of the rolling spending review that will be announced in full later this month.

Labour is under pressure from the scientific community, which is disappointed with its failure to reverse the slow drain in funds under the Tory governments of John Major and Margaret Thatcher.

The debate over PhD funding has intensified in recent years as government officials realised how important research students are for the future livelihood of academic communities, and for many industries. At the same time there has been increasing realisation of how badly research students have been treated up to now. They are among the worst paid professional trainees in the country. The boom in numbers in universities in the last decade also means that standards in training vary dramatically across the academic sector.

Denis Noble, professor of cardiovascular physiology at Oxford, and one of the founders of Save British Science, has argued that there may not be a net brain drain but that British science has in effect been decapitated by two decades of national meanness with research money.

From 1940 to 1980, scientists working in British laboratories averaged 10 Nobel prizes a decade. In the last 20 years, there have been six. Prof Noble argues that scientists on whom Britain's future record depends were prevented from reaching their potential by funding changes of the late 70s and 80s.

fields.headline: Missing prodigy emails home
fields.standfirst: 4 July: Prodigy went missing 'to find space'
fields.trailText: A child prodigy missing from Oxford University for the past two weeks is thought to have contacted her family, police said today.
fields.body:
A child prodigy missing from Oxford University for the past two weeks is thought to have contacted her family, police said today.

The father of Sufiah Yusof, 15, received an email late last night - the first apparent contact with any relative since her disappearance.

A Thames Valley police spokesman said: "An email was received late yesterday reportedly from Sufiah. Police are currently checking its contents and authenticity.

"We have no reason to believe this e-mail is not from Sufiah but we would not like to comment on its content."

The mathematics genius, in her third year of a masters degree at the all-women's college St Hilda's, disappeared on June 22 after finishing her final exam of the year. She had been expected to return to the family home in Coventry, but failed to make contact with either her mother, father or four brothers and sisters.

The only contact from her before last night's email was a telephone call to her college dean, made shortly after her disappearance, saying she was "OK, but needed some space".

Her father Farooq, 43, has been joined by university officials over the past few days in making impassioned pleas for her to return as fears grew for her safety.

Suggestions that she may have run away due to academic pressures were dismissed by both parties. It was revealed yesterday that she had passed her end of year exams.

A police source indicated today that Sufiah had left the city of her own will because of personal problems with her family and did not yet wish to return home.

Mr Yusof implied today that his daughter was with a third party and being held against her will despite the recent email. He said he now feared for her safety and well-being more than any other time since her disappearance.

"I make an appeal to whoever is with Sufiah to get in contact with me. I will meet them anywhere and at any time. We are a normal hard-working family and I believe those with my daughter have the wrong perception of us."

Thames Valley police, who now have four officers working on the case, have trawled through her deleted emails and studied CCTV images taken of her in Oxford city centre.

Police have said they are "fairly confident" that she is safe and well.

fields.headline: Through brick walls
fields.standfirst: Liza Ramrayka reports on how mediation is helping to tackle nuisance neighbours
fields.trailText: Liza Ramrayka reports on how mediation is helping to tackle nuisance neighbours.
fields.body:
The eviction notice recently served by Manchester city council on long-term nuisance tenant, Rosemary Brownsell, was hailed as a victory for neighbours everywhere who suffer harassment and threats. It was also the latest in a series of hardline actions by councils trying to deal with nuisance neighbours and a sign, perhaps, that the government's continued calls for tougher action on anti-social behaviour are finally being heeded.

But a report published today by the Chartered Institute of Housing questions the effectiveness of legal remedies for neighbour nuisance. An 18-month study, carried out by researchers at Sheffield Hallam University and funded by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, found that three-quarters of social landlords (local authorities and housing associations) had significant problems with nuisance neighbours. All said they were willing to take possession proceedings and, if necessary, evict tenants. But there was a strong feeling that eviction was, in effect, a failure as the problem was simply displaced to another street or estate, or to the private sector.

And while the use of legal remedies has increased over the past five years, many landlords told the researchers that this had presented new problems - such as witness intimidation and long delays in the legal process.

Home secretary Jack Straw has made plain his impatience that councils and police are not making more use of the powers available to them, which now include the anti-social behaviour order (Asbo) introduced last year by the Crime and Disorder Act. Last week, he told the Local Government Association's annual conference that only 80 Asbos had been issued by the courts. Announcing new guidance, he said the orders "should be used swiftly where circumstances demand it, not just against the very hard cases of unacceptable behaviour".

However, Judy Nixon, a co-author of today's report, argues that landlords may get better results from alternative routes, such as mediation or improved housing management. "The people who are responsible for these incidents often come from incredibly vulnerable groups and the issues are perhaps not effectively addressed by eviction from their home," she says. "Full investigation of the problems is needed, which means better training and better multi-agency working."

Nottingham Mediation Service is an independent neighbour mediation service developed and managed by Nacro, the offender resettlement charity. Funded by a variety of sources, including the local authority housing department and a local community regeneration programme, the service uses trained, volunteer mediators to find mutual agreements to neighbour disputes. Noise nuisance is the most common complaint, followed by verbal abuse and threatening behaviour.

Of the 70 mediation cases dealt with by the service each year, about two-thirds reach a successful conclusion. This can involve a verbal undertaking by the neighbour not to repeat the offending behaviour or a more formal written agreement, specifying such things as the maximum level for playing music.

Service co-ordinator Jean Hart believes that mediation helps. "A lot of people just don't have the resources or experience to deal with these incidents," she says, "so tensions build up, and the result is an explosive situation".

Liverpool city council's anti-social behaviour unit hit the headlines last year when it had the first English Asbos, granted against three teenagers who had made their neighbours' lives hell by urinating in public, swearing and possessing illegal drugs. The council has so far applied for nine such orders. Set up in 1997, the unit works with a range of agencies, including landlords, police and social and education services.

Gerard Murden, Liverpool's head of neighbour services, says eviction is seen as a last resort. "We use a problem-solving group made up of agencies and specialists to work on individual cases."

Wolverhampton city council co-funds an arms-length mediation service. But John Davies, assistant director of housing, says mediation alone is not always enough to stamp out instances of anti-social behaviour among tenants. "Some of the behaviour we come across borders on or is in fact criminal," he explains. "In these cases, the difficulty is getting both parties to agree to mediation."

Around 350 of Wolverhampton's 30,000 tenancies are at varying stages of review under a "safer estates" agreement. In about a third of cases, the tenants concerned have modified their behaviour following warnings.

For Jean Hart, in Nottingham, mediation is valuable because it allows all parties involved to buy into the final resolution. She says: "The strength of this approach is that we're not coming into people's homes to tell them how to live their lives, but to help them to agree what is acceptable."

The peace process

Wild parties in next door's garden are all very well if you're invited too, but one elderly couple on a Liverpool council estate found that nuisance neighbours almost ruined their retirement.

The pensioners live next to a middle-aged couple whose riotous lifestyle, noise and abusive language had been upsetting them and their visitors for more than two years. The friction was also having an impact on the whole street, as other residents had taken sides.

Complaints prompted the council to start collecting evidence, at which point The Independent Mediation Service (Tims) became involved. Set up four years ago, the service is funded by local councils and social landlords, among others, and is staffed by 40 volunteer mediators who work with all parties to resolve disputes. Of 200 cases dealt with over the last 12 months, half have resulted in verbal or written agreements.

Mediators visited the elderly couple, their neighbours and other complainants three times during eight weeksto come to a solution. The result was a written agreement where the nuisance tenants agreed not to play their music above a certain level or at certain times. Significantly, the agreement also specified how the parties would handle future disputes.

Sharyn Kinder, Tims manager, says mediation makes good financial sense. The average case costs £250-£350, compared to about £900 to transfer a tenant and £4,000 to take legal action.

The Tims approach is now placing more emphasis on face-to-face meetings. As Kinder says: "If you're in dispute, you dehumanise one another. It's 'that man' or 'that woman'. But if you see people with their children or parents it makes them human."

 Neighbour Nuisance, Social Landlords and the Law is available at £12.95, plus £1.50 p&p, from the Chartered Institute of Housing, Octavia House, Westwood Way, Coventry CV5 8JP

fields.headline: Wheels of fortune
fields.standfirst: In Norwich's youth jail, a scheme to restore old bicycles is bringing a sense of worth to young offenders, says  Les Woodland. Additional reporting by David Brindle
fields.trailText: In Norwich's youth jail, a scheme to restore old bicycles is bringing a sense of worth to young offenders, says Les Woodland.
fields.body:
The lad wheeling a Raleigh Chopper across the workroom floor has everything to please your granny. John is well spoken, smiles, talks intelligently and, until lately, had a good job with BP. The only trouble with John is that he used to set fire to things. He's inside for arson, reckless driving and heavy-handed assault. John expects six years when he returns to court for sentencing.

The bikes along one wall, the racks of tools and the heavy-duty mechanics' frames could be the back of some big bike shop. But this is the youth jail - the young offenders' institution alongside the Porridge-like pile of Norwich prison.

The lads make themselves coffee and call the boss by his first name. But a door never opens without being locked again. The bikes being mended by the team of six in red overalls will go to good causes overseas and, with luck, get the boys back into society. Some, admittedly, will get there sooner than others - John reckons on serving four of his anticipated six years.

John Bannister, who set up the workshop, says: "A lot of the kids in here, if you looked at their home lives, you would see they had been thrown out, perhaps for good reason. And their parents have either been in jail or they're jail potential."

The bikes come in by the vanload, maybe three dozen at a time, and are collected soon afterwards by charities which have sent a shopping list of what they need most for Romania or Botswana or wherever.

Norwich is one of just three youth jails with a bike workshop. Its 160 young offenders know well the value of working there - and not simply the £8 a week they get instead of the usual £2.50.

"This may be the first time these boys have done anything productive," says Bannister. "If we sold the bikes for profit, there would be trouble. But they know where the bikes are going and when the letters and pictures start coming back showing people using the bikes, the boys will be touched. That's when it will get to them."

Take "Essex" Tony, 21, sent down for three years for breaking and entering. He will be out in seven months. At one time it seemed he might not live that long.

"I've been in trouble and in prisons since I was 16," he says, as he works on a child's bike. Until jail, his only interest in bikes was BMX stunt riding and he paid his younger brother to do all his spannering for him.

"I was a heroin addict on the out and I just used to flip in here. It was the loneliness because, being so far from home, my family couldn't get in to see me."

"Flipping" is jail slang for lashing out at prison officers and generally being what Bannister calls "a real out-and-out tearaway". But Tony's trade was decorating, so Bannister got him painting an old office, fixing up shelves and shifting rubbish to turn it into a workshop. The work won him a place on the bike team.

"I've completely changed, haven't I?" he says, looking for confirmation from Bannister. "OK, I do still get down and flip now and then, but you know my worth now, don't you?" Another check for approval. "They say 'Oh, Tony's having a bad day, but he'll be OK.'"

In seven months, Tony will be out, looking for a job and enjoying life with his girlfriend whom he met over the prison fence. "She came to look for another bloke and shouted out her address and I wrote to her," says Tony. "Now she comes in to see me and I want to stay here in Norwich with her and look for a job somewhere."

The prison fence is a regular meeting place. The lads can't get to it, but they can gaze down at the girls who gather there. "One of the girls threw two plastic bottles of Jack Daniels over the fence the other night," says Russell Fish, the project manager. "I don't know how she thought her boyfriend was going to get them, but they were found in the morning by the security patrol."

Fish is a member of the Breckland cycling club in central Norfolk and a devotee of bicycles. After 15 years in a factory, he walked into a job centre and signed up to help Bannister set up Bicycle Recycle. "It was like I'd fallen on my feet," he says.

In his office are job details and the boys' records. Their work, along with some exam papers, adds up to the equivalent of a level one national vocational qualification. "For most of them," Bannister says, "it's their first experience of work. Why work if you can just go out and rob? Having to get out of bed in the morning and turn up for work, that's new for a lot of them."

Usually, they just need new tyres or inner tubes, the brakes need work and the whole lot needs cleaning up. We've got the tools and the manpower and there's only a small percentage we have to throw away."

But the supply needs to increase. To help more young offenders, meet demand for their output, the scheme needs more bikes. For John, it may be too late. But for Tony, and others like him, it may come just in time.

In touch with the outside

The Norwich scheme is one of 72 projects run by the Inside Out Trust, a charity set up in 1993 to meet the dual aims of providing meaningful work for prison inmates and products for good causes at home and overseas.

More than 700 prisoners and young offenders now work on projects including translating Braille books for blind people, repairing sewing machines and refurbishing toys and play equipment. In 1996, the charity won a Guardian Jerwood award for excellence.

At Norwich, the charity supplies everything except the project manager's wages, which are met by the prison service. Margaret Carey, Inside Out's founding director, says the scheme is typical of the way the charity is now seeking to develop projects that give the workers a basic qualification to take with them when they return to the outside world.

"It's an add-on, if you like, so that you have the charity work through which the prisoners feel part of the community, but they get a certificate as well. When they come out, they may be able to get an engineering job, say, on the basis that they have already done some training."

Many of the projects, like Norwich, are small. But the charity has recently won funding from the Northern Rock Foundation, enabling it to develop a workshop that will ultimately employ more than 60 prisoners at Frankland jail in Durham. The charity has also benefited from the national lottery.

Carey says Inside Out's approach is spreading. "We may be working with only 1% of the prison population but people are looking at copying the ideas, which is marvellous. We are acting as catalyst for change."

 The Inside Out Trust can be contacted on 01273-833050.
fields.bodyText: The lad wheeling a Raleigh Chopper across the workroom floor has everything to please your granny. John is well spoken, smiles, talks intelligently and, until lately, had a good job with BP. The only trouble with John is that he used to set fire to things. He's inside for arson, reckless driving and heavy-handed assault. John expects six years when he returns to court for sentencing. The bikes along one wall, the racks of tools and the heavy-duty mechanics' frames could be the back of some big bike shop. But this is the youth jail - the young offenders' institution alongside the Porridge-like pile of Norwich prison. The lads make themselves coffee and call the boss by his first name. Some, admittedly, will get there sooner than others - John reckons on serving four of his anticipated six years. webTitle: Time to join the real world

fields.headline: Time to join the real world
fields.trailText: Laurie Taylor
fields.body:
Nowadays, I routinely encounter former social science colleagues who appear to have abandoned their normal intellectual discourse on public issues in favour of an extended monologue about the difficulties they are having meeting research deadlines. One can understand such anxieties. My friends know only too well that their failure to produce the requisite number of articles in time will have serious financial implications for their department and might also mean their own demotion to a teaching only function.

But though the results of this pressure are evident in the dramatic rise in the number of published research articles, as well as in the appearance of more and more journals to accommodate this increased output, there are now questions being asked about the relevance of much of this research.

Only two months ago, Anthony Giddens argued in an LSE lecture that universities no longer had the type of monopoly on the production of social scientific knowledge that they enjoyed a generation ago. They were being replaced by think tanks that were not only quicker on their feet but also much more adept at getting their ideas represented in the media.

A more ideological attack upon academic research has now been mounted by Greg Philo, research director of the Glasgow University Media Group. In a book called Market Killing, to be published this autumn, Philo and co-author David Miller condemn a great deal of contemporary social science research for its failure to engage with the real world. Academics have become "lost in language games in which 'the real' is just another discourse". Indeed, so fascinated have some social scientists become with the relativistic and self-referential vacuities of post-modernism they completely ignore any reference to human agency, to the role citizens might play in changing the world in which they find themselves.

This self-insulation is compounded by the readiness of academics to retreat into private languages, to take refuge in an obscurity that "secures the status of the author" and, in some cases, disguises the "slightness of their contribution to public debate".

In these circumstances we can only be grateful that there are some new heroes on the block. The practical result of this academic "abdication of responsibility", conclude Philo and Miller, is that the hard work of uncovering the truth about such matters as political corruption, state secrecy and surveillance, censorship and news reporting, and the growth of media empires, has been left to journalists.

 Laurie Taylor discusses journalism and social science with Greg Philo and Jon Snow, of Channel 4 News, on Radio 4's Thinking Allowed at 4pm today.

fields.headline: The vacancy vicious circle
fields.standfirst: Occupational therapy crisis threatens rehabilitation plans
fields.trailText: Occupational therapy crisis threatens rehabilitation plans
fields.body:
One of the main findings of the government's recent public consultation on the NHS is that people want more doctors and nurses. Quite the worst thing ministers could do would be to take that too literally and fail to increase numbers of other, arguably even more crucial workers - such as occupational therapists (OTs).

As the audit commission's study of rehabilitation care suggested a fortnight ago, the availability of adequate numbers of therapists of all kinds will be crucial to plans to free up more hospital beds. And as the commission found, there are simply too few such specialists. "The extent to which a culture of independence can be achieved is likely to be seriously impeded by the lack of appropriately trained staff," the study report found.

One trust surveyed by the commission had an OT vacancy rate of more than 80% at senior grade 2 level. Kay East, who chairs the council of the College of Occupational Therapists, says: "We are facing an acute recruitment and retention crisis. Yet the focus of the NHS careers strategy has been on expanding the numbers of doctors and nurses."

There are almost 21,000 OTs, employed by either the NHS or social services. They have a critical role in enabling elderly hospital patients to return home, as they assess what is needed to help them cope.

According to the college, there is an overall shortfall of 20% in working OTs. This meant that patients who might otherwise be ready to go home remain in hospital while awaiting assessment, their beds unavailable for other patients.

Alice Mackenzie, head of OT in elderly services for the Brent, Kensington, Chelsea and Westminster Mental Health trust, west London, reckons the trust is carrying a vacancy rate of about 20%. "We try to get locum staff, but often they just do priority work and it's very difficult to develop any kind of service," she says. "It then becomes a vicious circle: if you cannot develop a service, how do you attract people to come and work in it?"

Lower priority work, increasingly left undone, would be running a therapeutic group or working one-to-one with an elderly person to prepare them for entering a care home.

"That kind of thing enhances people's quality of life," says Mackenzie. "But rehabilitation doesn't happen overnight. There is a whole process of engaging the person that requires time, staff and resources to do it."

The staffing crisis is undoubtedly worse in the inner cities. But it is far from plain sailing in the shires. Sylvia Cliffe, OT services manager for the King's Lynn and Wisbech hospitals trust in Norfolk, says she is "more or less fully recruited". The problem is, her establishment of 26 qualified staff and 15 support workers struggle to meet demand for all adult and children's services.

"What you have are staff under constant pressure - and that's a common picture across the country," says Cliffe, who chairs the college's external affairs committee.

As well as what Cliffe calls "unrealistic" establishment figures, she feels pay is inadequate to attract people into the profession - and keep them in it. Most therapists earn £17,000-£24,000 a year. Last year, numbers seeking entry to undergraduate OT courses slumped 30% before late applications were counted, and 18% after. One university started the course with 30 unfilled places.

Cliffe finds it extremely difficult to tempt senior staff to Norfolk. "I tried to recruit a deputy to myself last year and I advertised three times," she says. "I didn't get a single response."

The hope is that the audit commission's study will prove a spur to action on such problems. As the study report concluded, "if independence is to be promoted fully, workforce planning to make good the shortfalls will need to begin urgently".

fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.trailText: A problem shared...
fields.body:
A problem shared...

Your article on the audit commission's study on the care of older people and fragmented rehabilitation services (Home truths, June 21) is no shock to us healthcare workers.

One of the causes is the continued existence of traditional, professional demarcation boundaries. The baffled service user is confused by a service with many different professionals doing, as far as the user is concerned, very similar jobs but not delivering a high quality, seamless service that they expect and deserve.

Physiotherapy and occupational therapy students are currently educated at undergraduate level in universities, with shared modules such as anatomy, physiology and behavioural sciences. The model of shared learning is increasing. But is that enough? We propose one step further - that a full mapping exercise of skill sharing, commonalities and differences is undertaken with a view to ultimate merging of the two professions into one role of rehabilitation therapist who is truly responsive to the needs of the user in the changing NHS.
Pennie Roberts
 Principal lecturer
Sue Smith
Senior lecturer in physiotherapy
Leeds Metropolitan University
Simon Balmer
Consultant in public health medicine
Tees health authority

Private grief

Jane Feinmann, in her article on schizophrenia (It's good to talk, June 28), asks why people suffering it do not get cognitive therapy. I ask the same question about my son who suffers from depression. We are told how good it is, and that it is available under the NHS, but when it comes to the point it is not available.

The problem is presumably a shortage of therapists. There seem to be plenty of private sector therapists, charging high fees. There is obviously a need to train many more and for the NHS to pay realistically. I hope the charities in this field are pressing the government on this.
Frances Wilde
Nantyperchyll
Gwernogle
Carmarthen

At last! An acknowledgement that for many people "drugs don't work on their own", even in cases of severe mental illness. The Mental Health Foundation's "strategies for living" programme has worked for three years on discovering just what does really work for those experiencing mental health problems. While pharmacological approaches are important, our research reported that a range of other strategies - talking to people, accepting relationships, support groups, alternative therapies, economic independence - were highly significant in people's self-management.

Unfortunately, funding dictates that at present the weight of evidence is on the side of the pharmaceutical companies. Only a fraction of these total resources have been available to evaluate alternative non-drug-based therapies.
Ruth Lesirge
Director
Mental Health Foundation

Jane Feinmann deserves credit for remarkable creativity. Not only does she manage to smuggle in the old family tensions between psychiatrists and psychologists, but even implicates the charismatic RD Laing in the plot. Good writing, but a seriously misleading piece.

There is not conflict between psychiatrists and psychologists currently about the value of family psychological interventions in schizophrenia. A quick look at the history of these approaches reveals psychiatrists in the vanguard of their development and promotion. More important, a careful examination of the impressive results from these studies suggests that reduction in family tensions reduces breakdowns in significant measure because the treatment helps the patient comply with the medication regime. I know of no study that has shown improved outcome in schizophrenia with CBT and simultaneously stopping the medicines. On the other hand, the increased rate of breakdown when patients stop their drugs prematurely is well documented.

It is not simply a case of either/or, but of working together that gets good results. In my own team, as in many others, nurses have been trained in these techniques and regularly use them in conjunction with encouraging patients to continue with their medicines.
Tom Burns
Professor of community psychiatry
St George's hospital medical school
London

Jobs worth doing

People with a learning disability are denied jobs through fear, ignorance and a belief that they have nothing to offer the competitive market place. However, Mencap's employment service, Pathway, again and again successfully matches employers and employees in jobs across the employment spectrum (letters, June 28).

In reaching businesses, we would be naive to ignore the reality of productivity and profit. Yet the effective contribution made by employees with a learning disability has until now been largely ignored. It is important to write and talk about employment issues, but we must also do something about it.
David Congdon
Director of public affairs
Mencap

Serious affront

I realise that I'm an incorrigibly frivolous person, but I can't be the only one who viewed the new front page with dismay. I can't believe that fewer ridiculous things are happening around the country, or that even the most serious minded people really want to be serious all the time.
Robin Saxby
Wrexham

Society's front page was my weekly treat. I almost always saved it because our children (in their 30s) were equally hooked. Now on page 12, small, mingy and hard to read, it is not worth bothering with. You have so many arresting, serious articles throughout your paper, so please restore it to its pride of place.
Annabel Greaves
Chichester

 Write to Guardian Society, 119 Farringdon Road, London, EC1R 3ER; or fax 020-7713 4154 or email society@theguardian.com Please supply your full address. Letters may be edited

fields.headline: Protect and survive
fields.standfirst: How the abuse of vulnerable adults can be stemmed
fields.trailText: How the abuse of vulnerable adults can be stemmed
fields.body:
Reports on abuse of vulnerable adults invariably, and depressingly, conclude that little is done about it. But a new study shows that a concerted approach by police and social services can make a positive impact.

The research was conducted into a joint vulnerable adults policy in Southwark, south London. When the policy was agreed, in 1995, it was said to be the only one of its kind.

Researchers interviewed police and social care staff involved in 44 cases of abuse during an eight-month period in 1998. Half the cases concerned physical abuse and another quarter sexual abuse, all of which involved victims with a learning disability. Financial abuse was sole or part factor in a fifth of cases.

The study team - Alan Rushton, senior lecturer in social work at the Institute of Psychiatry, south London, Debbie Mayes, research worker at the institute, and Kay Beaumont, team manager with Southwark social services - found that almost two-thirds of the cases had come to light through concerns raised by care staff. One in four of the alleged abusers was also staff, but 44% were relatives of the victim.

Thirty of the total 44 cases were referred to police, yet these included fewer than half of the 16 cases in residential care. The study team says this "raises questions about the complexity involved in referring other staff members to the police, and the problems for social services in intervening in residential care homes they do not manage".

Criminal investigations were begun in only eight cases and in just two did the victims agree to go to court. In half the cases referred to police, officers determined that the victim lacked capacity to pursue the matter.

More encouragingly, though, the researchers found, six months after their initial interviews, that none of the victims had suffered further abuse of the same severity.

The Southwark approach is similar to the framework recommended in No Secrets, the government's recent guidance on tackling abuse of vulnerable adults. While cautious of overstating their findings, the researchers say it is "likely that the notification process led to activity to reduce the risk of further abuse".

 Full details of the study are published in the latest issue of the Journal of Adult Protection

Half the cases concerned physical abuse and another quarter sexual abuse, all of which involved victims with a learning disability. Financial abuse was sole or part factor in a fifth of cases. The study team - Alan Rushton, senior lecturer in social work at the Institute of Psychiatry, south London, Debbie Mayes, research worker at the institute, and Kay Beaumont, team manager with Southwark social services - found that almost two-thirds of the cases had come to light through concerns raised by care staff. One in four of the alleged abusers was also staff, but 44% were relatives of the victim. Thirty of the total 44 cases were referred to police, yet these included fewer than half of the 16 cases in residential care. The study team says this "raises questions about the complexity involved in referring other staff members to the police, and the problems for social services in intervening in residential care homes they do not manage". Criminal investigations were begun in only eight cases and in just two did the victims agree to go to court. In half the cases referred to police, officers determined that the victim lacked capacity to pursue the matter. More encouragingly, though, the researchers found, six months after their initial interviews, that none of the victims had suffered further abuse of the same severity. The Southwark approach is similar to the framework recommended in No Secrets, the government's recent guidance on tackling abuse of vulnerable adults. While cautious of overstating their findings, the researchers say it is "likely that the notification process led to activity to reduce the risk of further abuse".  Full details of the study are published in the latest issue of the Journal of Adult Protection

fields.headline: The culling fields
fields.standfirst: Government mired in row over badgers and bovine TB
fields.trailText: Government mired in row over badgers and bovine TB
fields.body:
Government ministers are poised to allow the slaughter of thousands more badgers, adding to a pile of 20,000 corpses already being collected in the infamous "Krebs experiment".

Ministry of Agriculture operatives are currently swarming all over Cornwall, Devon, Gloucestershire and Wiltshire, eradicating badgers in the experiment to prove they give bovine tuberculosis (bTB) to cattle. But the Secretary of State for Agriculture, Nick Brown, has spent months mired in farmyard manure and wellies, in an effort to show he listens to farmers. Although the experiment is costing £34m, he now seems poised to condemn badgers before the evidence is available, desperate to end farmers' incessant whining.

The problem is that proof of badger involvement will not be available until 2004 at the earliest. And the man gathering the evidence - Prof John Bourne - says it could go either way. "We don't know if culling badgers makes things better," he admits. "It could make things a sight worse." It's thought that if badgers are a source of bTB, culling leaves lonely survivors, which take the disease further afield.

But with bTB increasing in cattle at a rate of knots, the National Farmers' Union must be seen to be doing something. It's concocted a proposal for more badgers to be killed wherever badgers can easily be blamed for bTB break-outs.

The plan has been opposed by conservation and welfare organisations, and by Bourne, in the TB Forum, which was set up to look at short-term solutions to the disease, focusing on cattle management. But ministry civil servants have edited the opposition out of the minutes and left the badger proposals off the forum's website, so as not to alarm the public.

Instead, a sub-group has discussed the proposals in secret. Officials deny that Brown supports the plan, but in June he said he would consider further culling if the TB Forum asked him to. Sources at Westminster indicate that he is happy to proceed, as is Baroness Hayman, his Lords counterpart.

A secret NFU memo, seen by the Guardian, shows that next week at the TB Forum meeting, the NFU plans to force a vote on the issue. The Forum has been set up with a majority of pro-cull organisations, so a majority is inevitable if a vote takes place. Culling could then get formal approval while the fox hunting bill dominates Parliament, reducing unwelcome media attention. The NFU is also planning an autumn press campaign, designed to convince people that they can catch bTB from badgers.

"There's still no evidence that badgers even transmit bTB to cattle. They certainly don't to people," said Dr Elaine King from the National Federation of Badger Groups. "Ministers say they have no intention of approving 'widespread badger culling', while behind the scenes their officials appear to be engineering a fait accomplis to deliver just that."

Ironically, the proposals have thrown the NFBG and Bourne into an unlikely alliance. Bourne proposed the TB Forum in the first place, to concentrate on cattle issues, and it now threatens to backfire. "Badgers are not in its remit," he insists.

fields.headline: Spinning out of control
fields.standfirst: Is the government ducking the lessons of Waterhouse?
fields.trailText: Is the government ducking the lessons of Waterhouse?
fields.body:
When the government last week announced its formal response to the Waterhouse inquiry into abuse in north Wales children's homes, the spin was that its recommendations were, of course, being accepted without quibble. But were they?

John Hutton, social care minister, said in a press statement that, of the 63 general recommendations, "we agree with the spirit of every one". This is restated in the foreward to the response document, Learning the Lessons, with the added rider: "In a few cases, we propose taking a different route to achieve a similar end."

One of the more wide-ranging recommendations of the inquiry was a call for "a nationwide review of the needs and costs of children's services, based on local authorities' development plans and leading to a compre hensive and costed strategy for those services, including any necessary education and health elements".

Deep in the response document, ministers say: "The government does not believe that a national review is necessary.

Robust arrangements for assessing the delivery of services across five performance domains - national priorities and strategic objectives, cost and efficiency, effectiveness of service delivery and outcomes, quality of services for users and carers, and fair access - are already in place both nationally and locally."

Understandably, the Association of Directors of Social Services (ADSS) has told the media that the recommendation has been "rejected". But the Department of Health is adamant that it has not. According to a spokeswoman, "both the planning and cost of children's services have been built into Quality Protects".

Quality Protects (QP) is the initiative, worth £375m over three years, to improve social services for children in need. It has been broadly welcomed by those in the field, but there will be puzzlement that it can be equated with the kind of review proposed by Waterhouse. ADSS president, Jo Williams says diplomatically: "If that's what they believe, that's what they believe."

While QP is due to end in March 2002, all eyes are on the forthcoming comprehensive spending review to see if it will be extended. Williams says: "Most local authorities are already taking a prudent look at where we are going to make the savings if we don't get it."

 Learning the Lessons is available from the Stationery Office at £9.20

fields.headline: Over exposure
fields.standfirst: In 1998, the Jarawa tribe of India's Andaman Islands shrugged off over 1,000 years of hostility to outsiders and began coming out of their forest. No one knows why.  Sophie Grig  reports
fields.trailText: In 1998, the Jarawa tribe of India's Andaman Islands shrugged off over 1,000 years of hostility to outsiders and began coming out of their forest. No one knows why. Sophie Grig reports
fields.body:
Nobody even knows how many Jarawa there are. Estimates range from 200-700, but it is impossible to tell. They speak no other language and no one speaks theirs. No one knows where they came from, although DNA studies suggest that their nearest relatives may be the T'wa, or "bushmen", of southern Africa.

We do know from examination of abandoned camps that they hunt game such as wild pig and monitor lizard, fish with bow and arrow, and gather seeds, berries and honey. We know that they are nomadic, living in bands of 40-50 people, that they live in large communal houses or, when hunting, in small family huts.

We also know that, until recently, they have resisted contact with the outside world - despite Indian settlers camping on their doorstep. They also seem to have a lively sense of humour and enjoy shocking the Indian government officials on their now-monthly contact missions by urinating on their feet and squirting breast milk at them, while falling about laughing.

In 1998, they suddenly began to come out of the rainforest reserve along the western side of two of the main Andaman Islands. There are theories about why they decided to emerge: that a boy who was treated in hospital in 1996 told others that out siders were friendly; or that they lack enough food - although their obvious good health contradicts this. Some newspapers even suggest they have been lured out by a desire to eat curry! None of the arguments is convincing.

When the Jarawa came out they were at first just looking around. Sometimes they stopped cars and buses, and some even got on to the buses and the ferries that take vehicles across the creeks between the islands. They appeared to be as fascinated by the settlers as the settlers were by them.

After the first few months, the adults remained in the reserve, and now it is mostly the kids and youths that come out. They sometimes stop cars on the roads and ask for food, or just hang around the shops at the jetties. The bulk of the population, including the men who do the hunting, still spend their time in the forest.

So far there have been no missionaries allowed into the area. One group from the north-east of India applied to go into the Jarawa area, but has been refused permission by the Indian administration.

Earliest reports of the Andamanese tribes come from Marco Polo. He described them as having "heads like that of the dog, with teeth and eyes likewise". In 1857, when the British arrived, they tried to befriend the islands' tribes. They succeeded with the Great Andamanese but not with the Jarawa - which is undoubtedly the reason why they are still alive and living on their own land today.

But now the Indian government is intending to "resettle them". The consensus among island settlers and government employees is that the tribe is "primitive", and that it should be "civilised". By this it is meant that the members should become agriculturalists and wear clothes. The plan is for their "gradual integration" into the mainstream, and a court case brought by a local lawyer is forcing the issue.

In May 1999, the lawyer filed a case seeking to have the Jarawa settled. She stated: "This is high time to make them acquainted with modern civilisation." She has no specialist knowledge or experience: she saw Jarawa from a passing vehicle and felt that something should be done. The court convened an expert committee to examine the issue, a process which is still ongoing. The future of the Jarawa now rests with this committee.

Anthropologists are convinced that settlement would be disastrous. Evidence from around the world is that when nomadic peoples are settled, disease and extinction usually follow. Isolated tribal peoples have no immunity against the diseases, such as influenza and measles, that thrive in high density populations. It is not unusual for 50% or more of a population to die soon after settlement.

In Brazil, half of the 180 Matis tribe died after they were contacted, and of the 600 Panará contacted in 1972, only 69 survive today. After epidemics - often killing the old and very young - severe depression, a loss of confidence in their way of life, alcohol abuse, dependency and suicide often follow.

Witness the fate of the 5,000 strong Great Andamanese tribes who were contacted and settled by the British after 1857. Massive epidemics followed, along with addictions and dependency. Only 28 people now remain in government "breeding centres", where births are reported in the same way as the births of pandas in zoos.

Following a campaign by Survival, a petition opposing settlement was handed to the Indian government last week. It was signed by 46,500 people from 61 different countries. Probably as a result, the government now claims it never had any intention to settle the Jarawa.

No one has been able to consult the Jarawa about what they want because no one speaks their language. There are two government linguists trying to learn their language, but this is a very slow process.

It is not simply because the Jarawa are of enormous interest to anthropology that they should be allowed to continue living as they choose. It is not because they have a lot to teach us which would otherwise be lost. And it is not because they may provide a vital clues to prehistoric human migration. The reason that we should all be involved in stopping any attempt to forcibly settle or assimilate the Jarawa is that it is just plain wrong to take this people's land from them.

I believe that forcibly settling the Jarawa is tantamount to genocide. It would lead to them being wiped out. What right has any government, however well meaning, to impose its judgment of what is "civilised"? The Jarawa's future is their own, and they should be the ones to decide how they spend it.

 Sophie Grig works for Survival. For further information on the Jarawa project, contact: Survival, 11-15 Emerald Street, London, WC1N 3QL; telephone: 020-7242 1441; website: www.survival-international.org

fields.headline: Keeping the hill alive
fields.standfirst: Why sheep can no longer safely graze on Long Mynd
fields.trailText: Why sheep can no longer safely graze on Long Mynd
fields.body:
Brian Jones has been shearing sheep all day in pens high on top of the Long Mynd. He is one of the 16 commoners who are to be paid £2m over 10 years for reducing the number of sheep they graze on the hill. The new Environmentally Sensitive Area (ESA) scheme is the biggest so far announced.

The Long Mynd is a hazy, indeterminate place between the hills of south Shropshire and the Welsh border. The 16-mile ridge rises to 1,700 feet with its folds and plateaux, valleys and hollows and has the wild beauty of heather moorland.

Because of species which only occur much further south, the Long Mynd has been designated by the government as heathland. This gives it greater prestige in the conservation stakes and contributes to the way it has been revalued.

Some 5,500 acres of the Long Mynd is managed by the National Trust as a nature reserve, which has suffered over the years from overgrazing. Ben Shipston, of the trust, says: "With too many sheep we are losing natural regeneration of heather and bilberry; this affects rare insects and birds. If we removed all the sheep the hill would scrub over and we would lose the heathland species. It's a matter of maintaining a balance between too many and too few sheep."

From where Brian Jones is standing, the "balance" is weighted towards the interests of a closed shop of outsiders. For him, the hill is work and home, livelihood and responsibility. Jones's commoners' rights have been in his family for three or four generations. His 20 Long Mynd ponies are the last to graze here - a tradition probably as old as the remains of Iron Age settlements dotted about the hills. When it came to a choice between losing the ponies or reducing the sheep, the sheep that had to go.

Jones, like other commoners, accepted the compensation because of the crisis in hill farming. "There used to be a lot more sheep and hundreds of ponies in the past," he says. "We used to burn 40-50 acres of heather at a time, which hasn't been done for 30 years. There was plenty of wildlife then."

Way below Jones's shearing pens, in the historic beauty spot of the Carding Mill valley, groups of schoolchildren chase stone-fly nymphs in the stream. Day trippers peer through binoculars, take photographs of lambs or picnic in the heather, where incredible green tiger beetles stalk, wheatears flash their white backsides and grey wagtails bob on stream rocks. At the head of the valley, the Lightspout waterfall, a 20-foot high mossy slit, pours with the wild song of the western hills.

This is a song way beyond the plethora of the hill's official listings as an area of outstanding natural beauty, site of special scientific interest and environmentally sensitive area. It is a song beyond our notions of natural beauty and concern for biological diversity. For all the conservation money and the designations, it will not be captured by human interest.

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: Rules of thumb | Short shrift | Khor blimey
fields.body:
Rules of thumb
The World Bank, always keen that developing countries play by its tight rules, seems happy to sidestep them itself. In a Kafkaesque move, president James Wolfensohn has just declared that "critics" are pushing the bank towards a "literal and mechanistic application of the (bank's) operating principles that was never intended when they were written". Which begs the question: why bother with rules at all? Wolfensohn's comments came in a briefing to his board of directors, and appears to be an attempt to shoot the messenger of unwelcome tidings. They refer to last week's ruling by an independent panel that a proposed $40m scheme to resettle 58,000 Chinese in traditional Tibetan herder territory broke seven of the bank's 10 operating principles. So what does the Dalai Lama - who Wolfensohn says he admires - think of the plan? By chance he was in Washington and said it was "not the right time" for the loan and would "cause even more problems". Mr Wolfensohn then fled the capital.

Short shrift
Has Clare Short lost it? Certainly, the international development secretary and Britain's representative on the World Bank board seems to be taking an ever stronger line against anyone who begs to differ with her. Last week she gave a stormy interview to the Ecologist magazine, in which she dismissed criticisms of the Tibet resettlement project as "fashionable", lashed out at people criticising controversial oil developments in Chad and Cameroon, and said criticisms of the bank's policy of funding fossil fuel developments at the expense of renewables was "a bundle of prejudice". As reported elsewhere in this paper yesterday, some of these comments were swiftly erased from the official transcription of the interview. Clearly, she needs protection from herself.

Khor blimey
In April, Short slammed Oxfam for seeking a global education plan, and now she's specifically attacking Martin Khor, the leader of Third World Network, who she said was "wrong" for even suggesting that the World Bank might be undermining development in poor countries. Khor, she said, was not "representative" - which is daft, considering he is one of the most respected development thinkers in the world and TWN is a leading southern organisation, with offices in more than a dozen countries. Her outburst was sensibly erased, too.

Khor, she said, was not "representative" - which is daft, considering he is one of the most respected development thinkers in the world and TWN is a leading southern organisation, with offices in more than a dozen countries. Her outburst was sensibly erased, too.

fields.headline: Kosovo's key figures
fields.standfirst: Steve Brown on the vital role for accountants in restoring areas torn by conflict
fields.trailText: Steve Brown on the vital role for accountants in restoring areas torn by conflict
fields.body:
It is over a year now since the war in Kosovo came to an end. But for the 1m Kosovars forced to flee their homes during the conflict, the struggle continues. For now that the fighting is over they must attempt to rebuild their lives and their homes, many of which were destroyed and torched by Serb paramilitaries.

With the region now under intensive international care, Christian Aid is just one of an estimated 300 international agencies at work. The agency, based in the Rahovec municipality in the south-west of the province, became fully operational in January, since when it has reconstructed almost 350 homes for vulnerable families and helped reopen a local school in the village of Brestovic.

The most recent recruit to Christian Aid's Kosovo team is Tony Richings. He is not an engineer, a sanitation expert or a health care professional. Confounding most people's preconception of humanitarian relief workers, Richings is an accountant. And his presence in Kosovo is evidence of the growing recognition that proper financial management is a vital part of humanitarian relief.

"Sound financial control and administration are key components of successful operations," says Sara Packwood, an emergency programme manager for Christian Aid, currently based in Kosovo. "I've worked in three different agencies in three very different emergency relief contexts and in each one, qualified accountants were essential for a smooth-running operation."

Christian Aid is not alone in mobilising accountants for relief operations. Oxfam also recognises the importance of ensuring financial control is maintained in the field. "In the heat of a conflict, or with the fast arrival of refugees, the urge is to save lives, to get water supplies working, to provide adequate healthcare, to make sure there are enough latrines," says Nick Roseveare, one of Oxfam's humanitarian co-ordinators.

"It is not to make sure that the payment vouchers are sequentially numbered and that the cash adds up. But you can't do one without the other. If you don't look after the cash, things can go very wrong."

In fact financial skills - such as looking after income and systems to minimise the risk of fraud, paying staff and suppliers, devising ways of transferring money safely in the field and ensuring procurement is cost effective - are now widely recognised as essential among all humanitarian relief organisations. It is part of a growing push towards professionalism, which in recent years has seen voluntary codes adopted for the support that should be in place for relief workers and on the quality standards that relief operations should work to.

But recognising the need for financial management in the field is one thing. Finding suitably qualified or experienced people to go is another matter altogether. Given the competition for staff among the agencies and the tendency for relief operations to be mounted at extremely short notice, getting the right person with the right financial skills can be a headache. Enter a new organisation, called Mango (Management Accounting for Non Governmental Organisations).

Formed in November last year by experienced relief and developmental workers, Mango has been set up primarily to provide a reliable source of appropriate financial management staff to work in the field. Richings is the organisation's first placement.

According to Mango director Alex Jacobs: "Non-governmental organisations (NGOs) are driving the need for more professionalism and accountability in the way they run projects." Sound financial management can ensure agencies get the most out of limited funds. But increasingly agencies are accepting that they also have a responsibility to report back to their donors about use of funds. In fact, proper accounting and reporting can make a difference in securing funding. Several donor bodies, including the British government, the European Commission and the United Nations, have tightened funding rules.

"Good intentions are not enough any more," says Jacobs. "People want outcomes. And donors have realised that some people are better at run ning projects than others. Efficiency is important, saving two lives is better than saving one."

Having spent its first six months working with all the major agencies to understand their needs and secure their support, Oxford-based Mango is now busy compiling a register of financial staff who can make themselves available for placements ranging from one to 12 months. All staff on the register have been pre-selected and interviewed for their suitability for relief and development work. If agencies require specific skills, they can be matched with the competencies of staff on the register. And unlike some "voluntary" work, placed staff can expect to be paid a reasonable salary.

It's such a simple idea, it is not surprising that it has been done before. In fact the Mango concept is based on the well-established RedR service which helps agencies to recruit engineers for disaster relief operations.

Like RedR, Mango's creation, which has been supported by accountancy body Cima, has been warmly welcomed by all the leading agencies. With demand so high for qualified professionals of all types to help with relief work, a pool of appropriate finance staff is a major time saver.

"Mango makes our job easier," says Tim Boyes Watson, head of finance at Christian Aid. "The biggest problem in an emergency is the need to move fast and normal recruitment takes too long." Huge amounts of money can be spent in the first few weeks of an operation. "We want financial control from the word go and all donors want to know how their money has been spent."

Richings, a 58-year-old Australian citizen who discovered Mango via the internet, is now into his third week as Christian Aid's financial controller in Kosovo, responsible for accounting, procurement and warehousing. He is clear about his role. "I see the need for financial control as imperative to ensuring that the monies that have been donated are spent in an effective way and are accounted for as transparently and effectively as possible," he says.

Already he recognises the work is challenging and at times frustrating and upsetting. On a journey back from Kosovo's capital Pristina last week, he says he saw "ample evidence of destruction on a very personal scale... fresh graves... the scars of bullets of every calibre". But with "no two days the same", he says the work is ultimately satisfying.

It is a far cry from most people's idea of accountants at work. But if Mango continues to flourish, many more could be headed the same way.

 For further information about Mango, contact Alex Jacobs on 01865 433885 or via the website: www.mango.org.uk

Birmingham Evening Mail, 14.6.00 (David Spilsbury, Birmingham) .

Royal blue A suspect package which prompted a major security alert on a Royal Navy warship in Portsmouth turned out to be a pile of pornographic magazines. News North West, 15.6.00 (John Booth, Stockport).

fields.headline: Cut to the bone
fields.standfirst: When it now costs less per day to care for an elderly person than it does to stay in bed and breakfast, are government plans to raise standards sufficient without extra funding?  Kendra Inman  reports
fields.trailText: When it now costs less per day to care for an elderly person than it does to stay in bed and breakfast, are government plans to raise standards sufficient without extra funding? Kendra Inman reports.
fields.body:
Health secretary Alan Milburn says he wants to raise standards in social care and minimise variations in provision across the country. But the plan will fail, warns leading care provider Chai Patel, without a lot more money.

"We're at a stage where we pay less money per day for the [residential] care of elderly people than it costs to stay in a Travelodge," says Patel, the chief executive of Westminster Health Care. "Providers are expected to give what can be 24-hour nursing care and full board. But it is just not do-able for £50 per night."

As the government prepares to publish a green paper containing fresh plans to ratchet up the quality of social services, leading figures in social care will gather in London on July 17 to debate the quality agenda. The aim of the conference, organised jointly by the Guardian and the National Institute for Social Work (NISW), is to get a variety of perspectives on the issue.

John Hutton, the social care minister, will be among those speaking at the event and delegates will be listening closely to how the government expects its raft of initiatives - such as best value, performance assessment frameworks, joint reviews and the new regulatory framework - to gel. Even if they do, will improved performance necessarily result?

Not without greater investment, says Patel, who will speak at the conference. As a provider, he might be expected to complain about local authorities putting the screws on costs, but he is not the only one who thinks that cost cutting has gone too far.

Les Bright, deputy chief executive of Counsel and Care, a charity which works with older people in residential and nursing homes, echoes his concerns. "Local authorities are driving down prices year in and year out," he says. "In some cases, they are paying as little as you or I would to stay in a bed and breakfast for the night."

Patel, emerging as a key player in development of health and social care modernisation, says his sector absorbed "enormous" costs in implementing measures such as the working time directive and the minimum wage. "It costs money to train staff well and give them a sense of vocation about the work," he says. "Everyone aspires to good standards; a range of activities, single rooms and en suite bathrooms - it's not unreasonable to expect those things. There are cowboys everywhere, but on the whole people care."

Bright says that the squeeze on fees has a direct impact on residents' quality of life. Homeowners under pressure will cut back on decorating from once every two or three years to once every five. The number of leisure activities on offer for residents is also likely to be reduced.

In its response to the government's consultation document on national standards for residential and nursing home care, issued at the end of last year, Counsel and Care has argued that the push to raise standards is an opportunity to make local authority purchasers "comply with national standards of funding".

John Ransford, head of social affairs at the Local Government Association, rejects the idea that there is a need for a national "price list" setting out what local authorities should pay for services, regardless of local demand or supply. In effect, he suggests that local councils should be able to drive down the price where they can. But services should be planned in conjunction with the independent sector.

"It is time to sit down with contractors and say what the contract should look like, taking into account staff training, etc," Ransford says. A protocol and a good practice guide would be fine, but the price paid should be determined locally, he says.

Patel admits, somewhat ruefully, that local authorities have done a "fantastic" job driving prices down. "But if they want a long-term viable market," he says, "they need to look at what it costs to provide care".

Ransford counters that comparisons with hotel costs are meaningless. "What you need to look at is the level of service that is being provided for the money," he insists. What is important, he argues, is that commissioners and providers of care need to have an open relationship and understand each other's problems. But he admits that this sort of relationship is hard to nurture within the contract culture, "which often makes people go to the wall on determining the price".

Daphne Statham, director of the NISW, agrees that greater openness will improve the services on offer, although she accepts that a cultural change is needed before service users become as involved in care planning as they need to be.

Local authorities need to be up-front about what people have a right to expect, Statham says. "The complex nature of how we make judgments should be explicit. It is the least people can expect when the decisions are affecting the quality of their lives."

Staff should be able to explain why they arrive at a decision or judgment. "They should also be much clearer about when there are alternative decisions that could have been made, and about when they don't know what to do," Statham says. And everybody in social services needs to own the standards, whatever they are, and try to deliver them in a far more consistent way "regardless of where the service is coming from", she says.

Of course, openness can be hard to achieve in a climate where social care staff are publicly pilloried for mistakes. Statham believes, however, that the planned "social care institute of excellence" will herald a new era of transparency by promoting evidence-based practice.

Social services departments are currently undergoing some of the most intensive monitoring they have ever experienced, especially of services for elderly people, children and those with disabilities. But whether the government has gone far enough in its attempt to raise standards will become clearer as the remaining planks of the strategy are put into place.

Some of the questions about funding should be answered by the forthcoming comprehensive spending review. But it will be some time before the complete picture emerges. As Statham points out, however, service users are saying: "We can't wait, we need improvements now."

 For details of the Quality Agenda conference sponsored by Anchor Trust, Sheridan Systems and the British Association of Social Workers, call 020-7713 4961

webTitle: A hell of a tough job

fields.headline: A hell of a tough job
fields.standfirst: Max Caller, the new chief executive of Hackney
fields.trailText: Profile: Max Caller, the new chief executive of Hackney
fields.body:
For many, it was the job from hell. "I know the cesspits of London extremely well," smiles Max Caller. He's talking about the miles of sewers he had to endure as a young municipal engineer in the early 1970s, checking that the capital's problems were all flushed away. Not the most popular job, he admits - yet infinitely less hassle-free than his current position.

He knows this one is really the job from hell because it was advertised as just that. No matter that it offered a nice £40,000 salary hike to £150,000, as a final inducement for the faint-hearted. "It wasn't the money," he insists. "It was the challenge."

But this is Hackney. It's been labelled the country's ungovernable council, a nightmare authority with untold financial problems, a partly-privatised education service, damning inspections from Ofsted and the social services inspectorate, and this week an equally critical report from the district auditor alleging mismanagement and inadequate accounting on a large scale. Refuse collection is notoriously erratic and there's confusion in the housing service, which, at the last count, left over 20,000 with rent arrears and hundreds fearing eviction. And if all that wasn't bad enough, political leadership - how can one put it kindly? - has been tenuous because no party has had overall control in four years. Who would really want to be chief executive of this east London borough?

Step forward Caller. After a little persuasion, it seems, from the right people in local government, he finally moved into the hot seat three weeks ago and set about changing a culture of defeatism. For the wider town hall establishment, Hackney is seen as a test case for local government - through the newish Improvement and Development Agency and the Local Government Authority - to put its own house in order without government interference. So was his arm twisted?

"Not in the formal sense," he says, "but a number of people I respect said I should think about this and told me I was one of the few people who can do it, which is flattering."

Caller's rise to the top had been relentless. Starting working life as a civil engineer at the former Greater London Council in 1972, pounding those sewers, he was transferred to Thames Water two years later when (pre-privatised) water authorities were established.
