fields.headline: Blood on the pages
fields.standfirst: Britain's leading deaf charity riven by warring factions
fields.trailText: Britain's leading deaf charity riven by warring factions
fields.body:
Several thousand deaf people are expected to march in London on Saturday to promote awareness of British sign language (BSL) and call for its official recognition as the equivalent of a spoken tongue. The Federation of Deaf People, which is organising the march, says BSL is in more common use than Welsh, Cornish and Scottish Gaelic combined.

The federation has been set up by Doug Alker, former chief executive of the Royal National Institute for Deaf People (RNID), who this week also publishes a book setting out his version of the momentous events surrounding his departure from the charity in 1997.

At the time, the charity said he "wanted the freedom and time to tackle issues close to his heart". But Alker, whose severance deal included a two-year vow of silence on events, now says this was far from the truth. In a bitter and outspoken attack on the RNID leadership - in particular, chair David Livermore - he claims he was victim of a palace coup for moving too far and too fast towards a deaf people's agenda. The significance of this is that Alker was the first deaf chief executive of the RNID. His appointment in 1994 was hailed as a watershed in the world of disability charities. But, according to his account, he soon became mired in the long- running feud between "oralists" (those who believe deaf children should be exposed to conversation and discouraged from signing) and advocates, like himself, of BSL.

In the book, Really Not Interested in the Deaf?, Livermore is portrayed as sympathetic to the oralists. He is accused of manoeuvring to oust Alker and replace him with James Strachan, the current chief executive, who is also deaf but comes from a very different background to Alker.

Alker's departure in 1997 triggered outrage on the part of some deaf activists, who forced an extraordinary general meeting of the charity but failed to defeat the leadership. Many activists are said then to have drifted away from the organisation.

One of the saddest episodes in the saga, as the book recalls, was the involvement of police at the apparent instigation of the leadership. Officers visited a house being used as a mailing address by a self-styled "RNID action group", collecting support for the emergency meeting, and seized correspondence that was allegedly then handed over to the charity. Alker writes: "The RNID's involvement of the police against its own deaf members had a chilling effect."

Alker, 59, is now based in Lancashire, where he is working to attract young deaf people to the federation's rights agenda. The RNID says it is unable to comment on his book without seeing it, but points out that he worked for the charity for 10 years in all and that it shares his goal of official recognition of BSL.

 Really Not Interested in Deaf People? is obtainable at £16.95, plus £2 p&p, cheques payable to Doug Alker Associates, from PO Box 11, Darwen, Lancashire, B33 3GH

fields.headline: Tax breakdown
fields.standfirst: Public are ignorant about charity rules
fields.trailText: Public are ignorant about charity rules
fields.body:
Although we still await a promised campaign to promote the government's new tax incentives for charitable giving, public awareness of them is low. At this rate, chancellor Gordon Brown will struggle to hit his target of raising £1bn extra for charity by 2002.

According to the Future Foundation, which polls 1,050 adults every quarter on behalf of 19 leading charities, only 42% of people have heard anything about the chancellor's changes. Among those who have not donated to charity over the past three months, the figure is just 29%.

Equally worrying is that many people who have some awareness of the changes have no idea what they are. Of those who say they have heard about them, 62% cannot identify any single measure - and some of the 38% who think they can, have got it wrong.

The changes are, of course, quite technical. While they took effect in April, moreover, the relevant legislation is still wending its way through parliament. As a result, experts are even now discovering new aspects of the package.

Mazars Neville Russell, a specialist charity accountancy group, has just found a fresh angle for many conservation charities. Under the revised gift aid rules, any qualifying donation can now be increased 28% by tax relief other than in cases where the donor gets a significant benefit in return. Exceptions to this benefit exclusion, however, are in respect of right of admission to view a preserved building or conserved wildlife.

The inland revenue has confirmed Mazars' interpretation that this can be applied not only to membership fees, but also to single admission charges. Provided the individual gives details of name, address and how much is paid - and states a wish for the tax relief to be claimed - the 28% extra can be triggered.

This means that an eligible charity could get an additional £1.40 on a £5 admission ticket, or £9.30 more on a £33 family ticket. Andrew Burgess, who heads Mazars' charity practice, says: "We reckon that for a major charity, the potential is there to maybe increase their take by £500,000 a year - and that's a conservative estimate."

There is a further incentive, too, for higher rate taxpayers. Because the law awards tax relief on the gross value of a donation, people paying 40% tax should now be able to claim for the balance between 28% of a gift-aided admission ticket and 40% of the total sum of ticket price plus 28% relief. On that £33 family ticket, the saving would be a useful £7.62.

 Andrew Burgess can be contacted on 020-7220 3175 or email: andrew.burgess@mazars-nr.co.uk

webTitle: Chickens aren't funny for West End audiences

fields.headline: Chickens aren't funny for West End audiences
fields.trailText: Chicken Run audiences in the West End will be faced with a less-than-appetising nugget of information - an advertisement depicting the appalling conditions endured by a real battery bird
fields.body:
Chicken Run audiences in the West End will be faced with a less-than-appetising nugget of information - an advertisement depicting the appalling conditions endured by a real battery bird.

The £25,000 commercial, called Chicken Can't Run, aims to convert film-goers to vegetarianism, and will be screened before Aardman Animation's fun-filled plasticine caper at the UCI Cinema in London's Leicester Square.

The vegetarian society VIVA are behind the 20-second advertisement which is currently being filmed on a real-life battery farm. "We hope it will make audiences realise that an innocent nugget is not so innocent after all, but is about a life that's suffered terribly. The real chickens have a much worse time than the cartoon characters and do die," said director Juliet Gellately. "We hope it will nudge people into asking, 'Do they suffer? Do they feel pain?'"

The ad hopes to achieve similar results to the successful VIVA! pork commercial called Who Loves you Babe?, screened before talking pig movie Babe. Butchers saw a 10% drop in pork sales months after the film's release.

Irish farmers however have laughed off suggestions that the film will put children off eating poultry. A spokesman for the Irish Farmer's Association said, "We wouldn't envisage the film having an impact on kids' attitudes towards chicken products. Kids don't hate cats when they watch the Tom & Jerry cartoons. With the development of convenience food, it's also likely that kids think chicken comes in batter and wrapped in tinfoil."

The IFA's claims are in stark contrast to chicken farmers in Britain, who are worried that their business will be damaged by the film.

fields.headline: 5 July: In brief
fields.trailText: After consultation with the police, the British Board Of Film Classification has decided not to cut scenes from the latest Nic Cage actioner Gone in 60 Seconds which show Cage's character hotwiring cars. The censors had been concerned that Cage's light-fingered work in the film might amount to an, er, crash course in automobile thievery for impressionable young 'uns in the crowd.

After consultation with the police, the British Board Of Film Classification has decided not to cut scenes from the latest Nic Cage actioner Gone in 60 Seconds which show Cage's character hotwiring cars. The censors had been concerned that Cage's light-fingered work in the film might amount to an, er, crash course in automobile thievery for impressionable young 'uns in the crowd.

George Clooney fans can get that little bit closer to their hearthrob, courtesy of internet auction site Ebay. Bidding starts this week for the boat that Clooney used in The Perfect Storm, the true-life story of Atlantic fishermen caught in a battle against 'the perfect storm'.

Jim Carrey, famously snubbed twice by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, is fed up with waiting for an Oscar nomination. His performances in Man on the Moon and The Truman Show were reckoned to be Oscar material, but nominations were conspicuous by their absence. "They're bastards," said Carrey of the Academy. "Of course, I will probably get one eventually, probably when I'm in a wheelchair. I'll have to get somebody else to go up there and collect it for me, but that's okay too. It might be better that way."

fields.headline: Down Under by Bill Bryson
fields.standfirst:
Stephen Moss assesses the critical response to Bill Bryson's Down Under
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: Bill Bryson is, apparently, the most read author in Britain; his new book, Down Under (Doubleday, £16.99), is top of the hardback bestsellers list; it has just been read on Radio 4; the man can clearly do no wrong. But can he write? Many critics insist that the answer is no.
fields.body:
Bill Bryson is, apparently, the most read author in Britain; his new book, Down Under (Doubleday, £16.99), is top of the hardback bestsellers list; it has just been read on Radio 4; the man can clearly do no wrong. But can he write? Many critics insist that the answer is no.

"If there were an Olympic category for Expedient Book Writing, Bill Bryson would be World Champion," said Kathy Lette uncompromisingly in the Sunday Telegraph. "In Down Under, he's going for Gold in the 'Quick! Let's-Cash-In-By-Writing-a-Book-About-Australia-Just-In-Time-For The-Olympics!' event [these capital letters could become tiresome]. This book shows its roots - in a colour supplement commissioned by The Mail On Sunday, padded out with some A-level history and lots of twee observations of a country crossed at speed. Any decent publisher would have ordered the author to spend another six months with his subject - but hey, this is Bill Bryson."

Readers love Bryson; some critics spit with hatred. Amazingly, Mark Sanderson, in the London Evening Standard, was even more vituperative than Lette: "Australia is big, far too sunny and mostly empty: no wonder Bill Bryson feels it is his kind of place. He is not really a travel writer at all. He prefers bookshelves to backpacks; he goes in search of clichs rather than new experiences. With an ego the size of Ayer's Rock, he seems to think God's Own Country needs the help of a patronising American."

You can hate him, but you can't ignore him, as Sanderson proved. He reviewed the new Bryson alongside another book about Australia, Michael Davie's Anglo-Australian Attitudes. Sanderson much preferred the latter, yet devoted only 15 per cent of his review to it. "There is no shortage of idiots - which is why Down Under will sell thousands more copies than Anglo-Australian Attitudes." If he had bravely reversed his percentages, perhaps the public - surely not as idiotic as he suggests - might have been more likely to follow suit.

Terence Blacker, in the Sunday Times, was more temperate, but still dismissed the book as a hack job: "For someone about to visit Australia, Down Under presents a perfect, accessible introduction to the country, its history and its people. The problem is that, after a few pages, one finds oneself looking forward to the moments when Bryson takes us back to the library. The rich fascination of Australia's history and ecology, as seen by other writers, points up the thinness of our author's first-hand version of the country. From its defiantly dreary title onwards, Down Under feels like a journey taken at too great a speed on a road well-worn by other, more intrepid travellers, not to mention millions of ordinary, non-writing tourists."

Bryson's books seem so simple - solipsistic narrator, quick tour of country, lots of anecdotes, dash of humour, a few all-embracing conclusions - that some reviewers dismiss the skill with which they are put together. Not so James Urquhart in the Financial Times: "Down Under exhibits a smoother and more mature humour than previous works. The gags are still there - I couldn't help laughing out loud at some of his put-downs and deadpan conversations - but they are tempered with a satisfying breadth of historical perspective and research."

Urquhart was the most forgiving of the reviewers: it appears that one critic's research is another's hasty cramming, and others felt those gags had seen better days. Sara Wheeler, herself a writer of terrific travel books, perhaps got the balance right in the Daily Telegraph. First, the downside - and the crucial dividing line that distinguishes true travel writing from a superior tourist guide.

"Down Under is the story of a handful of short trips, all of them aimless," she said. "It is a shapeless book, lacking the travel narrative's raison d'etre. Bryson's massively successful Notes from a Small Island (1996) was convincingly billed as a valedictory tour to a country he loved and had called his own for more than 20 years. The Lost Continent (1989) was a rite of passage: when his father died it prompted him to discover the continent lost with his youth. These are Bryson's two best books because they sprang from a powerful sense of identity that gave them a shape. Because he did not spend long in Australia, occasionally the material in Down Under is so thin that even Bryson can't raise a good joke, and is obliged to wheel out Jurassic specimens ("a place where men were men and sheep were nervous").

Points well made, but just when you thought all was lost she produced a generous conclusion that helps to explain why Bryson gets away with his speed and shapelessness: "Bryson is such an agreeable, warm-hearted and witty companion that I ended up enjoying this book despite its shortcomings. This is, after all, a man who sits through the capital's promotional tourist video, Canberra - It's Got It All!, before renaming it Canberra - Why Wait for Death?" Bryson goes to Australia for a couple of months, produces a hack work that sells massively and even wins over a perceptive reviewer who has immediately seen through its slackness and superficiality. No wonder some critics loathe him. It just doesn't seem fair: he should at least have to suffer for his millions.

Because he did not spend long in Australia, occasionally the material in Down Under is so thin that even Bryson can't raise a good joke, and is obliged to wheel out Jurassic specimens ("a place where men were men and sheep were nervous"). Points well made, but just when you thought all was lost she produced a generous conclusion that helps to explain why Bryson gets away with his speed and shapelessness: "Bryson is such an agreeable, warm-hearted and witty companion that I ended up enjoying this book despite its shortcomings. This is, after all, a man who sits through the capital's promotional tourist video, Canberra - It's Got It All!, before renaming it Canberra - Why Wait for Death?" Bryson goes to Australia for a couple of months, produces a hack work that sells massively and even wins over a perceptive reviewer who has immediately seen through its slackness and superficiality. No wonder some critics loathe him. It just doesn't seem fair: he should at least have to suffer for his millions.

webTitle: The price of caging football's louts

fields.headline: The price of caging football's louts
fields.standfirst: Football violence: special report
fields.trailText: On the face of it Jack Straw's new anti-football hooligan proposal to give the police on-the-spot powers to prevent anyone leaving the country on the grounds of suspicion alone sounds like a major erosion of the international right to travel.
fields.body:
On the face of it Jack Straw's new anti-football hooligan proposal to give the police on-the-spot powers to prevent anyone leaving the country on the grounds of suspicion alone sounds like a major erosion of the international right to travel. But the sight of 20 well lubricated louts standing in the middle of an airport concourse chanting "I'd rather be a Paki than a Turk" or "No surrender to the IRA" while waiting for their plane for the next England game may prove sufficient evidence to persuade a magistrates court that the police were justified in preventing them leaving the country.

The home secretary justified these stringent new powers on the grounds that Euro 2000 had shown that football hooliganism was no longer a problem of a small hardcore of known thugs who could be policed but now large numbers of England supporters were getting involved in violence and disorder, most of whom were unknown to the police before they travelled.

The first two of the four elements in the home secretary's package announced yesterday are the least controversial.

Combining domestic and international bans

At present there are about 400 domestic bans in force. Police wrote to all of the individuals involved warning them not to travel to Euro 2000 but the authorities have no power to actually prevent them leaving the country. There are about 101 hooligans already banned from international games abroad who can legally be prevented leaving the country. Combining the orders will ensure that those banned for 10 years from attending domestic football games will not be able to travel abroad as well.

Confiscating passports

Every hooligan subject to a football banning order would have to surrender their passport while major overseas games were on. Courts currently have the discretion to impose such a condition on those served with an international football banning order but have only done so in 33 out of 101 cases.

Banning suspected hooligans

Far more controversial. This involves drawing much more widely the terms of who the courts can ban for 10 years from attending any football games at home or abroad. At present it is restricted to those convicted of football related violence. Mr Straw is now proposing that will no longer be necessary for those banned to have been convicted of any offence.

Instead the court will be able to impose a football banning order on a much lower standard of proof - the civil test of "balance of probabilities" rather than the criminal one of "beyond reasonable doubt" - and against people who have not been convicted. The idea is similar to Mr Straw's anti-social behaviour orders and will be imposed where the police believe it would help "prevent violence or disorder." Those who breached these civil orders could face the criminal sanction of jail.

Banned from leaving Britain

The most controversial. This would give to a police officer, of the rank of inspector or above, the new power to arrest and prevent somebody leaving the country where they believe there might be grounds for making a banning order.

Mr Straw said that after the police had stopped somebody leaving the country there would be a hearing in the magistrates' court who would decide if it was justified and whether they should face a football banning order. Those who ignored and simply skipped the country by another route - as some banned fans did during Euro 2000 - would face criminal sanctions, including possibly jail when they returned home.

fields.headline: Knowledge Unlimited
fields.trailText: We all know that England award caps to players competing in international fixtures. I was wondering where this tradition originated, and whether they still give the players caps? Do other countries give caps too, or do they give something else, e.g. scarves, beer glasses or plates? I can just imagine Big Ron saying when a player has played 47 international games: "He has 47 plates for his country!" asks Richard Cuddy.
fields.body:
We all know that England award caps to players competing in international fixtures. I was wondering where this tradition originated, and whether they still give the players caps? Do other countries give caps too, or do they give something else, e.g. scarves, beer glasses or plates? I can just imagine Big Ron saying when a player has played 47 international games: "He has 47 plates for his country!" asks Richard Cuddy.

According to the FA's David Barber, England players have been awarded caps for international matches ever since legendary FA committee member "Pa" Jackson decided to poach the idea from cricket in the early 1880s. In football's early days, the players actually wore caps during a game (because heading such a heavy ball wasnt really on). As such, an England cap was an ideal way to show off.

These days players are still given caps, although  unlike shirts  they don't get one for every game. "I remember Warren Barton asking whether he'd won a cap after Eire v England game was abandoned in Dublin in 1995," says David. "I was able to reassure him that the answer was a definite yes."

We assume its a solely a British tradition  does anybody know differently?

Why are Celtic called the Bhoys? asks Dan Reid

"That's quite an old one", said Celtic's helpful press officer, who admitted he wasn't able to give a definitive answer to our question but would give it a good shot.

The first tangible bit of evidence the club have for their strange nickname is a postcard from the turn of the century which refers to the Celtic team of the time as "the bould bhoys" (sic). It is thought the extra letter in "boys" was added to phonetically represent the Irish pronunciation of the word, with a soft inflection of the h.

The writer of the postcard didn't coin the nickname as such  the team were known to many as the "bold boys" soon after the club was founded in 1888. But whoever the scribe was is widely credited with the unique spelling, and deserves the thanks of anyone who has had to write a back-page headline for a Glasgow newspaper in the past 100 years or so. Not to mention us.

I've heard that the pregnant mother of John Lukic was on board the aircraft during the Munich air crash in 1958. Is it true? asks Wayne Spratt.

No its not. Despite being one of the biggest urban myths in football, even a cursory glance at the facts shows this story isnt true. The Munich air crash took place on 8th Feb 1958, while John Lukic was born nearly three years later on 11th Dec 1960.

However there was a passenger on board called Lukic, who had a young baby with her (they were both rescued by Harry Gregg) which is probably where the story came from.

In last week's Knowledge Unlimited Last week James Lowther claimed Terry Venables had never used the Christmas tree formation during Euro 96.

You're wrong! replied Philip Ritson. England played the Xmas tree against Holland (look at the tape, read his book). And Spain, England didnt play 4-4-2, but switched at half time to 3:4:1:2 with a team of Seaman; Southgate, Adams, Pearce; Neville, Gasciogne, Platt, Anderton; McManaman; Shearer Sheringham.

Any questions?

Send your football asks to the.boss@theguardian.com and we'll do our best to give you some answers.

fields.headline: Lara Croft
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about the world's favourite cyberbabe
fields.trailText: 1. Gun-toting pneumatic cyberbabe Lara Croft looks set to launch her next round of tomb-raiding from France, if British computer game company Eidos is bought up by French rival Infogrames, which has expressed interest in a takeover.
fields.body:
1. Gun-toting pneumatic cyberbabe Lara Croft looks set to launch her next round of tomb-raiding from France, if British computer game company Eidos is bought up by French rival Infogrames, which has expressed interest in a takeover.

2. Eidos's fortune is founded on the female Indiana Jones for the modern nerd, who has "become the first clearly distinguishable icon of the computer games world," according to games maestro Demis Hassabis.

3. Lara is chiefly distinguished by her assets. Computer magazine man Stuart Campbell reckons her popularity comes down to two words "and the second one is jugs".

4. But the boys might not drool if they knew the naked truth: Laura's fleshy charms actually exist as a polygon texture mapped model made up of 38,000 polygonal faces.

5. The girl has power and personality, claim her fans. When not tomb raiding, the daughter of Lord Henshingly Croft loves nothing more than curling up in her Surrey mansion with a plate of beans on toast and some easy listening - such as Nine Inch Nails - on the stereo.

6. Her cut-glass charms (She was made posh because "Americans love upper-class English accents", says one of her designers) have spawned a newspaper, pop videos, car adverts, Millennium Dome exhibits and, inevitably, a forthcoming Hollywood blockbuster.

7. Some reckon Bond got there first. The World Is Not Enough featured Christmas Jones, a buxom, hotpant-wearing nuclear scientist with a startling resemblance to Lara.

8. 007 got away with it, although Playboy got in trouble for dressing up former Lara model Nell McAndrew as a tomb raider. Asked if she would ever pose nude, Lara says no: "I do take comfort in the fact that by declining centrefold offers, I am at least helping budding artists to hone their life drawing skills."

9. Lara is a Bond for our times. Like 007, she has had several incarnations: as well as Ms McAndrew, Rhona Mitra and now Lucy Clarkson have portrayed the "real life" Lara.

10. You can leer at Lucy's vital statistics here.

fields.headline: French judges overrule censors
fields.trailText: Controversial French film Baise-Moi ('Fuck Me') has effectively been banned from cinemas in its home country after a damning lawsuit brought by French family values association Promouvoir
fields.body:
Controversial French film Baise-Moi - which translates as Fuck Me - has effectively been banned from cinemas in its home country after a damning lawsuit brought by French family values association Promouvoir.

Directed by Virginie Despentes (pictured), the film is about women who storm across France killing their sexual conquests. As we reported last month, it was originally given a PG-16 certificate (parental guidance for children under 16), but that has now been amended to a prohibitive X by the French high court. This means that the film can only play at 'specialist' cinemas, of which there are very few in the country.

The movie, according to the judges whose ruling eclipsed the decree of France's film censors, "is mostly made up of very violent scenes interspersed with scenes involving non-simulated sex, whereas other sequences do not denounce violence against women, contrary to the directors 'alleged intentions'."

Producer Phillipe Godreau, who is in danger of bankruptcy, has railed against the ban, arguing that "none of the critics who saw the film thought it was pornographic". According to the film's website, "[French far-right leader] Bruno Megret and his followers will rejoice in this ban". The site urges visitors to petition the high court in an effort to overturn the ruling.

webTitle: Steel wall erected after Drumcree violence

fields.headline: Steel wall erected after Drumcree violence
fields.trailText: The army has moved into Drumcree and                                                                    erected a huge steel barrier across the                                                                    road where police have come under attack                                                                    from loyalist rioters over the past three                                                                    nights.
fields.body:
The army has moved into Drumcree and erected a huge steel barrier across the road where police have come under attack from loyalist rioters over the past three nights.

The structure, twenty feet high and thirty feet wide, is made up of huge steel containers filled with concrete and topped with barbed wire and was put in place by army engineers.

An army spokesman said the barrier was in place because of the escalating violence and increasing tensions in the area.

Northern Ireland is clearing up today after Drumcree-related disturbances for the third night in succession.

A water cannon was deployed by the RUC for the first time in decades. Security forces exchanged fire with gunmen in Loyalist north Belfast. There were no reports of injuries.

Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson insisted the violence would not force a reversal of the decision by the parades commission to ban Drumcree Orangemen from marching along the nationalist Garvaghy Road in Portadown on Sunday.

He said: "Nobody by force of arms, use of violence, by bullying and intimidation is going to get any change of any decision, any law, any conclusion, that I, the Parades Commission or anyone else will have reached.

"That is not the way we conduct our affairs in Northern Ireland and people should understand that."

Earlier a lorry was driven at police lines from the lower Shankill area - although on the Unity Flats side. Unity Flats is a Catholic pocket on the fringe of the Shankill.

Meanwhile, clashes continued at Drumcree with youths continuing to hurl stones and fireworks at a police line in sporadic surges.

The water cannon was later used to push the crowd further away from the security forces' barricades.

Cars were also hijacked and torched in North Queen street in the north of Belfast while youths threw petrol bombs on the Ormeau Road in south Belfast.

Meanwhile, more roads were blocked as the evening progressed in Armagh, Dungannon, County Tyrone, Lisburn, County Antrim, Ballymena, County Antrim and Coleraine by demonstrators.

webTitle: Smooth Cruise wows fans at M:I2 premiere

fields.headline: Smooth Cruise wows fans at M:I2 premiere
fields.trailText: Tom Cruise goes walkabout at Leicester Square and sets his fans screaming
fields.body:
Tom Cruise descended on London's Leicester Square last night for the premiere of his latest movie Mission: Impossible 2.

The megastar did a 25-minute walkabout, greeting crowds and in one instance grabbing a fan's mobile phone and chatting to her mum. Schoolgirl Pamela Sakyi swooned, "He said to my mum, 'It's Tom Cruise here,' but I don't think she believed him. He said to her, 'It really is me, don't you recognise my voice?' It was then that my mum started screaming."

Pamela's mum isn't the only one who was screaming, as early reviews of the action flick hit the newsstands this week. "Facile and facetious," says Time Out magazine, "an elaborately silly exercise in treading water."

Undeterred, Tom Cruise is hoping that his powers of persuasion will work better than the critics'. "It's a great audience in Britain. I have a great time when I'm here. I just like people, I like going around and saying 'hello'. I just know what it would be like if I was there and I enjoy it," he said.

Some 3,000 people turned out to see the actor, who was joined at the event by co-stars Thandie Newton and Dougray Scott, and rent-a-celebs Caprice, Chris Evans and Kylie Minogue.

Back at the exclusive Dorchester Hotel, the intellectual Cruise was attempting a real Mission Impossible. The star used the alias Mr Bellacon - taken from Cervantes's novel 17th century mock heroic novel Don Quixote, apparently one of Cruise's favourites.

But a security guard let the ruse slip, and Cruise was greeted by a group of die-hard fans on his return to the hotel.

webTitle: Spy claims may tarnish Britain's 'Euro-friendly' image

fields.headline: Spy claims may tarnish Britain's 'Euro-friendly' image
fields.standfirst: France is taking a hard line on allegations that Britain fed industrial secrets to the US, writes the Guardian's Paris correspondent Paul Webster
fields.trailText: France is taking a hard line on allegations of British involvement in the feeding of secret industrial information to the US, writes the Guardian's Paris correspondent Paul Webster.
fields.body:
Revelations over British involvement in the US worldwide Echelon electronic industrial spying system could sour cross-channel relations inside the EU just as the worst of the ideological wars between London and Paris appeared to be over.

The French and the European parliaments are taking a strong line on the $4bn dollar operation run by US, British and Commonwealth listening bases which allegedly feed Washington with ultra-secret information on potential European business contracts, including Airbus and weapons sales.

While the French have started legal proceedings that they hope will lead to prosecutions for "an attack on national interests", MEPs in Strasbourg will today discuss the setting up of a commission to inquire into the Echelon programme overseen by the US National Security Agency. The NSA uses cold war technology to eavesdrop on billions of telephone, fax and e-communications every day in co-operation with top-secret British, Australian, Canadian and New Zealand listening facilities.

In one day, Echelon can pick up as much information as that stashed in all of Washington's political and cultural archives. Computers automatically pick out key words in private conversations to identify sensitive economic material.

The central European eavesdropping facility is linked to GCHQ in Cheltenham which is said to concentrate more and more on economic espionage. Information is forwarded to Fort Meade in Maryland where 40,000 NSA analysts work, according to the French, "without democratic control".

Reports that Cheltenham handed on information which sabotaged at least two big French deals in Saudi Arabia will revive criticism that the British are bad Europeans and still favour the so-called "special relationship" with the US. This is disappointing news for French diplomats who, with France presiding over the 15-nation EU for the next six months, have been putting around the message that Britain under New Labour was fast evolving into a Euro-friendly force.

"The atmosphere today around the negotiating table is incredibly relaxed in comparison to the bitterness of the Thatcher and the Major years, when British and French negotiators only thought of scoring the most points off each other," a French foreign office adviser said.

"Echelon can only revive suspicion that loyalties inside British delegations are divided."

"The atmosphere today around the negotiating table is incredibly relaxed in comparison to the bitterness of the Thatcher and the Major years, when British and French negotiators only thought of scoring the most points off each other," a French foreign office adviser said. "Echelon can only revive suspicion that loyalties inside British delegations are divided."

webTitle: Police must be given reporter's notes, court told

fields.headline: Police must be given reporter's notes, court told
fields.trailText: Newspapers and former security service officers must be prevented from disclosing information about the activities of British intelligence, even if it revealed involvement in a plot to assassinate the head of a foreign government, the high court was told yesterday.
fields.body:
Newspapers and former security service officers must be prevented from disclosing information about the activities of British intelligence, even if it revealed involvement in a plot to assassinate the head of a foreign government, the high court was told yesterday.

The assertion was made by prosecution lawyers who are insisting that the Guardian and Observer must hand over any emails or notes they may have relating to the former MI5 officer, David Shayler.

The newspapers are challenging a ruling by an Old Bailey judge that they should give to the police special branch any information they may have from Mr Shayler about a plot to kill Colonel Gadafy, the Libyan leader, in 1996.

Asked by Mr Justice Gibbs whether the disclosure of such a plot would be seriously damaging, Clare Montgomery QC, counsel for the crown prosecution service, replied: "Yes".

It would lead to a loss of confidence in MI5's ability to retain confidential material, she said. When the judge suggested it would be far less damaging if the public knew the security and intelligence services were involved in unlawful activities, she replied that according to the Official Secrets Act, such disclosures would still be damaging.

"One man's whistleblower is another man's traitor", she said.

The prosecution wants the original of a letter Mr Shayler wrote to the Guardian in February confirming the existence of the Libyan plot and the notes of Martin Bright, an Observer journalist who reported that Mr Shayler had named two MI6 officers involved in the plot.

Ms Montgomery insisted it was "absolutely vital" for the police to get their hands on the material. Without that evidence Mr Shayler probably could never be prosecuted, she claimed.

Michael Tugendhat QC, counsel for the newspapers, pointed to other, much earlier, evidence showing that Mr Shayler had previously disclosed information about the plot. They included a BBC Panorama programme cleared by government lawyers in 1998 and a book on the Shayler affair published last year.

"Why the Guardian, why now?," asked Mr Tugendhat. "The police have got to start somewhere", Ms Montgomery told the court.

Earlier, Ben Emmerson, QC for Mr Bright, insisted the journalist was entitled to protection from self-incrimination, a principle established in common law and in the European convention on human rights.

Asked by Lord Justice Judge whether she could give an undertaking that Mr Bright would not be prosecuted under the Official Secrets Act, Ms Montgomery said she could not. She suggested that Mr Bright could be prosecuted not only for disclosing information but for trying to encourage Mr Shayler for placing the names of MI6 officers on the internet.

Mr Shayler might feel aggrieved if he was prosecuted and Mr Bright was not, she told the court. The prosecution needed the information, she added, to prepare secrets charges against Mr Shayler who says he plans to return to Britain voluntarily in the autumn.

The court reserved judgment.

 Mr Shayler, who lives in Paris, said yesterday that MI5 and government lawyers had cleared his novel, The Organisation - a thinly veiled attack on MI5 - for publication.

webTitle: DiCaprio forbidden fruit goes to market

fields.headline: DiCaprio forbidden fruit goes to market
fields.trailText: Don's Plum, the 1995 film that Leonardo DiCaprio and Tobey Maguire went to court in an attempt to block its release, is finally on the verge of cinema distribution.
fields.body:
Don's Plum, the 1995 film that Titanic star Leonardo DiCaprio and Tobey Maguire went to court in an attempt to block its release, is finally on the verge of cinema distribution.

DiCaprio and Tobey Maguire - the Pleasantville and Ride with the Devil star - succeeded last year in preventing the indie flick from reaching American and Canadian cinemas, claiming in court that they had not been aware it was intended for commercial release. Producer David Stutman alleged that Maguire wanted to block its release because the actor felt he did not come off as strong a leading man as DiCaprio, and that some improvisational comments he had made in the course of the film would undermine his public image. DiCaprio - despite apparently liking the film when he first saw it - opted to put his considable weight behind his pal's attempts to prevent the film's release.

But earlier this year, Danish director Lars von Trier's Zentropa studio snapped up the pic for international distribution. Its release is now imminent. "We are adding the finishing touches to the movie right now and expect it to be complete around August 1," says a spokesperson for the Copenhagen-based studio.

The likelihood of a worldwide release will alarm DiCaprio and Maguire - the film is rumoured to feature 'steamy' scenes involving the pair and several of their friends.

Director David Stutman has always denied the duo's claims. In his legal case against DiCaprio and Maguire, Stutman claims that "Maguire and DiCaprio decided to stop the film for their own egomaniacal purposes." He alleges that the pair, using DiCaprio's clout as a newly-annointed superstar, "carried out a fraudulent and coercive campaign to prevent release of the film and destroy its value."

When, earlier this year, an unnamed executive producer complimented the pair publicly for "their amicable spirits, gentlemanly behaviour and wisdom" throughout the imbroglio, Maguire and DiCaprio promptly sued him too for so much as mentioning the affair because doing so violated a confidential settlement agreement.

 Read an excerpt from the lawsuit filed by producer Stutman against DiCaprio and Maguire.

webTitle: Missing Sarah: one of detained men freed

fields.headline: Missing Sarah: one of detained men freed
fields.trailText:
Police hunting the missing eight-year-old Sarah Payne said today they had released one of the men arrested in connection with her
disappearance.
fields.body:
Police hunting the missing eight-year-old Sarah Payne said today they had released one of the men arrested in connection with her disappearance.

The man, in his 30s, was given police bail but detectives were still questioning another man.

As the search continued for Sarah, who vanished on Saturday from fields near her grandparents' home in East Preston, West Sussex, police said they were intensifying efforts to find her.

Sussex Assistant Chief Constable Nigel Yeo said: "It's obvious that the situation gives increasing cause for concern as the time goes on."

He said police had received 800 calls offering assistance in the case and that more than 300 members of the public were currently helping specialist teams of officers comb the countryside near where Sarah disappeared.

He said police were working through information from members of the public and their own records - including the register of known sex offenders - in an effort to track down the youngster.

Police have until midnight tonight to either charge or release a man in his 40s who was arrested locally on Sunday, or apply to a magistrate for more time to hold him.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: We trawl through the papers but only come up with an old bike and a mattress
fields.trailText: Manchester United have launched a £10m bid to snatch Italian centre back Fabio Cannavaro from Parma, according to the Sun. Apparently Alex Ferguson "believes Cannavaro will be the perfect foil for Jaap Stam in defence." You don't say. In the past few months the paper has linked Gianluigi Buffon and Lilian Thuram - who both happen to play for Parma - with a move to Old Trafford. Third time lucky for Fergie - and the Sun - perhaps?
fields.body:
Manchester United have launched a £10m bid to snatch Italian centre back Fabio Cannavaro from Parma, according to the Sun. Apparently Alex Ferguson "believes Cannavaro will be the perfect foil for Jaap Stam in defence." You don't say. In the past few months the paper has linked Gianluigi Buffon and Lilian Thuram - who both happen to play for Parma - with a move to Old Trafford. Third time lucky for Fergie - and the Sun - perhaps?

Sylvain Wiltord's move to Arsenal seems to have more substance to it. The Daily Mail, in a back page exclusive, collar Wiltord's agent Giselaine Dugueteroux - and find he expects the French international to be playing at Highbury next season. "We hope that he will come to London for this season to play in your beautiful country," says Dugueteroux. "We expect him to join Arsene Wenger and his French team-mates from the European Championships. Sylvain likes the UK and he wants to play in the Champions League. Arsenal are a great club." The only slight surprise is the size of the transfer fee - which is reputed to be an incredible £15m.

Another French striker reportedly on the move is Nicolas Anelka. Planet Football claim that Paris Saint Germain have offered Real Madrid £21m for broody striker.

George Graham expects to wrap up a £13m double deal for Wimbledon's Ben Thatcher and Carl Cort by the end of the week, says the Sun. Not so claims the Daily Express, who predict that Cort is bound for Newcastle and Thatcher's £5m transfer to Spurs is close to collapse. One of them is bound to be right - but will it be the Sun's Pat Sheehan or the Express's Kevin Moseley? We wait with baited breath.

Southampton have joined the chase for Jordi Cruyff. Cruyff's agent Frannie Martin revealed: "Southampton have asked for a meeting and they are keen. We are also talking to Spanish clubs and two other English clubs. Harry Redknapp is interested but he has told us he doesn't have the money to fund the deal yet." Give him time, man

Sheffield Wednesday's Des Walker and West Ham's Neil Ruddock are set to swap clubs later this week. Apparently Walker doesn't want to play to play Nationwide football, and Wednesday are happy to get rid of one of their highest wage earners.

Leicester boss Peter Taylor has admitted he wants another four new players - with Wolves' Ade Akinbiyi high on his list.

Sheffield United are poised to sign Newcastle full-back Carl Serrant, 24, on a two-month loan deal, with a view to a permanent transfer.

fields.headline: Who's leaving home?
fields.standfirst: Many couples wait until their children have flown the nest before splitting up, in the belief that they are protecting them. But that may be far from the truth, says  Hadley Freeman
fields.trailText: Many couples wait until their children have flown the nest before splitting up, in the belief that they are protecting them. But that may be far from the truth, says Hadley Freeman
fields.body:
Carol Barnes, the television newscaster told the Daily Mail in an interview last week: "My marriage and job had become stale. The children were growing up and I decided it was time for me."

At 55, she has joined a growing list of celebrities who have left long-term marriages: Mick Jagger and Jerry Hall, Robin and Margaret Cook, Norman and Rosemary Lamont, Roger and Luisa Moore - they all separated after at least 19 years of marriage, and all had teenagers or children in their 20s.

This is not just a celebrity trend. The number of divorces between people over 45 has risen by a third over the past decade, an increase 10 times greater than the total rise in divorce. Between 1986-96, there was a 15% rise in divorces after 20 years of marriage, more than double any other category.

It is not always the case that parents wait before living separate lives. During their children's teenage years, parents feel less needed, which can leave a yawning gap. Often that gap is filled by an affair or major lifestyle change which does not include the partner. People who had much in common in their 20s may find themselves living with someone from whom they have grown apart. In the past couples were more likely to have accepted the situation. Now that the stigma attached to divorce has gone, they question it and take control of their lives. However, many parents assume that because their children are older the divorce will affect them less emotionally.

Barnes's youngest child, for example, is 18, the average age a child leaves home. He is one of an increasing number of teenagers and students who find that life after adolescence is not just a matter of getting used to raging hormones and academic stress, but coming to terms with the break-up of a family to whom they are still emotionally attached. Sometimes divorce results in the sale of the family home, making the children feel more alone and rootless.

"It just felt too weird to go 'home' to my mum's new flat," says Amanda Stevens, whose parents divorced during her second year at university. "So I really made university my home and stayed up in my student house during the holidays with my boyfriend."

Such a sudden cutting of ties can leave young people overly dependent on friends who may not be able to support them in a crisis. Rows with boyfriends or girlfriends can seem particularly threatening if there is no solid base to fall back on.

"Parents often believe that they have made the right decision by waiting until the children are a little older," says Julia Cole, a counsellor with Relate. "But when the children leave home to go to university or start work, they often feel they're taking a huge step into a new life and need their parents more than when they were younger."

However, while there are shelves of books for divorced parents with young children or for the young children themselves, there is remarkably little help for older children.

More! magazine's agony aunt, Emma Marlin, says that parents often underestimate the impact divorce has on older children. "It feels like a death - it's that shocking. Everything that you thought about your family and the way you perceived your childhood was a lie."

During his first year at Edinburgh University, Ben Jackson was confronted with his father's revelation that he had been having an affair for five years and had been waiting for his son to leave home so he himself could leave. "I just felt really sick - it had all been some pathetic charade for my Dad while he led this double life," he says. "Now when I look back on things, even just memories of him giving my mother a kiss, I really wonder how he lived with himself."

Jackson's mother was equally horrified by her husband's confession and turned to her 18-year-old son for support, calling him in tears several times a day and often asking him to come home at weekends.

Cole says this is a common problem for older children of divorced parents. "This really is a breach of parental responsibility, undermining any good parental intention of having stayed together for the children."

Some older children whose parents had waited for them to leave the nest, experience feelings of guilt, knowing that their parents had believed they needed to stay married unhappily for their sakes.

As a consequence, they may lash out at their parents or, on the other hand, become particularly protective of one parent, as Ben Jackson did with his mother. "I don't want my parents to be unhappy, and of course they have their own lives," he says. "But I think that my dad would have done me a bigger favour if he had left five years ago rather than make the assumption that if he had waited until now everything would be fine."

Older teenage children are often expected to react to their parents' divorce as an adult friend would, which is not the case. According to Marlin, the parents will often give them inappropriate details about their former partner: for example, about sexual behaviour or shortcomings. This problem may be aggravated if the divorce is particularly acrimonious. Louise Simpson's parents went through a very bitter divorce while she was away on a gap year. "I had to take on the go-between role," she remembers; she felt forced to assume the mantle of adulthood prematurely.

This does not mean that children should not support their parents. "You just need to make boundaries and say: 'Mum I'm happy to talk to you about such-and-such, but I'm not prepared to listen to you talk about your new boyfriend."

New partners bring difficulties too."I think it is worse for older kids," says Simpson. "Little children just have this vague idea of a new daddy, whereas I know exactly what this means. No one likes the thought of their parents having a sex life."

The strong feelings aroused in such a situation may affect the teenager's own romantic relationships. According to Marlin, an older child might throw himself or herself into a serious relationship as a form of compensation, or even reject the idea of ever having a long-term relationship. Conversely, some older children feel that they must remain childlike to make the deserted parent feel needed. "Anything to do with your close family is obviously going to affect you," Simpson says, sadly. "I just wanted my parents and friends to acknowledge that I was going through something quite horrible."

 Names of the children have been changed.

fields.headline: Lost boys of Thatcherism
fields.standfirst: Policing crime: special report
fields.trailText: The Home Office is soon to announce that rates of violence have continued their inexorable rise. Yet most other kinds of crime, such as car theft, go on falling. Criminologists are mystified.
fields.body:
The Home Office is soon to announce that rates of violence have continued their inexorable rise. Yet most other kinds of crime, such as car theft, go on falling. Criminologists are mystified. While it may be imperfect, my explanation (Juvenile Violence in a Winner-Loser Culture, Free Association Books, 1995) increasingly looks to be the most likely one: that the rise was largely caused by Mrs Thatcher's policies.

The rate of increase in violence against the person from 1950 to 1979 was like the acceleration of a Metro - a steady average of 3,000 more crimes a year. The rate of increase between 1980 and 1986 was not much faster - a middle-range Sierra at 4,000. But since 1987 there has been an acceleration like a formula one Ferrari: an average 12,000 more crimes a year.

The joyrider on this statistical rocket is increasingly likely to be juvenile. Juvenile violence also rose from 1987 and the proportion of all juvenile crime that is violent doubled (despite the fact that juvenile violence should actually have been falling by one fifth, because of a 20% drop in the birthrate in the 70s - there were actually one fifth fewer youths around to commit crime).

Worldwide and throughout history, people who commit violence are nearly all young, from a low income family and male.

Studies of identical twins and adopted boys prove that genes or biological makeup are very rarely involved. Rather, the difference is caused by three aspects of parenting in childhood: severe physical abuse, usually dressed up as punishment; witnessing parental disharmony, with or without fighting; and maternal irritability, nearly always caused by depression.

Using all the family predictors, we can estimate with an 80% accuracy which of the one in five of all boys who are aggressive will become the violent men. What causes these violence-inducing parental patterns? The answer is very well known: a low income. A Home Office funded study following 412 boys from age eight found that 42% of the boys from the poorest homes had become seriously violent by the age of 32. All the studies there have ever been have had similar findings.

It then stands to reason that the more boys being raised in low income homes in a given society, the more boys there will be experiencing violence-inducing care; and the more violent men there will be a few years later.

In 1979 in Britain, 19% of boys were being raised in a low income home (defined as 140% of supplementary benefit - about £160 a week). From 1981 the proportion was 30% and it has only recently begun to fall. So I estimate that every year since 1981, an additional 17,000 16-year-old boys who will become violent have been growing up.

And that, I believe, is why violence started to mushroom in 1987: more boys from Thatcher-created violence-inducing homes growing up to be violent men. Neither the police nor the present government can possibly be blamed for the fact that Mrs Thatcher spawned an American-shaped society with a dog-eat-dog, winner-loser culture and violence statistics to match.

What is more, my theory accords with the broader picture. Assaults are twice as common in poorer, developing nations as opposed to richer, developed ones. Between developed nations, murder rates correlate strongly with the size of the gap between rich and poor in the nation - the more inequitable, the more murderous. North America has a very large proportion of its population living in almost shanty town conditions, with virtually no health or other welfare support. It also has by far the most millionaires. This, far more than its gun laws (only half its murders involve guns), explains why America is far and away the most violent developed nation.

A 70s study found that the higher the levels of benefit, the lower the levels of violence in the States across America. Texas was both one of the most violent and the least supportive of its poor people; Wisconsin one of the least violent and most supportive.

To what extent they will actually address the huge disparities in rich and poor remains to be seen, but Surestart and attempts to improve the income of low-income parents are surely signs that the government does have an eye on the long-term violence statistics.

But in the shorter term, it is not so easy to see what they can do. The uncomfortable truth is that Mrs Thatcher's violent legacy will be with us for a great many years to come.

fields.headline: 'Britain attracting record foreign investment'
fields.standfirst:
Invest in Britain bureau
Department of trade and industry
fields.trailText: Britain attracted record levels of inward investment last year despite fears that the strength of sterling was holding back overseas firms, new figures announced this morning show.
fields.body:
Britain attracted record levels of inward investment last year despite fears that the strength of sterling was holding back overseas firms, new figures announced this morning show.

A record number of new jobs, new projects and levels of investment by foreign firms in this country were reported by the Invest in Britain Bureau.

The number of inward investment projects was 757 in the last financial year - up by 16% on the previous 12 months, creating 52,783 new jobs, a rise of over 16%.

The number of jobs safeguarded by the investment was 81,411, an increase of 8.4% on the previous year.

The figures were warmly welcomed by government ministers and will confound pro-euro campaigners who have been warning that overseas investment is being threatened by the government's wait-and-see policy on the single currency.

The IBB's own chief executive Andrew Fraser has warned in a leaked memo of a manufacturing "melt-down" unless the argument for joining the euro is put more strongly.

fields.headline: Greer attacker put on probation
fields.trailText: A student who hoped to adopt Germaine Greer as her "spiritual mother figure" sent her distressing letters, then invaded her Essex home and held her prisoner for two hours, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A student who hoped to adopt Germaine Greer as her "spiritual mother figure" sent her distressing letters, then invaded her Essex home and held her prisoner for two hours, a court heard yesterday.

Karen Burke, 19, took a camping holiday in the fields near the feminist author's country house before turning up unannounced on her doorstep in April, which eventually led to the occupation of Ms Greer's house.

Burke, a student of Italian, German and European studies at Bath University, pleaded guilty yesterday at Harlow magistrates court to harassing Ms Greer between January and April 25 by sending her distressing letters and holding her against her will.

Magistrates imposed a two year probation order.

Burke was ordered to undergo treatment from psychiatrist Richard Turner. She was also ordered not to contact Ms Greer nor to go within five miles of her home.

The court heard that Ms Greer's ordeal was preceded by a series of letters from Burke which "did not make a great deal of sense".

Ms Greer encountered Burke at her home on April 24. Dinah Walters, prosecuting, said: "She gathered from conversation she had with Karen Burke, that Karen Burke was infatuated with her and wished to adopt her as some form of spiritual mother figure."

She allowed Burke to spend the night in her summerhouse then took her to a railway station. Burke returned soon after midnight and rang the doorbell of the writer's home in Saffron Walden.

Ms Greer called police who warned the student she could be arrested for harassment. But at 6.30pm the following day she arrived at the house again as Ms Greer was leaving.

The writer screamed and tried to get back indoors, but Burke jumped on her back, shouting: "Mummy, mummy, don't do that."

The pair struggled back inside the house and in the ensuing fracas both women sustained injuries and the phone was ripped out of the wall.

Dinner guests arrived at the house and found Burke holding Ms Greer by the legs.

Magistrates decided against making an order for costs or compensation because the student had no income.

In a statement to police, Burke said: "I don't know what got into me. I just wanted to get all this stuff out of my head. It is an emotional thing. I wanted to hug her."

webTitle: Second string blow it at Lord's

fields.headline: Second string blow it at Lord's
fields.trailText: The England cricket team deserve all the praise coming their way for their close and exciting win over West Indies in the second Test at Lord's. All kinds of reasons have been put forward for the victory - Alec Stewart's rallying call, the allround performance of Dominic Cork, and Andy Caddick with the ball.
fields.body:
The England cricket team deserve all the praise coming their way for their close and exciting win over West Indies in the second Test at Lord's. All kinds of reasons have been put forward for the victory - Alec Stewart's rallying call, the allround performance of Dominic Cork, and Andy Caddick with the ball.

But West Indians put their failure down to something rather different - Jimmy Adams blew it tactically by bowling Franklyn Rose for at least two overs too many at the end. Every time Rose came on, the pressure came off. Curtly Ambrose was being as miserly as ever from the Pavilion end - but Rose's first ball to Caddick next over was short and wide outside off-stump and smashed for four. Another short one to Cork was hooked for six.

With 30-odd runs to get, Rose was bowling so badly and was so embarrassed by it that he looked as if he wanted the ground to swallow him up. His body language made it clear to everyone in the ground except Adams that he'd rather pick a fight with a Kingston yardie than bowl. Caddick had just fallen leg-before to Ambrose and the Windies could smell victory. It was Rose next over but tellingly, he just plodded over to his mark, nothing in his step suggesting that his team had just got a breakthrough. Even Mike Tyson's opponents look more willing. Another tight, skilful and desperately unlucky over from Ambrose, and the Caribbean supporters at the Pavilion end saw Rose removing his sweater. A hubbub of disbelief went up. An over later, the England fans gave him a standing ovation when he took up his position at fine leg. He had, of course, helped their cause hugely.

But it would be wrong to heap all the blame on Rose, just as it would be ungracious not to give Cork, Darren Gough, Caddick, Mike Atherton and Michael Vaughan the credit they deserve. It is true to say though that he, and to a lesser extent Reon King, did not accept responsibility by taking the burden off Walsh and Ambrose. It's clear why Ambrose hasn't seen the need to retire until this series has ended, or Walsh hasn't (so far) seen the need to chuck it in at all. Walking away now would be like letting the reckless teenager run the family business. Rose and King cannot yet be trusted with the legacy.

I watched them both bowl that afternoon in the company of Allan Rae, who formed such an effective opening batting partnership with Jeffrey Stollmeyer in the 1950 series that Ramadhin and Valentine dominated. His opinion was that King and Rose did not understand their role - which was to give away as few runs as possible and keep the pressure on the for older strike bowlers. Instead they tried too hard. "We're lucky to have Ambrose and Walshy", Rae told me, "but they cannot bowl all day". Rae does reackon King and Rose are good bowlers though. Maybe the only thing that would force them and others to step up is the great opening pair finally leaving. Walsh did not look as if he was going to be a great fast bowler when a 40-year-old batsman named Roy Fredericks was smashing him all around the Bourda ground in the 1983 Red Stripe Cup competition. So there is hope for the Windies first- and second-change bowlers.

What about that 54 all out, their lowest-ever total against England? The England bowlers really raised their game, but the unanimous view of ex-players like Geoff Boycott and Desmond Haynes is that it was not a devilish pitch. I think it was a combination of good bowling, poor batting and some bad and crucial umpiring decisions. Barry Richards feels that the West Indies batsmen suffered far worse from the umpiring. Replays showed that Wavell Hinds and Shivnarine Chanderpaul were not even close to being dismissed, and that Adams was unlucky. How many runs were those three wickets worth? Ten, 20, 30 or 80? No-one knows for sure but in the context of a close and low-scoring game, it made the difference between victory and defeat. Funny how such a crucial factor gets overlooked in the seemingly ceaseless search for the hero by England cricket writers. The Windies will be hoping that decisions like those don't figure as much as they did when South Africa visited England in 1998, and were denied a series win through erratic decision-making by the Pakistani umpire Javed Akhtar. England do tend to get the breaks at home.

But not everyone is blaming the umpires. Both Haynes and the Barbados-born ex-England player Roland Butcher criticised the Windies batsmen for fending off short deliveries during England's bouncer barrage, and not trying to hook or pull the ball. They were aghast at this most un-Caribbean approach to the batting, and it's fair to say that the ball off which Chanderpaul was given out caught at short leg, would have been disappearing through midwicket or over the square-leg boundary had either of these happy hookers been at the wicket. Haynes did tell me that "any Test-playing side ought to get 187 on this pitch", shortly after he'd seen his side collapse for 54. He was right - just.

Orin Gordon, born and brought up in Guyana, has lived in London for five years and currently works as a broadcast journalist.To read his previous column, on West Indies' win at Edgbaston,click here

fields.headline: Policeman questioned over Swansea murders
fields.standfirst: Three arrested over murder of family
fields.trailText: A police sergeant and his estranged wife, a former policewoman, are among the three people being questioned in connection with the murders of three generations of a family in Swansea.
fields.body:
A police sergeant and his estranged wife, a former policewoman, are among the three people being questioned in connection with the murders of three generations of a family in Swansea.

They were arrested yesterday, almost a year after 80-year-old Doris Dawson, her daughter Mandy Power, 34, and her grandchildren Katie, 10 and Emily, eight, were bludgeoned to death in their home.

Sgt Steve Lewis, 38, and his estranged wife Alison Lewis, 34, were arrested on suspicion of murder and taken to separate police stations in south Wales.

A second man, also aged 38, was arrested simultaneously on suspicion of perverting the course of justice. All three are from the south Wales area.

The brutal killings shook the close-knit Swansea valley community and gave rise to the biggest murder inquiry yet in south Wales.

Over the past 12 months officers have taken almost 15,000 witness statements and visited more than 900 homes.

They used BBC TV's Crimewatch series three times to appeal for information and also issued e-fit images of potential suspects on the internet.

fields.headline: Sect banned by rock festival
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: A Christian fundamentalist sect has been banned from attending this year's Reading festival after the Guardian revealed that the sect was using rock events to distribute anti-semitic literature.
fields.body:
A Christian fundamentalist sect has been banned from attending this year's Reading festival after the Guardian revealed that the sect was using rock events to distribute anti-semitic literature.

The festival organiser, Mean Fiddler, yesterday turned down an application from Twelve Tribes to bring its mobile cafe, The Common Ground, to Reading.

The cafe was a popular meeting point at this year's Glastonbury festival, where sect members gave out literature attacking multiculturalism and blaming Jews for the "murder" of Jesus.

A spokesman for the organiser of the Reading event, which takes place over the bank holiday weekend August 25-27, said: "The Mean Fiddler has always believed that music events should not be used by organisations to preach religious or political beliefs at attendees, regardless of the content of those beliefs.

"In accordance with this policy, both the Twelve Tribes and Common Ground cafe have had their application for the festival rejected."

While all religious preaching is prohibited at Reading, the content of Twelve Tribes' literature "made the decision to ban them much easier", a spokesman said.

Artists playing the Reading weekend include Oasis, Primal Scream, Stereophonics and Beck.

webTitle: Brown unmoved in euro leaks row

fields.headline: Brown unmoved in euro leaks row
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown will today shrug off mounting pressure from politicians and business leaders and resist suggestions that Britain will be willing and able to join the European single currency soon after the next general election.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown will today shrug off mounting pressure from politicians and business leaders and resist suggestions that Britain will be willing and able to join the European single currency soon after the next general election.

In a speech to 200 British and American financiers at a conference in London this morning the chancellor will stick to his existing policy and the five economic tests that he set in 1997, despite a flurry of pro-euro leaks which yesterday triggered a full-scale Whitehall investigation.

With the government's own Invest in Britain Bureau today producing figures that show 25% of all inward investment into the EU still comes to the UK, Mr Brown will praise the achievement - especially since Britain's share of US investment is 40%.

But he will avoid any support for the Eurosceptic case that says such figures prove Britain can thrive outside the euro zone. That would amount to picking a direct fight with key cabinet colleagues - the foreign secretary Robin Cook, the trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers and the Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson - who endorse warnings that industry is close to "meltdown" because of the strong pound.

Mr Brown will speak against a background of mutual sniping over the government's euro strategy and angry accusations by opponents of the currency that senior ministers - notably Mr Cook - actively connived in leaks to the Guardian and other newspapers.

Yesterday's leak of a confidential Foreign Office memo from Britain's ambassador in Japan, Sir Stephen Gomersall - warning of the loss of Japanese investment if the UK does not join the euro - prompted the tycoon, Lord Hanson, to accuse Mr Cook directly.

After Downing Street said Tony Blair will sack anyone - official or minister - caught making leaks, the shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude said: "If Robin Cook ordered this document to be leaked, will Tony Blair sack his foreign secretary?"

Mr Cook demanded an apology from Lord Hanson. But Mr Maude tabled a series of Commons questions asking in detail who would have had access to Sir Stephen's diplomatic telegram.

In reality, their number is high and the chances of finding the leaker is even smaller than usual. Mr Blair's junior spokesman said: "I am sending out a very strong signal: if we can pin down where these leaks have come from, that person will be dismissed." Asked if that included ministers, he replied : "Yes."

Many MPs assume that it was the buoyant figures from the Invest in Britain Bureau that prompted pro-euro forces to get their retaliation in first by leaking Sir Stephen's warning and one from Andrew Fraser, head of the Invest in Britain Bureau - both say the government must get off the euro fence.

Sir Stephen's memo said that uncertainty over the government's stance on the euro could "trigger a much stronger move towards disinvestment in the manufacturing sector" - a point which fellow diplomats said he would be expected to make.

Lord Hanson said the leak was "another example of spin". "Ambassadors do as they are told by the foreign secretary," he said. "We all know that Robin Cook is desperate to force this issue ahead."

His remarks were backed by Business for Sterling which complained of "disgraceful" leaks by the other side.

Mr Cook retaliated. "The suggestion that I instructed Sir Stephen Gomersall to doctor his report so that it could be leaked is an outrageous slur on a distinguished diplomat and on ministers. I am sure that when Lord Hanson reflects on what he has said, he will want to apologise. He should do so promptly," he said.

As he said in his Mansion House speech last month the chancellor continues to believe that entry should be based on a more rounded judgment of the economic conditions. As well as the impact of euro membership on investment, the tests include whether or not the two economic cycles are sufficiently converged and what will happen to the City.

Mr Cook demanded an apology from Lord Hanson. But Mr Maude tabled a series of Commons questions asking in detail who would have had access to Sir Stephen's diplomatic telegram. In reality, their number is high and the chances of finding the leaker is even smaller than usual. Mr Blair's junior spokesman said: "I am sending out a very strong signal: if we can pin down where these leaks have come from, that person will be dismissed." Asked if that included ministers, he replied : "Yes." Many MPs assume that it was the buoyant figures from the Invest in Britain Bureau that prompted pro-euro forces to get their retaliation in first by leaking Sir Stephen's warning and one from Andrew Fraser, head of the Invest in Britain Bureau - both say the government must get off the euro fence. Sir Stephen's memo said that uncertainty over the government's stance on the euro could "trigger a much stronger move towards disinvestment in the manufacturing sector" - a point which fellow diplomats said he would be expected to make. Lord Hanson said the leak was "another example of spin". "Ambassadors do as they are told by the foreign secretary," he said. "We all know that Robin Cook is desperate to force this issue ahead." His remarks were backed by Business for Sterling which complained of "disgraceful" leaks by the other side. Mr Cook retaliated. "The suggestion that I instructed Sir Stephen Gomersall to doctor his report so that it could be leaked is an outrageous slur on a distinguished diplomat and on ministers. I am sure that when Lord Hanson reflects on what he has said, he will want to apologise. He should do so promptly," he said. As he said in his Mansion House speech last month the chancellor continues to believe that entry should be based on a more rounded judgment of the economic conditions. As well as the impact of euro membership on investment, the tests include whether or not the two economic cycles are sufficiently converged and what will happen to the City.
