webTitle: Chirac pledges to strengthen inner euro group

fields.headline: Chirac pledges to strengthen inner euro group
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: President Jacques Chirac piled the pressure on to Tony Blair yesterday when he promised to use France's six-month presidency of the European Union to strengthen both the powers and profile of the "Euro-11" group of member states which have already adopted the single currency.
fields.byline: Ian Black  in Brussels and  Michael White
fields.body:
President Jacques Chirac piled the pressure on to Tony Blair yesterday when he promised to use France's six-month presidency of the European Union to strengthen both the powers and profile of the "Euro-11" group of member states which have already adopted the single currency.

Though French politicians and diplomats are taking an unthreatening and pragmatic stance towards the creation of a two-speed Europe, dominated by a Franco-German core, the thrust of their rhetoric may prove a serious pre-election problem to Mr Blair in the months ahead.

The French EU presidency, which started on July 1, proposes to improve the functioning of the Euro 11 - soon to become Euro 12 when Greece joins next year - by giving its work more visibility and authority, Mr Chirac told Euro MPs in Strasbourg.

There is also fresh encouragment for the creation of a political post of "Monsieur Euro" to match the foreign policy position now held by Javier Solana of Spain.

With Greece joining Euro 11 in advance of its adoption of the euro next January, Denmark is holding a referendum in September, possibly followed by Sweden. Facing the prospect of a Euro 14, Britain fears that France's approach could undermine the monthly meeting of finance ministers, known as Ecofin, where Gordon Brown, the chancellor, is accepted as an equal.

Whitehall's position is to be calm about pressure to make it easier for inner groups to act alone, as Britain and France do on defence. But France's explicit targeting of the Euro11 group for "reinforced cooperation" is worrying. "Our attitude is 'You can do what you want provided you respect the Ecofin agreement' ," one official said. In theory that means that any economic decision affecting Britain would still have to be taken to the full Ecofin with Mr Brown present.

Yet Paris could try to avoid difficulties by keeping any changes informal..

It is another sign that the euro juggernaut is bearing down on the British "wait and see" position.

Harmonising taxation policy and actively preparing for the arrival of euro notes and coins in January 2002 were also identified by the French president as crucial to his social and economic plans for Europe.

"Everything practically and humanly possible must be done to ensure the success of this great step," he said.

Mr Blair can take more comfort from Mr Chirac's remarks on the proposed charter of fundamental rights. Euro-sceptics have said this could form the basis for an EU constitution and the prime minister has threatened to block if it extends existing human rights and has legally binding force.

The French president said the charter should be completed in time for the EU's next summit in Biarritz in October. But he played down the prospect that it could be made legally binding by being incorporated into the planned Treaty of Nice in December, as Germany and others want.

"It will be some time before we can express an opinion on that point and I am not sure we will be in a position to have a view in Nice," he said.

Mr Chirac's address was more practical than the visionary approach he adopted in the Bundestag in Berlin last week, when a call for a "pioneer group" of integrationist minded countries caused alarm in Britain. He said that reforming the EU's creaking institutions before the union could enlarge to the east was the main priority of France's six-month stint at the euro helm.

webTitle: US hits bum note for Cuban tuners

fields.headline: US hits bum note for Cuban tuners
fields.trailText: Cuban music is almost the soundtrack for modern American life: you cannot enter a bookshop, a coffee shop or a park without hearing a son, a danzon, a bolero or a guajira.
fields.byline: Michael Ellison  in New York and Duncan Campbell  in Los Angeles
fields.body:
Cuban music is almost the soundtrack for modern American life: you cannot enter a bookshop, a coffee shop or a park without hearing a son, a danzon, a bolero or a guajira.

But while its music is welcome throughout the States, Havana's top piano tuners are a different matter.

Invited to the Piano Technicians' Guild convention, taking place today in Virginia, Yuli Diaz, her husband Armando Gomez, and Raquel Montejo presented their credentials at the US interests section in the Cuban capital.

But there it was judged that the piano tuners were a threat to US national interests. The immigration service turned them down because it was assumed that they would try to stay in the US.

"What must they think of Cubans?" said Ms Diaz, who pointed out that all three would leave behind children, homes and careers were they to defect. Her husband returned to Cuba after attending the convention two years ago.

The three had been invited to make the trip as guests of the Send A Piano To Havana project.

Its founder, Ben Treuhaft, said: "This encounter has been months in the planning . . . The whole thing is sabotaged by a functionary who can't tell a piano tuner from a refugee."

webTitle: Loyalists open fire on RUC as parade rage rises

fields.headline: Loyalists open fire on RUC as parade rage rises
fields.standfirst:
Roadblocks spread across Belfast as police come under bombardment
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The RUC came under gunfire from loyalists in the Shankill Road area of Belfast late last night as the protests over the parade commission's ban on the Orange Order from marching the nationalist Garvaghy Road in Portadown took another sinister turn.
fields.body:
The RUC came under gunfire from loyalists in the Shankill Road area of Belfast late last night as the protests over the parade commission's ban on the Orange Order from marching the nationalist Garvaghy Road in Portadown took another sinister turn.

Police said they returned fire, and reported no injuries. But it is believed to be the first such incident in several years, and cast doubt over the mainstream loyalist ceasefire, announced in October 1994.

The attack came in the fiefdom of Ulster Freedom Force commander Johnny Adair, who sparked concern among the RUC when he appeared on Monday at Drumcree, with 50 UFF colleagues, to march to the police line. Never before had the UFF openly attended Drumcree.

There were road blocks last night across Belfast, bringing much of the city to a halt. Some were peaceful, but in north Belfast police were pelted with petrol bombs, and cars were hijacked and set alight.

Similar demonstrations were taking place in at least five towns across Northern Ireland as loyalists responded to Portadown district master Harold Gracey's call to take to the streets. He had demanded protests against the parade commission's decision to ban the Orange Order from the Garvaghy Road for the third year running.

At Drumcree, outside Portadown, where the RUC is blocking access to the Orangemen's traditional route, police resorted to using water cannon late last night to prevent protesters throwing missiles at officers. It was the first time water cannon had been used in almost 30 years.

Two tankers, on loan from Belgian police, forced protesters 200 yards away from police barricades after officers came under sustained attack, and a police vehicle was doused in petrol and set alight. But the missile throwing quickly resumed, and intensified.

Police were early this morning warning protesters that force would be used to remove them. They were shaping up to clear the area again.

With four days to go until Sunday, security forces believe there will be a further escalation of violence, and fear it will culminate in fatality. They expect protests to last beyond July 12, the climax to the Orange Order's marching season.

The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, led criticism of the violence, labelling it thuggery. But he vowed there would be no change to the pa rade commission's decision.

Mr Adair and his followers had marched to police lines on Monday under a UFF banner wearing white t-shirts with the slogan "Simply the best: their only crime, loyalty." Even his alsatian, named Rebel, was wearing one of the t-shirts, complete with Red Hand of Ulster.

Mr Adair, a bystander as LVF masked gunmen later on Monday fired a volley of shots into the air, insisted he knew nothing in advance of the show of strength. But he made sure the UFF banner of the 2nd battalion C company was to the fore, and instructed TV cameras where to set up.

His UFF company was behind last month's threat to the six year ceasefire, claiming nationalists were attacking Protestant homes. The threat was suspended only after intevention from the Ulster Democratic Party, allied to the UFF, which yesterday criticised Mr Adair's presence at Drumcree as reckless.

An unrepentant Mr Adair said he would be back at Drumcree before Sunday. He said he wanted only peaceful protests.

He said yesterday: "I was in Portadown at the request of the Protestant people and in response to Harold Gracey's comments. Are we going to sit back and let these people trample us into the ground?"

Ulster Unionist MP Ken Maginnis, using parliamentary privilege at Westminster, claimed Mr Adair's presence was "more to do with who controls the drugs trade in Northern Ireland than it has to do with God and Ulster". Mr Adair denies involvement in the growing drugs trade.

Mr Adair, 35, a father of three, was freed last September under the Good Friday agreement after serving five years of a 16-year sentence on the unprecedented charge of directing terrorism. There were calls for him to be returned to prison, but he had committed no specific offence.

Among other terrorist suspects present during this year's dispute at Drumcree is one man believed to have been involved in the no-warning Dublin and Monaghan car bombings, when 33 people died in May 1974. Another is reputed to be the leader of the Orange Volunteers, responsible last year for a series of sectarian blast bomb attacks.

According to one moderate Orangeman yesterday, their presence would persuade many Orange Order members to stay away on Sunday. There are worries within the movement that the Portadown district is giving tacit encouragement to those intent on violence.

webTitle: Youths on murder charge 'copied Reservoir Dogs'

fields.headline: Youths on murder charge 'copied Reservoir Dogs'
fields.standfirst: Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Three teenage boys who appeared in court yesterday charged with the murder of another teenager were alleged to have copied the film Reservoir Dogs in making an attack on him.
fields.body:
Three teenage boys who appeared in court yesterday charged with the murder of another teenager were alleged to have copied the film Reservoir Dogs in making an attack on him.

The three, two aged 15 and one aged 16, lured 15-year-old Michael Moss from a care home on to a playing field at night, it was said at Liverpool crown court.

They attacked him, stripped him naked and carried out a "sustained and violent assault" over a period of two hours. They stamped, punched and kicked Michael, known as Mossy, over his entire body, it was alleged.

"This was a murder which involved systematic and extreme violence, violence for its own sake," said Anthony Gee QC, prosecuting.

"Michael Moss was quite defenceless and overwhelmed. The injuries inflicted on him included an attempt to cut off his ear. The defendants, it seems, were acting out a scene from a violent film called Reservoir Dogs, according to what one of the defendants said later."

Mr Gee told the jury the attack, in November last year, had been sparked by jealousy. The defendant who spoke of the Reservoir Dogs link said he believed Michael was going out with his former girlfriend.

The three boys, all from Merseyside and all now 16, cannot be named for legal reasons. They all deny murder.

Mr Gee told the jury: "The case is appalling in many ways, you may think, not least because of the ages of these children, but also because of the very manner of the attack which they inflicted of Michael Moss."

He asked jury members to steel themselves before showing them photographs of Michael's body and a video of the scene on the playing field.

Michael had suffered bruises, fractures and flesh wounds to his entire body, the cuts possibly being caused by the neck of a broken bottle, the jury heard.

There were deep cuts to his feet which had not bled, proof that they had been inflicted after Michael had died and his circulation had stopped, Mr Gee added.

The video showed his blood splattered across the climbing frame and over the ground.

"The attacks delivered to Michael's head were such that he suffered a separation of two vertebrae in his neck," said Mr Gee. "This was not a spontaneous outburst of violence. There was a degree of pre-meditation on the part of at least two of the defendants."

The trial continues.

fields.headline: The best farmhouse scene
fields.standfirst: Chicken run
fields.trailText: Chicken run
fields.body:
Mrs and Mrs Tweedy (the voices of Tony Haygarth and Miranda Richardson) stand in their farmhouse kitchen. Mr Tweedy peers darkly out towards the chicken coop with a pair of binoculars.

"Oh yes... those chickens are up to summat."

"Quiet!" scolds his wife. "I'm up to something."

"They're organised, I know it."

"Quiet!"

"That ginger one, I reckon she's their leader."

Mrs Tweedy slams her fist on the kitchen table. Mr Tweedy turns round. Looking at her through his binoculars, she appears huge.

"Mr Tweedy! I may finally have found a way to make us some real money around here, and what are you on about? Ridiculous notions of escaping chickens!"

"B-b-but..."

"It's all in your head, Mr Tweedy. Say it!"

Mr Tweedy stares at the floor.

"It's all in me head."

"Now you keep on telling yourself that, because I don't want to hear another word about it. Is that clear?"

Mr Tweedy cowers in his seat.

"Yes, love. But you know that ginger one...?"

"They're chickens , you dolt! Apart from you they're the most stupid creatures on the planet. They don't plot. They don't scheme."

She looms over her husband.

"And they are NOT organised!"

Don't see also: Children Of The Corn

webTitle: China steps up policing after Dover deaths

fields.headline: China steps up policing after Dover deaths
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The police authorities in Fujian, the home province of the 58 Chinese migrants who died in the Dover tragedy, have broken silence to explain their inability to stop the illegal traffic in humans.
fields.body:
The police authorities in Fujian, the home province of the 58 Chinese migrants who died in the Dover tragedy, have broken silence to explain their inability to stop the illegal traffic in humans.

They are demanding better equipment, including highspeed planes and boats and unspecified weapons, to deal with the "snakeheads" who organise the trade.

The Fujian's border guards complain that their anti-smugging equipment is comparatively backward and in some places they have to conduct patrols in rented fishing boats.

The Fujian authorities say the penalties prescribed by existing laws are too light and do not adequately deter persistent offenders.

But allegations of collusion between local officials and the snakeheads have now been published in the Chinese press.

A news clampdown was imposed in the province for more than a week after word of the deaths reached China.

The national media reported the investigation in Britain but carried almost no information from Fujian. At the end of last week the Fujian press finally reported that a large-scale operation against the smuggling was launched on June 20, the day after news of the Dover tragedy broke.

Several Chinese newspapers, including the Southern Weekend and the China Youth Daily, both known for investigative journalism, have been allowed to publish interviews with the families and local security officials.

The identity of the main snakehead gang leaders is common knowledge in the districts of Changle and Fuqing and other centres of illegal emigration.

The Southern Weekend reporter, who pretended to be a would-be migrant during his investigation, was given the names of several snakeheads and officials.

"There are plenty of people who can help you," he was told in one village.

"If you want to go to Japan in a hurry you can look for Chen Meng X - he's a township official." The newspaper did not publish the official's full name.

The reporter was also given the name of a village Communist party secretary involved in the trade.

"It is fairly well known that the provincial authorities and the snakeheads have very good links," a western diplomat said yesterday.

"It is the usual problem that while cooperation can be secured at the national level, progress really depends on winning support and consent locally."

Some foreign reporters in China who tried to visit the snakehead areas in Fujian were detained and told to leave the province.

The provincial authorities have said that they are too busy to accept journalists from abroad.

Fujian officials rely heavily on the long history of emigration from the province to explain why the traffic is so difficult to stop.

They also blame foreign countries for lax controls and for allowing some illegal migrants to gain political asylum.

A border guard spokesman suggested that the province should organise proper routes for legal migration so that people could come and go safely.

A sizeable number of Fujian migrants already leave China with travel documents that are completely in order.

Foreign experts monitoring the movement of migrants are accustomed to the sight of parties of Fujianese heading for central Europe or the Caribbean with valid tourist visas.

The families of the migrants say that Chinese passports and third-country visas are supplied by the snakeheads or their contacts in return for payment.

The Fujian authorities have not said how they intend to deal with this problem, in spite of a succession of campaigns against smuggling.

The border guard chief, Colonel Wu Jiansen, has been quoted as saying that a full-scale campaign against the snakeheads was launched in April and was still under way when the new drive was started on June 20.

Last year was declared to be a triumph in the struggle against the snakeheads. But local families interviewed since the Dover tragedy - even some of those who believe they have lost relatives - say they are convinced that the traffic will continue.

At the end of last week the Fujian press finally reported that a large-scale operation against the smuggling was launched on June 20, the day after news of the Dover tragedy broke. Several Chinese newspapers, including the Southern Weekend and the China Youth Daily, both known for investigative journalism, have been allowed to publish interviews with the families and local security officials. The identity of the main snakehead gang leaders is common knowledge in the districts of Changle and Fuqing and other centres of illegal emigration. The Southern Weekend reporter, who pretended to be a would-be migrant during his investigation, was given the names of several snakeheads and officials. "There are plenty of people who can help you," he was told in one village. "If you want to go to Japan in a hurry you can look for Chen Meng X - he's a township official." The newspaper did not publish the official's full name. The reporter was also given the name of a village Communist party secretary involved in the trade. "It is fairly well known that the provincial authorities and the snakeheads have very good links," a western diplomat said yesterday. "It is the usual problem that while cooperation can be secured at the national level, progress really depends on winning support and consent locally." Some foreign reporters in China who tried to visit the snakehead areas in Fujian were detained and told to leave the province. The provincial authorities have said that they are too busy to accept journalists from abroad. Fujian officials rely heavily on the long history of emigration from the province to explain why the traffic is so difficult to stop. They also blame foreign countries for lax controls and for allowing some illegal migrants to gain political asylum. A border guard spokesman suggested that the province should organise proper routes for legal migration so that people could come and go safely. A sizeable number of Fujian migrants already leave China with travel documents that are completely in order. Foreign experts monitoring the movement of migrants are accustomed to the sight of parties of Fujianese heading for central Europe or the Caribbean with valid tourist visas. The families of the migrants say that Chinese passports and third-country visas are supplied by the snakeheads or their contacts in return for payment. The Fujian authorities have not said how they intend to deal with this problem, in spite of a succession of campaigns against smuggling. The border guard chief, Colonel Wu Jiansen, has been quoted as saying that a full-scale campaign against the snakeheads was launched in April and was still under way when the new drive was started on June 20. Last year was declared to be a triumph in the struggle against the snakeheads. But local families interviewed since the Dover tragedy - even some of those who believe they have lost relatives - say they are convinced that the traffic will continue.

webTitle: Irvine plans to slash lawyers' legal aid fees

fields.headline: Irvine plans to slash lawyers' legal aid fees
fields.trailText: Barristers who do criminal defence and family cases on legal aid are to have their fees slashed under plans outlined yesterday by the lord chancellor.
fields.body:
Barristers who do criminal defence and family cases on legal aid are to have their fees slashed under plans outlined yesterday by the lord chancellor.

Lord Irvine warned the Bar this year that he thought fees for criminal defence lawyers were too high, although the rates are paid under a scheme agreed years ago between the bar and his department.

Fees under the graduated fees scheme - which covers cases lasting up to 10 days in the crown court - are to be cut by 10% from December 1, producing a projected £7m saving on the 1999-2000 bill of £71m.

Fees for prosecuting counsel, paid for by the crown prosecution service at rates up to 34% lower, will be brought up to the new defence levels and from next April a joint scheme will cover both prosecution and defence counsel. The move follows complaints from the CPS and the Bar that the disparity in defence and prosecution rates meant the prosecution often fielded a more junior advocate than the defence.

The changes will not affect the best-paid cases, such as fraud, which can produce earnings of £400,000 a year for a handful of top barristers.

Lord Irvine plans to bring these under control through a system of contracts, and to bring cases lasting up to 25 days into the graduated fees scheme.

Bruce Houlder QC, vice-chairman of the Criminal Bar Association, said: "We welcome the move to create parity between prosecution and defence."

Family law barristers will be brought for the first time under their own fees scheme. At present their pay is assessed by judges after the case is finished.

webTitle: Water cannon turned on Drumcree protest

fields.headline: Water cannon turned on Drumcree protest
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The RUC resorted to water cannon late last night to prevent Orange Order protesters throwing missiles at the police lines during trouble at Drumcree outside Portadown, Co Armagh, for the third night running.
fields.body:
The RUC resorted to water cannon late last night to prevent Orange Order protesters throwing missiles at the police lines during trouble at Drumcree outside Portadown, Co Armagh, for the third night running.

It was the first time water cannon had been used in Northern Ireland for almost 30 years. Two tankers, bought from Belgian police, forced protesters 200 yards back up the hill towards the Church of Ascension after officers came under sustained attack, and a police vehicle was doused in petrol and set alight. But the missile-throwing soon resumed, and intensified.

Police late last night reported gunfire in the Shankill Road area of west Belfast, fiefdom of the Ulster Freedom Force commander, Johnny Adair. His appearance at Drumcree the previous night sparked deep RUC concern.

A lorry was also driven at police lines on the Shankill, but there were no immediate reports of injuries.

There were road blocks across Belfast, bringing much of the city to a halt. Some were peaceful, but in north Belfast, police were pelted with petrol bombs and cars were hijacked and set alight.

Similar demonstrations were taking place in at least five towns across Northern Ireland as loyalists responded to Portadown district master Harold Gracey's call to take to the streets. Three days ago he demanded protests against the Northern Ireland parade commission's decision to ban the Orange Order from the nationalist Garvaghy Road.

Security forces believe there will be further escalation of violence, in the run-up to Sunday, and fear it will culminate in a fatality. They also expect heavy protests at least until July 12, the climax to the Orange Order's marching season.

The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, led criticism of the violence, labelling it thuggery, and said that there would be no change to the commission's decision.

The security forces were taken aback on Monday at the arrival at Drumcree of Mr Adair, who brought with him more than 50 members of the Ulster Freedom Fighters from Belfast. They marched to police lines under a UFF banner wearing white t-shirts with the slogan: "Simply the best: their only crime, loyalty."

It was the first time the mainstream paramilitary organisation had attended Drumcree as a unit in six years of the ongoing wrangle over a march down the nationalist Garvaghy Road.

Mr Adair was later seen with leaders of the renegade Loyalist Volunteer Force, raising fears this year's dispute might prove to be the most violent yet.

Mr Adair, a bystander as LVF masked gunmen later on Monday fired shots into the air after a spokesman in paramilitary uniform outlined support for the Orange Order, insisted he knew nothing in advance of the show of strength.

But he made sure the UFF banner of the 2nd battalion C company was to the fore. His UFF company was behind last month's threat to the ceasefire, claiming nationalists were attacking Protestant homes; the threat was suspended after intervention from the Ulster Democratic Party, allied to the UFF, which yesterday criticised his presence as reckless.

Mr Adair was unrepentant. He said he would be back at Drumcree before Sunday, when the Orange Order's annual march will be halted short of its traditional route of the Garvaghy Road for the third year running. He said he wanted only peaceful protests.

fields.headline: Blind teacher wins £60,000 payout
fields.standfirst:
Tribunal finds for woman made to feel she was 'a burden'

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Tribunal finds for woman made to feel she was 'a burden'
fields.body:
A blind teacher who became "a burden" where she worked has received £60,000 in damages after an employment tribunal ruled that her school broke the law by failing to provide a classroom assistant to help her.

Liz Abbott, who was born with a visual impairment and is registered blind, won her case against St Mary's Roman Catholic primary school in Chingford, east London, after resigning in June 1997 on health grounds due to depression and stress.

Supported by her trade union, the Association of Teachers and Lecturers and with the help of the Royal National Institute for the Blind, Mrs Abbott took her case to the tribunal, which last year ruled that she had been discriminated against because of her disability, and unfairly dismissed.

The tribunal concluded that "Mrs Abbott had become a burden to [her employers] and one they no longer wished to bear". The school lost a subsequent appeal and Waltham Forest local education authority has paid the damages for loss of earnings and injury to feelings.

Speaking in London yesterday where the award was announced, the assocation's solicitor, Sharon Liburd, described how Mrs Abbott, 51, had qualified as a teacher in 1970 and joined St Mary's in 1987, first as a support teacher. The following year, she was given her own class and required assistance to help pupils with their reading and with health and safety.

She was given a classroom assistant, Mrs Thomas, who worked 25 hours a week and whose salary was funded through the disablement employment service. But when Mrs Thomas left, the school made little or no attempt to recruit a replacement, citing "budgetary restraints" as the reason. Mrs Abbott retired on ill health grounds in 1997 after feeling she had become a problem.

The tribunal hearing in Stratford, east London, found the school had breached the Disability Discrimination Act and the Employment Rights Act 1996, failingto ensure she was provided with "reasonable adjustments" so that she could perform her job.

Mrs Abbott said yesterday: "When a statement is made about you being a burden, it makes you feel like a second class citizen. Nobody deserves this kind of treatment.

"It took the decision of an impartial tribunal to prove to me that this whole experience was not my fault. I was beginning to doubt my own abilities not only as a teacher but as a person."

Accompanied by her guide dog, Gavin, she said she felt sad that she was unable to return to teaching, a job she had loved.

Ms Liburd added: "Funding for the assistant's post had been received during the preceding eight years. There was no logical reason for the school to think that funding would not be available for a new classroom assistant."

Catherine Casserley, legal officer with the RNIB, added that Mrs Abbott's problems were not unusual. "Her case shows that unfair and discriminatory practices can be successfully challenged under the Disability Discrimination Act.

"It also demonstrates to employers that retiring an employee on the grounds of ill health rather than giving them the support they need can be subject to legal action."

Waltham Forest said it had reluctantly agreed to settle to limit continuing legal costs.

webTitle: Union chief 'claimed expenses worth fifth of salary'

fields.headline: Union chief 'claimed expenses worth fifth of salary'
fields.trailText: Roger Lyons, general secretary of the Manufacturing, Science and Finance union, claimed nearly a fifth of his salary - some £14,000 a year - in expenses including a claim every time he met Tony Blair or Gordon Brown, an employment tribunal was told yesterday.
fields.body:
Roger Lyons, general secretary of the Manufacturing, Science and Finance union, claimed nearly a fifth of his salary - some £14,000 a year - in expenses including a claim every time he met Tony Blair or Gordon Brown, an employment tribunal was told yesterday.

Marcia Solomon, 32, the former secretary to Nelson Mendes, the union's finance chief, is claiming unfair dismissal under new "whistleblower" legislation. Yesterday she gave evidence on how she uncovered huge numbers of unreceipted expenses claims and was asked to destroy a document giving details of a £4,000 loan to Mr Lyons. She also claimed she saw copies of cheques payable to Mr Lyons and Mr Mendes from fake union branches.

On Mr Lyons's expenses she said: "He seemed to be claiming unreceipted expenditure for food and drink in respect of almost every meeting he at tended, including meetings with Tony Blair and Gordon Brown. I found it bizarre."

She added that she received instructions from Mr Mendes to destroy financial records including "confidential packages paid to departing members of staff and wages reports from Nelson to Roger." She also typed out a "confidential memo" about a £4,000 interest-free loan to Mr Lyons and was then told "to get rid of it".

She claimed later that a secret source contacted her with copies of two cheques payable to Mr Lyons and Mr Mendes. They were drawn on two MSF branches - MSF Daxo and MSF Guildhall. She could find no trace of the branches having any membership. She then found a statement showing that the two branches contained £130,000 in cash but the money in one year had dwindled to £60,000. The account also showed that Mr Lyons had drawn a cheque for £29,000.

The tribunal continues.

webTitle: Train derailed after rain starts landslide

fields.headline: Train derailed after rain starts landslide
fields.trailText: Two hundred rail passengers were last night trapped in a tunnel near Bristol for up to four hours after a landslide caused by torrential rain across the south of England derailed a London to Cardiff commuter train.
fields.body:
Two hundred rail passengers were last night trapped in a tunnel near Bristol for up to four hours after a landslide caused by torrential rain across the south of England derailed a London to Cardiff commuter train.

The engine hit debris, including a tree which had fallen on to the track, throwing passengers to the floor. No one was injured.

A Railtrack spokesman said the landslip, 200 yards from the entrance to the tunnel covered one rail. Earth and vegetation caused the front wheels of the engine to leave the track at 6.10pm, he said. Passengers were escorted up steps at the side of the tunnel to a road where coaches waited.

He said: "The driver of the train came to a controlled stop inside the tunnel and all the carriages remained upright."

One man in his 50s was given oxygen after he complained of respiratory problems.

Sarah Reynolds, a passenger from Pontypridd, said: "The front engine was tilted against the tunnel wall. If the tunnel hadn't been there it would have twisted and two or three carriages would have turned over with it. I think the tunnel worked in our favour."

Alan Townshend, a passenger from Hull, said people were stuck on the train for about "3 hours because we were in a tunnel and had to take the train backwards out of the tunnel and detach the engine."

Flooding caused problems elswhere. In Midhurst, West Sussex, five adults and three children were rescued from their car.

In Washington, West Sussex, two semi-detached houses were set ablaze after lightning struck them.

fields.headline: Branson goes virtual
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson's move into internet-based gas and electricity supply is another launch into cyberspace, taking him away from the kind of physical assets with which he made his name.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson's move into internet-based gas and electricity supply is another launch into cyberspace, taking him away from the kind of physical assets with which he made his name.

Virgin insists that recent investment decisions such as new trains for Virgin Rail underlines a commitment to the old economy, but Branson-watchers say the new Virgin is positioning itself as an "e" player.

Many of Virgin's dot.com companies are expected to grow much faster this year than some of the 11 key older companies, seven of which are losing money.

The yet unproven but possible stars for the future are Virgin Mobile a 50/50 joint venture with One2One and the wholly owned Virgin Active health club side. The 75% owned Virgin Energy enterprise announced yesterday with London Electricity will come under the wholly owned Virgin.com arm.

The net-based booking service, Virgin Trainline.com, is another of the new ventures. It is 51% owned by Virgin and 49% Stagecoach, but again has little in the way of overheads. This compares with his starting point with Virgin Records and his 1984 move into airlines with the launch of Virgin Atlantic.

Two years later Branson raised $44m by taking Virgin Records, Virgin Retail and Virgin Communications public. He then sold the record label to Thorn EMI for $1bn and moved into a range of other businesses as diverse as Virgin Bride, Virgin Cola and Virgin Mobile.

But his businesses continued to enjoy mixed success and 1999 was used to raise more cash by disposing of a 49% stake in Virgin Atlantic to Singapore Airlines and Virgin Radio to Scottish Media. His Our Price record chain has been losing money but so have his financial services arm Virgin Direct, V2 Records and Virgin Bride.

The main companies, Virgin Travel, Virgin Entertainment Group and even Virgin Rail are successful. But it is clear as Sir Richard celebrates his half century that Virgin is planning to build much of its future around the net.

fields.headline: Fire halts Center Parcs sale
fields.trailText: A fire at a Dutch holiday camp has delayed the sale of Scottish & Newcastle's Center Parcs leisure division, which is expected to command a price of around £800m.
fields.body:
A fire at a Dutch holiday camp has delayed the sale of Scottish & Newcastle's Center Parcs leisure division, which is expected to command a price of around £800m.

The news emerged on a bad day for Scottish & Newcastle -the brewing group's market value slumped by £240m amid disappointment about trading in its pubs.

Scottish & Newcastle's chief executive, Brian Stewart, said the fire at the company's De Eemhof holiday village had delayed an auction of Center Parks by "several weeks".

Mr Stewart said that despite the problem, the group hoped to narrow down its shortlist to just one or two buyers next week. Scottish & Newcastle is also selling its Pontin's holidays business, which is likely to fetch a much smaller amount in a deal to be concluded later in the year.

The brewing group's annual pre-tax profits fell 19% to £262m due to exceptional charges of £147m. These one-off items covered reorganisation, redundancies and a £44m write-down in the value of Pontin's. Underlying profits edged up 5% to £409m but the shares slumped 39p to 489p.

Scottish & Newcastle's brewing operations turned in higher profits thanks to booming sales of Fosters, Kronenbourg and Newcastle Brown Ale. The group expressed confidence about a decision from the European commission next week on whether to permit its £470m purchase of French group Danone's brewing division.

Danone is the parent company of Kronenbourg, which Scottish & Newcastle produces under licence in Britain. The move is crucial to the Edinburgh-based group's plans for expansion across Europe.

However, there was disappointment about a 3% fall in like-for-like sales from the group's pubs.

Branded pubs, including the Chef & Brewer chain, did well but the figures were depressed by a poor performance from smaller, local houses.

"This company is all about the imponderable upside of Kronenbourg versus the tangible downside of the tail-end of the pub retailing estate," said Nigel Parsons, an analyst at West LB Panmure.

Another analyst bemoaned the bad news from Center Parcs, which has been a problem for the company for many years.

"Center Parcs has managed to hand them one last disappointment - it's spitting in their eye as it walks out of the door," he said.

fields.headline: Millennium calls for heads
fields.trailText: The embattled International Biotechnology Trust is preparing a last-ditch attempt to defeat an attack by the New York-based Millennium Fund by offering a cash payout to shareholders of at least £90m.
fields.body:
The embattled International Biotechnology Trust is preparing a last-ditch attempt to defeat an attack by the New York-based Millennium Fund by offering a cash payout to shareholders of at least £90m.

Directors of the £270m trust, which invests in drug development firms, face removal at an extraordinary general meeting on Friday convened by Millennium, which wants a shake-up following revelations about poor corporate governance.

In an attempt to appease disgruntled shareholders, the trust last week held out the prospect of a £45m distribution of funds. The board is likely to double this at least, after further discussions with institutions, which have indicated they remain unhappy.

An announcement on the increase could come out as early as today, to pre-empt this afternoon's closing date for proxy votes at the meeting.

The outcome of the vote could still be on a knife-edge because the trust has refused to bow to another demand - that it asks the merchant bank Rothschild to "re-pitch" for its role as investment manager.

The battle between IBT and Millennium has become acrimonious. The trust's principal, Jeremy Curnock Cook, resigned on health grounds last week. He said his heart condition had been aggravated by stress, following revelations from Millennium that he held share options worth more than $1m (£660,000) in bio-tech companies in which the trust had made investments.

The chairman of the trust, Jock Green-Armytage, has spent the past few days negotiating with shareholders, which include Axa Sun Life and AstraZeneca.

Many have privately expressed concerns about corporate governance at the trust, which initially said it was happy with Mr Curnock Cook's share options, but subsequently asked him to give back any profits from them.

Mr Green-Armytage wants to offer institutions such a payout so big that it returns their original investments, effectively giving them a free bet on any future profits.

The rebellion of IBT's shareholders is a rare stand on corporate governance grounds against a company which has turned in a good financial performance - IBT's shares have tripled in a year.

webTitle: Austria plays referendum card against EU partners

fields.headline: Austria plays referendum card against EU partners
fields.standfirst: The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Austria upped the stakes in its response to European Union sanctions yesterday, unveiling plans for a national referendum despite repeated pleas from Brussels and member states not to go ahead with the vote.
fields.byline: Ian Black in Brussels and Kate Connolly
fields.body:
Austria upped the stakes in its response to European Union sanctions yesterday, unveiling plans for a national referendum despite repeated pleas from Brussels and member states not to go ahead with the vote.

The chancellor, Wolfgang Schüssel, announced the decision after six hours of deliberation by a special committee.

Austria's 14 EU partners collectively imposed an unprecedented quarantine in February when Mr Schüssel formed a coalition government with the far-right Freedom party, then led by Jörg Haider.

With France unlikely to lift sanctions during its six-month tenure of the EU presidency, Austria will use its referendum as a way of piling the pressure on a divided EU to find a way out of the impasse.

It has already threatened to delay the institutional reforms needed before the union can enlarge, and there are fears that a referendum will further increase the anti-EU feelings of Austrians.

Vienna demonstrated its capacity for disruption when it blocked a deal on the controversial withholding tax on savings at the EU summit in Feira, saying it could not sign for "constitutional reasons".

As a compromise, Portugal, then holder of the EU presidency, proposed that "three wise men" should report on Austria's commitment to "European values", an approach which infuriated domestic opinion in Austria.

Mr Haider was on the committee which made yesterday's referendum decision. EU countries have been appalled by his past comments sympathetic to aspects of Nazi rule and his party's use of xenophobic slogans in last year's parliamentary election.

The referendum will consist of six questions, starting with: "Should the federal government...ensure by all possible means that the unfairly imposed sanctions on Austria be lifted immediately?"

Subsequent questions, interpreted by observers as opposition to the EU's eastward expansion, include the future form the EU should take and whether it is fair that larger countries can override the will of other states.

Mr Schüssel denied last night that the referendum was tantamount to a veto.

"The topics covered by the questions won't end in a blockade, but quite the opposite," he said, adding that the aim was not to hinder the union. "We only want to change the union in a positive way."

He put forward two possible autumn dates on which the referendum might be held - October 29 and November 26. Parliament will make the final decision Tuesday.

A government spokesman insisted that the referendum would be abandoned if the EU lifted its sanctions before the autumn.

Mr Haider said last night: "I never believed a diplomatic solution would work." He added that he regarded the referendum as a "fair solution". But he said he was confident that the report of the "wise men" would be positive.

Mr Haider, who gave up the nominal leadership of his party, has substantially increased his popularity thanks to the wave of anti-EU sentiment in Austria.

Critics have warned that a referendum is likely to further strengthen his party's position and his future chances of becoming chancellor.

The sanctions are relatively minor measures, such as bans on cultural and sports events and secondary military cooperation accords. Even so, they have humiliated Austria and soured the atmosphere at EU meetings.

Several EU members, including Italy, Ireland, Finland and Greece, have made it clear behind the scenes that they want the sanctions lifted quickly, now that they are seen as ill-considered and hasty.

But France and Belgium, which have their own far-right parties, have taken a much tougher approach.

fields.headline: Baby-flap refuge takes first deposit
fields.trailText: The operators of a controversial drop-off centre for unwanted babies announced last night that they had received and placed their first foundling.
fields.body:
The operators of a controversial drop-off centre for unwanted babies announced last night that they had received and placed their first foundling.

The scheme, which allows unwanted infants to be put through a flap in a door next to a church in Hamburg, has stirred controversy since it was set up in April. The child is placed on a platform, setting off an alarm which alerts volunteers to his or her arrival.

Heidi Kaiser, head of the Findelbaby project, said the first baby to be deposited had been left two months ago. "The little girl is already living with her adoptive parents outside Hamburg," she said.

The organisation waited to make its announcement because mothers can reclaim their children up to eight weeks after abandoning them. After that, efforts are made to place them with a family.

Critics say that the scheme will lead to more infants being abandoned. Supporters have argued that it will save the lives of foundlings who would otherwise die.

Ms Kaiser, who is the mother of four children, started the project after reading of a baby found dead last year on the conveyor belt of a waste-recycling plant in Hamburg.

The infant was one of four abandoned in the city last year, and one of two that died. Around 20 babies are abandoned each year in Germany, and roughly half die.

The Findelbaby project has won the support of the city's Protestant and Catholic bishops. Ms Kaiser said the baby left in May was recovered in seven minutes. It had been born about three weeks early, and the mother had apparently cut the umbilical cord herself, tying it with a piece of string.

Her group plans to set up a second baby slot in Hamburg later this month.

The existing project is expected to cost £50,000 to run. A third of the funding comes from the city council. It is hoped that the rest will come from donations.

Hungary was the first country to inaugurate baby drop-off points, but infanticide is a much more serious problem there than in Germany.

webTitle: Whips offer counselling to Labour MPs facing defeat

fields.headline: Whips offer counselling to Labour MPs facing defeat
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Labour whips, who relish their reputation as the bovver boys of Westminster, have shown their caring side to MPs who usually live in fear of their every move.
fields.body:
Labour whips, who relish their reputation as the bovver boys of Westminster, have shown their caring side to MPs who usually live in fear of their every move.

During quiet moments between late night votes, whips have been taking aside MPs in marginal constituencies to counsel them on their career prospects, ahead of their inevitable defeat at the next general election.

Labour officially insists that it is on course to hold onto its 179 seat majority. But privately, ministerial sources say they will be lucky to come back with a majority of 100.

The new agony uncles of the whips' office, who usually terrify Labour backbenchers with blunt pager messages, have drawn up a list of MPs who will need help to find work after the next election. High-profile MPs in marginal seats, such as Christopher Leslie and Stephen Twigg, will have little difficulty in finding employment. But scores of other MPs in marginal seats are being offered counselling sessions.

The whips, supported by junior ministers, examine the MPs' CVs and advise them on possible careers. Many of the MPs have been put in touch with the industry and parliament trust, a cross-party group that links Westminster and businesses.

"Everybody thinks the whips are bullies," one Labour source said. "But this shows that they have got hearts of gold."

A ministerial source said the counselling sessions were arranged after Millbank revised its projection for Labour's majority down from 100 to 50-60.

"Let's face it - we know we're going to lose seats," the source said. "That means some very good people are going to be out of work, possibly in less than a year."

The whips are focusing on MPs in the most marginal constituencies. Paul Stinchcombe, whose 187 majority at Wellingborough is Labour's smallest, has escaped counselling because he will have no difficulty in resuming his career as a barrister.

But MPs in the next most marginal seats include Eileen Gordon, who was a constituency worker for Tony Banks before scraping home at Romford in 1997 with a majority of just 649; Philip Sawford, who worked as a training manager before winning Kettering with a 189 majority; and Ivan Henderson who was a union organiser before winning Harwich with a majority of 1,216.

webTitle: Let's drink a loyal toast to Dennis Skinner

fields.headline: Let's drink a loyal toast to Dennis Skinner
fields.trailText: The Commons discussed the civil list yesterday. It is an important opportunity for them to ponder one of Britain's longest-lived institutions, which, while held in deep affection by millions, has not yet fully adjusted to the demands of modern life.
fields.body:
The Commons discussed the civil list yesterday. It is an important opportunity for them to ponder one of Britain's longest-lived institutions, which, while held in deep affection by millions, has not yet fully adjusted to the demands of modern life.

Yes, Dennis Skinner was called by the Speaker to give his views on funding for the royal family. It was one of those ceremonial moments that the British do so well, enhanced as ever by Mr Skinner's radiant scowl.

The prime minister had announced that the civil list was to be frozen for the next 10 years because inflation is so low and the Queen has been very economical: no more birthday presents for Fergie.

William Hague had agreed with everything Tony Blair said - always a bad sign - although he did claim credit for the fall in inflation.

Were it not for Tory economic policy, he implied, Prince Charles would be going round selling organic oven gloves.

David Davis startled his fel low Tories by demanding that the civil list be opened to scrutiny. The monarchy was, he said, the last vital check on the executive (in which case the Queen has been doing a rotten job lately).

This was a contrast to the usual salivatingly obsequious Tory speech about the royals, which sounds like a long loyal toast without the booze. Labour MPs muttered with pleasure at this lese-majeste, which a few years ago might have got Mr Davis attacked in the street, perhaps by heavily disguised corgis.

Mr Blair pointed out that the civil list amounted to 0.00% of public spending. "I think there are bigger items we can get our teeth into," he said, and he was right: given that the government spends around £12,500 a second, the royals cost us less than 11 minutes of our national annual income.

Then Mr Skinner was called. The whole house wriggled with anticipation. The ritual is strict and unvarying. Like the Queen, Mr Skinner has his own fixed place in parliament - hers a throne in the House of Lords, his one corner of a Commons bench. He also has his traditional costume: a grey sports coat and scarlet tie, unchanged down the decades.

Like Her Majesty, he is proud of his breeding. His Who's Who entry still records that he comes from "good working-class mining stock". And, like the Queen, he is intensely aware of the symbolic importance he has in our national life.

"This is a pretty big winter heating allowance," he said, with ferocious sarcasm. Happy smiles wreathed the Tory frontbench. "What's so special about this family that they qualify for £7.9m instead of 75p?" he demanded. ("Yeah!" shouted a voice, the equivalent of "Huzzah for Her Majesty!" at another regal occasion.)

"If the prime minister really wants to save money, ship 'em off to the Millennium Dome and they can have a zone apiece."

It didn't quite work, did it? Not really funny enough. But no one cared. Like the Queen Mum, Mr Skinner is a cher ished figure in the great pageant of British life, a golden thread in the tapestry of our history, and we should rejoice that he is still with us.

Later Sir Peter Tapsell tried to rebuke the prime minister. "As New Labour," he said with ineffable grandeur, "tends to cheapen and to vulgawise evewything it touches, will you pwotect the institution of the monarchy _"

Mr Blair pointed out that he had spoken in good faith and had paid tribute to the Queen. "I would have expected a slightly more gracious reply from you."

It was like watching a man attack a rhino with a fly-swatter, and so greatly appealing to us all.

webTitle: Straw to rush through hooligan crackdown

fields.headline: Straw to rush through hooligan crackdown
fields.standfirst: Football violence: special report
fields.trailText: A tough package of emergency powers to tackle football hooligans, including a 10-year ban on travel to foreign matches for "suspected" troublemakers, is to be rushed through parliament by the end of the month, the home secretary Jack Straw said last night.
fields.body:
A tough package of emergency powers to tackle football hooligans, including a 10-year ban on travel to foreign matches for "suspected" troublemakers, is to be rushed through parliament by the end of the month, the home secretary Jack Straw said last night.

The legislation, to be published in draft this Friday, will come too late to save England's bid to stage the 2006 World Cup: the host nation is to be decided in Zurich tomorrow by football's world governing body Fifa, which has been waiting for signs of a new British attempt to tackle hooliganism. But it will save the face of the team making England's final presentation today.

With the government's law and order credentials already tarnished, the home secretary, Jack Straw will find it hard to get the powers onto the statute book by the end of July in the name of getting rid "once and for all of the obnoxious taint of hooliganism".

Although there were signs last night that the Tories and Liberal Democrats would back the emergency bill, it may not make it through the Lords without its most controversial elements being watered down.

The government claims the rush to get the new powers made law before parliament's summer recess lies in the fact that England's next game is against France on September 2 - before MPs reassemble in October.

The main battleground will come over Mr Straw's proposal to give senior police officers the on-the-spot power at an airport or train station to prevent a suspected, but not convicted, football hooligan from travelling abroad if they have grounds to believe they are out to cause trouble. The hooligan would be able to appeal to a court but only once he had been stopped from travelling.

Other measures outlined by Mr Straw included merging domestic and international football banning orders and enabling courts to impose 10-year bans on travelling to football games at home or abroad on those who may have been arrested but not convicted of any offence. The effect is likely to mean that thousands rather than the current 500 orders will be in force. All will have their passports confiscated when England play abroad.

The home secretary justified the stringent nature of the package, saying Euro 2000 demonstrated that the nature of hooliganism had changed. It was no longer confined to a hardcore of troublemakers known to the police but had spread to a larger number of supporters, few of them known to the police in advance.

Of the 965 England fans arrested in Holland and Belgium, only 30 were known football hooligans. Some 409 of them however did have other convictions, including for violence.

"The events in Charleroi and Brussels shamed our national game and our national reputation," said Mr Straw.

The Tories, who have already given a promise of support for any new anti-hooligan measures, last night made it clear clear they would expect other bills to be dropped as the price of votes for a bill that the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, described as having "very serious implications for civil liberties".

But it was clear last night that her hint of Tory cooperation was causing deep internal tensions in her party.

Long-standing Tory supporters of a hooligan crackdown, such as Simon Burns, gave the measures their backing, but senior backbenchers, including Eric Forth, David Davis and Douglas Hogg claimed the measures breached the British principle of innocence until guilt was proven in a court of law.

Reflecting Tory unease over hasty legislation, Peter Ainsworth, the shadow culture secretary said: "We don't want the fiasco of the Dangerous Dogs Act followed by a Dangerous Yobs Act."

Shadow cabinet members said privately that Mr Straw had tabled maximalist demands in the hope that they would split the Tories, ensuring the bill did not reach the statute book by the summer and so leaving the Conservatives to shoulder the the blame for any violence that occurs this autumn or winter.

The Lib Dems offered broad support to Mr Straw but said they wanted the new measures restricted to those with criminal convictions for violence rather than see a new "sus" law put into place.

The Football Association welcomed the package but regretted it had not provided a power to try in British courts those who committed hooligan acts abroad. The police argued they should also have the power to endorse the passports of "those likely to cause trouble" so authorities abroad would know who "may not be conducive to the public good".

But the civil rights organisation, Liberty, protested that Mr Straw was proposing to undermine the presumption of innocence with the use of non-conviction evidence. "The legalisation of 'we know he's going to do it but we can't prove it' should ring alarm bells," said Liberty's director, John Wadham.

The new powers

Police to be given new on-the-spot power to stop suspected troublemakers leaving the country

New 10-year banning orders to prevent hooligans from attending matches at home and abroad

Bans imposed on those convicted of any offence, not just those convicted of football-related crimes - and on suspected troublemakers, even if the evidence falls short of a conviction

Passports will be confiscated when England play abroad

New effort by football authorities to tackle displays of racism. Arrangements for ticketing, travel and stewarding to be examined

The main battleground will come over Mr Straw's proposal to give senior police officers the on-the-spot power at an airport or train station to prevent a suspected, but not convicted, football hooligan from travelling abroad if they have grounds to believe they are out to cause trouble. The hooligan would be able to appeal to a court but only once he had been stopped from travelling. Other measures outlined by Mr Straw included merging domestic and international football banning orders and enabling courts to impose 10-year bans on travelling to football games at home or abroad on those who may have been arrested but not convicted of any offence. The effect is likely to mean that thousands rather than the current 500 orders will be in force. All will have their passports confiscated when England play abroad. The home secretary justified the stringent nature of the package, saying Euro 2000 demonstrated that the nature of hooliganism had changed. It was no longer confined to a hardcore of troublemakers known to the police but had spread to a larger number of supporters, few of them known to the police in advance. Of the 965 England fans arrested in Holland and Belgium, only 30 were known football hooligans. Some 409 of them however did have other convictions, including for violence. "The events in Charleroi and Brussels shamed our national game and our national reputation," said Mr Straw. The Tories, who have already given a promise of support for any new anti-hooligan measures, last night made it clear clear they would expect other bills to be dropped as the price of votes for a bill that the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, described as having "very serious implications for civil liberties". But it was clear last night that her hint of Tory cooperation was causing deep internal tensions in her party. Long-standing Tory supporters of a hooligan crackdown, such as Simon Burns, gave the measures their backing, but senior backbenchers, including Eric Forth, David Davis and Douglas Hogg claimed the measures breached the British principle of innocence until guilt was proven in a court of law. Reflecting Tory unease over hasty legislation, Peter Ainsworth, the shadow culture secretary said: "We don't want the fiasco of the Dangerous Dogs Act followed by a Dangerous Yobs Act." Shadow cabinet members said privately that Mr Straw had tabled maximalist demands in the hope that they would split the Tories, ensuring the bill did not reach the statute book by the summer and so leaving the Conservatives to shoulder the the blame for any violence that occurs this autumn or winter. The Lib Dems offered broad support to Mr Straw but said they wanted the new measures restricted to those with criminal convictions for violence rather than see a new "sus" law put into place. The Football Association welcomed the package but regretted it had not provided a power to try in British courts those who committed hooligan acts abroad. The police argued they should also have the power to endorse the passports of "those likely to cause trouble" so authorities abroad would know who "may not be conducive to the public good". But the civil rights organisation, Liberty, protested that Mr Straw was proposing to undermine the presumption of innocence with the use of non-conviction evidence. "The legalisation of 'we know he's going to do it but we can't prove it' should ring alarm bells," said Liberty's director, John Wadham. The new powers Police to be given new on-the-spot power to stop suspected troublemakers leaving the country New 10-year banning orders to prevent hooligans from attending matches at home and abroad Bans imposed on those convicted of any offence, not just those convicted of football-related crimes - and on suspected troublemakers, even if the evidence falls short of a conviction Passports will be confiscated when England play abroad New effort by football authorities to tackle displays of racism. Arrangements for ticketing, travel and stewarding to be examined

fields.headline: Game over
fields.standfirst: How foreign companies took control of Britain's trailblazers
fields.trailText: The industry is driven by the "Britsoft" creative engine, with about 250 development studios producing games - more than in the rest of Europe put together. However, some of these studios are owned by foreign publishers, and at the publishing level, British companies have been reduced to a minority in the industry. Eidos is one of few UK-owned publishing powerhouses, but it looks likely to go the same way as these famous names:
fields.body:

However, some of these studios are owned by foreign publishers, and at the publishing level, British companies have been reduced to a minority in the industry. Eidos is one of few UK-owned publishing powerhouses, but it looks likely to go the same way as these famous names:

Gremlin

Founded in Sheffield 1984 as a development company which expanded into publishing games. In December 1996, Gremlin purchased Scottish developers DMA Design in a deal worth around £4.2m, taking its employee numbers to 300 at 3 sites. Its titles include the Actua Sports series and Grand Theft Auto. In March 1999 the French publisher Infogrames acquired Gremlin for £24m.

Psygnosis

Based in Liverpool's Wavertree Technology Park, Psygnosis has long been seen as one of Britain's premier software development houses, churning out games for Sony, Sega and PCs. But since 1993 it has been owned by the Japanese console maker Sony, which realised it needed quality content to promote sales. Current products include the Formula One game for Playstation 2. It employs 220 staff, most of whom are in their 20s.

Virgin Interactive Entertainment

Founded by Sir Richard Branson, but run since last year by France's Titus Interactive, which took a majority stake. With offices in Britain, Germany, France, and Spain it was one of the best known names in the industry. However it has fallen on hard times and cut production schedule, especially in the US. It combines licensing and creating games and its brand name is on Resident Evil, Street Fighter, and the Dino Crisis franchises.

webTitle: Lara Croft falls victim to the French as UK loses out in cyber takeovers

fields.headline: Lara Croft falls victim to the French as UK loses out in cyber takeovers
fields.standfirst: Tomb Raider heroine of British success story may end up storming the Bastille
fields.trailText: Lara Croft, the all-action cyber-heroine of the British computer games industry, is on the verge of being captured by the French. Eidos, the company that fathered the hugely popular Ms Croft, looks like becoming the latest high-profile British computer games company to be bought by a foreign competitor after receiving a takeover approach from its French rival Infogrames.
fields.body:
Lara Croft, the all-action cyber-heroine of the British computer games industry, is on the verge of being captured by the French. Eidos, the company that fathered the hugely popular Ms Croft, looks like becoming the latest high-profile British computer games company to be bought by a foreign competitor after receiving a takeover approach from its French rival Infogrames.

The deal is an unlikely ending to one of the British business success stories of the last few years, which saw sales of Lara's Tomb Raider series of games transform Eidos from an obscure Wimbledon-based "video compression" firm into the first indigenous £1bn computer games company.

Last year the World Economic Forum named Eidos the world's most successful company ahead of leviathans such as Boeing, Hewlett-Packard and Merrill Lynch.

Tomb Raider has consistently sat at the top of the sales charts. Lara's iconic status has been confirmed by marketing and advertising campaigns around the world. Her Uzi-toting antics have been splashed across billboards and buses in New York.

Pop videos

She has featured in pop videos, car advertisements in France, exhibits in the Millennium Dome and been subjected to salivating profiles in august US journals. She has even been made an official cultural ambassador and the Hollywood film studio Paramount will shortly release a Tomb Raider film.

Demis Hassabis, chief executive of the games developer Elixir Studios, said it was not just Lara's pneumatic appearance that had proved so popular with gamers of all ages.

"Lara's physical charms are well known but as a female Indiana Jones-type figure she has become the first clearly distinguishable icon of the computer games world," he said.

"She captured the imagination at a time when computer games were becoming mainstream and combined with some great marketing and design has become a globally known figure."

Now British games developers fear that unless City attitudes change towards backing creative talent in the games industry more domestic firms will be lost to overseas competitors.

The games trade association Elspa plans to lobby the government for more support when the minister for tourism, film and broadcasting, Janet Anderson, attends its annual gathering next week.

"It is very, very disappointing to see yet another British games company being sold overseas," said Roger Bennett, Elspa director general.

"This is a domestic creative industry that is bigger than both film and music and yet there is only a handful of British owned publishers left. We are very good at inventing things but we're bloody awful at hanging on to them."

The trend towards overseas sales is well established after Sony's acquisition of the Liverpool-based software house Psygnosis, Nintendo's investment in Rare and Gremlin Group's sale to Infogrames.

Multi-billion dollar firms such as Electronic Arts of the US, Infogrames and Havas Interactive of France and now Microsoft, which is entering the market with a games console of its own, are trawling the British market looking for further acquisitions.

It is not difficult to work out what they are looking for.

Experts reckon that there are 80m PCs in use and 70m games platforms such as the Sony playstation, Nintendo 64 and Sega Dreamcast funding a global computer games market worth more than $17bn.

Games pie

According to Elspa more than £1.4bn worth of computer and video games software was sold in the UK last year, outstripping cinema and video rental receipts.

Britain appears to be taking a healthy slice of the games pie. A quarter of the games bought in Europe originate in the UK, as do 12% of the games bought in the US. The industry now supports about 250 development studios employing 5,600 people directly and indirectly affecting the livelihoods of around 100,000.

In 1998 British developed games generated an export value of £503m exceeding export takings from either British film or TV.

Analysts point out that in France shares in computer games companies such as Infogrames, Havas, Ubi Soft and Titus are given far higher values, enabling them to mount takeover bids for British rivals.

However, it is not hard to find reasons why investors should be wary of the games industry.

It is a "hit-driven" business. A publisher can have a chart-topper in one quarter and nothing in the next year's corresponding quarter, when the product of an 18-month £1.5m development cycle turns out to be a flop.

Other creative industries based on publishing books, records and movies have similar problems. One flop can wipe millions off a company's value.

It is also a cyclical business. Games sales have minor upturns during school holidays and peak at Christmas, which can lead to disaster when games developers miss deadlines, or companies ship products before they are ready.

In the longer term, fortunes rise and fall as successive generations of games technology sweep away earlier ones. The last generation of consoles - where PlayStation battled it out with the Nintendo 64 and Sega Saturn - is starting to be replaced by a new series of consoles.

That means the public will not buy new releases until the consoles are in the shops and that is part of the reason why Eidos's shares have fallen so sharply.

If Infogrames does manage to persuade Eidos directors to accept an offer rumoured to be worth around £700m it will be hoping that it does not get just a one-product company.

Eidos has several high-profile licences in the pipeline: Who Wants to be a Millionaire, Chicken Run and three Disney-related games.

By the time the industry discovers whether they are as popular as Tomb Raider, Lara will probably be storming the Bastille.

Europe led by UK developers

A total of 7.3m UK homes had a computer games console by the end of 1999; 2m bought in that year alone

In Britain the computer games industry is bigger than film and music industry and twice the size of the home video market, generating sales of £1.4bn last year

A quarter of all the games bought in Europe now originate from the UK, as do 12% of the games bought in the US

One of the gaming world's most important cities is Liverpool. About 70% of Japanese computer games are designed within a 30-mile radius of the city

The industry now supports about 250 development studios employing 5,600 people directly and indirectly affecting the livelihoods of around 100,000 people

In 1998 British-developed games generated an export value of £503m - exceeding export earnings from either British film or television

The global market in computer games is now worth more than $17bn

webTitle: Two held as police target paedophiles in hunt for missing girl

fields.headline: Two held as police target paedophiles in hunt for missing girl
fields.trailText: Police hunting the missing schoolgirl Sarah Payne yesterday spoke of a growing possibility that she had been abducted, as they revealed that two men had been arrested and their homes searched in connection with the case.
fields.body:
Police hunting the missing schoolgirl Sarah Payne yesterday spoke of a growing possibility that she had been abducted, as they revealed that two men had been arrested and their homes searched in connection with the case.

Sarah disappeared on Saturday near her grandparents' home in Kingston, near Ferring, West Sussex. Police will continue to question a local man in his 40s, arrested on Sunday, and a man from outside the area in his 30s, who was detained on Monday, amid fears that the girl was seized by paedophiles.

While detectives admitted they were searching the homes of known sex offenders, they refused to disclose whether the two arrested men were on the sex offenders' register or if they were hunting a paedophile ring. They confirmed that more arrests were likely.

"In an inquiry of this size and seriousness, I would anticipate we will be arresting further people," said Detective Superintendent Alan Ladley.

The announcement of the arrests came on the fourth day of the hunt for Sarah, who disappeared at around 8pm on Saturday after playing with her brothers and sister in a cornfield just behind her grandparents' home.

As 100 volunteers joined 150 police officers to scour an extensive area close to the nearby town of Worthing, Mr Ladley said the two men had been arrested to enable police to question them fully and search their homes.

He stressed the arrests did not affect the search for Sarah. "This does not alter the fact that we are still searching for Sarah. We're still desperately trying to recover her alive."

Mr Ladley also indicated that police believe Sarah is being held alive.

"We have to consider the growing possibility that she was abducted...and clearly in tandem with the search for Sarah we are checking to see if we can find any evidence with regard to that abduction.

"Our prime concern is the safety of Sarah. We have to have concerns now that if anyone has Sarah, we don't want to scare them into doing something untoward," he said.

Earlier, the assistant chief constable of Sussex police, Nigel Yeo, said he "refused to give up hope" that Sarah would be found alive. He referred to a case his force dealt with 18 months ago in which two 10-year-old girls were found four days after being seized by a paedophile. In that case, the abductor had already served seven years for indecently assaulting an 11-year-old girl and had been brought to the attention of police just weeks before kidnapping and assaulting the two children.

Referring to the case, in Hastings, East Sussex, in January 1999, Mr Yeo said: "Everyone would have bet a month's salary that the two girls were not alive, but they were.

"My gut feeling was that they were never going to be found alive. We are still looking for Sarah and until we have a reason not to we will still keep looking."

Mr Yeo said divers yesterday searched the last of the wells in the area, and officers had received more than 600 calls from members of the public.

Sarah's parents, Sara and Michael Payne, continued to keep a vigil with their extended family at the house in Kingston, after issuing a plea to any possible kidnappers.

Speaking to Sky News, Mrs Payne, 31, said: "Just bring her home. Drop her at the end of the road. I don't care about you. Let her walk away. Don't be scared and frightened. I just want my baby."
