webTitle: Britain and US accused in spy row

fields.headline: Britain and US accused in spy row
fields.trailText: France, backed by MEPs from most states, has launched an unprecedented investigation into the US-led Echelon intelligence operation, in which Britain is suspected of involvement in worldwide economic espionage.
fields.byline: Paul Webster  in Paris and Ian Black in Brussels
fields.body:
France, backed by MEPs from most states, has launched an unprecedented investigation into the US-led Echelon intelligence operation, in which Britain is suspected of involvement in worldwide economic espionage.

A public prosecutor has ordered the French DST counter-espionage service to build up evidence accusing Washington and London of an attack on the fundamental interests of the nation, it was confirmed in Paris yesterday.

In Strasbourg today, the European parliament is likely to set up a committee to investigate Echelon, despite the opposition of most British MEPs and strenuous lobbying by the UK government.

Jack Straw, the home secretary, was forced to discuss the issue for the first time at an EU meeting last month. He insisted that Britain's involvement in Echelon did not breach EU standards on the interception of communications.

Britain is concerned because the issue has been presented as a choice to be made between loyalty to the US and to Europe - and because intelligence and security matters are normally strictly off-limits for the EU.

Echelon is a vast electronic spying network developed from systems used during the cold war. Based at Fort Meade, in Maryland, its main listening post is run by Britain's Cheltenham-based GCHQ eavesdropping centre. Canada, Australia and New Zealand are also involved.

For months, there have been accusations in France of an Anglo-Saxon conspiracy to spy on Europe's industrial secrets through 24-hour electronic surveillance.

The French say huge contracts have been lost by the Thomson weapons firm and Airbus because of information gathered by the US national security agency (NSA), which oversees Echelon in cooperation with Commonwealth intelligence services.

The NSA, which has a $4bn (£2.7bn) budget, employs 40,000 people who interpret electronically-gathered information from all forms of communications systems throughout the world, including telephones and faxes. French critics have alleged that Echelon is a law unto itself and has no democratic control.

The French investigation was secretly ordered by the public prosecutor, Jean-Pierre Dintilhac, after a complaint by Thierry Jean-Pierre, an MEP and former judge.

Normally an investigation of this type leads to criminal prosecution, but it is not clear if action is aimed at individuals. A DST source said action might be taken against NSA representatives in France, a move that would inevitably have serious diplomatic repercussions.

MEPs were told by the British researcher Duncan Campbell that Echelon had helped the Americans to obtain military contracts with Saudi Arabia that France had expected to win, and had supplied the US aviation firm, McDonnell-Douglas, with financial information on Airbus.

webTitle: Three arrested over murder of family

fields.headline: Three arrested over murder of family
fields.standfirst: Two men and a woman held in year-long search for killer who bludgeoned four people to death
fields.trailText: Two men and a woman were arrested yesterday in connection with the savage murder of three generations of one family at their home in a Welsh village last year.
fields.body:
Two men and a woman were arrested yesterday in connection with the savage murder of three generations of one family at their home in a Welsh village last year.

Police have refused to name those arrested during early morning swoops on three separate addresses in south Wales but it is understood that those being questioned about the crime include two police officers and a former policewoman.

Mandy Power, 34, her mother, Doris Dawson, 80, and her daughters Katie, 10, and Emily, eight, were bludgeoned to death at their home in Clydach, near Swansea. The killer then set the house on fire in an attempt to destroy any clues.

Firemen found the family's battered bodies when they were called to the blazing house in the early hours of June 26 last year.

There has been repeated criticism of the lack of progress in what has become Wales's biggest murder inquiry. Yesterday, following early morning raids on addresses in the Pontypridd and Pontardawe areas, a 38-year-old man and a 33-year-old woman were arrested. They were still being questioned on suspicion of murder last night. A second man, also 38, was held on suspicion of attempting to pervert the course of justice. A number of people linked to two of those arrested were also being interviewed by detectives.

webTitle: Police work on stalling Drumcree violence

fields.headline: Police work on stalling Drumcree violence
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Police in Northern Ireland were preparing plans to scoop up orchestrators of violence at the Orange Order protest at Drumcree outside Portadown, Co Armagh, yesterday after a serious increase in violence ahead of Sunday's restricted parade.
fields.body:
Police in Northern Ireland were preparing plans to scoop up orchestrators of violence at the Orange Order protest at Drumcree outside Portadown, Co Armagh, yesterday after a serious increase in violence ahead of Sunday's restricted parade.

The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, led criticism of hijacking and car-burning which broke out in several areas in support of the Orangemen. He labelled as thuggery attacks on RUC lines at Drumcree, which finally prompted the police to mount a clean-up operation.

The security forces were taken aback at the arrival at Drumcree of loyalist leader Johnny Adair, who brought with him more than 50 members of the Ulster Freedom Fighters from the Shankill Road in Belfast. They marched to police lines under a UFF banner wearing white T-shirts with the slogan "Simply the best: their only crime, loyalty".

It was the first time the mainstream paramilitary organisation had attended Drumcree as a unit in six years of the wrangle over a march down the nationalist Garvaghy Road. Adair was later seen with leaders of the Loyalist Volunteer Force, raising fears that this year's dispute might be the most violent yet.

Adair, a bystander as LVF masked gunmen on Monday fired a volley of shots into the air after a spokesman in paramilitary uniform outlined support for the Orange Order, insisted he knew nothing in advance of the show of strength. But he made sure the UFF banner of the 2nd battalion C company was to the fore.

Adair's UFF company was behind last month's threat to the six year ceasefire, claiming nationalists were attacking Protestant homes. The threat was suspended only after intevention from the Ulster Democratic party, allied to the UFF, which yesterday criticised Adair's presence as wreckless.

Adair was unrepentant. He said he would be back at Drumcree before Sunday, when the Orange Order's annual march will be halted short of its traditional route of the Garvaghy Road for the third year running. Adair said yesterday: "I was in Portadown at the request of the Protestant people - are we going to sit back and let these people trample us into the ground?"

The Ulster Unionist MP Ken Maginnis, using parliamentary privilege, claimed Adair's presence was "more to do with who controls the drugs trade in Northern Ireland than it has to do with God and Ulster". Adair denies involvement.

Adair, 35, was freed last September under the early release scheme of the Good Friday Agreement after serving five years of a 16-year sentence on the unprecedented charge of directing terrorism.

Among other terrorist suspects present during this year's dispute at Drumcree are a man believed to have been involved in the May 1974 Dublin and Monaghan car bombings, when 33 people died. Another is reputed to be the leader of the Orange Volunteers, responsible for a series of sectarian bomb attacks.

According to one Orangeman yesterday, that would persuade many Orange Order members to stay away on Sunday. There are worries in the movement that the Portadown district is tacitly encouraging violence.

David Jones, spokesman for the Portadown Orangemen, denied there was any contradiction in welcoming convicted terrorists to Drumcree while refusing to speak to Breandan MacCionnaith, leader of the Garvaghy Road residents' coalition. He was jailed in 1982 over the bombing of the Royal British Legion.

webTitle: Whoops. There goes the Velcro again

fields.headline: Whoops. There goes the Velcro again
fields.standfirst: A serial streaker reveals all to  Emma Brockes
fields.trailText: A serial streaker reveals all to Emma Brockes
fields.body:
There is a special outfit Mark Roberts wears when he anticipates getting out of his clothes quickly. A customised pair of tracksuit bottoms and a T-shirt, with the former slit up the seams and secured with Velcro, so that it can be ripped off in two fluid moves. He wears his tracksuit bottoms without pants, socks or a sense of impending shame, although slipping into them is always a precursor to appearing naked in front of thousands of people. This week, the Velcro ripped open for the 157th time.

The great British streaker - that quaint tradition of taking off one's clothes in public - made its summer comeback on Monday when Roberts interrupted a doubles match at Wimbledon. The 35-year-old from Liverpool chose the Kournikova-Zvereva contest to make his debut at the All England Club, following successful streaks at St Andrews golf course, Aintree and the gun-dog trials at Cruft's. He had hoped to streak across centre court during one of Kournikova's singles matches, but had to settle for court 14 when she was knocked out early. "I've always liked a good laugh," he says. "Ever since I was small."

Talking to Roberts involves weathering various permutations of "I like a good laugh". He is cheerful in that thumbs-up, Norman Wisdom sort of way, which may strike some as creepy when used by 30-something men to denote a zany sense of humour. His mother, who likes a good laugh, is said by Roberts to be "very proud" of him. His children, two girls aged 11 and three, and a six-year-old boy, have a more complicated relationship with their father's streaking. The 11-year-old lives with her mother and Roberts only sees her "once in a blue moon", although he doesn't connect this with his exhibitionism. The six-year-old finds his father's frequent appearances on the news hilarious. "I don't mean to hurt anyone or offend them," Roberts repeatedly says. So when his children grow up and are totally mortified by him, he'll stop? "I would think greatly about it," he says. "But it's just a good laugh, isn't it? I've always been a joker."

What distinguishes Roberts from the common variety streaker, apart from the fact that he is an unemployed father of three, not a madcap student fulfilling a dare, is his high regard for the "art" of streaking. Unlike amateur streakers, Roberts has evolved a sophisticated routine involving props and body stencilling. He talks about it as his "job", although it makes him no money, since apart from odd shifts as a gardener, a barman and an actor, it is the only activity that defines him. "You have to be professional about it, or else you're just another everyday streaker."

At the Grand National, he donned a cowboy hat, clipped on a gunbelt and a Mexican moustache, daubed the word "rawhide" on his back and streaked across the race course. At St Andrews, he traversed the putting green bearing the legend, "19th hole". And at Cruft's, he came up with the witticism "pedigree bum", and stencilled it across his rump before doing a few laps of the ring. (It was met with stony silence.)

At Wimbledon, he was in two minds over what approach to take. His first notion was to paint "Anna Cover-me-over" across his chest, but this idea lost out to the equally hilarious "Only the balls bounce", a take on the slogan for Kournikova's bra adverts. He painted on the lettering, without the aid of a mirror, in a public toilet, before taking his place for a six- hour wait in the spectator section for court 14.

Roberts says that his only motivation is the adrenalin rush he gets from being cheered on by the crowd, as he is chased about by a red- faced constabulary (there is nothing sexual about this rush, he is keen to emphasise).

His first streak was eight years ago when he was working in a bar in Hong Kong and was dared, by his mates, to disrupt a rugby match between the All Blacks and the Springboks. He was ejected from the stadium, only to get in an hour later and do it again. "I wanted to die, the first time I did it," he says. "But it's like an addiction. I love the publicity. I love the rush of making people laugh. I'd stop doing it straight away if they started booing."

As a child, Roberts wanted to be an actor and in 1987 he made his debut as an extra in Business as Usual, a film featuring Glenda Jackson. But he didn't have the temperament to continue with it and jacked it in soon after. When his first streak made the pages of the Mirror and solicited interviews from TV crews all around the world, he had a rethink. If he could have the celebrity without doing any of the work, then why not grab at it? "I am an actor in a way," he says. "I play myself. I love the attention."

Roberts points out that he has suffered for his art. He once broke his ankle while dashing naked across the set of the Reeves and Mortimer show. And when Chinese authorities in Hong Kong formed a human ring around him, they broke two of his toes with their boots.

These incidents do not overshadow the triumphs of his career. There was the time he streaked across the This Morning weather island, jumping from Wales to Ireland and shaving years off the life of horrified weatherman, Fred Talbot, who tried to shield him with his clipboard. More recently, he made an uninvited appearance on the axed talk show, Vanessa. "Oh my goodness!" exclaimed the ruffled host. "Get away! Could someone come and remove this idiot from the audience please?"

To date, he has streaked at 30 major televised events and run up more than £2,000 in fines. "It's money well spent," says Roberts, who is now looking for a sponsor to pay for him to streak at the Sydney Olympics. Well, he has always been a joker.

fields.headline: Ministers proud of their complacency
fields.standfirst:
Cars crisis is far from over

Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The government yesterday sought to draw a line under its role in the Rover debacle earlier this year. Its response to the trade and industry select committee's report on the events leading up to BMW's decision on March 16 to sell Rover is a model of self-serving, self-exculpating platitudes. Ministers, especially industry secretary Stephen Byers, it says, are off the hook.
fields.body:
The government yesterday sought to draw a line under its role in the Rover debacle earlier this year. Its response to the trade and industry select committee's report on the events leading up to BMW's decision on March 16 to sell Rover is a model of self-serving, self-exculpating platitudes. Ministers, especially industry secretary Stephen Byers, it says, are off the hook.

But are they? Recent events, most notably Nissan's threats, show that the story is far from over. The issues raised by BMW three months ago about the strength of sterling, competitiveness and Britain's very commitment to manufacturing remain unresolved. The takeover of the Longbridge plant by the Phoenix consortium, the government said yesterday, "offers good prospects both for continued volume manufacture" and "for the retention of jobs".

But that brings a host of questions, not least whether Phoenix can deliver on its pledge to produce around 200,000 units a year of the model range bequeathed by BMW and introduce new models in a European market awash with cars chased by too few buyers.

The government professes itself pleased, too, at the sale of Land Rover to Ford, but the division's new chief executive, Bob Dover, has said this week that Britain is "a very bad place to make cars" because of the pound, poor transport infrastructure and high fuel costs.

David Botterill, the Engineering Employers' Federation chief executive in the West Midlands, said a quarter of his members, or 400 companies, supplied the automotive industry and their output remained at risk because of the pound and uncertainty surrounding Rover.

The government says the immediate threat to suppliers has receded with Phoenix. This seems grotesquely complacent when tens of thousands of jobs, in marginal constituencies, are at stake.

Forget the leaks from senior civil servants and ambassadors; this government needs to make clear its intentions towards manufacturing and its role in the modern economy. That means, as with everything else these days, its intentions towards the euro.

Price pumpers
The price of London Brent fell less than a dollar yesterday following Saudi Arabia's unilateral decision to turn on the crude production taps. The stock market rightly saw this as the end of a period of sky high oil prices and punished the oil companies accordingly.

Riyadh's initiative came ten days after the Organisation for Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed to make token cuts which failed to move the markets.

The price is currently still well short of the OPEC target figure of $25, remaining three times the level of 18 months ago. It was when the crude oil price hit rock bottom that the Opec nations imposed production restrictions in order to inflate the price.

Prices above $30 per barrel are good news for the desert kingdoms' coffers but cause political conflict with the Saudis' biggest customer and strategic defence ally, the US.

While the move was being interpreted as a willingness to please its American friends, self-interest was also very much part of the Saudi strategy. The Saudis sit on the biggest oil reserves in the world and are keen to retard growth in the use of alternative energy resources such as gas and renewables.

They also want to avoid rivals searching far and wide for their own new sources of oil, particularly in areas such as the Caspian sea, off Brazil and Angola.

Both the US and Mexico claimed prior knowledge of the Saudi decision, whereas Middle East neighbours such as Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates complained that they had been kept in the dark. Some in the west interpreted this as a deliberate snub, but wiser heads put it down to Saudi diplomatic ineptitude. Certainly Saudi oil minister Ali al-Naimi was working hard later on to sooth his Opec colleagues' ruffled feathers.

Al-Naimi said that, if the price did not decrease, Saudi and other producers would increase production by another 500,000 barrels.

In fact only Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the UAE have the power to increase output anyway. Other Opec countries are close to capacity.

Still the manner of the Saudi announcement - by-passing Opec channels - will undermine the oil cartel while emphasising the world's biggest oil producer's willingness to go it alone.

The US vice-president, Al Gore, was quick to congratulate the Saudis. Washington has been putting increasing pressure on the kingdom after taking flak from consumers at a sensitive time, with the presidential elections looming. American motorists are now wrestling with record high gasoline costs.

The US government has even been looking at tax cuts to reduce the pump price. It would be safe to assume the British government is not contemplating a similar move.

fields.headline: Jellyworks opens door to merger
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Jellyworks, the internet investment vehicle that has seen its shares slump amid waning interest in new economy stocks, said yesterday that it is in talks which could lead to it merging with investment bank Shore Capital.
fields.body:
Jellyworks, the internet investment vehicle that has seen its shares slump amid waning interest in new economy stocks, said yesterday that it is in talks which could lead to it merging with investment bank Shore Capital.

Shares in the company rose 5p to 39.5p after it said that "preliminary discussions are ongoing with Shore Capital Group which may or may not lead to an all-share offer".

Jellyworks is also understood to have held talks about forging a three-way merger with Durlacher and Value Management Research, the German internet firm in which it owns a 20% stake.

The company said it was considering its options "in the context of the general consolidation within the sector". It has a £2m stake in Shore. Other investments include shares in Sportal, Antfactory and Beenz. Privately owned Shore is thought to have close links with the Israeli high-technology sector.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Jean Harlow: The Blonde Bombshell | Robin And Marian | The Game | Vengeance Is Mine
fields.body:
Jean Harlow: The Blonde Bombshell
9.30am, TCM

Sharon Stone leads this review of the original platinum blonde's full-throttle career. Her elopement aged 16 was an early warning sign, and her subsequent discovery by Howard Hughes paved the way for an even more tempestuous private life and status as Hollywood's number one sex symbol. Despite the off-screen melodrama, she found time to build an illustrious career, usually paired with Clark Gable. Their final outing, Saratoga, during which she died of kidney failure, plays afterwards.

Steve Rose: Robin And Marian
(Richard Lester, 1976)

6pm, FilmFour

Lester is in wistful, elegiac mood in this account of the Robin Hood legend. Sean Connery's weary Robin returns from the crusades to confront Robert Shaw's sheriff of Nottingham once more, but despite their heroic final duel, it's Connery's scenes with Audrey Hepburn as a middle-aged Marian that make the magic; Nicol Williamson, too, is a touchingly faithful Little John.

The Game
(David Fincher, 1997)

8pm, Sky Premier

Fincher's follow-up to Seven is not as violent, but is a similarly unsettling thriller. It pitches a stinking rich investment banker into a Kafkaesque world in which his life is gradually wrecked by a mysterious game, with no apparent rules. An intriguing premise, and Michael Douglas makes the most of his hero/victim role, with Sean Penn the flakey brother leading him into the mess.

Vengeance Is Mine

(Shohei Imamura, 1979)

1.55am, FilmFour

This little-seen Japanese thriller is an interesting addition to FilmFour's Killing Time season. It starts like a standard true crimes policier: two bodies found in the undergrowth, the cops taking notes and closing in on the killer. But through a series of flashbacks Imamura draws a complex portrait of real-life multiple murderer Iwao Enokizu (played with hatchet-faced anger by Ken Ogata), his flashes of terminal violence driven by hatred of his father.

fields.standfirst: What sunbathers are watching on television
fields.trailText: What sunbathers are watching on television
fields.body:
Nicky Fellows: "Big Richard and Judy fan really. I watch it when I'm not at college. I told my boyfriend that he should dress more like Richard. He's a lot scruffier. He's not a suave... ho, what other programmes? Well, I really like the repeats of This Life. I really fancy Egg from This Life. He can chop my basil anytime. I do tend to watch only people I fancy on TV."

Claire Lumsden: "Ronnie Barker (looks a bit mad). We've just been talking about his utter genius. A great man, love Porridge. Comic genius, but how much was Corbett part of the magic? Yes, I have these conversations all the time. I love older men. Sid James, ha ha. New programmes? Er, League Of Gentlemen. Fantastic. Phwor!"

Richie Ellens: "Me? Er, I try not to watch too much TV. I like reading and seeing friends around the country. Last programme I watched? Er, well I don't get glued to Friends. I'll tell you. I like more conspiracy documentaries... MI5, war stuff, world-bank updates. Hate Kilroy. I hate most of it. I'm in a band. I'd rather do that."

Sam Hitchenson: "Heh! We were just talking about getting a TV makeover because I'm getting married in a couple of months and I want to look good. Got to lose a bit of weight, hair done... I like nature programmes, the Fast Show, Friends, TFI Friday... Will that do?"

Kai Min: "Um, who is this for? I'm not sure I can say what I like... can I remember? Pet Rescue? No, don't like that. Collectors' Lot? No, haven't seen it. EastEnders. No, no , I don't like anything. I like music."

fields.headline: The boys from Brazil
fields.trailText: Michelle In Brazil | TV To Go | Silence Of The Sea Lions
fields.body:
Michelle Collins had no illusions about her role as an Oxfam ambassador to Brazil. "Sadly, things have become quite celebrity-based", she said in Michelle In Brazil (BBC1), with an understatement worthy of Gentlemen Prefer Blondes. "But if it takes someone like me to get people to watch, so be it." Collins was packed off to Recife, a big city in north-eastern Brazil, to meet the children who prefer life (and death) on the streets to poverty and abuse at home. She started off in brisk, matter-of-fact mode, but by the time she'd met Julio, an ethereally beautiful child, the only survivor of four brothers (one died of fever, two were shot by vigilantes), the façade was slipping. Julio, like most of the street kids, was stoned out of his mind on glue, and faced the prospect of a short life and brutal death with solvent-based equanimity.

For the parents living in the favelas, life was a long, exhausting round of anxiety and bereavement. Collins met and comforted one frantic mother, who waited every day for news that her daughter was dead, but was swiftly bundled out of the slum quarter as rumours of a nearby gunman sent residents rushing back into their huts. "I feel sick", said Collins, recovering in the back of the van. This was clearly not going to be one of those charity reports that harps relentlessly on the uplifting.

Things took a turn for the better when Collins and her attendant press pack journeyed inland to meet the Xucuru Indians, who were living in a permanent roadblock in protest against the confiscation of their land. Marcinhos, the 21-year-old chief of the tribe, was blessed with film-star good looks and sported a covetable feather outfit, but calmly expected to be gunned down at any moment - just like his father was, two years ago.

The show ended on a happyish note, with Collins playing football with the bright-eyed residents of a children's community based on a local farm, where street survivors come to kick glue and eat some decent food. "This was my salvation", said 16-year-old Oscar, who had lived through unspeakable horrors. "Now I feel free, like a bird." Collins could barely tear herself away, and the rest of us were left holding our breath for this fragile moment of hope in an otherwise grim picture. Michelle In Brazil was a cut above its usually cheesy genre. Quite why the BBC1 schedulers hid it away at 11.20pm remains a mystery, particularly when the previous slot was occupied by something as hit- and-miss as TV To Go.

TV To Go (BBC1) was a pilot, or "one-off" as we must call them these days, that rounded up some of the brightest comic talents around in the hope that they'd be even funnier in a group. We waited in joyous hope of laughs that just didn't come. All the performers - including Bill Bailey, Pauline McLynn and Hugh Dennis - have the proven ability to be funny just by walking on to the screen, but their material let them down. Jokes about mobile phones have to be pretty special to cut it these days - and these weren't. A promising sketch about supermarket loyalty cards went on too long, as did a joke about a church website. There were some fine moments - two dreadful holiday-makers boring the pants off a bemused barman by talking about car insurance, for instance, and a good joke about smoking rooms - but in a show like this you need machine-gun laughs, not the occasional chuckle. With a bit of fine-tuning, TV To Go could take on The Fast Show or even Smack The Pony.

Anyone feeling in need of an antidote to euphoria - French football fans, for example - would have found the ideal prescription in Silence Of The Sea Lions , a grim offering from National Geographic. Remember those Disney wildlife films, where fluffy chicks made friends with baby lambkins? Well this was the exact opposite. The sea lions of Alaska are dying out, probably because we have overharvested the waters of the north Pacific. But it was hard to empathise much with the creatures, as they routinely killed pups and slashed each other to ribbons. We watched in horror as one newborn infant was tossed around by a group of adults, and finally had its brains dashed out on the rocks while its mother bellowed impotently nearby. The absurdly portentous voice-over - "Many Will Never Return!" - was the final straw in a debilitatingly miserable piece of television.

webTitle: Hague promises to set schools free

fields.headline: Hague promises to set schools free
fields.standfirst:
Education Unlimited
Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: The next Conservative government, William Hague vowed last night, "will defeat once and for all the attitudes that are holding back our education system and we will set Britain's schools free".
fields.body:
The next Conservative government, William Hague vowed last night, "will defeat once and for all the attitudes that are holding back our education system and we will set Britain's schools free".

In a speech to the Politeia thinktank in London, the Tory leader fleshed out his "free schools" plan to liberate parents, pupils and schools from the constraints of local and central government.

But those he wants to set free gave the speech a mixed response, questioning whether they would be more free, and whether they wanted the freedom that was promised. Margaret Morrissey of the National Confederation of Parent Teacher Associations said: "It's choice if you are an upwardly mobile parent with lots of money who can pay for the school uniform, with a bright child, who knows how to play the system. If you are not well off and you have got children with special needs, you have got no choice at all."

Under Mr Hague's plan, popular schools would prosper, and poor ones sink. Restrictions on expanding popular schools would be abolished. "Parents will be free to apply to whichever school can best bring out the potential of their child. Government money will then follow the pupil," he said.

Where parents were not satisfied, under a "parents guarantee" they could call for a special Ofsted inspection. If the inspectors agreed with the parents, new school management would be found.

Value-added tables, which enable parents to measure progress, and key stage one results at age seven, kept secret up until now, would be published.

"Every parent wants his or her child to have a good education. Yet every morning, tens of thousands of parents wave goodbye to their children knowing that those children are going to a bad school. And they also know that there is absolutely nothing that they can do about it, because power in our education system rests with local education authorities and Whitehall bureaucrats," Mr Hague said.

Tony Travers, a local government expert at the London School of Economics, said it was a "very urban" solution. "If you live in Birmingham, Manchester or London there are all kinds of schools. If you are on Anglesey, the Isle of Wight or in Cumbria the idea that there is much of a choice even of secondary schools is romantic."

Mr Hague would make it easier for heads to exclude pupils, particularly for flouting school uniform regulations - a proposal welcomed by John Dunford of the Secondary Heads Association. Exclusion targets would be abolished, and more money used to fund "progress centres" for excluded children.

Overall, with funding direct from central government to schools, rather than via a local education authority, Mr Hague said, "head teachers and governors will then be free to manage their own budgets, free to employ their own staff, free to set their teachers' pay, free to determine their own admissions policy, free to run their own school transport, free to manage their own opening hours and term times, and free to set and enforce their own standards of discipline."

But there would still be a national curriculum, albeit in a slimmed down version. The literacy and numeracy hours would stay. Chris Woodhead, the head of Ofsted, would have more powers. "I do not just praise his work, I propose to build on it," said Mr Hague. Inspections would take place "with little or no notice".


Some heads not keen to assume extra powers

It may seem strange to William Hague, but some head teachers do not necessarily want the extra powers he would give them.

He wants to take £4bn in money and responsibility from central government (£1bn) and local govern ment (£3bn) and give it to head teachers - £540 per pupil in England.

Some of that money - the Labour party estimates £560m - will come from taking over powers for running school transport.

But David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teach ers, said: "I don't honestly believe that the vast majority of schools want to run their own transport."

Under Mr Hague's plan, LEAs would retain control of special educational needs and the educational welfare service and, Tory education spokeswoman Theresa May said, support ing failing schools, at a cost of £500m a year. Funding would go direct from government to schools under a national funding formula.

Heads like the idea of national funding but many believe councils do have a role and are reluctant to see their responsibilities reduced still further.

fields.headline: Retail banks
fields.trailText: Consumers might applaud the prospect of a price war among the major banks but investors in their shares are far from excited.
fields.body:
Consumers might applaud the prospect of a price war among the major banks but investors in their shares are far from excited.

None of the banks that have been in and out of favour with the stock market of late was able to end the day in positive territory yesterday.

Alliance & Leicester took the biggest drubbing; it was the second worst performer in the FTSE 100, losing 33p to 557p.

But, just when things looked bleak for the banks, some respite appeared in the shape of analysts at Deutsche Bank.

While analysts see the decision by HSBC to cut almost one percentage point off its standard variable rate as the advent of a full scale price war, they still see reasons to buy some of their shares.

For a start, a price war among the majors will make life more difficult for the new upstarts who will find it harder to undercut the established players.It is also a long predicted phenomenon that has held back the share price performance of some of the so-called mortgage banks.

This is why the analysts see value in Abbey National's shares below 800p (746p yesterday). The value they see in Halifax's shares is under 550p, just below the 588p they were trading at yesterday. The bleak news is for Lloyds TSB, once the doyen of the banking sector and now finding it harder to please investors.

The analysts write that the price wars are less likely to have been priced into the shares of the broader commercial banks, such as Lloyds, HSBC and Barclays. Their position cannot be helped either by the brutal attacks by the mortgage banks on their core current account business.

Deutsche's analysts do not expect the price war to erupt just yet. It might need another lender such as Royal Bank of Scotland or Barclays to enter the fray before the big boys like Lloyds, Abbey or Halifax sit up and take notice.

Even then, they might find it easy to reduce their standard variable mortgage rate because they know that most home loans involve fixed or discounted products.

webTitle: New drug provides irritation for Glaxo

fields.headline: New drug provides irritation for Glaxo
fields.standfirst: Market forces  Neil Hume
fields.trailText: Shareholders in Glaxo Wellcome should beware some irritating news: Lotronex, its drug for irritable bowel syndrome, is unlikely to become the kind of blockbuster the company was hoping for.
fields.body:
Shareholders in Glaxo Wellcome should beware some irritating news: Lotronex, its drug for irritable bowel syndrome, is unlikely to become the kind of blockbuster the company was hoping for.

The market for treating the disease has long been seen as an El Dorado for the drug industry. Irritable bowel syndrome is a chronic disease that affects a fifth of adults.

Peaks sales were expected to run into hundreds of millions of pounds and Glaxo, which claimed to be the first to market with an effective treatment, stood to be one of the main beneficiaries.

But concerns about Lotronex have refused to go away ever since a number of patients using the drug were taken to hospital suffering from constipation and ischemic colitis - a condition blocking blood supply to the colon.

Although a panel of experts convened by the US food and drug administration earlier this year to examine the drug decided that it did not have to carry the dire "black box" safety warning, concerns have remained. So much so, that yesterday analysts at Charterhouse Securities slashed its peak sales forecast for the drug to £150m from £600m.

News of the downgrade was enough to knock 27p off Glaxo shares, which finished the day at £19.81.

According to Charterhouse, sufficient uncertainty will develop around the risk-reward benefit of the drug to damage its prospects permanently.

While undoubtedly affecting quality of life, there are no associated health concerns with irritable bowel syndrome. In contrast, ischemic colitis, which appears to be associated with the drug, may be life threatening, and faced with this risk-reward profile GPs were likely to be worried about prescribing it, Charterhouse said.

Nevertheless, when set against the bigger picture of Glaxo's merger with SmithKline Beecham, the problems with Lotronex seem to be insignificant. Charterhouse, for example, still retains a "buy" rating on the stock.

And with the volatility in the global equity markets continuing, the defensive qualities of Glaxo Wellcome and the rest of the pharmaceutical sector are likely to prove attractive for investors of all sizes.

The market for treating the disease has long been seen as an El Dorado for the drug industry. Irritable bowel syndrome is a chronic disease that affects a fifth of adults. Peaks sales were expected to run into hundreds of millions of pounds and Glaxo, which claimed to be the first to market with an effective treatment, stood to be one of the main beneficiaries. But concerns about Lotronex have refused to go away ever since a number of patients using the drug were taken to hospital suffering from constipation and ischemic colitis - a condition blocking blood supply to the colon. Although a panel of experts convened by the US food and drug administration earlier this year to examine the drug decided that it did not have to carry the dire "black box" safety warning, concerns have remained. So much so, that yesterday analysts at Charterhouse Securities slashed its peak sales forecast for the drug to £150m from £600m. News of the downgrade was enough to knock 27p off Glaxo shares, which finished the day at £19.81. According to Charterhouse, sufficient uncertainty will develop around the risk-reward benefit of the drug to damage its prospects permanently. While undoubtedly affecting quality of life, there are no associated health concerns with irritable bowel syndrome. In contrast, ischemic colitis, which appears to be associated with the drug, may be life threatening, and faced with this risk-reward profile GPs were likely to be worried about prescribing it, Charterhouse said. Nevertheless, when set against the bigger picture of Glaxo's merger with SmithKline Beecham, the problems with Lotronex seem to be insignificant. Charterhouse, for example, still retains a "buy" rating on the stock. And with the volatility in the global equity markets continuing, the defensive qualities of Glaxo Wellcome and the rest of the pharmaceutical sector are likely to prove attractive for investors of all sizes.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Poor performances from two heavily-weighted oil stocks and further selling of the battered banking sector brought to a close two days of strong gains for the FTSE 100 on Tuesday.
fields.body:
Poor performances from two heavily-weighted oil stocks and further selling of the battered banking sector brought to a close two days of strong gains for the FTSE 100 on Tuesday.

With Wall Street shut for the Independence Day holiday, the FTSE 100 closed a quiet session 53.4 points lower at 6,417.0. The FTSE 250, Small Cap and TechMark indices all closed higher but gains were limited.

BP Amoco, down 18p at 630p, and Shell, off 15.5p at 555p, were the main factors behind the weakness of the blue chip index. Both were unsettled by Saudi Arabia's pledge to begin pumping a fur ther 500,000 barrels of oil a day. BP also suffered from a downgrade from SG Securities, which cut its target price to 650p from a previous figure of 700p.

Second-tier oil stocks were also out of favour after Dresdner Kleinwort Benson lowered its recommendations on number of oil exploration and production stocks. Worst affected were Lasmo, which fell 8p to 131.5p, and Enterprise Oil, which retreated 21p to 525p.

The banking sector had another tough session following Monday's decision by HSBC to slash nearly 1% off its basic mortgage rate which continued to undermine investor sentiment.

In the wake of that news, which many observers said could prompt a full scale price war, analysts at Deutsche Bank issued sell advice on Alliance & Leicester, down 33p to 557p, Woolwich, 3p lower at 272p, and Lloyds TSB, off 14.5p at 604.5p. Barclays was also hit, giving back 60p to stand at £15.90p.

But Scottish & Newcastle walked away with the FTSE 100's wooden spoon falling 39p to 489p as investors took fright at the full year figures and news that its core pubs business has struggled to make headway.

On the upside, Dixons advanced 15.75p to 280p, as buyers moved in ahead of full year figures due today.

Hilton shrugged off recent underperformance with a gain of 10p to 233p. Dealers said that a buy note from Deutsche Bank was responsible for the move.

Lower down, Eidos shot up 45.75p to 538p on speculation that the French group Infogrames is set to pounce on the creator of the computer game heroine Lara Croft with a 700p a share bid.

The biotech company Cambridge Antibody also shone, notching up a gain of 237.5p to £32.10p after victory in a key patent dispute.

Meanwhile on AIM, Jellyworks appreciated 5p to 39.5p after it disclosed that it was in preliminary take-over discussions with the stockbroker Shore Capital.

fields.headline: Mergers will hit record
fields.trailText: Corporate financiers, the marriage brokers to big companies, took a pause for breath over the second quarter when dot.com stocks fell out favour. Despite this surprise, the industry is on track for a record level of deals by the end of the year.
fields.body:
Corporate financiers, the marriage brokers to big companies, took a pause for breath over the second quarter when dot.com stocks fell out favour. Despite this surprise, the industry is on track for a record level of deals by the end of the year.

This means the bankers at the predominantly US-owned finance houses can also expect another round of healthy bonuses after an unprecedented wave of mergers and acquisitions by big companies around the world.

Thomson Financial Securities, the media group which compiled the data, said that even though levels had fallen back in the second quarter such a momentum had built up for deals that activity in the next half of the year will not be knocked off track by "jittery stock markets".

While the value of deals in the second quarter of the year took a 32% dive from the record $1.12 trillion (£741bn) in the first three months of the year - primarily because corporate finance activity slackened off in the US - when combined with the first three months stood at a record level.

More than $1.88 trillion of transactions were recorded in the first half, a 26% rise on the already record levels of 1999 and 6% higher than 1998.

Five of the top six deals which took place during the half were in media, telecoms and technology.

Much of the slackening in pace in the second quarter followed a reduction in activity followed the jitters over dot.com stocks and larger and larger attempts to raise financing by telecoms compa nies.

But activity in Europe remained as frantic as ever, with the value of deals reported at $298bn, barely changed from the $303bn over the first three months.

Goldman Sachs, the US investment bank, topped the tables for all deals conducted across the world, closely followed by Morgan Stanley and Merrill Lynch.

In Britain, the positions were reversed, with Merrill Lynch taking a 43% share of the mergers and takeovers conducted and Goldman Sachs taking second place.

In a league dominated by US-owned investment banks, two European banks, Dresdner Kleinwort Benson and UBS Warburg, took third and fourth place, positions which would have been reversed if Dresdner had completed its planned merger with Deutsche.

No British-owned investment bank figured in the top 10 advisers to British companies although Solomon Smith Barney, which now owns Schroders, was ranked eighth.

fields.headline: High flyer backs £60m bio-chicks
fields.trailText: Nigel Wray, the high-profile City financier, has emerged as a key backer of the biotech firm TranXenoGen, which is joining Aim with a market capitalisation of £60m.
fields.body:
Nigel Wray, the high-profile City financier, has emerged as a key backer of the biotech firm TranXenoGen, which is joining Aim with a market capitalisation of £60m.

TranXenoGen specialises in altering the genetic make-up of chickens to make them produce useful proteins in their eggs. It believes it has found a way to make insulin in egg whites.

Mr Wray, who used to chair Nottingham Forest, was introduced as an investor in 1998 by TranXenoGen's chairman, Kim Tan. He was part of a group which has injected $3m into the business over two years. After the flotation, his 10% stake will be worth £6m.

TranXenoGen's chief executive, Steve Parkinson, said: "Nigel's a gentleman I have a lot of respect for. He's a far-sighted guy and he saw some potential here."

Mr Wray made his name as a property developer, chairing Burford Holdings and is on the board of several companies in cluding Domino's Pizza, and the Hartford restaurant business. He was one of the "awesome foursome" behind Knutsford, the penny stock which became an e-business venture.

There has been controversy over the timing of his sale of shares in Columbus, a publishing company. It recently issued a profits warning and is being investigated on competition grounds by the DTI. Mr Wray has strenuously denied any knowledge of the profits warning or the DTI inquiry at the time he sold the shares.

Mr Wray is a long-term associate of Kim Tan, who is one of Britain's wealthiest biotech entrepreneurs with a paper fortune of more than £300m. He was an investor before the flotation of another of Dr Tan's companies, KS Biomedix.

TranXenoGen, which is based in the US, has raised £11.5m in its placing of shares.

The shares are expected to begin trading on AIM on July 18 and have been priced at 200p by the broker WestLB Panmure.

fields.headline: Signs of recovery
fields.standfirst: Bank of Japan's survey shows improved confidence
fields.trailText: As shoppers walked through the Shibuya district of Tokyo yesterday, new figures indicated a sharp upturn in business confidence. The Bank of Japan's "tankan" survey showed a majority of major manufacturers are upbeat about the economy for the first time since the recession struck in 1997. And it looks inevitable that the central bank will raise interest rates for first time in 10 years.
fields.body:
As shoppers walked through the Shibuya district of Tokyo yesterday, new figures indicated a sharp upturn in business confidence. The Bank of Japan's "tankan" survey showed a majority of major manufacturers are upbeat about the economy for the first time since the recession struck in 1997. And it looks inevitable that the central bank will raise interest rates for first time in 10 years.

The resurgence of export markets in Asia and signs of a domestic recovery have brightened the outlook for big corporations such as Sony, Toyota and Toshiba.

It appears that Japan's economy is now pulling out of its worst recession since the second world war. The unemployment rate has dropped from a record high, salaries are rising and exports are strong.

Revised figures for corporate investment last year are expected to show an increase of 2.3% - the first rise in two years.

"The tankan supports our view that the economy is on a sustainable recovery track," said Peter Morgan, senior economist at HSBC who forecasts that Japan's output will grow 2.5% this fiscal year.

webTitle: Bidder walks out of Hamleys talks

fields.headline: Bidder walks out of Hamleys talks
fields.trailText: A disagreement over price has aborted takeover talks between Charterhouse Development Capital and Hamleys, Britain's most famous toy shop.
fields.body:
A disagreement over price has aborted takeover talks between Charterhouse Development Capital and Hamleys, Britain's most famous toy shop.

Charterhouse walked away after Hamleys' chairman, Howard Dyer, demanded a price of at least 200p a share, valuing the business at £42m.

Insiders say the venture capital firm was prepared to pay little more than 170p a share. One source said: "It was obvious they weren't going to come up with anything beginning with a two. The Hamleys board feel they couldn't get anything lower than that past the shareholders."

Charterhouse's proposal would have involved Hamleys' chief executive, Simon Burke, remaining with the company. He was therefore considered "on board" the takeover and was not involved in the board's decision to reject it. Hamleys' shares dived 26.5p to 141.5p.

Analysts said Charterhouse's approach could provoke interest from alternative bidders. Philip Green, the retail entrepreneur who recently bought Bhs, was again mentioned as a possible buyer yesterday but he has denied looking at Hamleys, saying he has "too many other toys to play with".

Any new bid is likely to come either from another venture capital firm or from a foreign company. Other high street chains are likely to be put off by the effort needed to turn around the business, and the limited scope for expansion; Hamleys' satellite stores have been generally unsuccessful.

Richard Ratner, an analyst at Seymour Pierce, said: "It's not the sort of thing that would attract the big retailers. It's just a trophy."

Mike Godliman of the retail consultancy Verdict said: "They've got a world renowned brand and their store is considered a big destination. Those things are worth a hell of a lot of money."

But Hamleys has been hampered in recent years by poor store design and a shift in demand from traditional toys to electronic games.

fields.headline: Mobile mania
fields.standfirst:
Yet the net phone boom has barely started

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: To call it mobile mania would be an understatement. Over 50% of Britons now own a mobile - a staggering 85% above the same time last year - with analysts predicting that penetration will be 60% by the end of the year. It is quite possible that in a few years time it will hit 80%.
fields.body:
To call it mobile mania would be an understatement. Over 50% of Britons now own a mobile - a staggering 85% above the same time last year - with analysts predicting that penetration will be 60% by the end of the year. It is quite possible that in a few years time it will hit 80%.

The ubiquity of the mobile is already changing relationships. Parents can no longer eavesdrop on what their children are up to through the fixed link, but they bond through knowing where their children are and through text messaging. For youngsters it brings back the herd instinct as they head out alone, meeting up later after messaging.

And we haven't seen the start of it. The new Wap (wireless application protocol) phones linked to the internet are slow, often incompatible, and very flaky in performance - but interesting applications are emerging. You can get instant news, live share prices, plus step-by-step directions to the nearest cash machine or pizza parlour. During the next few years, as phones get smarter and faster - and with the arrival of continuous "broadband" access to the internet - the phone will know who you are and where you are, enabling you to consult a doctor remotely, call up live pictures of traffic jams (or anything linked to a camera). It will be a goldmine for enterprise as thousands of programmers work out innovative applications. The mobile will become the most popular product the industrialised world has known - and continuous technological change could induce users to buy new models every few years.

It offers developing countries a chance to leapfrog over their lack of telephone infrastructure (half the world has never made a phone call) into the 21st century. That will require new social entrepreneurs with skills to persuade multinationals to allow cheap Third World access to their satellites as they pass unused overhead. If developing countries aren't hooked into the information revolution, they will fall further behind.

webTitle: Queen's spending listed as pay is frozen at £7.9m

fields.headline: Queen's spending listed as pay is frozen at £7.9m
fields.standfirst: The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: The Queen's annual expenses were revealed in detail for the first time yesterday as the prime minister confirmed that the civil list will be frozen at £7.9m a year until 2011.
fields.body:
The Queen's annual expenses were revealed in detail for the first time yesterday as the prime minister confirmed that the civil list will be frozen at £7.9m a year until 2011.

A breakdown of the royal household's spending were unveiled as part of a deal between Buckingham Palace and the Treasury under which the Queen has agreed to take on extra costs as part of her civil list spending, including staff pensions and some palace running costs, totalling £25m over the next decade.

Tony Blair told MPs in a Commons statement that the Queen would continue to receive £7.9m a year of public money for the upkeep of the royal households - the same amount she has received on the civil list every year since 1991.

He said the settlement was possible because of the "very substantial efficiencies" made by the royal family - totalling 10% in real terms over the decade - and a lower than expected inflation rate during the 1990s. This resulted in a £35m surplus, which will be used to meet civil list expenditure over the next 10 years.

Although the civil list makes up only a fifth of all spending on the royal family, latest figures show the annual cost of the monarchy to the taxpayer, excluding security, has been reduced in real terms by 55% during the last 10 years to £37m, Mr Blair said.

Details of the annual civil list spending over the past decade revealed that the single largest expense was the £4.4m spent on staff salaries while the costs of entertaining foreign dignitories and providing meals for 500 staff every day has taken its toll on the crockery and cutlery budget, which cost £13,550 last year alone. However, officials were quick to point to economies achieved through a range of minor savings, including the discovery that green tents and marquees for garden parties were cheaper than white to hire.

Mr Blair justified the expenditure on the royal household, saying that the Queen receives about 80,000 guests a year, there are 2m visitors to the royal palaces every year and about 3,000 engagements undertaken by members of the royal family. "I think that is a pretty impressive work record by any stretch of the imagination," he said.

But the left-wing Labour MP Dennis Skinner described the deal as a "disgrace", saying: "This is a pretty big winter heating allowance. What is so special about this family that they qualify for £7.9m instead of 75p?"

Expenditure on royal households 1999

Salaries £4,387,835

Wines and beverages £57,470

Garden parties £404,911

Carriage processions £121,787

Stationery £136,828

Uniforms £81,947

Travel £246,596

Crockery and cutlery £13,550

Housekeeping £198,711

Furnishings and equipment £132,931

Legal advice and other professional services £68,624

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Plans to build a 41-storey office tower on the site of the historic Baltic Exchange in the heart of the Square Mile were given the go-ahead yesterday by City planners.
fields.body:
Erotic gherkin to go ahead

Plans to build a 41-storey office tower on the site of the historic Baltic Exchange in the heart of the Square Mile were given the go-ahead yesterday by City planners.

The £300m building - dubbed the "erotic gherkin" by some detractors - has been designed by Lord Foster and backed by Kvaerner, the Anglo-Norwegian construction group. It will be the headquarters of Swiss Re, the insurance group.

The original listed Baltic Exchange building was blown up by an IRA bomb in 1992.

'Buzz off' on Go and Buzz

European regulators refused to comment last night on reports that BA and KLM might be forced to sell off their low-cost operations, Go and Buzz, as the price of approving a merger of the two airlines.

Chief executives of both BA and KLM met the EU competition commissioner, Mario Monti, on Friday to discuss their proposed link-up, which could fall short of a full merger. But an EU spokesman said it would be "premature and inappropriate" to discuss the issues".

Chief executives of both BA and KLM met the EU competition commissioner, Mario Monti, on Friday to discuss their proposed link-up, which could fall short of a full merger. But an EU spokesman said it would be "premature and inappropriate" to discuss the issues".

fields.headline: Bottom of the class
fields.standfirst:
Mr Hague wants secondary moderns

Education Unlimited

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Yesterday's much-trailed big speech on education was not a top-of-the-class performance by the Tory leader. It was not good even on his own terms.
fields.body:
Yesterday's much-trailed big speech on education was not a top-of-the-class performance by the Tory leader. It was not good even on his own terms, which these days consist of psephological cherry-picking, aiming his speeches at those parts of Labour's 1997 support which seem most mobile. In his pursuit of headlines he missed opportunities to score.

Usually it is naive to say politicians should be less deliberately partisan. Not on this occasion. Talking about schools, William Hague could have pointed out just how many of his party's old clothes New Labour has pinched: curriculum, inspection, payment by results, delegated school budgets. He half sees this. He pushes his pro forma lambasting of the "liberal establishment" while rejecting the outrageous allegation that David Blunkett is a Conservative. In policy terms, of course, he is, and Mr Hague might have made capital of Mr Blunkett's distinct kinship with the late Sir Keith Joseph.

The Tories think the polling data make secondary selection a card worth playing. Their assumption is that even if grammar schools accommodate only a quarter of the 11-plus age group, many of the also-ran parents are aspirational and would vicariously cherish schools which had rejected their own. History suggests this is a false turn. Mr Hague should turn up Edward Boyle's papers from a generation ago on the damage done to his party by 11-plus triage. Tory logic says 70% of 11-18 year olds will be the goats going to the not-grammar schools. They will, whatever Mr Hague says about technology and unspecified "options", be secondary moderns. Giving schools a universal right to choose their students sooner or later means large numbers of rejects. The Tories, having abolished local education authorities, ought to tell us who will take them in.

The future of the local education authorities is another missed chance. Once Tories were the party of local choice, defenders of the idea that the best (and probably the most frugal) government was that closest to people. Now William Hague seeks to outbid Labour in rejecting any role for councils in schooling. This allows him to do some creative arithmetic. His £540 per pupil stems from redistributing the money councils spend on Cinderella services, school buses and special needs. Here Mr Hague chose not to use his Politeia speech to come clean. Does he believe, with sundry Tory educational thinkers, that "special needs" is a plot to provide jobs for social workers and psychologists - in which case needy children can straightforwardly be put into mainstream classes. If he does not, who pays for them, in what sort of school?

Labour has huge problems of consistency in its approach to local democracy's place in maintaining schools. But Mr Hague now has even more explaining to do. Those councillors of Kent and Buckinghamshire who kept the anti-comprehensive flag flying all those years are to be shoved aside not - this used to be the mantra - in pursuit of parental choice but in favour of a Hagueite educational autarky. The new phrase is schools choose. It may be some heads and teachers like this promise of "independence" (except from inspectors, presumably). Others are more considerate of parents and children, present and future, and see how social circumstance hinders and disables - they know there must be coordination in order to ensure fair access. But fairness and that concern to see schools participate in remedying society's larger inequalities, which still informs David Blunkett's tenure, play no part in Mr Hague's make-up.

fields.headline: Engineering 'on the brink'
fields.trailText: Britain's engineering industry is hovering on the brink of recession and badly needs a further fall in the value of the pound below the critical level of DM3 to prevent new blows to investment and jobs.
fields.body:
Britain's engineering industry is hovering on the brink of recession and badly needs a further fall in the value of the pound below the critical level of DM3 to prevent new blows to investment and jobs.

The Engineering Employers Federation said yesterday that sterling's recent fall - more than 10% since the high of DM3.40 in April and May - had happened just in time to prevent manufacturing falling into recession.

The EEF's latest quarterly trends survey puts renewed pressure on ministers to give a clearer lead on joining the euro and on the Bank of England to signal that interest rates have peaked at 6% when its monetary policy committee meets today and tomorrow.

Engineering industry executives voiced fears that the continued strength of sterling, which would be boosted by an increase in interest rates, would force more inward investors abroad and bring an even steeper decline in capital spending by British firms.

The EEF's survey showed that, after three successive quarters of growth, engineering output had fallen - and not just in traditional metal-bashing.

Old economy engineering firms have seen total orders cut back heavily, while electrical and electronic firms have also experienced slower growth. The steepest fall has come in the south-east, west Midlands and Yorkshire-Humberside.

Stephen Radley, the EEF's chief economist, said engineering had still to reap the consequences of the high pound earlier this year but hoped for a "bounce-back" if the pound continued to fall.

"We expect the pound to fall further against the euro and dollar which will restrain any increase in the cost of imports, thereby reducing the threat of inflation , and this could lead to a revival of exports," he said.

The EEF has consistently argued for the pound to enter the euro at a rate of between DM2.60 and DM2.80. But David Botterill, chief executive of the EEF's west Midlands region, said industry could now live with a higher level - preferably below DM3.

He also pointed out that euroland interest rates were rising - closing the gap between the cost of borrowing in Britain and on the continent.

Investment in engineering has fallen each quarter for the past two years and Mr Radley said any increase in the cost of borrowing would be unjustified by the inflationary prospects. Productivity in engineering, which was growing at 8% late last year, is now increasing at 6%. Earnings have risen by a little more than 5% with one in six firms reporting a pay freeze.

Engineering has shed 25,000 jobs in the past year, the bulk of them in the past six months, and EEF leaders are braced for further losses as the Rover, Ford and Corus cut-backs take effect. Job cuts are the sole reason why productivity growth has been so strong.

fields.headline: American home truths
fields.standfirst:
Offering an alternative to Bush 'n' Gore

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: The candidate's vision was startling, presenting a different, harsher and perhaps more honest perspective on the United States than that normally on show.
fields.body:
The candidate's vision was startling, presenting a different, harsher and perhaps more honest perspective on the United States than that normally on show. Richer and more powerful than at any time in its history, America was in truth an "under-developed democracy" where "corporatisation" and "globalisation" were systematically usurping citizens' rights.

Children, 20% of whom live in poverty, were the victims of ruthless mass marketing and the "commercialisation of childhood". Today's workers, he said, received less pay in real terms, for longer hours, and millions were steeped in debt. Unemployment was masked by breadline, part-time jobs, record numbers lacked any form of health insurance, and all around, public services from transport to schooling were crumbling.

The big corporations were despoiling and polluting the land, degrading the food supply, and dodging taxes; and all the time, the gap between the wealthiest and the poorest was growing. Bill Gates's accumulated wealth, for example, was greater than that of 120m Americans combined. The top 1% of American households was richer than all the "bottom" 95% together. And what the corporate "monster", unchecked by a supine political establishment and a "voyeuristic" media, was doing in the US, it was also doing internationally, using tools like the World Trade Organisation. Americans, the candidate said, needed "to build a deep democracy by working hard for a regenerative progressive politics, as if people mattered". The Democratic party must "shape up or ship out".

Unfortunately, many might feel, this was not the Democrats' presidential candidate speaking. Al Gore was nowhere to be seen, or heard, when Ralph Nader, the veteran consumer rights and environmental campaigner, issued his radical manifesto in Denver last week while accepting the Green party's nomination. Mr Nader has no realistic chance of winning the White House. But he is going to try. And with one poll showing him with 7% support nationally, and with much higher ratings in some key states like California, he could tip the balance in a close-run race between Mr Gore ("Tweedledee" in Mr Nader's lexicon) and his Republican rival, George W "Tweedledum" Bush. Mr Nader's entry into a contest mired in cautious, cloying, centrist complacency is a breath of fresh air. At last, a plain-speaking, genuine man of the people, ready to break a few eggs.

webTitle: Lecturer 'could get life' for killing colleague

fields.headline: Lecturer 'could get life' for killing colleague
fields.trailText: Steven Reid, the lonely lecturer who battered to death a university colleague because he admired her "caring" nature, was warned he could face a life sentence after being found guilty of manslaughter yesterday.
fields.body:
Steven Reid, the lonely lecturer who battered to death a university colleague because he admired her "caring" nature, was warned he could face a life sentence after being found guilty of manslaughter yesterday.

During the trial, Ian Cummings, a psychiatrist who treated Reid at Belmarsh prison, had warned that the socially inept and suicidal psychology lecturer could kill again.

Reid, 34, of Marylebone, west London, who had never had a girlfriend, bludgeoned to death Elizabeth Stacey, 24, the IT technician who had befriended him, on November 5 last year at the University of Westminster.

He had lured her to a little-used research room, complaining of a computer problem, before battering her over the head with a rolling pin at least seven times.

A jury at Middlesex Guildhall crown court returned unanimous verdicts of not guilty to murder but guilty to manslaughter.

Reid, who had barely flinched throughout the trial, showed no emotion as the decisions were read out.

Sentencing was adjourned for four weeks for psychiatric reports. The judge, Fabyan Evans, said: "All options must remain open and the court must still have in its mind a life sentence."

Jeffrey Pegden QC, for the defence, had persuaded the jury that, on the balance of probability, Reid had suffered from diminished responsibility when he attacked Stacey because she was someone he "liked and respected".

Reid, a research assistant studying for his PhD, had told how he killed Stacey so she could be his friend in the afterlife. He said he had always intended to commit suicide and join her.

Reid, who went on the run after the killing, was arrested in Brighton on November 16 after his photo appeared on the television programme Crimewatch.

He told police he had attempted suicide by taking an overdose of aspirin, but was later sick. He then tried to cut his wrists but survived.

Reid, who hated his parents, disliked being touched, and rarely smiled, had often complained of depression.

He had attempted suicide before, using antibiotics and a bottle of whisky. More recently, he had ordered beta blockers over the internet to combat depression.

Contemporaries at the University of Westminster, where he worked for six years, said Reid was "very bright, hard working and capable" but also described him as "quietly spoken, a loner, shy, and introverted".

When Stacey joined the psychology department, hoping to improve her IT skills, Reid took an instant liking to her. He became more animated and would happily chat to colleagues in bars and began to enjoy drink, which he had seldom touched before.

He recalled: "[Stacey] was a very warm, compassionate person, very caring, and made a special effort to ask me how I was doing."

She had lent him books and CDs and they swapped emails.

He denied that he had a crush on her or that he was jealous of her gregariousness. They had a "mutual bond" of friendship, he said.

As a child in Edinburgh, Reid had few friends and left school at 17. He described a string of jobs that followed as "aimless". In 1993 he moved to London to study psychology in the hope that it would help him relate to people.

Stacey's parents yesterday said in a statement: "We are grateful for the happy times that we had together. The lives of many people have been enriched by her warm, loving presence."

She had returned to live with her parents and sister in Finchley, north London, after gaining a BA in physics and masters degree in natural sciences at Christ's College, Cambridge.

webTitle: Auctioneer's art: Drawing fetches record price

fields.headline: Auctioneer's art: Drawing fetches record price
fields.trailText: A world record price for an old master drawing was set in London yesterday, when a Michelangelo in chalk and ink was sold to a German art dealer for £8.1m.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
A world record price for an old master drawing was set in London yesterday, when a Michelangelo in chalk and ink was sold to a German art dealer for £8.1m.

The price, for a work described by Christie's deputy chairman Noel Annesley as "one of the most brilliant and famous drawings to appear at auction since the second world war", was almost £3m over the maximum estimate.

The drawing was last sold in the same gallery, in 1936, for 3,400 guineas to Sir Brinsley Ford, who became one of the great collectors and experts on old master drawings, chairman of the National Arts Collections Fund and a trustee of the National Gallery. Yesterday's sale was by his heirs.

It beat the previous record, also at Christie's in London, set in 1996, when a Raphael, the Heart and Hand of an Apostle, sold for £5.2m.

Michelangelo's small two sided sketch, in red and black chalk overdrawn in black ink, is a working drawing for his last completed sculpture, the life size nude statue of the Risen Christ, made for the Church of Santa Maria sopra Minerva in Rome, a commission which he struggled with for almost a decade.

The drawing went to a telephone bid from the dealer Katrin Bellinger, who outbid several dealers present at the auction.

Another sheet of drawings, by Leonardo da Vinci, comes up for auction at Sotheby's today.

webTitle: Drunk passengers 'forced Jamaica plane to divert'

fields.headline: Drunk passengers 'forced Jamaica plane to divert'
fields.trailText: Holidaymakers flying to Jamaica were left petrified when a group of drunken passengers started a midair brawl and forced the airliner to divert to the US, a court was told yesterday.
fields.body:
Holidaymakers flying to Jamaica were left petrified when a group of drunken passengers started a midair brawl and forced the airliner to divert to the US, a court was told yesterday.

The flight from Gatwick to the Caribbean island made an unscheduled stop in Norfolk, Virginia, on January 31 last year after the group shouted, swore, and tried to attack a Jamaican passenger, Hove crown court, east Sussex, heard.

Francis Coyle, 40, and Myles Connors, 36, are charged with affray, endangering an aircraft and being drunk on a plane. Elizabeth O'Driscoll, 34, Angela O'Driscoll, 39, and Josephine Cooper, 19, are charged with being drunk on an aircraft. The five, who deny the charges, were among 12 passengers who were the last to board the Airtours Boeing 767 plane to Montego Bay, the court heard.

Passengers on the 9 hour flight had to cry and scream at the "boisterous" party to sit down as they sang songs, including Summer Holiday, and became increasingly drunk on vodka and champagne, said Michael Warren, prosecuting.

An empty half-bottle of spirit was later discovered at the rear of the plane near the seats which had been occupied by the defendants, who are from a caravan park in Lewisham, south-east London.

Mr Warren said the air crew had tried to calm the situation by refusing to serve the group more alcohol and ordering them to sit down and be quiet.

Connors and Coyle became involved in an argument with a Jamaican passenger, in which Connors hit out after the man lost his temper and threw beer over him saying: "I am not your slave."

Mr Warren said: "One air stewardess stood between Connors and the Jamaican, effectively keeping them apart. Connors was trying to attack the man, saying: 'I am going to get you. When we land you are mine.' The situation became out of hand. One passenger said all hell had broken out."

Kattya Bassingthwaighte, 32, from Australia, sitting behind the group, described her terror as the "bar room brawl" erupted, and she and other passengers were ushered to the front of the plane.

Mr Warren said the captain announced the plane would be diverted - the first time he had done so in his career. The group fell silent as the captain made his announcement and were escorted from the jet by the FBI on landing in Virginia in the US. There they were grounded as the plane continued to Jamaica, and they flew home three days later.

The trial, expected to last three weeks, continues today.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: £10,000 for McLibel Two
fields.body:
£10,000 for McLibel Two

The "McLibel Two" who spent three years in court defending themselves against the fast food chain, have accepted £10,000 in an out of court settlement with the Metropolitan police. Dave Morris and Helen Steel accused the force of giving information, including their addresses, to McDonald's.

Drink adverts toned down

Words like "energising" or "stimulating" should not be used to suggest alcoholic drinks enhance capability, according to a voluntary code for brewers. The maker of Red Square, a vodka drink, said it would be described as "reloaded" rather than "energising".

Kent families evacuated

More than 200 families were yesterday evacuated following the discovery of a second pipe bomb buried beneath the village of Hawkinge in Kent. The bomb was designed to blow up a wartime airfield if the Germans invaded.
