webTitle: US gene firm poaches Bespak boss

fields.headline: US gene firm poaches Bespak boss
fields.standfirst: The ethics of genetics: special report
fields.trailText: Celera, the US company at the forefront of mapping the human genome, has poached the British boss of asthma inhalers manufacturer, Bespak, as its new chief operating officer.
fields.body:
Celera, the US company at the forefront of mapping the human genome, has poached the British boss of asthma inhalers manufacturer, Bespak, as its new chief operating officer.

Peter Chambre, 44, is leaving Bespak at the end of the month to be the right-hand man to Craig Venter, the controversial scientist who heads Celera.

Mr Chambre said the job offer had come "completely out of the blue". He has been running Bespak since 1994, having previously worked at building materials group Caradon.

"This is a unique opportunity to develop an organisation and to use the information revealed by the sequencing of the human genome," he said.

Celera has raised hackles in the scientific community through its commercial approach to the Human Genome Project.

The company was a late entrant to the race to complete a "map of life" and competed with a group of non-profit making British academics to finish the work. A unit of PE Corporation (formerly Perkin-Elmer), Celera plans to continue exploring not just the human genome but also the genetic stuff of mice, fruit flies, rice, and other life forms.

It will license access to its vast computer archive at $5m-$15m (£3.3m-£9.9m) a year to biotech and drug firms, research organisations, and other life sciences firms.

There have been concerns at the extent to which Dr Ventner will claim ownership of the genetic map, and attempt to control access to other drugs companies.

Mr Chambre is a surprise choice for the role. A tennis enthusiast, he was educated at City of London School and Reading University. He lives in Cambridge with his wife, Sarah, and their five children - four girls and a boy.

He began his career at the consumer goods group Unilever, then worked for the management consultancy Bain & Co.

His six years at Bespak have been mixed. The group prospered in the mid- 1990s, amid the introduction of dry-powder inhalers, which are much easier to use than traditional devices for asthma sufferers.

Bespak's shares touched £10.25 in 1998, valuing the company at more than £250m. However, since then they have slumped amid a succession of delays and setbacks in introduction of new inhalers across the industry as a whole.

The company's share price edged up 5p to 488.5p in trading yesterday.

Bespak made a pre-tax loss of £15.5m in the year to April, hit by a £30.3m exceptional charge on the sale of the company's US subsidiary, Tenax, which makes equipment for keyhole surgery. Underlying profits rose 10% to £14.8m despite a fall in the number of Diskus inhalers supplied to Glaxo Wellcome.

Mr Chambre said: "We've met all the goals we set this year. We've dramatically strengthened the pipeline of new product opportunities."

He said that during his time at Bespak, the "underlying business has improved essentially every year".

"My main experience for Celera is in the leadership and development of a business serving the pharmaceuticals industry," he said.

Celera, which is based just outside Washington, is keen to capitalise on its research by becoming the definitive source of information for the drugs industry on genetics and proteins.

As well as providing scientific databases, the company offers services to help its clients interpret information in the search for new gene-based drugs.

webTitle: Nurses to get fast track to train as doctors

fields.headline: Nurses to get fast track to train as doctors
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Nurses will be offered express training to qualify as doctors under a plan to break down professional boundaries in the NHS that is due to be agreed today by the action teams preparing the government's overhaul of the health service.
fields.body:
Nurses will be offered express training to qualify as doctors under a plan to break down professional boundaries in the NHS that is due to be agreed today by the action teams preparing the government's overhaul of the health service.

According to the confidential final report of the team investigating reform of the professions, the NHS will have to scrap traditional demarcation lines if it is to correct aserious skills shortage.

In the long term, it recommends a single regulatory body for all the health professions, merging the powers of the General Medical Council and parallel bodies for nurses, therapists and social care workers. In the short term it wants to give greater responsibility for nurses, midwives and therapists to take decisions about patient care.

"They should be empowered to carry out functions such as taking the patient history, physical examination, diagnostic tests, diagnosis, development and implementation of a treatment plan including prescription and clinical interventions, and discharge decisions," the report says.

There should be a "skills escalator" allowing staff at every level to progress on the career ladder. Nurses who had established competence in relevant training modules, could use them as credits to qualification as a doctor, shortening the training period.

The report was drawn up by a team including Sir George Alberti, president of the Royal College of Physicians. Ministers are understood to be convinced by the arguments and will almost certainly include them in the national plan for health later this month.

The report tells the government to offer lifelong learning to all NHS staff. There should be "routes into health care roles for support workers such as porters, administrative and secretarial staff", and scope for extending the health expertise of other staff.

Andrew Foster, speaking for the NHS Confederation of health authorities and trusts, said: "The logical conclusion is that a hospital porter could become a consultant.

"We have a long way to go towards unjamming the regulatory systems that would allow that to happen, but it is an exciting message."

webTitle: Careworker sacked for giving MS patient cannabis

fields.headline: Careworker sacked for giving MS patient cannabis
fields.trailText: A teenage careworker has been sacked and cautioned by police after he supplied cannabis to a nursing home resident with multiple sclerosis.
fields.body:
A teenage careworker has been sacked and cautioned by police after he supplied cannabis to a nursing home resident with multiple sclerosis.

Ashley Moore, 18, was arrested after he was dismissed from a nursing home in Oldham, Greater Manchester. He had supplied cannabis to Lawrence Brierley, 58, who had asked him for the drug.

Liz Hague, matron of the Chadderton Total Care Home, said: "The actions of the careworker were foolish but I feel desperately sorry for him. He was in a difficult position but the action we took was appropriate. It was a kind act and it is very unfortunate really that we had to sack him.

"Lawrence has always been very open about the fact that he takes cannabis to ease his pain and we have accepted that as part of his care."

The care worker said he was just trying to help. "I don't blame [Mr Brierley]," he said. "I knew he would not have asked me if he wasn't desperate."

Mr Brierley, who was diagnosed 14 years ago, said: "The kind of people who get me this drug usually are the kind who panic if they get a parking ticket. But they break the law to help me." No one at the home had ever supplied him but he had asked Mr Moore because he was desperate.

Mr Brierley has been smoking cannabis for seven years for pain relief and to curb his depression. "This illness can be unbearable and cannabis helps me and many other people to cope with it," he said.

Yesterday British scientists announced their findings in a study on the impact of cannabinoids - the active ingredient in the drug - on pain relief. The team, based at Imperial College, London, found that cannabinoids act on the spinal cord as well as the brain, which paves the way for a drug which would combat pain but bypass the brain and avoid the high associated with cannabis.

webTitle: Britain pressed to return aboriginal bones

fields.headline: Britain pressed to return aboriginal bones
fields.standfirst: Australian PM asks Blair for 2,000 remains to be repatriated
fields.trailText: Australia's prime minister, John Howard, yesterday took the opportunity of a visit to Downing Street to press Tony Blair for help in persuading British museums and universities to repatriate the remains of more than 2,000 aborigines.
fields.body:
Australia's prime minister, John Howard, yesterday took the opportunity of a visit to Downing Street to press Tony Blair for help in persuading British museums and universities to repatriate the remains of more than 2,000 aborigines.

The bones were taken by British scientists from the 18th century up until the 1920s and 30s. The Australian high commission said yesterday that aboriginal organisations wanted them back because their ancestors would find no peace until they were buried in their homelands.

Museums in Europe have been secretive about whether they have bones and in what quantities - some from lack of proper cataloguing, others fearing such requests from indigenous peoples; some custodians argue that the scientific value of the bones outweighs their cultural significance.

Downing Street said that Mr Blair would give the request "a fair wind" but no firm commitment was made.

The department of culture, media and sport said that museums were generally forbidden by law to return items, constrained either by their trustees or acts of parliament; however, the department drew a distinction between human remains and artefacts such as the Elgin Marbles which Greece wants returned. A change to the 1983 National Heritage Act would be considered.

A decision could be announced when the culture secretary, Chris Smith, visits Australia for the Olympics in September. Aboriginal organisations have threatened to protest at the games, unhappy at the failure of Mr Howard's government to apologise for the treatment of their people over two centuries.

Mr Howard, who saw Mr Blair at Downing Street, was in Britain to mark the centenary of Australia becoming a federation.

Tony Eggleton, chief executive of the national council for the centenary of federation, said there were various bones round the country. "We are not expecting miracles overnight. It would be a good gesture to the indigenous population to have them collated and returned. Having forebears remain overseas and unrecognised is painful for them."

The remains would be buried in their homelands, and those that could not be identified could be placed in a shrine to be built in Canberra, if the aboriginal organisations agreed.

Neil Chalmers, director of the Natural History Museum at Kensington in London, said the issue should be seen in context: the museum had 68m items, of which 20,000 were human remains from round the world. Of these 448 were from Australia.

Some 340 of the 448 items were digits, leg bones, skulls and other parts, rather than complete skeletons, he said. Australia estimates that between 15 to 20% of the remains in Britain are identifiable, but Dr Chalmers said that those in the museum could not be traced to a named individual with known living descendants.

He said some remains were known to have come from Queensland but the regional location of most of them was unknown.

The parts were used to study human origins and evolution, human diversity, diet and disease. "We can do this because we have the whole collection together," he said. Asked if the scientific benefits outweighed the cultural ones, he said: "The scientific benefits are global in their importance."

Dr Chalmers hoped there could be a way of reconciling the scientific and the cultural, with perhaps a sacred area in the museum or the remains being taken to Australia but being available for further scientific research.

The law in Scotland is different, and museums and universities are freer to dispose of their assets. A spokesman for Edinburgh University said that its historical anatomy collection had handed over aboriginal remains to Australia a fortnight ago; they had gone to a university in Canberra until a decision was taken on where they went next.

Over the past decade the university had returned eight moko mokai (shrunken heads) to the Maoris, nine Tasmanian aboriginal skulls, and a Tasmanian aboriginal hair sample. The university adopted a sensitivity to indigenous claims in 1990.

Sally James Gregory writes: The extent and whereabouts of aboriginal remains in Britain is unknown. The Australian high commission estimates there are between 2,000 and 2,500 remains.

The Natural History Museum in London has 20,000 remains from round the world, of which 448 are from Australia. Australian ones include 340 digits, leg bones, skulls and other parts rather than whole skeletons. Museum says collection has huge scientific importance and compromise has to be negotiated

British Museum, London houses collection of roughly 30 objects from Aboriginal sources. The only human remains are incorporated into artefacts, eg amulets with knucklebones and decorated skulls

Royal College of Surgeons, London has small number of skulls remaining from a much larger collection, including skeletons, held until the building was bombed in 1941. After the war most of the remains were transferred to the Natural History Museum. It has a policy of return of named individuals but has no names relating to any remains held

Horniman Museum, London had some remains in the original collection but a previous director removed them from display and offered to return them. For 10 years they have been packed away awaiting an official request

According to the World Archeological Bulletin the following have remains:

Oxford University Museum, Oxford Institute of Biological Anthropology, Pitt Rivers Museum, Oxford, Duckworth Osteological Collection at the University of Cambridge

webTitle: Belgrano claim lodged with Strasbourg court

fields.headline: Belgrano claim lodged with Strasbourg court
fields.trailText: Lawyers yesterday filed papers at the European court of human rights in Strasbourg claiming damages from the UK on behalf of relatives of Argentine sailors killed when the General Belgrano was sunk by a British submarine.
fields.body:
Lawyers yesterday filed papers at the European court of human rights in Strasbourg claiming damages from the UK on behalf of relatives of Argentine sailors killed when the General Belgrano was sunk by a British submarine.

Jorge Appiani and Jorge Antonio Oliveira filed a claim for damages for breach of the right to life, guaranteed by article 2 of the European convention on human rights.

The submission stated that the relatives, a mother and a father of two of the 323 sailors who died claimed compensation from "the British government, in the person of former prime minister Margaret Thatcher and her war cabinet, for violating the right to life by ordering the Argentine battle cruiser Belgrano sunk on May 2, 1982."

The lawyers' arrival from Buenos Aires to file the court papers, which are usually sent by post, suggested that they hoped to secure publicity for the move.

They acknowledged to reporters that they wanted to put pressure on the Argentine government to take Britain to the international court of justice in the Hague.

Lawyers in Britain rate the Strasbourg claim as having limited prospects of getting a hearing.

The rules say that claimants must first exhaust all remedies in the domestic courts, and then bring a claim within six months.

webTitle: MPs urge review of diplomats' safety

fields.headline: MPs urge review of diplomats' safety
fields.trailText: The Foreign Office said yesterday staff security was a top priority, after being accused of complacency by the Commons foreign affairs select committee over the assassination of the defence attache in Athens.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill and Helena Smith  in Athens
fields.body:
The Foreign Office said yesterday staff security was a top priority, after being accused of complacency by the Commons foreign affairs select committee over the assassination of the defence attache in Athens.

Brigadier Stephen Saunders was killed last month by the leftwing group November 17.

The cross-party foreign affairs committee said it was "deeply disquieting" that the threat to staff in Athens had been classified as "broadly compatible" with that in other European Nato states, and called for an urgent review of embassy security measures.

It said security had remained at the same level, de spite the increased tensions in Greece over the Kosovo war.

Donald Anderson, chairman of the committee, called for more money to be spent on protecting diplomats. Asked what was wrong with the Foreign Office's action to protect diplomats such as Brig Saunders, Mr Anderson said: "Complacency - we find it incredible that there was not greater priority given to the protection of our diplomatic personnel."

The Foreign Office denied being complacent: "We review continually the security of our posts abroad _ there was no evidence that British diplomats were likely to be targets.

"If staff overseas are to do their job, it is impossible to guarantee 24-hour total security."

It promised to take a further look at security in the light of the committee's criticism.

The Foreign Office acknowledged in a memorandum to the committee that it had known that terrorists, who might previously have attacked US targets, were liable to seek "softer" targets because of the increased American security levels. The US was spending huge amounts on upgrading security compared with Britain.

"We very much hope that this modest amount will prove adequate to provide the protection necessary," the committee said. "Where there is a new threat, new money must be found, not simply reallocated. We recommend that the Foreign Office urgently reviews protection and assures the committee that no necessary security precaution is ever forgone for reasons of cost."

webTitle: Mint goes roaming to cut mobile call charges

fields.headline: Mint goes roaming to cut mobile call charges
fields.standfirst: British firm banks on expansion through pre-paid and flat-rate worldwide fee
fields.trailText: Talk costs, they say in the mobile phone industry. Take the two minute phone call from Spain to Switzerland on Telefonica's network charged at a rate of £19 a minute. Or ring for a taxi in Hungary on consecutive days at the same hour and find the international roaming charge of the call has swung from £2 a minute on the first occasion to £4 a minute the next.

Talk costs, they say in the mobile phone industry. Take the two minute phone call from Spain to Switzerland on Telefonica's network charged at a rate of £19 a minute. Or ring for a taxi in Hungary on consecutive days at the same hour and find the international roaming charge of the call has swung from £2 a minute on the first occasion to £4 a minute the next.

With business going global, mobile phone costs are spiralling and one British company hopes to cut through the apparently arbitrary charges that mobile users encounter when they leave Britain. Mint Telecom, a small "virtual operator", hopes to hit the big time with its launch of a pre-paid global roaming service at a flat-rate fee of 85p a minute anywhere in the world.

Adrian Wood, Mint Telecom director, said the mobile user is often unaware of the high costs of internationally roaming until they return to Britain and receive a copy of their bill.

Charges for international roaming usually cannot be controlled by any of Britain's four operators - Vodafone, Orange, One2One or BT Cellnet - and if a mobile phone user has a dispute with the charge they have to take it up with the foreign mobile network operator.

"There's a tremendous move, we have found, in large corporations and in the medium-size business market to try and arrest these costs," Mr Wood said.

"We are very confident that we will achieve 400,000 subscribers across Europe in our first year."

Mint Telecom claims it can save corporations up to 40% on international roaming charges on a monthly mobile phone bill.

The London-based company is able to offer its cheap flat rate of 85p a minute because it has bought bulk airtime from 200 network operators globally and has coverage in 115 countries.

Mint Telecom charges a flat 42.5p fee for mobile users when they are receiving calls outside their home country.

The company has agreements, lasting up to 20 years, with those operators and has made its first bulk purchase of 155m minutes which it expects to last for three months. Once its subscriber base grows, it intends to boost this level of buying to 200m minutes a month.

Mr Wood said the most popular part of Mint Telecom's service would be the pre-paid el ement so that large businesses know what they are paying for up front.

In the British retail mobile market there are about 15m users on pre-paid contracts.

The margin that Mint Telecom would make from its flat-rate fee was slim, Mr Wood said. A mobile user wanting to use the network would insert a Mint Telecom SIM card into their mobile phone before heading overseas.

The user would then be roaming on the Mint network and could make a call which would be routed through one of its switching stations in either Switzerland or Iceland that allows for the distribution of its service.

Mint Telecom owns 50% of the third GSM licence in Ice land and also offers its own portal for WAP-enabled phones. The portal delivers content to its users such as email, share prices, news, weather and sport.

The company, which is owned by six private investors, is capitalised at about £5m.

The owners say they have pumped tens of millions into the company over the past four years, refusing to be specific as to the exact level of investment, however, because of confidentiality agreements.

They are seeking a further $18m (£12m) to $20m in the next three months from venture capitalists to develop further the infrastructure, sales team and web portal as it expands.

The company employs 22 sales staff and has distribution agreements with telecoms operators globally to promote its service, having linked with European Telecom in Britain.

Mint Telecom's success may well, however, depend on whether its prospective business customers accept the idea and marketing that its service is "a fresh and new approach" to mobile usage.

webTitle: KPN and DoCoMo in talks to take stake in Hutchison

fields.headline: KPN and DoCoMo in talks to take stake in Hutchison
fields.trailText: KPN, the Dutch mobile phone company, confirmed that it is in discussions with its partner, NTT DoCoMo, the Japanese mobile operator, to buy a stake in Hutchison Whampoa's British division, which owns a third-generation mobile licence.
fields.body:
KPN, the Dutch mobile phone company, confirmed that it is in discussions with its partner, NTT DoCoMo, the Japanese mobile operator, to buy a stake in Hutchison Whampoa's British division, which owns a third-generation mobile licence.

KPN, however, declined to confirm the size of the stake. However, there was market speculation that the stake may be as high as 35%, with a price tag of possibly just over £1bn.

Hong Kong conglomerate Hutchison Whampoa declined to comment yesterday. It and partner TIW, the Canadian telecoms company, bought the British licence in April for £4.4bn.

That licence has the largest amount of spectrum capacity of the five third-generation mobile licences auctioned by the British government.

Third-generation mobile phones will begin operating in Britain in 2002 delivering high speed internet access and performing simple computing tasks.

"Together with NTT DoCoMo and Hutchison, we are looking at possibilities in the universal mobile telecommunications systems field in a number of European markets and Britain is one of those," said Bram Oudshoorn, a KPN official. "At the moment there is no further information."

If the sale were a 35% stake then it was suggested that NTT DoCoMo would take the larger slice of 20% in the operating company which owns the licence and KPN would have 15%. This would leave Hutchison Whampoa with 58% and TIW with 7%. An announcement confirming the sale might come by the end of the week, said sources close to the companies.

Analysts said Hutchison Whampoa's sale of the stake would reduce the company's exposure to the estimated cost of building the network on which the third-generation licence would operate.

Canning Fox, Hutchison group managing director, has estimated that the network would cost about £5bn to build.

The agreement between the three telecom carriers may pave the way for further alliances in the European market where other countries are auctioning third -generation licences.

The Dutch third-generation licence auction is due to begin tomorrow.

fields.headline: Careless talk costs votes
fields.standfirst:
Labour has always been good at internecine squabbles. But now there's an election coming
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Labour has always been good at internecine squabbles. But now there's an election coming
fields.body:
A landmark within the Washington Post newspaper is a column called Miss Manners. Readers send their inquiries ("in black or blue-black ink, on white writing paper") to the resident mistress of etiquette, who then advises them on the right way to address a step-grandmother at Thanksgiving or the appropriate gift to bring back to the office after a long trip abroad. Well, now I have a question for Miss Manners. What, pray, is the proper conduct for people of the centre-left who want Labour to win the next election - and yet find themselves appalled by so much of what this government gets up to?

Should we keep our lips buttoned, save only for the cheer we let out when urging our side on against the enemy? Should we keep all dissent to ourselves in the interests of unity and retaining power? Or can we follow the lead set by Ken Follett at the weekend, and launch vicious attacks on the very people we voted for and support - so that they might change their ways?

The question has become urgent because two rocks in the landscape have begun to shift - in opposite directions. First, more Labourites are attacking Labour. Second, they are doing it just as the case for shutting up is growing stronger.

Start with the new wave of internecine vitriol. For Follett was no freak. He was only putting into airport thriller language sentiments already expressed less luridly by others. Mo Mowlam, Clare Short and Frank Field have all complained, in one form or another, of the "men in the dark" who spread poison about their colleagues.

What was new was Follett's aim of the arrow so precisely in the direction of the prime minister. Until now politicos had obeyed the ancient law of the regal court: you must never attack the king, only his "evil ministers". For a while that held, so that anyone who wanted to pour scorn on the New Labour project unleashed it on Peter Mandelson or Alastair Campbell rather than Tony Blair. Now that rule has been trashed: the PM has become a legitimate target.

The conventional wisdom traces the death of Blair's immunity to that Ceaucescu moment at the Women's Institute, when an audience of real people dared to rain on the Sun King. But the quieter shift may have struck a day or two earlier, when Labour's former general secretary, Tom Sawyer, broke the Tudor rule - and criticised the leader directly. He said Blair lacked the personal connection with the voters that had kept Margaret Thatcher in business, and that his standing within Labour was particularly low. Sawyer could not be dismissed as a crypto-Tory like the women of the WI; he is a party stalwart and a credentialed Blairite. Just like Ken Follett.

What their interventions, and the echoes from assorted middle-ranking former ministers, have proved is that the magic ring of confidence that once encircled the PM is broken. But the timing is odd. For this cracking of Labour self-discipline comes just when that quality is needed most, a time when political parties normally close ranks and unite behind their leader - it comes, in short, just before a general election.

OK, we're not exactly on the eve of polling day. But when summer is over, we'll be into pre-election party conferences (unless Blair surprises us all and holds on for a full five years). Now should be the season of buried differences and full-frontal assault on the opposition. But that is not happening inside the centre-left camp: instead we are turning on each other.

Why? Part of it is history. The left tribe has always been congenitally fratricidal; it comes with the territory. A movement rooted in dissent does not have much talent for conformity or even for unity. People who believe in reform are not temperamentally suited to cheering the status quo - even when it is their own side in charge of it. For proof, just recall the party conferences of old. Long before news management, the Tories were the loyal applauders, happy to be stage-managed and to wave the flag. Labour's were slanging matches and blood feuds - as full of tensions as a family at Christmas. When Labour is in government the problem is even worse: the myth of perennial betrayal runs so deep, many on the left woke up on May 2 1997 ready to feel let down.

A second cause, to be fair to the tribe, is the conduct of New Labour and of Blair in particular. It is hard to jump to the barricades for a man who suggests on-the-spot cashpoint fines for louts - and then, when rebuffed by the police, insists the whole idea, though spun in advance and stated explicitly, was only a "metaphor". That is an insult to the intelligence of every voter who heard it.

But a third factor might be a simple absence of fear. Too few on the left actually think there is any threat out there; too few believe the Tories have any chance of getting back. The polls are moving, but the impression has frozen in Labour-supporting minds that William Hague is unelectable and that a second term is assured. There is no need to stand together because there is no credible threat to face. Tony Blair never tires of saying that the choice is not between this Labour government and the Labour government of your dreams, but between this one and the Conservatives. All too few take that seriously. Instead they concentrate on perfecting this administration, imagining its 179-seat majority is good for 10 years.

The American left went through something similar in the first two years of Bill Clinton's presidency. They attacked him for his weakness and his lack of vision - until Newt Gingrich came along. He scared activists and commentators so much, they scrambled back to Clinton as the shield who alone could save them from the rightwing horrors of Gingrichism.

Our system is not like theirs: Hague's gains in the polls do not translate into the power to do real things which might start frightening people back into the Labour fold. But we should think on the prospect anyway. We should close our eyes and imagine the morning of, say, May 4 2001 - when a smiling William and Ffion are waving outside Number 10, Michael Portillo next door and Ann Widdecombe polishing the leg-irons at the Home Office.

If that sounds absurd, then listen to what the right is telling itself. In the Times yesterday, Michael Gove promised the Tories they were on their way to a famous victory. The more "Labour at war" headlines they see, the bolder, and more disciplined, they become. They may be wrong. And fear of a Conservative comeback is hardly a sufficient motive for backing Labour. But we should remember the alternative - even as we fulfil the obligation of every true friend, and keep on supplying the candid advice.

We should remember that image - Hague, smiling and waving outside Number 10 - just before we fall asleep, every night from now until polling day.

webTitle: Gore and Bush dance to a Latin beat

fields.headline: Gore and Bush dance to a Latin beat
fields.standfirst:
Hispanic votes pave the rival paths to the White House

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Hispanic votes pave the rival paths to the White House
fields.body:
The music of Santana blasts out over loudspeakers as 2,000 of America's Latino activists settle down behind white tablecloths in the ballroom on this warm Californian evening.

Tonight the second most powerful man in the land is going to ask them to dance, as it were, and how they respond will be seen as signalling which way the country's fastest growing ethnic minority will vote in this November's presidential election.

Traditionally the Latino vote has gone to the Democrats, but Al Gore, trailing George W Bush in most polls, knows he can take nothing for granted. Most recent national surveys have shown him behind Mr Bush.

Nevertheless, his team are heartened by the latest Newsweek poll, which shows him ahead of Bush by 46% to 45%, although dipping below his Republican rival if the Green party's Ralph Nader and his 6% is included in the equation.

The poll encapsulates Mr Gore's dilemma: he must keep the traditional Democrat vote from the unions, ethnic minorities and environmentalists while reassuring the floaters that he is committed to a healthy economy.

The style of the two candidates as the campaign enters its pre-convention stage is also a sign of how the race is running. While Mr Bush banters with crowds and reporters, Mr Gore earnestly delivers policy measures on everything from education and immigration to health care and military training.

In past elections the courted voter was the "soccer mom", but this year it is the Latino family. Although the Latino vote accounts for only 6% nationally, in such crucial states as California, Texas and New York it is significantly higher.

Mr Bush has been making a big effort with Spanish language commercials and much reference to his Latino sister-in-law, and polls of Latinos show the gap between the two men narrowing. He has also been pushed by Mr Gore into denying that he is "anti-immigration" and "anti-education", accusations which the Gore team hope will bring the newly powerful immigrant communities towards the Democrats.

So this week both men will be addressing the national council of La Raza in San Diego, since 1968 the main Latino civil-rights organisation in the US, and one whose approval a candidate must win if he is to activate the large but slumbering Latino vote.

Looking very Anglo in his suit, white shirt and red tie, Mr Gore does his best to let the audience know that there is a little Latin in his soul. His speech is punctuated with enough " felicidades " and " si, se puedes " and " de nadas " to let them know that both his heart and his phrase book are in the right place. And he knows which buttons to press for standing ovations.

"All of America can learn from the Latino community about the importance of family," he tells them. Praising the family to a Latino audience is like telling the British voter that dogs are nice little fellows but Mr Gore is anxious to reassure his constituency before he takes questions from the crowd.

"I honour all the parents who read to their children at night," he says. "My wife Tipper and I have done that to each of our four children."

He is a grandfather, he explains, who has just celebrated his 30th wedding anniversary. How many here have celebrated 30 years of marriage? Since a long marriage in Cali fornia is around 18 months, this is not too fertile territory and the vice-president seems much more at ease when he is dealing with the weightier matters of health policy, the economy and civil rights.

"We have the lowest Latino unemployment rate in the history of the United States," he says. "This is a time of pride and plenty." This week he has been outlining key reforms in medical insurance, pledging that by the end of his first term he would make sure that every child had medical insurance; currently one in four Latino children do not.

He attacks the pharmaceutical companies for keeping their prices high and the insurance companies for their reluctance to pay up, subliminally blaming them for the poor health of Latino children.

Then come the questions from the floor. There are a few lobbed pelotas . On funding for the arts? "The arts are like air and water, we need them to lead good healthy lives." Affirmative action? "I'm strongly in favour of it and Governor Bush is opposed to it."

Then some younger Latinos ask some rather tougher questions. What about the 541 would-be migrants who have died crossing the border in the five years since the US started its get-tough Operation Gatekeeper policy?

"Every country has a duty to protect its border but it must be done with compassion, with respect for human dignity . . . If you elect me president, I will change that."

A young man asks about the bombing tests on the Puerto Rican island of Vieques. "I believe the bombing should stop as soon as possible."

How many Latino faces would there be in a Gore cabinet, and when would there be the first Latino supreme court judge? "My cabinet will look like America, it will embody the diversity of America."

The reception is friendly and enthusiastic if not ecstatic. Yes, seems to be the answer, they would like to dance but they are still not entirely certain whether Mr Gore is going to stand on their toes.

Gilberto Moreno, from Houston, says, as Mr Gore disappears in a sea of shaken hands and flashing cameras: "I think he did extremely well. I don't believe Bush will get the same kind of reception."

Edna Esquer, 28, an activist in the National Association of Hispanic Nurses, is also impressed. "He has improved ac cess to health care and he's very proactive. Yes, I think he will be able to persuade young Latinos to vote for him."

Outside, a handful of anti-abortion protesters carry placards of blown-up foetuses and a sign saying "Liar, Liar, Pants on Fire", while some Bush supporters discreetly hand out a leaflet mocking Mr Gore for being a "suck-up"' to the Latino community.

Mr Bush, a Dallas reporter covering the conference says, has the greater facility in Spanish, but few past presidents have ever managed much more than an " adios, amigos " over a campaign burrito. One former vice-president, Dan Quayle, is still credited with having thought that the people of Latin America spoke Latin.

There is more glad-handing to be done before Mr Gore is driven past the trolley-cars and palm trees to the airport for his plane back to Washington.

As he leaves the rally with La Raza, Santana's Supernatural speeds him on his way. Right now, Mr Gore would probably settle for just plain natural.

But at least he was present at a vast gathering of Latinos who cheered loudly when the Californian lieutenant governor, Cruz Bustamente, welcomed him as "the next president of the United States".

So this week both men will be addressing the national council of La Raza in San Diego, since 1968 the main Latino civil-rights organisation in the US, and one whose approval a candidate must win if he is to activate the large but slumbering Latino vote. Looking very Anglo in his suit, white shirt and red tie, Mr Gore does his best to let the audience know that there is a little Latin in his soul. His speech is punctuated with enough " felicidades " and " si, se puedes " and " de nadas " to let them know that both his heart and his phrase book are in the right place. And he knows which buttons to press for standing ovations. "All of America can learn from the Latino community about the importance of family," he tells them. Praising the family to a Latino audience is like telling the British voter that dogs are nice little fellows but Mr Gore is anxious to reassure his constituency before he takes questions from the crowd. "I honour all the parents who read to their children at night," he says. "My wife Tipper and I have done that to each of our four children." He is a grandfather, he explains, who has just celebrated his 30th wedding anniversary. How many here have celebrated 30 years of marriage? Since a long marriage in Cali fornia is around 18 months, this is not too fertile territory and the vice-president seems much more at ease when he is dealing with the weightier matters of health policy, the economy and civil rights. "We have the lowest Latino unemployment rate in the history of the United States," he says. "This is a time of pride and plenty." This week he has been outlining key reforms in medical insurance, pledging that by the end of his first term he would make sure that every child had medical insurance; currently one in four Latino children do not. He attacks the pharmaceutical companies for keeping their prices high and the insurance companies for their reluctance to pay up, subliminally blaming them for the poor health of Latino children. Then come the questions from the floor. There are a few lobbed pelotas . On funding for the arts? "The arts are like air and water, we need them to lead good healthy lives." Affirmative action? "I'm strongly in favour of it and Governor Bush is opposed to it." Then some younger Latinos ask some rather tougher questions. What about the 541 would-be migrants who have died crossing the border in the five years since the US started its get-tough Operation Gatekeeper policy? "Every country has a duty to protect its border but it must be done with compassion, with respect for human dignity . . . If you elect me president, I will change that." A young man asks about the bombing tests on the Puerto Rican island of Vieques. "I believe the bombing should stop as soon as possible." How many Latino faces would there be in a Gore cabinet, and when would there be the first Latino supreme court judge? "My cabinet will look like America, it will embody the diversity of America." The reception is friendly and enthusiastic if not ecstatic. Yes, seems to be the answer, they would like to dance but they are still not entirely certain whether Mr Gore is going to stand on their toes. Gilberto Moreno, from Houston, says, as Mr Gore disappears in a sea of shaken hands and flashing cameras: "I think he did extremely well. I don't believe Bush will get the same kind of reception." Edna Esquer, 28, an activist in the National Association of Hispanic Nurses, is also impressed. "He has improved ac cess to health care and he's very proactive. Yes, I think he will be able to persuade young Latinos to vote for him." Outside, a handful of anti-abortion protesters carry placards of blown-up foetuses and a sign saying "Liar, Liar, Pants on Fire", while some Bush supporters discreetly hand out a leaflet mocking Mr Gore for being a "suck-up"' to the Latino community. Mr Bush, a Dallas reporter covering the conference says, has the greater facility in Spanish, but few past presidents have ever managed much more than an " adios, amigos " over a campaign burrito. One former vice-president, Dan Quayle, is still credited with having thought that the people of Latin America spoke Latin. There is more glad-handing to be done before Mr Gore is driven past the trolley-cars and palm trees to the airport for his plane back to Washington. As he leaves the rally with La Raza, Santana's Supernatural speeds him on his way. Right now, Mr Gore would probably settle for just plain natural. But at least he was present at a vast gathering of Latinos who cheered loudly when the Californian lieutenant governor, Cruz Bustamente, welcomed him as "the next president of the United States".

fields.headline: Devolve and thrive
fields.standfirst:
The Scottish parliament and Welsh assembly offer a useful lesson in comparative governance. Now they need to enthuse the public

Devolution in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The Scottish parliament and Welsh assembly offer a useful lesson in comparative governance. Now they need to enthuse the public
fields.body:
I didn't see any flags in the streets of Glasgow this week and according to the polls Scottish people are none too impressed by the first year of their new parliament. Its anniversary is worth observing none the less. Forget high-flown stuff about reconvening an institution that shut up shop in 1707 and look at the day to day performance. Coalition has worked (and allowed Scotland to break away on student fees). Backbenchers do a proper job in their committees. The Edinburgh parliament's style (including civilised hours of operation) puts the unmodernised House of Commons to shame. Whatever else gets written in Tony Blair's epitaph, it will say he shifted power away from Westminster. Irreversibly.

The doings at Holyrood and on Cardiff Bay have not exactly set news editors' hearts aflutter, except perhaps for the fight over section 28 (Clause 28, section 2a is the Scottish designation), and the deposition of Alun Michael. But that poses a risk that people in England will not profit from a lesson in comparative governance.

It is worth reading. If law-making is what legislatures are about, Holyrood can claim to have improved productivity. It has passed seven bills (including, finally, the abolition of Scottish feudalism) and has 11 statutes under consideration - not a bad record compared with the one to two specifically Scottish bills that used to be passed by the Westminster parliament each year. Edinburgh committees look at bills in advance. They have made an effort not to dance to the executive's tune, allowing Tommy Sheridan, the sole representative of the Scottish Socialist party, to secure his bill forbidding forced sales of debtors' property. They are holding inquiries on drugs and community care. The Labour-Liberal Democrat executive will find it hard to sideline them over housing stock transfers and council finance (a third of MSPs are former councillors).

In Wales, however, the complaint is that too much time has been spent with lawyers poring over exactly what the assembly's "secondary" powers are. There the relationship between executive and backbenches has not been settled.

Throughout the western world, confidence in public institutions has been sliding so the biggest question to be asked about devolution is whether the new setup has tickled the public's palate. The parliament's leaders have, with the exception of Donald Dewar and Jim Wallace, yet to become household names. But its poor press may not be MSPs' fault. The past year has been marked by atavistic antagonism of two of Scotland's leading papers, the Daily Record, part of the Mirror group, and Andrew Neil's Scotsman - owned by those famous Channel Islanders, the Barclays.

Perhaps press barons, multinationals and (a scandal blew up in Edinburgh earlier this year) lobbyists may find it easier to target small-country politicians. Besides, the parliament scored some own goals. The death this week of Enric Miralles, architect of its proposed new home, has probably not helped public perceptions of mismanagement - the building having started out at £40m but now is likely to cost some £195m. The Welsh assembly's new home will probably cost £30m and that is before a decision is made on physically separating legislature and executive - but Cardiff gets a splendid new building in return.

Yet the new arrangements have their pluses. The chart shows the high proportion of women involved. True, vested interests have been palliated (farmers in Wales for example). They have also been upset - Scottish lawyers do not like MSPs' interest in their appointments and practices. The style in both Edinburgh and Cardiff is participative, so much so that voluntary groups and churches, called in to give evidence, have complained of "fatigue". To make parliament work, says researcher Sue Innes, you need to "build capacity" in civil society, which might entail grants for interest groups so they can attend committee hearings.

The new bodies carry a few Westminster genes. Some 19% of MSPs have been MPs, 15% in Cardiff. But a self- sufficient political class is in formation, not just representatives but lobbyists, aides as well. A question becomes how far the best and brightest begin to see parliament and assembly as the summit of their ambitions, rather than Westminster (or Strasbourg). Cardiff's older guard has been cleared out. Plaid Cymru's Dafydd Wigley is retiring; Tory leader Rod Richard is unlikely to recover. Meanwhile Labour's Rhodri Morgan is carving out a niche for himself at some distance from Millbank. In Edinburgh the race to succeed recuperating Donald Dewar has quietly begun.

Ron Davies, the man destined to lead the new Welsh assembly but for an amble on the common, called devolution a process not an event. Right, the redistribution of power has not ended. The Welsh assembly will, probably after the elections due in 2003, press for more powers. The "B" word (Barnett) hovers over Holyrood, though surprisingly the parliament's allocation has not yet been called into question.

That is because MSPs have focused on practical, do-able politics. Ralf Dahrendorf, the social thinker, recently warned "defenders of democracy do well to remain cautious of regionalism". Small, more homogeneous units might attract authoritarians and become intolerant. So far there have been no signs of such a development. Banality has triumphed in the past 12 months but that is how it should be, in the establishment of an executive and legislature that work. As a result (to borrow Tom Nairn's phrase), Ukanian government looks a lot healthier now than in April 1997.

fields.headline: Bailiffs will lose seizure powers
fields.trailText: The government is to remove bailiffs' powers to seize private property to recover lost debts following legal advice that it breaches the European Convention on Human Rights.
fields.body:
The government is to remove bailiffs' powers to seize private property to recover lost debts following legal advice that it breaches the European Convention on Human Rights.

Lord Irvine, the lord chancellor, has been one of the great champions of incorporation of the European convention into British law and has been undertaking a thorough review of all British court procedures to ensure they are compliant.

All bailiffs are required to apply for county court certificates, lasting two years. But they are not required to seek court orders in advance of seizing private property on behalf of landlords seeking to recover rent arrears.

Their powers arise from laws passed in 1888. The law commission has recommended that the power be removed, or that it can be constrained by a requirement to seek a court order first. The power has been used less frequently by private sector landlords, than by landlords seeking to recover debt owed on commercial premises.

The Lord Chancellor's department has been advised that the practice may breach conventions covering the right to private property, and the right to a fair trial. Arguably it also breaches the right to privacy and a family life. The European Convention is due to come into force in Britain on October 2 and has prompted a review of public administration rules right across Whitehall, the police, the courts and local government.

The review of the powers of distress has been examined as a part of a wider review by the Lord Chancellor's department into the powers of enforcement in courts, including attachment of earnings by the courts. The review is also examining whether a distinction can be made between debts due to inability to pay, and debts due to an unwillingness to do so.

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.trailText:
Book of the day
Lady Thatcher is promising us a riveting new read. Not content with churning out two volumes of her personal memoirs she is now threatening to issue a third tome, about leadership and how leaders should follow her advice. She says in the age of spin doctors and soundbites leaders are tempted to follow fashion rather than their instincts. "That was not how the west won the cold war," she thunders. A sure bestseller then.

Asked about his thoughts on the threat from above Mr Kaufman was nonplussed. "I do not feel like responding," he said.

webTitle: Tories issue new farming challenge to EU

fields.headline: Tories issue new farming challenge to EU
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The government joined forces last night with pro-European Tories to lambast William Hague after he unveiled a blueprint for British farming which laid the ground for renewed confrontation with the European Union. The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, accused Mr Hague of "anti-European extremism" after the Tory leader held out the prospect of a unilateral ban on imports of EU food.
fields.body:
The government joined forces last night with pro-European Tories to lambast William Hague after he unveiled a blueprint for British farming which laid the ground for renewed confrontation with the European Union. The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, accused Mr Hague of "anti-European extremism" after the Tory leader held out the prospect of a unilateral ban on imports of EU food.

His remarks were echoed by a senior pro-European Conservative who described the new Tory farming policy as "barmy". The cross-party criticism of Mr Hague came after the Tories unveiled a new set of policies, entitled Fair Deal for Farmers, which are designed to court the votes of farmers who have suffered a massive drop in income in recent years.

In a provocative move, the shadow agriculture minister Tim Yeo warned that a Tory government would take retaliatory action against the EU over the beef ban by banning the import of European beef which fell below British safety standards.

Mr Yeo also promised unilateral British action on food labelling to end "misleading European labelling". Speaking at the Royal Agricultural Show in Stoneleigh, Warwickshire, Mr Yeo underlined his Eurosceptic approach to farming when he rounded on the government for its handling of Europe. "Britain needs a government and minister of agriculture who stand up for British industry in Europe," Mr Yeo said. "The story under this Labour government has been one of consistent refusal to confront any European government or institution, however unlawful or damaging their policies," Mr Yeo said.

His outburst was rejected by Mr Brown who launched a scathing attack on the Tory document. "Banning imports would start a trade war, putting at risk £6bn of British food and drinks exports to Europe," said the agriculture minister. "Unilateral action on food labelling would undermine the legal basis of free trade in the European single market. All this shows that the Tories are more extreme than ever and have only one solution for the complex problems facing British farming: blame Europe."

Mr Brown's attack was echoed by a pro-European Tory. The former Tory minister, who asked to remain anonymous, said: "Banning imports which do not meet our high animal welfare standards is barmy. It is illegal and it would risk other British exports. These are the sort of ideas which are dreamt up in a pub at 2.30 on a Sunday afternoon."

fields.headline: No more girl power
fields.standfirst: Girl Thing  were meant to be the new Spice Girls. But the public had other ideas.  Caroline Sullivan  reports
fields.trailText: Girl Thing were meant to be the new Spice Girls. But the public had other ideas. Caroline Sullivan reports
fields.body:
Although it's hard to remember a time when the Spice Girls didn't exist, it's only four years since they exploded out of their shared house in Maidenhead with their debut single, Wannabe. Reviews at the time could not have been less flattering. The group were pronounced cynical, derivative and talentless, and the term "one-hit wonder" cropped up constantly. Twenty-eight million albums down the line...

Their original manager, Chris Herbert, says he spotted a gap in the market for a female counterpart to the then-reigning Take That, and went about building a group to fill it. Their success probably had more to do with luck and soundbites than with foresight on his part, but one thing everybody agrees now is that before the Spice Girls, British girl-pop was nowhere.

Nothing succeeds like success, and four years later you can hardly move for sassy girls with bare midriffs. There's All Saints, of course; there's the Irish Spices B*Witched, the Scouse Spices, Atomic Kitten, and Hepburn, whose gimmick is playing their own instruments. There's even a Jonathan King-backed outfit called Six Chix, whose oldest member is 52.

Most of these bands were recruited from stage schools by managers or labels working to a specific brief: to find the next Spice Girls. "A lot of the groups are very the same, trying to be them," says Celeste Cruz of teen duo Daphne & Celeste, knowledgably.

But even as it seems that this particular genre can't be milked any further, the industry magazine Music Week has announced that this year will see the launch of another 35 girl bands. That's on top of the 20 or so that emerged in 1999. All of them are praying they'll be the next Spice Girls, while insisting that they're nothing like them.

None more so than Girl Thing, who are on course to be 2000's biggest success - or else its most ignominious flop. Though most people were probably unaware of them before last month's debut single, Last One Standing, they've been "in development" for two years, working through a rumoured £1.5m advance spend. If true, that makes this one of the most expensive launches ever, and they'll need to sell a vast number of records to recoup it.

Invented by a kiddy-pop dream team consisting of Chris Herbert, A&R man Simon Cowell (who gave us Westlife and Five) and the former Smash Hits editor Gavin Reeve, the five-piece have been painstakingly positioned to take up the Spice mantle. And the finished product is impressive, as these things go.

Linzi, Nikki, Michelle, Jodi and the token foreigner Anika (a Gemini from Rotterdam) have the same easily copied Top Shop fashion sense as the early Spice Girls, and the crucial up-for-it mentality that made them so appealing.

"We're like a big gang, and we want everyone to join us," roars 19-year-old Linzi Thing, whose hobby is "having a laugh". That's exactly the attitude that attracted little girls in their millions back in 1996.

Last One Standing, co-written by the Spice songwriter Eliott Kennedy, even sounds brazenly similar to Wannabe, cleverly alternating playground-style rap and sweet harmonies. The Spices might take the lyric personally, too: "It's the end of an era, the start of a new day... Forget everything you've heard before, no matter how many times you hear this, you wanna hear it some more."

Just one problem - all of this presupposes that the public wants a carbon copy of the Spice Girls, and that's where, at the moment anyway, Girl Thing are going wrong.

"People don't want another Spice Girls. I think they underestimated the intelligence of their audience," says a publicist. The fact that the song wasn't playlisted on Radio 1 didn't help. And so, despite one of the most aggressive campaigns in teen-pop history, including a lavish press launch at the Eiffel Tower and a Smash Hits cover (a first for the magazine, which has never given a cover to a band that hasn't had a top-five single), Last One Standing entered the chart at a not very sensational number eight. Even a Top of the Pops appearance on Friday didn't keep it from sliding to 19 in its second week.

"The level of promotion demanded a top three at least, so the opinion is that it hasn't performed as well as it might have done," says Hugh Goldsmith, manager of rivals Atomic Kitten. "Ten-year-old kids have already seen the Spices once. They're hip to what's happening and aware they're being targeted."

"Obviously, not enough people wanted to buy the record," Cowell admits. "Maybe it is a bit close to Wannabe. We wouldn't have released if we'd known there'd be such a backlash. But this record will probably sell 100,000 in the UK, we've gone in at eight, which is fine, and we're poised to put out a much stronger song for the second record [So You Want to Have Sex]. This is going to work for them."

Girl Thing are just one of almost three dozen Spicealikes, and would-be fans are shunning all of them. Recent chart positions of other girl groups aren't encouraging. Even B*Witched, the first girl group to have four singles enter the chart at number one, only managed a miserable 16 for their last record. Of the newer bands, only Daphne & Celeste and Atomic Kitten have managed to get into the top 10, while the much-promoted Six Chix scraped in at 72.

"You're either alive or dead now on your first record," Cowell once said. "If your first record doesn't go top 10, you've got a major problem." Under-performers such as Hepburn and 21st Century Girls (the latter are protegees of the ex-Spice Girls manager Simon Fuller) have already been dropped by their labels, along with the more successful Fierce, whose top-three single apparently cut no ice.

It's a pop jungle out there, with more and more groups competing for the same group of 10 to 15- year-old fans, who must be pretty bewildered by now. Factor in the number of boy bands also hungry for the kiddy pound and it's no wonder that only the very biggest, such as Westlife and All Saints, are actually selling records in any numbers.

"In some ways Girl Thing are a test case," says the editor of Smash Hits, John McKie. Which means that it's impossible to second-guess a market as fickle as young teenagers. What worked in 1998, when Operation Girl Thing began, won't necessarily work in 2000.

What pop needs is a new Spice Girls, yet a Spice Girls that's somehow different. Witness the growing support for R&B soloists such as Jamelia and the black Irish teenager Samantha Mumba, whose first single debuted at number two this week. "I don't think Samantha would have had the same impact if she'd been part of a five-piece group," muses her A&R manager, Peter Lorraine. Something for those dozens of girl groups to think about.
fields.bodyText: Although it's hard to remember a time when the Spice Girls didn't exist, it's only four years since they exploded out of their shared house in Maidenhead with their debut single, Wannabe. Reviews at the time could not have been less flattering. The group were pronounced cynical, derivative and talentless, and the term "one-hit wonder" cropped up constantly. Twenty-eight million albums down the line... Their original manager, Chris Herbert, says he spotted a gap in the market for a female counterpart to the then-reigning Take That, and went about building a group to fill it. Their success probably had more to do with luck and soundbites than with foresight on his part, but one thing everybody agrees now is that before the Spice Girls, British girl-pop was nowhere. Nothing succeeds like success, and four years later you can hardly move for sassy girls with bare midriffs. There's All Saints, of course; there's the Irish Spices B*Witched, the Scouse Spices, Atomic Kitten, and Hepburn, whose gimmick is playing their own instruments. There's even a Jonathan King-backed outfit called Six Chix, whose oldest member is 52. Most of these bands were recruited from stage schools by managers or labels working to a specific brief: to find the next Spice Girls. "A lot of the groups are very the same, trying to be them," says Celeste Cruz of teen duo Daphne & Celeste, knowledgably. But even as it seems that this particular genre can't be milked any further, the industry magazine Music Week has announced that this year will see the launch of another 35 girl bands. That's on top of the 20 or so that emerged in 1999. All of them are praying they'll be the next Spice Girls, while insisting that they're nothing like them. None more so than Girl Thing, who are on course to be 2000's biggest success - or else its most ignominious flop. Though most people were probably unaware of them before last month's debut single, Last One Standing, they've been "in development" for two years, working through a rumoured £1.5m advance spend. If true, that makes this one of the most expensive launches ever, and they'll need to sell a vast number of records to recoup it. Invented by a kiddy-pop dream team consisting of Chris Herbert, A&R man Simon Cowell (who gave us Westlife and Five) and the former Smash Hits editor Gavin Reeve, the five-piece have been painstakingly positioned to take up the Spice mantle. And the finished product is impressive, as these things go. Linzi, Nikki, Michelle, Jodi and the token foreigner Anika (a Gemini from Rotterdam) have the same easily copied Top Shop fashion sense as the early Spice Girls, and the crucial up-for-it mentality that made them so appealing. "We're like a big gang, and we want everyone to join us," roars 19-year-old Linzi Thing, whose hobby is "having a laugh". That's exactly the attitude that attracted little girls in their millions back in 1996. Last One Standing, co-written by the Spice songwriter Eliott Kennedy, even sounds brazenly similar to Wannabe, cleverly alternating playground-style rap and sweet harmonies. The Spices might take the lyric personally, too: "It's the end of an era, the start of a new day... Forget everything you've heard before, no matter how many times you hear this, you wanna hear it some more." Just one problem - all of this presupposes that the public wants a carbon copy of the Spice Girls, and that's where, at the moment anyway, Girl Thing are going wrong. "People don't want another Spice Girls. I think they underestimated the intelligence of their audience," says a publicist. The fact that the song wasn't playlisted on Radio 1 didn't help. And so, despite one of the most aggressive campaigns in teen-pop history, including a lavish press launch at the Eiffel Tower and a Smash Hits cover (a first for the magazine, which has never given a cover to a band that hasn't had a top-five single), Last One Standing entered the chart at a not very sensational number eight. Even a Top of the Pops appearance on Friday didn't keep it from sliding to 19 in its second week. "The level of promotion demanded a top three at least, so the opinion is that it hasn't performed as well as it might have done," says Hugh Goldsmith, manager of rivals Atomic Kitten. "Ten-year-old kids have already seen the Spices once. They're hip to what's happening and aware they're being targeted." "Obviously, not enough people wanted to buy the record," Cowell admits. "Maybe it is a bit close to Wannabe. We wouldn't have released if we'd known there'd be such a backlash. But this record will probably sell 100,000 in the UK, we've gone in at eight, which is fine, and we're poised to put out a much stronger song for the second record [So You Want to Have Sex]. This is going to work for them." Girl Thing are just one of almost three dozen Spicealikes, and would-be fans are shunning all of them. Recent chart positions of other girl groups aren't encouraging. Even B*Witched, the first girl group to have four singles enter the chart at number one, only managed a miserable 16 for their last record. Of the newer bands, only Daphne & Celeste and Atomic Kitten have managed to get into the top 10, while the much-promoted Six Chix scraped in at 72. "You're either alive or dead now on your first record," Cowell once said. "If your first record doesn't go top 10, you've got a major problem." Under-performers such as Hepburn and 21st Century Girls (the latter are protegees of the ex-Spice Girls manager Simon Fuller) have already been dropped by their labels, along with the more successful Fierce, whose top-three single apparently cut no ice. It's a pop jungle out there, with more and more groups competing for the same group of 10 to 15- year-old fans, who must be pretty bewildered by now. Factor in the number of boy bands also hungry for the kiddy pound and it's no wonder that only the very biggest, such as Westlife and All Saints, are actually selling records in any numbers. "In some ways Girl Thing are a test case," says the editor of Smash Hits, John McKie. Which means that it's impossible to second-guess a market as fickle as young teenagers. What worked in 1998, when Operation Girl Thing began, won't necessarily work in 2000. What pop needs is a new Spice Girls, yet a Spice Girls that's somehow different. Witness the growing support for R&B soloists such as Jamelia and the black Irish teenager Samantha Mumba, whose first single debuted at number two this week. "I don't think Samantha would have had the same impact if she'd been part of a five-piece group," muses her A&R manager, Peter Lorraine. Something for those dozens of girl groups to think about.

webTitle: Why I fell in love with the Scottish colourists

fields.headline: Why I fell in love with the Scottish colourists
fields.standfirst: By  Michael Portillo
fields.trailText: By Michael Portillo
fields.body:
M y Scottish grandfather, John W Blyth, was a man addicted to paintings. A manufacturer of linen, he spent all his surplus money on pictures. My grandmother was worried not only about the amount of cash he was spending, but also about where in their Kirkcaldy home the paintings might be kept.

So my grandfather took to smuggling paintings into the house and returning from work at lunchtime so that he could look at each new acquisition; only very gradually would he let it emerge that he had made a new purchase. It is a lovely image: a man coming home in his lunch hour simply to stare at one painting.

Many of the works he owned were huge, imposing canvases by William McTaggart which he hung in his stairwell - pictures of storm-lashed seas, children cowering in mortal terror on beaches being pounded by the wind and the rain. I remember climbing the stairs to bed and being frightened by them. But many of the others were works by the four Scottish Colourists - Samuel John Peploe, of whom I always think first, but also Francis Campbell Boileau Cadell, John Duncan Fergusson and George Leslie Hunter - and they are part of my childhood.

My grandfather, who was always keen to promote living artists, staged an unprecedented exhibition of Peploe's works at Kirkcaldy in 1928. So I am in no sense an impartial witness to the exhibition of the Colourists' work that has just opened at the Royal Academy.

They were rather modest people, unashamedly influenced by the French Impressionists but also happy to refer in their work to other influences from the history of art. They probably did not understand in what high regard they would be held today.

It is their great commitment to light that impresses me the most. As others have written, the term "colourist" is a strange one and it is the light, rather than the colour, that hits you first. Their paintings of Royan and the other French towns they visited exude a tremendous feel of light and heat; whether it is the cold, white light of a beach in Iona or the brilliant, dazzling light of Antibes. That said, there is also a tremendous imagination in their risk-taking with colour: a shadow might be painted counterintuitively orange; the side of a ship outlined in bright colours - bold colours that are most imposing when the paintings are viewed from a distance.

These are pictures that lift the heart - I can never remember being depressed by any of the Colourists' paintings. Especially compared with McTaggart, the Colourists have an enormous amount of humour, particularly when they're painting Paris - there's always something humorous about the way the ladies are sitting, or the portrayal of the French waiter, with his apron and his bouteilles de vin. Even the still lifes are, generally speaking, positive: these are not portrayals of decay but a celebration of life.

But perhaps the most important factor explaining the Colourists' popularity today is that they are approachable: they do not require an enormous amount of interpretation. And they are in profusion. There are around 1,000 Peploe oils in existence, and while most people can never aspire to owning a Renoir or a Cézanne, it is just possible to imagine owning a Peploe or a Fergusson.

When the Kirkcaldy gallery held a commemorative Peploe exhibition in 1998, it was the first to be staged in the 70 years since the one my grandfather had organised.The John W Blyth collection still hangs in the art gallery at Kirkcaldy today. I often visit, and seeing those paintings now I can still remember how they made me feel as a small boy. If the Royal Academy exhibition whets your appetite, Kirkcaldy is well worth a visit. The place has been renovated, the pictures re-hung - and the tea shop serves some of the most outstanding teas anywhere in the UK.

 Michael Portillo was talking to Oliver Burkeman. The Scottish Colourists 1900-1930 is at the Royal Academy, London W1 (020-7300 8000), till September 24 and at the Scottish National Gallery of Modern Art, Edinburgh (0131-624 6200), from November 4 till January 28 2001.
