webTitle: 'God has blessed me with a unique ability to defy reality'

fields.headline: 'God has blessed me with a unique ability to defy reality'
fields.standfirst: Michael Fenne was a colourful boss. He harangued workers over the public address system, made staff pray in his office and, worst of all, spent most of the company's money on a lavish launch party. But no one realised quite how colourful he was - until a colleague noticed his resemblance to a notorious con-man on the run from the law.  Dan Goodin  unravels a tale of greed, guile and gullibility
fields.trailText: Michael Fenne was a colourful boss. He harangued workers over the public address system, made staff pray in his office and, worst of all, spent most of the company's money on a lavish launch party. But no one realised quite how colourful he was - until a colleague noticed his resemblance to a notorious con-man on the run from the law.  Dan Goodin  unravels a tale of greed, guile and gullibility
fields.body:
Late in the afternoon of November 12 last year, several squad cars from the Orange County sheriff's department converged on San Juan Capistrano in California, home of Pixelon, a high-profile internet company selling a new way of broadcasting television-quality video over the internet. A hastily formed coalition of company officers and directors were planning to oust Pixelon's founder and chairman, Michael Fenne. They had called the police because they worried Fenne - a big man weighing in at 350lbs - might turn violent.

From the start, Fenne - who was partial to signing his emails "Big Giant Head of Pixelon" - had proven a highly unusual founder. He had demanded that he be paid out of the company's expense account, and displayed a tyrannical and bizarre management style, requiring some employees to work 36-hour shifts and holding a mandatory prayer meeting in his office. But the final straw had come when the company's investors learned that Pixelon had spent $16m (£10.8m) of a recently agreed $20m (£13.6m) round of financing on a star-studded launch party. Lee Wiskowski - chairman of Advanced Equities, the Chicago investment bank that had handled the financing, and a Pixelon director - had hastened to company headquarters for an emergency board meeting.

The first thing Wiskowski and his two companions heard when they arrived was the sound of Fenne's voice over the Pixelon public address system. "This is the master speaking," at least a half dozen people present remember Fenne barking. "George better respond to me immediately, and if he doesn't have all the answers I might have to take him out behind the barn for a whooping!" Another message rang out: "Frank, report to the woodshed, your uncle is going to give you a whooping." The messages might have been funny - were it not for the air of fear they created.

Later that morning, a Pixelon executive briefed Wiskowski's group. A week or two earlier, the executive told them, he had walked into Fenne's office for a meeting to find another executive on his hands and knees with his head bowed before Fenne, who was sitting in a chair with his hands on the man's head. "I've never been around a cult leader, but that's the way it felt," the executive told the team. "This feels weird," one member of the group planning to remove Fenne from the board remembers confiding to another. "This feels like someone could die tonight."

Only later, after Fenne was given the boot and the company was struggling to regain its footing, would the full truth emerge: Michael Fenne, the charismatic man who raised more than $28m (£19m) for his venture, was in fact David Kim Stanley, a convicted con artist and fugitive on the run since 1996. Born in the poor rural south, the son and grandson of Appalachian preachers, Stanley had used his status and a near-hypnotic speaking style to fleece his impoverished neighbours out of more than a million dollars. In 1989 Stanley pleaded guilty to more than 50 fraud-related charges; a judge sentenced him to 36 years in prison and agreed to suspend all but eight if Stanley repaid his victims. In early 1996, having paid back only a fraction of the money, Stanley vanished.

He turned up in the sleepy town of San Juan Capistrano in late 1996, just as the internet was transforming the most unlikely people into overnight multimillionaires. His weight, once a fit 220lbs, had ballooned to more than 350lbs. He and his new wife Sheila lived out of their Hyundai and showered at a nearby beach; he told locals that Sheila had recently escaped a Mormon cult that was bent on getting her back. A letter he wrote to his former wife - who had refused to go on the run with him - gives a sense of his plans for his new life. "It has always been, and always will be, a mistake to lose faith and underestimate me," Stanley wrote. "God has blessed me with a unique ability to defy reality."

Stanley set up a fledgling computer business, Restec, whose clients, he said, included the Saudi royal family. Some of his Restec customers eventually asked him if there was a way to replay races at the local horse track over a computer so that people in other locations could place bets. Stanley told them their inquiry had caused him to stumble on a totally new way of playing high-quality video over everyday computers. By the middle of 1997, Stanley, Chuck Hauswirth - the owner of a "tele-business centre" who had leased office space to Stanley in return for a cut of Restec - and two associates had founded Digital Motion Video.

Pulling video off a television and turning it into a file that can be played over a computer is no small feat, and this was even more true in 1997. The amount of information carried in the typical video is so vast that it would take a day or more to download a 30-minute sitcom. But in less than a year's time, Digital Motion had come up with video that seemed on the cutting edge, producing large images with the size and fluidity of television.

Soon, Stanley was pitching his plan to launch a 1,000-channel internet broadcasting empire that would rival anything that CBS or Disney could ever build. His first crop of takers included a psychologist, the owner of a tile company and a local insurance agent. Each invested between $50,000 and $125,000. And thus was born Future Link Communications, later renamed Pixelon.

By the spring of 1999, Pixelon was giving every impression of being well on its way to going public within the next year. The company struck an exclusive deal with Paramount Pictures to make web versions of its trailers for the upcoming movie, Star Trek: Insurrection, and forged a similar pact with Will Smith to make his Wild Wild West video available over the web in Pixelon's format. It was against this backdrop that Lee Wiskowski, whose investment bank Advanced Equities was looking for its first hot deal, met Pixelon on a Saturday morning in May 1999.

Stanley rattled off the usual litany of his former employers, which included the CIA, Walt Disney and Sony. He showed them the Will Smith video. The financiers were impressed, and Pixelon agreed to make the firm its agent for a $20m private placement - a method of raising money from wealthy individuals - that would later rise to $28m.

But while Pixelon's backers were gloating, employees inside the company were growing suspicious. Gary Devore, a video-encoding engineer, says he had suspicions about the technology, but didn't fully appreciate the deception until mid-August, when Stanley claimed Pixelon was using its proprietary technology to broadcast highlights of the Iowa Straw Poll - the bellwether vote of the US presidential race - live over the internet. When Devore reported to work that day, he discovered Pixelon was actually using Microsoft's Windows Media Player - the very technology Stanley so often cast as inferior - to broadcast the event.

Stanley, meanwhile, was becoming increasingly tyrannical and abusive. One Sunday in August, he instructed all employees to meet in his office for what was described as a worship service. At the meeting, held in near-darkness, Stanley played a piano and sang a hymn he said he had written. His wife sat close by, wiping tears from her eyes.

Devore says he went along with it partly because he still had hopes of becoming rich when Pixelon went public. "Michael would say in meetings that everybody in this company is going to be a millionaire in a short period of time. The mania [was] the glue that kept the dysfunctional family together."

Until autumn last year, the drama unfolding inside Pixelon was a carefully kept secret - and it would probably have remained that way were it not for iBash 99, Pixelon's extravagant launch party. Held at the MGM Grand in Las Vegas on October 29, the day-long extravaganza included a reunion by the Who and performances by the Dixie Chicks, Faith Hill, Tony Bennett, and Kiss. The idea was to get Pixelon's name in front of all kinds of people, from stockbrokers addicted to classic rock to senior citizens who liked lounge crooning. The event would provide the perfect opportunity for Pixelon to showcase its unique ability to broadcast high-quality video live over the internet.

But it never happened that way. Despite spectacular performances, Pixelon was unable to broadcast the event live using the very technology the event was designed to hype. The vast majority of footage never made it online. And, worse than being a public relations disaster, iBash turned into a financial black hole that largely sank Pixelon's chances of ever getting off the ground. For their efforts, the Who received $2m (£1.3m) in cash and a generous offering of stock. LeAnn Rimes made $1m (£686,000). The Dixie Chicks got $875,000 (£595,000) and at least $230,000 (£156, 500) in stock. All told, iBash cost more than $16.2m (£11m) - more than 75% of the capital Pixelon had taken in during its year and a half of existence.

As that November day wore on, Wiskowski and others who wanted to oust him worried that Stanley - who was clearly unhappy about their visit - might erupt if he learned of the plan. They decided to get him into the conference room and that Robert Feldman, a recently hired Pixelon employee, would keep an eye on the room from outside through a window. If the plotters thought Stanley was about to go ballistic, one of them would gesture to Feldman with a thumbs down, the agreed-upon signal for him to call the police.

As the group attempted to meet again with Stanley, they encountered a new problem: posted outside his office were two large bodyguards, and word around the office was that they were armed. Wiskowski and a colleague walked past the guards and entered the office. Sensing he was close to being ousted, Stanley suddenly was in a mood to bargain.

"Give me 90 days and I'll turn the company around," he told them. Cam Fraser, another new Pixelon executive, approached the office door and asked the bodyguards to leave. They refused. As nonchalantly as he could, Wiskowski feigned a yawn and a stretch, clasping his fingers together and turning his hands so that his two thumbs were clearly pointing downward. Within a half hour, squad cars arrived and removed the bodyguards peaceably.

The three Advanced Equities principals remained in Stanley's office trying to coax him into the conference room. By nightfall the board meeting finally got into gear. Wiskowski smacked his palm on the table and made a motion that Stanley be suspended for 30 days. "You betrayed me," one meeting participant remembers a clearly stunned-looking Stanley saying. Interim chief executive Paul Ward seconded the motion before Wiskowski had a chance to respond. Stanley was even more shocked. "Now I know who my Judas is," he said. Stanley's reign at Pixelon was over.

Almost immediately, however, it became clear that the drama was not over. Soon after the board meeting, word circulated in Pixelon's inner circles that someone had found a document on Stanley's computer laying out a detailed plan to leave the country in the event an unidentified "they" discovering his con. The letter discusses using hair dye and coloured contact lenses to create a new identity and eventually re-entering the country. "I would only do this after a face change through plastic surgery."

Stanley wasted no time rising from the ashes of his failed company, buying a house in Big Bear City, California, and setting up several new companies. But then, in early April, he got the call he had dreaded for four years. A disgruntled associate from one of his earlier San Juan Capistrano ventures had spotted a picture of David Kim Stanley, one of Virginia's 12 most-wanted fugitives, and thought it looked a lot like the man called Michael Fenne. A few days later, as San Bernardino sheriff's deputies moved to take custody of Stanley, they found only his empty house, clearly vacated in a hurry.

In May, Pixelon laid off its remaining employees; the last executives were fired last week and a replacement board appointed. Stanley, who turned himself in, now sits in Wise County jail in Virginia, where he is being held pending a hearing in which a prosecutor will demand that he finally serves the prison sentence he received more than a decade ago.

Nobody knows for sure if he was simply good at concealing a fortune in ill-gotten gains or simply lied and cheated for sport and revenge. What is clear is that he believes he has done nothing wrong, sees great things in his future and, when he gets out of jail, plans to finish what he started at Pixelon.

"In running for my life, I found my life in technology," says Stanley, who likes to remind people of all he was able to accomplish at Pixelon without so much as a social security number. "When I'm operational again, whenever that will be, without the chains and limitations of being underground, I am going to build that network."

 A longer version of this article is published in the Industry Standard magazine and is available online at www.thestandard.com A European edition of the Industry Standard will be launched this autumn

And thus was born Future Link Communications, later renamed Pixelon. By the spring of 1999, Pixelon was giving every impression of being well on its way to going public within the next year. The company struck an exclusive deal with Paramount Pictures to make web versions of its trailers for the upcoming movie, Star Trek: Insurrection, and forged a similar pact with Will Smith to make his Wild Wild West video available over the web in Pixelon's format. It was against this backdrop that Lee Wiskowski, whose investment bank Advanced Equities was looking for its first hot deal, met Pixelon on a Saturday morning in May 1999. Stanley rattled off the usual litany of his former employers, which included the CIA, Walt Disney and Sony. He showed them the Will Smith video. The financiers were impressed, and Pixelon agreed to make the firm its agent for a $20m private placement - a method of raising money from wealthy individuals - that would later rise to $28m. But while Pixelon's backers were gloating, employees inside the company were growing suspicious. Gary Devore, a video-encoding engineer, says he had suspicions about the technology, but didn't fully appreciate the deception until mid-August, when Stanley claimed Pixelon was using its proprietary technology to broadcast highlights of the Iowa Straw Poll - the bellwether vote of the US presidential race - live over the internet. When Devore reported to work that day, he discovered Pixelon was actually using Microsoft's Windows Media Player - the very technology Stanley so often cast as inferior - to broadcast the event. Stanley, meanwhile, was becoming increasingly tyrannical and abusive. One Sunday in August, he instructed all employees to meet in his office for what was described as a worship service. At the meeting, held in near-darkness, Stanley played a piano and sang a hymn he said he had written. His wife sat close by, wiping tears from her eyes. Devore says he went along with it partly because he still had hopes of becoming rich when Pixelon went public. "Michael would say in meetings that everybody in this company is going to be a millionaire in a short period of time. The mania [was] the glue that kept the dysfunctional family together." Until autumn last year, the drama unfolding inside Pixelon was a carefully kept secret - and it would probably have remained that way were it not for iBash 99, Pixelon's extravagant launch party. Held at the MGM Grand in Las Vegas on October 29, the day-long extravaganza included a reunion by the Who and performances by the Dixie Chicks, Faith Hill, Tony Bennett, and Kiss. The idea was to get Pixelon's name in front of all kinds of people, from stockbrokers addicted to classic rock to senior citizens who liked lounge crooning. The event would provide the perfect opportunity for Pixelon to showcase its unique ability to broadcast high-quality video live over the internet. But it never happened that way. Despite spectacular performances, Pixelon was unable to broadcast the event live using the very technology the event was designed to hype. The vast majority of footage never made it online. And, worse than being a public relations disaster, iBash turned into a financial black hole that largely sank Pixelon's chances of ever getting off the ground. For their efforts, the Who received $2m (£1.3m) in cash and a generous offering of stock. LeAnn Rimes made $1m (£686,000). The Dixie Chicks got $875,000 (£595,000) and at least $230,000 (£156, 500) in stock. All told, iBash cost more than $16.2m (£11m) - more than 75% of the capital Pixelon had taken in during its year and a half of existence. As that November day wore on, Wiskowski and others who wanted to oust him worried that Stanley - who was clearly unhappy about their visit - might erupt if he learned of the plan. They decided to get him into the conference room and that Robert Feldman, a recently hired Pixelon employee, would keep an eye on the room from outside through a window. If the plotters thought Stanley was about to go ballistic, one of them would gesture to Feldman with a thumbs down, the agreed-upon signal for him to call the police. As the group attempted to meet again with Stanley, they encountered a new problem: posted outside his office were two large bodyguards, and word around the office was that they were armed. Wiskowski and a colleague walked past the guards and entered the office. Sensing he was close to being ousted, Stanley suddenly was in a mood to bargain. "Give me 90 days and I'll turn the company around," he told them. Cam Fraser, another new Pixelon executive, approached the office door and asked the bodyguards to leave. They refused. As nonchalantly as he could, Wiskowski feigned a yawn and a stretch, clasping his fingers together and turning his hands so that his two thumbs were clearly pointing downward. Within a half hour, squad cars arrived and removed the bodyguards peaceably. The three Advanced Equities principals remained in Stanley's office trying to coax him into the conference room. By nightfall the board meeting finally got into gear. Wiskowski smacked his palm on the table and made a motion that Stanley be suspended for 30 days. "You betrayed me," one meeting participant remembers a clearly stunned-looking Stanley saying. Interim chief executive Paul Ward seconded the motion before Wiskowski had a chance to respond. Stanley was even more shocked. "Now I know who my Judas is," he said. Stanley's reign at Pixelon was over. Almost immediately, however, it became clear that the drama was not over. Soon after the board meeting, word circulated in Pixelon's inner circles that someone had found a document on Stanley's computer laying out a detailed plan to leave the country in the event an unidentified "they" discovering his con. The letter discusses using hair dye and coloured contact lenses to create a new identity and eventually re-entering the country. "I would only do this after a face change through plastic surgery." Stanley wasted no time rising from the ashes of his failed company, buying a house in Big Bear City, California, and setting up several new companies. But then, in early April, he got the call he had dreaded for four years. A disgruntled associate from one of his earlier San Juan Capistrano ventures had spotted a picture of David Kim Stanley, one of Virginia's 12 most-wanted fugitives, and thought it looked a lot like the man called Michael Fenne. A few days later, as San Bernardino sheriff's deputies moved to take custody of Stanley, they found only his empty house, clearly vacated in a hurry. In May, Pixelon laid off its remaining employees; the last executives were fired last week and a replacement board appointed. Stanley, who turned himself in, now sits in Wise County jail in Virginia, where he is being held pending a hearing in which a prosecutor will demand that he finally serves the prison sentence he received more than a decade ago. Nobody knows for sure if he was simply good at concealing a fortune in ill-gotten gains or simply lied and cheated for sport and revenge. What is clear is that he believes he has done nothing wrong, sees great things in his future and, when he gets out of jail, plans to finish what he started at Pixelon. "In running for my life, I found my life in technology," says Stanley, who likes to remind people of all he was able to accomplish at Pixelon without so much as a social security number. "When I'm operational again, whenever that will be, without the chains and limitations of being underground, I am going to build that network."  A longer version of this article is published in the Industry Standard magazine and is available online at www.thestandard.com A European edition of the Industry Standard will be launched this autumn

fields.headline: The same old story
fields.standfirst: Ibiza Uncovered was a hit for one reason - it dispensed with the notion that the island was cool or trendy. But its imitators have failed to make that distinction, which is why they make such dire TV. By  Jacques Peretti
fields.trailText: Ibiza Uncovered was a hit for one reason - it dispensed with the notion that the island was cool or trendy. But its imitators have failed to make that distinction, which is why they make such dire TV. By Jacques Peretti
fields.body:
Adecade separates the first documentary about excessive behaviour in Ibiza, A Short Film About Chilling, and the latest, The Dog's Balearics. Comparison of the two titles is enough to tell one how perceptions of the island have changed: the first was a pun on a cultish Polish arthouse film of the time, Kieslowski's A Short Film About Killing. The latest is simply a way of saying bollocks.

I must confess a certain rave snobbery about Ibiza. I travelled to the island for three consecutive summers: 1985 to 1987. A Short Film... was shot by A Man Called Adam in the early 90s, documenting the aftermath of the torrential downpoar of ecstasy pills on the island.

Ibiza had been a secret haven of excess since the early 60s - first as a hippy hang-out, then as a gay holiday capital of Europe. The island developed a Bacchanalian reputation, based on the illicit good times enjoyed by gay holiday-makers (especially Spanish gay men, free from the mainland constrictions of Franco's regime). It was this reputation - and the extraordinarily camp venues - which provided the basis for the club explosion of the mid-80s.

The first time I went to Ibiza, my jaw hit the floor. I simply could not believe how outrageously licentious the island was, particularly the open use of drugs. It was a fantastic contrast to pre-Acid House England, still nursing a warm pint of lager.

By 1987, people were already saying Ibiza was over (not the first and certainly not the last generation of Ibiza-goers to make this bitter observation). The secret was out, everyone wanted a piece of the action: one morning, I went into the sea and cut my foot on a broken bottle of poppers. The beach was littered with them.

The island portrayed in The Dog's Balearics is just as jaw-dropping as the Ibiza of A Short Film..., but for a different reason. Now it is a giant Club 18-30 camp on E. Perfect, in other words, television entertainment.

Conspiracy theorists could justifiably look upon Ibiza (or Ibeefa, as it was rechristened by the English) less as an island than as a Truman Show-style TV experiment.

How else could one account for the creating of this ultimate TV studio in the middle of the Mediterranean? Half-a-million handpicked studio guests, returning each year to perform lewd acts upon one another (and the production team doesn't even have to ply them with drugs - they do it themselves).

The problem with a programme like The Dog's Balearics, 15 years down the line, is not so much the rehashing of content, as the touchingly dated style. A step back to a time before the ground was rehashed so splendidly by Ibiza Uncovered.

When Sky produced Ibiza Uncovered, no one believed it was going to be anything but the same pap. No one certainly expected such a genius piece of satire, upending the long-held cliché that Ibeefa was still glamorous, even - gulp - worth visiting.

Uncovered showed the island for what it had become: a giant vomitarium inhabited by lobotomised teenagers and reptilian club promoters. Sky may have been hoping for Human Traffic-meets-Trainspotting-by-the-sea. But they got Mike Leigh.

In reality, Sky knew exactly what they were doing. Ibiza Uncovered, like its follow-up, A Bit Of Posh (about the hooray unwaged), was a conscious effort to up the channel's quotient of quality documentary. It was voyeuristic (of course) but it was just as strong on the cruelties of the club economy: the homesick dancer left waiting six hours in the sun to audition for a non-existent job.

Channel 4 bought Uncovered, and followed up with Fantasy Island, about the Two-Step Garage scene in Agia Napa. The failure of Fantasy Island highlighted the problem of assuming that people dancing in a nightclub can always be treated in the same exploitative fashion as post-pub gawp fodder.

Agia Napa is qualitatively different from Ibiza. The scene is more about fashion and music than getting blathered (plus Cyprus's police have a tough anti-drugs policy, which mitigates against mass oblivion). Anyone could have told C4 that it would make for very dull TV.

Which leads me to the two basic ground rules for producing quality club TV, ie trash voyeurism:

a) The programme-makers must surrender any notion they are filming something cool or happening (they must under no circumstances give a jaunty round-up of "places to go".) Stick to filming girls in platforms puking up into flower-tubs and you can't go wrong.

b) If you must have a presenter, don't have a wry, slightly bemused comedian but a brainless clubber. By far the best club programme on TV remains Clubavision on Carlton, a late-night no-frills half hour in Hell, locked in a sweaty Essex disco with scary, incoherent clubbers and a busty blonde presenter called Janine. The programme is genius. It is beyond criticism and certainly beyond parody.

Youth TV always fails when it attempts to be down wit' da kidz. It's best when it steadfastly holds the gap between the medium and the subject, ideally bringing the two into head-to-head conflict (Bill Grundy meets The Sex Pistols).

In the 60s, Professor Hans Keller interviewed Pink Floyd. His first question was "Why does it have to be so loud?" Why indeed. It was a question worthy of Janine at her very best.

 The Dog's Balearics, tonight, Channel 4, 1.30am

webTitle: Tony plans a trip down in Devon

fields.headline: Tony plans a trip down in Devon
fields.standfirst: Let's hope the ministers enjoy Exeter University as much as I did
fields.trailText: We live in the age of irony. It is apparently all right to make sexist jokes if you do it ironically; it is fine to do gags about gays if it is done with a knowing wink. But now I have suddenly realised that we are living through the biggest satirical wind up of them all. This government is being ironically rightwing.
fields.body:
We live in the age of irony. It is apparently all right to make sexist jokes if you do it ironically; it is fine to do gags about gays if it is done with a knowing wink. But now I have suddenly realised that we are living through the biggest satirical wind up of them all. This government is being ironically rightwing.

All this reactionary talk about single mothers and asylum seekers and on-the-spot fines - it's OK; it's all ironic. The Labour government's style says: "Yeah, yeah, obviously we're in favour of all that old equality and redistribution of wealth stuff; but we've come through all that and this is the next stage." They're not New Labour but Postmodern Labour.

This weekend the cabinet, Labour MPs, MEPs and trades unions will all descend on Exeter University to thrash out the policies that will form Labour's next manifesto. I hope all those ministers enjoy Exeter University as much as I did when I was there, although it is hard to imagine John Prescott and Margaret Beckett skinny dipping in the River Exe and then getting out of their heads on magic mushrooms.

If, as looks likely, Labour wins the election, then who knows, this weekend could end up being a turning point in the history of this administration. Because hundreds of Labour MPs will demand that Labour's second term is more radical than the first and Tony Blair will enthusiastically endorse a socialist manifesto for the next general election. I can see it all now. Or perhaps those magic mushrooms take longer to wear off than I thought.

Three years ago, when Labour finally came to power, we all felt much as Nelson Mandela must have after he was released - an enormous euphoria that quickly disappeared when he realised that now he had to live with Winnie. Tony Blair's first term was all about making people believe that Labour could look like a government. Unfortunately, because the governments of the previous 18 years had been full of deranged rightwing psychopaths, Labour's task occasionally involved postures and policies that would have made Norman Tebbit blush. Now, when Jack Straw gets a taxi, the cabbie ends up saying: "Well I wouldn't go that far, I mean I think some of them are genuine refugees and, er, live and let live and all that. . ."

But Labour's mission has been accomplished. The party looks comfortable with the reins of power and, for the first time in its history, a full second term looks within its grasp. This was arguably Tony Blair's top priority for his first period of office and maybe for some of those heading down to Devon this would be enough for the second. In which case the next manifesto will read: "If elected, Labour will seek to be elected again. Because without power, Labour can never achieve its goal of being in power, and if we fail in this ambition we believe the voters will throw us out of office. No, hang on, will have already thrown us out of office."

The top brass gathering at Exeter University are the luckiest Labour party members ever. They have the greatest ever majority. They look set to be the first ever Labour government to win a full second term. And to cap it all the student union building has a two pool tables and sells cheap cider. Are members going to let the next election pass by without seizing this chance to win with a manifesto that would really attack the inequalities in this country? Will they be satisfied with more of the same? In years to come, will they sit their grandchildren on their knee and say: "Aye, the party had never been stronger, and the Tories had never been weaker and oooh, you should have seen what we did with all that power! Why, the ordinary folk were dancing in the street when we granted independence to the Bank of England!"

After a hard day's debating, on Saturday evening the ministers and MPs will all sit down to a slap-up meal. Dinner will consist of a couple of eggs, still in their shells, rolling around on the plate. It's what is known as a New Labour omelette. Labour were cautious with their last manifesto, which is kind of understandable when they had failed to win a workable majority for seven elections in a row. But the time has come to break some eggs. We cannot reach the end of a second Labour term with the health service still underfunded, with a failing education system, with a growing underclass and high unemploy- ment. For once in our lifetimes Labour can win on a radical programme. Historic opportunities such as the next election are as rare in politics as witty Ulster Unionists.

The prime minister told us he wants to think the unthinkable and rewrite the rule book, so how about this for a radical idea: a Labour government that moved to the left once it was in office? That really would be a completely New Labour.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Slow Train To Woking | The Real Sherlock Holmes
fields.body:
At 52 Daniel still has a hard time with his Mum, whose suburban home he must visit without fail every week. Down the years he's worked out how to reduce the agony. He takes the Slow Train To Woking (2.15pm, Radio 4), so he just misses the connecting bus and can get some reviving time in the pub. Every character in Michael Mears's gently penetrating study is splendidly played by the author.

The Conan Doyle season continues with The Real Sherlock Holmes (9.0pm, Radio 4). It's generally accepted that the detective was based on Dr Joseph Bell of Edinburgh, with whom Doyle worked closely as a young medical student. Bell repeatedly demonstrated his remarkable observational powers while Doyle took copious notes. But the traffic was not all one way. A French criminologist was later inspired by a Conan Doyle story to analyse dust particles and mud, and the eminent Home Office pathologist Bernard Spilsbury adopted Holmesian forensic techniques.

webTitle: Rates stay steady but fear still grows as communities wait for government lead

fields.headline: Rates stay steady but fear still grows as communities wait for government lead
fields.standfirst: Policing crime: special report
fields.trailText: Othery, Wrexham and Sheffield are not obvious places to visit for a series on crime. They have not featured in the news recently   (not for crime anyway), and they are never likely to rival London, Manchester or Glasgow in the premier league of crime hotspots.
fields.body:
Othery, Wrexham and Sheffield are not obvious places to visit for a series on crime. They have not featured in the news recently (not for crime anyway), and they are never likely to rival London, Manchester or Glasgow in the premier league of crime hotspots.

That, in essence, was the best reason to choose them. Hard core criminal activity - murders, shootings and gang feuds - is prevalent in only a handful of cities and accounts for a fraction of recorded crime. But shocking incidents always jostle other issues out of the spotlight.

It takes a case like the conviction of the Norfolk farmer Tony Martin to make ministers and opinion-formers realise how out of touch they are with the way people are feeling. In villages such as Othery, the fear of crime is every bit as damaging and undermining to community spirit as villainy itself.

Pity the "beat manager" PC Rachael Cooke, who diligently covers Othery in her beat of 12 parishes. Quite rightly, the statisticians at Avon and Somerset's head quarters cannot justify putting another officer in the area. Even PC Cooke is hard-pressed to think of reasons why she should have help. The community, though, feels isolated and vulnerable.

Depression is pervasive and deep-rooted. Villagers say they "cannot be bothered" to report crimes because there is no point.

Crime rates remain the same, PC Cooke tootles around in her car none the wiser, and the force sees no good reason to consider re-evaluating the situation. The police, on the other hand, believe villagers cling to the idea of having a beat bobby because it represents an age which has passed.

But PC Danny Morgan, who was Othery's much-loved policeman between 1954 and 1970, says he dealt with just as much crime in his day.

Village life is changing at a speed many find hard to accept. There are more "outsiders" living in Othery, while traditional industries such as farming have struggled to survive.

Wrexham is a different case altogether. It is a busy provincial town that is beginning to suffer from the sort of inner-city problems London got used to long ago. The police have done a great job tackling the town's "traditional" crime - public disorder and shoplifting.

The Venture playground on the Caia estate is a gem of a project which shows what can be achieved by involving children who would otherwise have nowhere to go.

But drug dealing and drug addiction are different problems, and they require more sophisticated solutions. Wrexham needs help and advice from the forces which have been there and done that, otherwise the dealers will have a free hand.

Quite how Superintendent Steve Hicks solves Sheffield's prostitution problem is another matter. He is juggling with an issue that will not be sorted out by policing alone, yet people look to the force to sort things out. This is as true of the difficulties in Othery and Wrexham.

In all three places, the fear of crime has grown, even though crime rates have been constant. There has obviously been a breakdown in trust. The police say they are doing all they can. The public wants more. Both are waiting for government to take the lead.

Crimes reported last year 740

fields.bodyText: Othery, Wrexham and Sheffield are not obvious places to visit for a series on crime. They have not featured in the news recently (not for crime anyway), and they are never likely to rival London, Manchester or Glasgow in the premier league of crime hotspots. That, in essence, was the best reason to choose them. Hard core criminal activity - murders, shootings and gang feuds - is prevalent in only a handful of cities and accounts for a fraction of recorded crime. But shocking incidents always jostle other issues out of the spotlight. It takes a case like the conviction of the Norfolk farmer Tony Martin to make ministers and opinion-formers realise how out of touch they are with the way people are feeling. In villages such as Othery, the fear of crime is every bit as damaging and undermining to community spirit as villainy itself. Pity the "beat manager" PC Rachael Cooke, who diligently covers Othery in her beat of 12 parishes. Quite rightly, the statisticians at Avon and Somerset's head quarters cannot justify putting another officer in the area. Even PC Cooke is hard-pressed to think of reasons why she should have help. The community, though, feels isolated and vulnerable. Depression is pervasive and deep-rooted. Villagers say they "cannot be bothered" to report crimes because there is no point. Crime rates remain the same, PC Cooke tootles around in her car none the wiser, and the force sees no good reason to consider re-evaluating the situation. The police, on the other hand, believe villagers cling to the idea of having a beat bobby because it represents an age which has passed. But PC Danny Morgan, who was Othery's much-loved policeman between 1954 and 1970, says he dealt with just as much crime in his day. Village life is changing at a speed many find hard to accept. There are more "outsiders" living in Othery, while traditional industries such as farming have struggled to survive. Wrexham is a different case altogether. It is a busy provincial town that is beginning to suffer from the sort of inner-city problems London got used to long ago. The police have done a great job tackling the town's "traditional" crime - public disorder and shoplifting. The Venture playground on the Caia estate is a gem of a project which shows what can be achieved by involving children who would otherwise have nowhere to go. But drug dealing and drug addiction are different problems, and they require more sophisticated solutions. Wrexham needs help and advice from the forces which have been there and done that, otherwise the dealers will have a free hand. Quite how Superintendent Steve Hicks solves Sheffield's prostitution problem is another matter. He is juggling with an issue that will not be sorted out by policing alone, yet people look to the force to sort things out. This is as true of the difficulties in Othery and Wrexham. In all three places, the fear of crime has grown, even though crime rates have been constant. There has obviously been a breakdown in trust. The police say they are doing all they can. The public wants more. Both are waiting for government to take the lead. fields.headline: Court circular
fields.standfirst: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.body:
Yet another Ruff Ryde has landed hip-hopster DMX in hot water.

Not to be outdone by such felony-friendly rap upstarts as Eminem, the rapper (aka Earl Simmons) has been indicted for possession of marijuana and an unlicensed handgun, following a January spin-out in which his Jeep ran off a highway.

Prosecutors in White Plains, New York say Simmons's Jeep spun off the road and hit a guardrail before finally coming to a stop. He was reportedly uninjured in the crash.

But inside the car, the indictment alleges, was a loaded 9mm pistol, as well as some joints in two of the ashtrays. He's now charged with two felony counts of third-degree weapon possession and marijuana possession. If convicted, the chart-topping rapper could face up to seven years in the slammer.

Of course, the guy's got his hands full. DMX is currently trying to get out of a 15-day jail sentence in Buffalo, which he received for driving with a suspended permit and possessing marijuana when he was stopped by police in March.

Perhaps he figured those platinum records directly correspond with criminal records. The rapper's most recent disc, ...And Then There Was X, sits at number 33 on the Billboard charts and has sold more than 10 million copies.

Chronically troubled actor-jailbird Robert Downey Jr , who is currently serving a three-year prison term for drug possession, confesses to Vanity Fair magazine in an interview that his imprisonment is causing him to suffer deep depression.

The Oscar-nominated film star, who could be released from a California state prison as early as November after time off for good behaviour, said in a series of interviews for the magazine's August issue that he has not used drugs since June 1999 and that he's ready to rejoin society.

"I'm just sinking further into my depression sessions," Downey said. "Sometimes I'm just dead."

webTitle: 'I'm a show-off. I'm the kind of person that loves opening fetes'

fields.headline: 'I'm a show-off. I'm the kind of person that loves opening fetes'
fields.standfirst: Julie Walters tells Lyn Gardner why she's back on the stage after nine years
fields.trailText: Julie Walters tells Lyn Gardner why she's back on the stage after nine years
fields.body:
It is almost nine years since Julie Walters last appeared on stage. Still reeling from the discovery that her three-year-old daughter Maisie was suffering from leukemia, Walters had to do nightly battle with the emotionally charged role of Serafina, the widow in Tennessee Williams's The Rose Tattoo who must free herself from the bonds of love before she can set her own daughter free.

"It was pure torture," recalls Walters. "Playing someone in such torment on stage when Maisie was so ill was a mistake. Since then I've been offered some wonderful stage roles. But with my home situation I couldn't face them. If I'd have taken on another part like Serafina, I think my heart would have broken."

The Walters heart is thankfully intact. Daughter Maisie is now 12 and has been pronounced fully cured. And this week Julie is back on stage playing Kate Keller, the mother at the heart of Arthur Miller's 1947 play All My Sons who refuses to accept that her pilot son is dead, even though he has been missing in action for more than three years.

In the script Miller describes Kate as "a woman of uncontrolled inspirations and an overwhelming capacity for love". It could be a description of Walters herself: she chats away warmly as if I was a neighbour who has just popped in to borrow a cup of sugar, her conversation peppered with tangents, dead ends, indiscretions and a laugh that could crack crockery. With her scrunched-up face and tiny currant eyes she should be plain, but the mobility of her features makes her oddly beautiful. When she laughs her eyes twinkle like distant stars.

The writer Alan Bleasdale, who first met her when she was working at the Liverpool Everyman in the early 70s, and remains a close friend, once said: "Everyone falls in love with Julie Walters. She rubs off on people."

From the moment Walters starred as the hairdresser trying to better herself in the 1983 film Educating Rita, she rubbed off on the nation's consciousness as the lovable girl next door who didn't mind sending herself up. On TV this led to parts such as Mrs Overall in Acorn Antiques and, more recently, the slovenly Petunia in Dinnerladies, written by another close friend, Victoria Wood. Walters has the knack of being ordinary.

"I am like Kate. I understand her desire to keep everything back as it was before - before the war and before Larry went missing. But she is not neurotic - she is a woman of enormous strength, the centre of that house and trying to hold it all together. So she finds things to hang on to, like astrology. The other day in rehearsal Howard [Davies, the director] was talking about 'all this nonsense about astrology' but I'm like that myself. I consulted an astrologer when Maisie was ill and I think she was certainly helped by healers. If something terrible happens to your child you have to find another dimension. You become spiritual, otherwise you would disappear into an angry black hole."

All My Sons marks a watershed in Walters's life and career, her own attempt to move on now that her daughter is well and on the cusp of independence.

"When Maisie was so ill I remember talking with Grant [her husband] about how we would ever go forward if it turned out to be the worst possible scenario. How could we have left the house where we were living, and how could we have stayed? I think the war made a lot of people feel like that. It took them a long time to learn how to move forward."

Walters admits that she has had to be given a bit of a shove. After years of turning down job offers because they would take her away from home and a sick child, she now has no excuse.

"For a long time I'd calculate how much I could afford to stay at home, and do it as much as possible. But when I was offered Kate Keller I felt that if I didn't take it I was in effect saying that I was giving up acting. I became an actor to be in the theatre. I didn't want to be on TV or be a film star."

She is also honest enough to admit that she enjoys a little publicity. "Once, when I hadn't worked for a while, Grant said, 'How would you feel if nobody ever recognised you again?' Of course I bristled and said that I'd never been in acting for the fame. But the truth is I would find it difficult. I'm a show-off. I am the kind of person that loves opening village fetes."

Even leaving aside her daughter's illness, Walters's entire career has been defined by a theme of mothers and daughters. First there was her own mother, a driven working-class woman who pushed her children for success and was appalled to discover that her only daughter intended to become an actress. "You'll be in the gutter before you're 21," she predicted. She never managed to tell her daughter that she was proud of her, although the book of press cuttings that was found after her death spoke volumes.

Then there have been those defining performances, so many of which have been about parent-child relationships: Serafina struggling with the demons that threaten to taint her child's happiness; Fiona the daughter in Sharman Macdonald's When I Was a Girl I Used to Scream and Shout, who damages her own and her mother's happiness by deliberately getting pregnant at the age of 15; the repressed mother in the underrated film Intimate Relations, who makes such a fatal stab at sexual freedom; and the one in the TV series Jake's Progress who cannot love her own son.

Now there is Kate, and in September she will be seen in Stephen Daldry's debut movie Dancer, now retitled Billy Elliot, playing a frustrated dancing teacher who neglects her own child and puts all her hopes and dreams into the small boy she discovers and pushes to become a ballet dancer.

Yet somewhere between these performances, the long-ago knowing innocence of Rita and the ragbag of grotesques in which TV has so often cast her, there is another Julie Walters. Sixteen years ago I saw her playing opposite Ian Charleson in Sam Shepard's Fool for Love, about a relationship so combustible that it had no limits.

"You're going to erase me," Walters's May told her former lover Eddie when they ran into each other in a Mojave Desert motel. She proceeded to commit emotional suicide in a performance so wild and daring that it made you want to sit way back in your seat out of harm's way. I think of this performance every time I see Walters on TV giving one of her comic turns in a show written by one of her friends. And while there is much pleasure to be had from these performances, I always wish that we could see more of the other Julie Walters - the one who can terrify you with her sheer power of feeling, who on stage has no limits.

But Walters makes no apologies for making people laugh. "Of course I've regretted turning down some great parts. But I'd have regretted it much more if I'd worked and not been with Maisie," she says firmly. "The truth is that if I had not had a child I would have done more. But I did, and I took an easier road.

"And really. I really don't mind people associating me with Mrs Overall. I feel a long way from Rita but not from Mrs Overall. She is in me and all the parts I play."

She puts her hand over her mouth in mock horror. "I shouldn't say that. The critics will get me for it."

 All My Sons is at the National Theatre, London SE1 (020-7452 3000), from tomorrow till September.

webTitle: Oldest profession soldiers on in city battered during Thatcher years

fields.headline: Oldest profession soldiers on in city battered during Thatcher years
fields.standfirst:
Figures to be published this month will show that recorded crime is rising. But what is the experience of crime in the cities, towns and villages of Britain? Are we more frightened of crime than we need to be, and can we be confident the police are coping? The last of a three-part series examines how the city of Sheffield is being affected

Policing crime: special report
fields.trailText: Figures to be published this month will show that recorded crime is rising. But what is the experience of crime in the cities, towns and villages of Britain? Are we more frightened of crime than we need to be, and can we be confident the police are coping? The last of a three-part series examines how the city of Sheffield is being affected
fields.body:
Just about every other industry in Sheffield took a battering during the Thatcher years, and some disappeared from South Yorkshire altogether. The oldest of them, however, survived recession and has thrived in the new millennium.

It is the bane of Steve Hicks' life.

"Prostitution", roars Superintendent Hicks, his hands clasped tightly behind the back of his head, "is one of our major problems."

In its way, he says, it is more of a dilemma than drugs and violent crime (though prostitution is often linked to both), and a higher priority than burglaries or vandalism. Mr Hicks is not sure how many prostitutes there are in Sheffield. "It's historic. Don't ask me why, but we have always had them. Street girls, call girls, massage parlours, escort agencies, you name it ... "

But he knows business is booming because of the number of kerb crawlers that appear on the street every evening, the number of used condoms they leave behind, and the complaints he receives about both.

The police have tried all sorts of ways of controlling the industry. Some have been radical; they formally supported proposals to zone off pockets of the city, but the idea infuriated people living in the chosen areas.

Nimby brigade
"The nimby [not in my back yard] brigade had a point," said another officer. "But if we had cordoned off certain sites for prostitution, at least that would have been one way of hiding it away and controlling it."

Arresting and charging prostitutes, the police found, is a dispiriting and ultimately pointless exercise; to pay the fines, women need to work much harder, so they go straight back on the streets.

Putting up a CCTV camera in one red light district, Devonshire Green, was supposed to deter prostitutes from working there. Instead, it encouraged them.

This is, after all, Yorkshire Ripper country, and Devonshire Green, with its poor street lighting and industrial decay, is not the safest place for anyone to be walking around after dark.

Knowing they were being watched gave the prostitutes extra security, so they huddled together in view of the camera.

Mr Hicks argues that prostitution is a political and social problem. He says it needs "multi-agency involvement" - police speak for "I can't sort this out on my own." He knows too that rows over tackling vice are significant because they are symbolic. They go to the heart of his strategy for policing Sheffield.

Clarence Swindell, chairman of the police authority, thinks he knows the solution to cutting crime. "I am 68 years old and I have seen a lot of changes," said Mr Swindell, a no-nonsense type who lives in Rotherham. "And nobody will ever persuade me that the answer is not more uniformed officers on the street. People behave themselves when they see a police officer on patrol. It is a simple as that."

Mr Hicks does not agree. He is in charge of one of the busiest city centres in the country. Between 150,000 and 200,000 people commute to Sheffield, and the central area a resident population of 100,000. Most of them would be surprised to learn the number of officers Mr Hicks has on standby to protect them.

"Fourteen, tops. That's on a good day, and we don't have many. Sometimes we have fewer than that, but I am not going to give you exact figures because it might give people the wrong idea. We don't want to cause any anxiety."

Mr Hicks does not have the manpower to have police officers roaming the streets in a reactive way, waiting to respond if something happens. He favours schemes which shift or at least share responsibility, like using security guards rather than "beat bobbies" to patrol neighbourhoods.

He sees the planned redevelopment of Sheffield city centre as a fantastic opportunity to "design out crime".

Recently, he approved a pilot scheme to "hire out" police officers to Sheffield University, which wanted a uniformed presence on campus because students felt threatened by the number of prostitutes, pimps and kerb crawlers. The university paid for an officer to patrol Neverthorpe, in the north west of the city, between 5pm and 9pm every day for a fortnight.

Mr Hicks persuaded the university to allow the officer to include in his walkabout a housing estate in Edward Street, where residents had complained about prostitutes.

"You could argue this means you don't have policing for all, just for those that can afford it. But this is the reality of policing today. The scheme made common sense to me, and the people who live in the Edward Street flats got a patrol."

Mr Hicks has been promised extra uniformed officers, which should bring the overall strength on day shifts to 20. But this will not make any difference to the way the city is policed.

To a certain extent, he is a victim of Sheffield's success. Crime rates have declined since the early 1990s, and the most recent figures confirm it is one of the safest cities in the country.

The overall number of crimes committed in the city last year, 740, is still less than the 1997-98 figures, and the detection rate, 45%, is the highest in the force.

Murders are infrequent. What violent crime there is tends to be drug related. Last month, a crack cocaine dealer, John Copeland, was jailed for 13 years for attacking elderly people in their homes, including a 94-year-old widower, Fred Revill. Another of his victims was an 82-year-old woman, Hannah Morgan. Copeland, 23, broke her hip.

The police also have to deal with occasional shootings. Six weeks ago in Burngreave Road, three men jumped into the back of a car and shot a man in the passenger seat. The victim lost a lot of blood and suffered severe damage to his spleen, but survived.

"I would say that was probably drug-related too," an officer said. "Incidents like that are few and far between. When I go to training courses and I speak to officers from London or Manchester, I realise we don't have anything like the problems they have."

Perversely, drug culture has benefited the city, which has some of the trendiest nightclubs in the country.

"The dance crowd are very different from the pub crowd," said Detective Inspector Colin Fisher. "The clubbers come to Sheffield for a weekend, and they don't stop for 48 hours. They don't cause any trouble. They are not interested in fighting or getting drunk. Twenty years ago, it was different. The culture was pub, curry house, and a brawl in the street."

Drug deaths
Drug-related deaths in Sheffield are nearly always from heroin overdose, and often involve prostitutes.

In recent months, Sheffield has reorganised its community policing teams to tackle vandalism and burglary. The impact was immediate.

Officers work in fortnightly rotation; one week, they walk the beat, the second they join together to target hotspots like the Wyburn estate, often working undercover, on the trail of known offenders.

In Gleadless, another problem area, crime went into freefall when the police set up a "swat team", made up of a sergeant, Dave Annakin, and three constables. They worked in conjuction with but were quite separate from the beat officers. During the team's spell in the Arbourthorne estate, crime fell by 28%.

The trick was to identify the ringleaders, then arrest them in front of their friends. "When it was made clear they were not untouchable, things quietened down," Sgt Annakin said.

"Every estate in Sheffield wants one of these teams now," said a city councillor, Robert Harpham. "But there aren't the resources to keep them permanently."

Mr Hicks persuaded the university to allow the officer to include in his walkabout a housing estate in Edward Street, where residents had complained about prostitutes. "You could argue this means you don't have policing for all, just for those that can afford it. But this is the reality of policing today. The scheme made common sense to me, and the people who live in the Edward Street flats got a patrol." Mr Hicks has been promised extra uniformed officers, which should bring the overall strength on day shifts to 20. But this will not make any difference to the way the city is policed. To a certain extent, he is a victim of Sheffield's success. Crime rates have declined since the early 1990s, and the most recent figures confirm it is one of the safest cities in the country. The overall number of crimes committed in the city last year, 740, is still less than the 1997-98 figures, and the detection rate, 45%, is the highest in the force. Murders are infrequent. What violent crime there is tends to be drug related. Last month, a crack cocaine dealer, John Copeland, was jailed for 13 years for attacking elderly people in their homes, including a 94-year-old widower, Fred Revill. Another of his victims was an 82-year-old woman, Hannah Morgan. Copeland, 23, broke her hip. The police also have to deal with occasional shootings. Six weeks ago in Burngreave Road, three men jumped into the back of a car and shot a man in the passenger seat. The victim lost a lot of blood and suffered severe damage to his spleen, but survived. "I would say that was probably drug-related too," an officer said. "Incidents like that are few and far between. When I go to training courses and I speak to officers from London or Manchester, I realise we don't have anything like the problems they have." Perversely, drug culture has benefited the city, which has some of the trendiest nightclubs in the country. "The dance crowd are very different from the pub crowd," said Detective Inspector Colin Fisher. "The clubbers come to Sheffield for a weekend, and they don't stop for 48 hours. They don't cause any trouble. They are not interested in fighting or getting drunk. Twenty years ago, it was different. The culture was pub, curry house, and a brawl in the street." Drug deaths Drug-related deaths in Sheffield are nearly always from heroin overdose, and often involve prostitutes. In recent months, Sheffield has reorganised its community policing teams to tackle vandalism and burglary. The impact was immediate. Officers work in fortnightly rotation; one week, they walk the beat, the second they join together to target hotspots like the Wyburn estate, often working undercover, on the trail of known offenders. In Gleadless, another problem area, crime went into freefall when the police set up a "swat team", made up of a sergeant, Dave Annakin, and three constables. They worked in conjuction with but were quite separate from the beat officers. During the team's spell in the Arbourthorne estate, crime fell by 28%. The trick was to identify the ringleaders, then arrest them in front of their friends. "When it was made clear they were not untouchable, things quietened down," Sgt Annakin said. "Every estate in Sheffield wants one of these teams now," said a city councillor, Robert Harpham. "But there aren't the resources to keep them permanently."

webTitle: Dover victims' relatives too afraid to come forward, says lawyer

fields.headline: Dover victims' relatives too afraid to come forward, says lawyer
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Only one of the 58 Chinese people who suffocated in a lorry at Dover last month has been positively identified because the Home Office is refusing to grant immunity to friends and relatives who wish to come forward, a solicitor has claimed.
fields.body:
Only one of the 58 Chinese people who suffocated in a lorry at Dover last month has been positively identified because the Home Office is refusing to grant immunity to friends and relatives who wish to come forward, a solicitor has claimed.

While the investigation into the deaths of the 58 Chinese immigrants has led to several arrests in Britain and Holland, the task of identifying the victims is taking much longer.

Kent police say they are confident of the identities of around half of the victims, but so far only one body has been positively identified, according to Tan Wah Piow, a London-based lawyer who has been in touch with seven people with relatives who were aboard the lorry.

Relatives of the dead are reluctant to come forward because of their own legal status. Mr Tan believes that at least one third of the victims had relatives in Britain.

He said he was in contact with a man whose brother died at Dover two weeks ago, but he was too afraid to come forward.

But despite appeals for help by agencies investigating the tragedy, the Home Office has refused to waive immigration legislation for any relatives of the victims who have entered the UK illegally.

"There can be no possibility of granting general amnesties to those who may or may not be in a position to identify the bodies," an official said.

Mr Tan's plans to have pictures of the dead released to the Chinese community in Britain have met with little success.

Identification has been hampered by the absence of documentation carried by the victims.

But Chinese police officers from Fujian province, from where the dead are thought to have travelled, arrived in Britain last week to help with the inquiries and Kent police say they think they know some of the names.

One Kent police officer said: "It's a big jigsaw and we are doing our best to put all the pieces together."

fields.headline: Cyril Offord
fields.standfirst: Master mathematician with a world view of justice
fields.trailText: Cyril Offord, who has died aged 93, was emeritus professor of mathematics at London University and one of the few remaining masters of classical analysis, a part of mathematics made famous in this country by GH Hardy and JE Littlewood in the early part of the last century. With Littlewood, Offord pioneered probabilistic analysis.
fields.body:
Cyril Offord, who has died aged 93, was emeritus professor of mathematics at London University and one of the few remaining masters of classical analysis, a part of mathematics made famous in this country by GH Hardy and JE Littlewood in the early part of the last century. With Littlewood, Offord pioneered probabilistic analysis.

This technique studies the typical behaviour of a mathematical expression such as a polynomial - the sum of a series of terms, each of which is the product of a constant and a variable squared, cubed, etc. By varying its components, it may be possible to show that almost all objects of a certain class have typical properties (even if one cannot construct a particular one that does). Offord showed later that when the basis for choosing the expression is changed, the typical behaviour can alter radically.

The son of a master printer at the publisher Eyre and Spottiswoode, Cyril was brought up in London. With his two brothers, he attended Hackney Downs grammar school; they joined the medical profession, while he studied mathematics, first at University College, London, and then at St John's College, Cambridge, of which he was a fellow from 1937-40.

He then became a lecturer at the University College of North Wales, Bangor, before moving on in 1942 to what was then King's College, Newcastle, where he became professor in 1945. In 1948, he joined Birkbeck College, London, and 18 years later moved to the London School of Economics. On retirement, he became a senior research fellow at Imperial College, before going to live in Oxford in 1980.

Cyril had an eye for quality in his own work, and that of others. In Newcastle, he appointed WW Rogosinski, who succeeded him as professor, and myself. We formed a small but enthusiastic seminar and were all fellows of the Royal Society within 10 years. At Birkbeck, he helped appoint Roger (now Sir Roger) Penrose as professor of applied mathematics, and David (now Sir David) Cox as professor of statistics.

Cyril always had a strong sense of social justice. In the 1930s, he belonged to Science For Peace and was in at the early stages of the Academic Assistance Council, now the Council for the Aid of Refugee Academics (Cara), as well as the Chinese Friendship Society. He visited China, and enabled others to do so at a time when few westerners could. Global problems of the world, such as famine and peace, were always close to his heart.

In Newcastle, he had met Marguerite Yvonne Pickard, a specialist in English literature and an editor of the Oxford dictionaries; they married in 1945. He loved gardening, and his clematis and roses were a joy to see. He was keen on classical music, and particularly chamber music, such as Haydn's string quartets.

Cyril was soft spoken and gentle, and his criticisms, while insightful and constructive, were never hurtful. He gave up his father's religion, the Plymouth Brethren, early in life, but was received into the church of England by the Bishop of Oxford shortly before his death. He kept up his interest in mathematics and attended meetings until a year or so before he died.

Marguerite died in 1998. Their daughter, Margaret, is also a literary editor.

 Cyril Albert Offord, mathematician, born June 9 1906; died June 4 2000

webTitle: The inspector who won't be inspected

fields.headline: The inspector who won't be inspected
fields.trailText: Ofsted makes patronising remarks about performance and accountability in your report (Is Ofsted right to attack local education authorities?, July 1). They are, perhaps, best judged in the context of the following complaint against Ofsted by County Durham LEA. The facts of the complaint, by Durham education authority against an Ofsted registered inspector, Ofsted itself and against Her Majesty's chief inspector, Chris Woodhead, are now a matter of record.
fields.body:
Ofsted makes patronising remarks about performance and accountability in your report (Is Ofsted right to attack local education authorities?, July 1). They are, perhaps, best judged in the context of the following complaint against Ofsted by County Durham LEA. The facts of the complaint, by Durham education authority against an Ofsted registered inspector, Ofsted itself and against Her Majesty's chief inspector, Chris Woodhead, are now a matter of record.

Mr Woodhead intervened in the complaint before Ofsted's investigation was complete, to express a view in Ofsted's favour and directed the investigator to communicate his view to the complainant. Ofsted's own adjudicator judged this as "unwarranted" and "implicitly threatening". Last month - three years after the original complaint, and when, throughout, Ofsted had found no fault with itself - we received an unreserved written apology from both Ofsted and HMCI, to myself, a colleague and the LEA.

But a more significant issue has emerged. Mr Woodhead has been involved in intervening in a complaint in breach of any published Ofsted procedures. At no point has he given an account of himself. The LEA has demanded that such accountability be undertaken and at every stage it has been rejected. The LEA also offered that the matter should be referred to an independent arbitrator. That, too, was rejected.

Where is Ofsted's accountability? Wherein lies accountability for Mr Woodhead's personal conduct in this affair? This complaint has been sent to ministers and the parliamentary select committee to which alone, apparently, HMCI is accountable. It remains stubbornly and bizarrely unclear why the government's all-powerful political principles of modernisation and accountability should bind everybody but Ofsted. We have the central paradox of a government committed to educational accountability but its ministers are unable to act when a highly damaging gap in accountability on a national level has been exposed.

The real question is not whether Ofsted has the right to judge LEAs but whether Ofsted has the credibility to judge anything until its stables are cleared out?

Keith Mitchell
Director of education, Durham county council

fields.headline: David Tomlinson
fields.trailText: David Tomlinson (Obituary, June 26) became a friend of mine 25 years ago because we both had sons of approximately the same age who suffered from autism. This became a central feature of David's life.
fields.body:
David Tomlinson (Obituary, June 26) became a friend of mine 25 years ago because we both had sons of approximately the same age who suffered from autism. This became a central feature of David's life.

Willie, his third child, exhibited the troublesome features of autism at a time when even less was known about the condition than is currently the case, and when diagnosis was extremely difficult to come by. David used his influence to gain publicity and funds for what was then the fledgling autistic movement, roping in friends from the theatre such as Ian Carmichael, Felicity Kendal, the Beatles, and, especially, Robert Morley. He made a television appeal in the 1970s, which raised more money than any other appeal had done up to that time.

David and his wife, Audrey, were among the 20 or so families who helped to found Somerset Court, the first residential home in Europe devoted specifically to adults suffering from autism. Willie stayed there until relatively recently, when he transferred to another offshoot nearby.

Like his father, Willie is skilled with his hands; he has his own workshop at home and has become an expert craftsman in wood.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: Sir John Evans, quoted in our front page report, yesterday, Police push Blair into yob fines climbdown, is the chief constable of Devon and Cornwall, not Somerset and Avon.
fields.body:
Sir John Evans, quoted in our front page report, yesterday, Police push Blair into yob fines climbdown, is the chief constable of Devon and Cornwall, not Somerset and Avon.

Edward VIII, referred to in our review of the television programme about Wallis Simpson, page 22, G2, yesterday, was proclaimed king on the death of his father, but was never crowned. He abdicated before the date set for the coronation.

There were numerous mistakes in our piece about Dresden, pages 6 and 7, Travel, July 1. We should have said Görlitzer Strasse; Saxon (not Saxony) Switzerland; Haus Altmarkt (not Altmarket); Planwirtschaft, planned economy (not Plantwirtschaft), und so weiter.

One of the entrants commended in our BBC Proms competition, page 8, Education, yesterday, was Alex Campkin, not, as it appeared, Alex Camplin. Apologies.

Homophone corner, from page 4, G2, yesterday, where we referred to questions "that illicit particularly spirited replies". (In this piece we also misspelt and misunderstood the term Pyrrhic victory, "a victory in which the victor's losses are as great as those of the defeated" - Collins Millennium).

And another homophone, from page 18, July 3, where in a review of the band Radiohead at the Royal Festival Hall, we mentioned "guitar effects peddles that do everything short of telling jokes..."

We rarely give the correct version for homophones, preferring to encourage the use of the dictionary.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number.
