fields.headline: Enric Miralles
fields.standfirst: Inspiring and original architect who brought a Catalan's sense of freedom to Scotland and its new parliament building
fields.trailText: If there was anyone who could understand the significance of the new Scottish parliament at the foot of the Royal Mile in Edinburgh, it was its architect, Enric Miralles, who has died from a brain tumour aged 45.
fields.body:
If there was anyone who could understand the significance of the new Scottish parliament at the foot of the Royal Mile in Edinburgh, it was its architect, Enric Miralles, who has died from a brain tumour aged 45. As a Catalan, he could empathise with the sense of identity that the new political situation had created in Scotland. The design is based on boats, a reflection of Scotland's maritime history, and perhaps a poetic way of expressing his belief of a democratic government as a gathering of diverse ideas.

Miralles was the Barcelona architect who most embodied the spirit of that city. By combining the characteristics of Catalan architecture - once described by Nikolaus Pevsner as being anarchic and, at the same time, filled with the serenity of economic structure - he broke every established rule of his calling, rearranging concepts to allow a fresh breeze to carry his imagination along new routes. This, however, was always tempered by a profound understanding of the capacity of the site to inform the process of the design.

Physically large, with untidy hair and beard, Miralles reminded one of GK Chesterton or Hilaire Belloc, and, with his mischievous sense of humour, of Lutyens. It would not be inappropriate - considering his projects and buildings - to suggest that he was on his way to becoming another legendary figure, like Antoni Gaudí.

Like Gaudí, he had an enormous capacity to communicate, especially with his office team and collaborators, but also with his clients and constructors. His gentle charm, combined with an almost encyclopaedic cultural memory, won him the admiration of countless students where he taught, whether it was Harvard, the Architectural Association, Frankfurt or in Barcelona.

Miralles had studied at the Escuela Técnica Superior de Arquitectura in Barcelona, going on to complete his doctoral thesis on William Adam, Edinburgh's great 18th-century architect, at Columbia University, New York. He had earlier visited Edinburgh as a teenager, to learn English.

But students only really listen to people who go beyond the academic and can actually manage to get an idea built successfully. In this, Miralles, for all his youth, could cut the mustard. Between 1974 and 1989, he was a rising star within the office of the Barcelona architects Helio Piñon and Albert Viaplana. There, he was involved in the design of the Plaça dels Països Catalans, the square in front of the main railway station, which drew the attention of the world's architects to the new approach to the design of public spaces in this city.

He qualified in 1978 and, in 1983, set up his own office with Carme Pinós, his first wife, with whom he designed the cemetery for the town of Igualada. Completed in 1991, this project launched him into international fame. It was there that he was buried yesterday.

These early works were more on the edge of architecture - as well as the Igualada cemetery, for example, there had been Barcelona's Olympic archery area and the pergola in the Olympic village - before he moved on to design his first buildings in 1990. These were a sports hall in Huesca and a gymnasium in Alicante. Although they both fitted beautifully into the landscape, they were somewhat chaotic, and wilfully aggressive in the abuse of structure. For a time, it might have seemed that Miralles was becoming trapped by his own ingenious and mysterious drawings.

Fortunately, stimulated by competition successes (he won the bid for the Scottish parliament against four other teams), his later works showed an increasingly masterly control of his almost casual compositions. He was in the process of marrying his lyrical and poetic imagination to the representational character of institutional buildings, such as the Scottish parliament, the extension to the town hall in Utrecht, the school of architecture in Venice and the headquarters for the gas company in Barcelona.

However, it is easy to understand that Miralles's heart was particularly in a project just round the corner from where he lived in the old medieval quarter of Barcelona. This was a project that the mayor had asked him to undertake - to replace the old market of Santa Caterina and its immediate surroundings. It was a challenge to find within the culture of our time an answer to the medieval street structure of the city. Fortunately, like the Scottish parliament, the design is far advanced, and his office will be able to finish the details. Yet, there will inevitably be something missing - the humour perhaps, which was an integral part of Miralles himself.

Personally, I shall miss our casual encounters in the early morning, when we met cycling to work - our offices were almost next door to each other. We used to exchange brief comments on our respective projects. He was sometimes accompanied by his second wife and partner since 1993, Benedetta Tagliabue, and their children, Caterina, aged six, and a boy, Domènec, aged three.

He was extremely fond of his family and had many friends, and, as a natural master, many pupils, who will continue to be inspired by his free approach to his art.

Professor Andrew Macmillan writes: Enric Miralles and I first met in the early 1990s, when he came to talk about his work to us at the Mackintosh school of architecture in Glasgow. He stayed on to look at the students' work, and to inspire them - and he came again and again.

He enjoyed architecture, he lived at his most intense through it. He reminded me of Pavarotti, who stops and smiles radiantly when he knows he has done well, pleased with himself and sharing his pleasure.

With Enric, you were with a mind that was never at rest, a man with poetic insight into the stimuli that produce form and meaning in architecture. I remember walking in the rain along the Crinan canal during one of his visits, when we came across a fish-shaped puddle. Look, he said, in my next cemetery I will make one, a permanent puddle. At that time, he had just completed two brilliant cemeteries near Barcelona - the Spaniards still take death seriously.

In discussion, his deep interest in art, in the depiction of light and space, his readings in philosophy, his encyclopedic knowledge of architectural sources, historical and contemporary, revealed how profoundly his own work was based.

His presentation to the selection panel seeking an architect for the new Scottish parliament building was always stimulating, challenging and, above all, poetic, with unexpected twists and yet astonishingly practical at the same time.

As a Catalan, he had a sympathy with Scotland - he liked the land and its people. He wanted to give of his best to make its forum, its first significant public building, special - to the place, to the people, to its enlightened traditions. He wanted to make it a building of today, looking forward not back.

His sudden death is shocking, a cutting-off of a unique talent. Fortunately, architects work in teams, buildings are complex, and the personal involvement which is implicit in an atelier like that Enric operated and inspired - and that includes the new Scottish partners - means that dedicated, involved people can and will finish the parliament building. I hope Enric will be remembered for it.

 Enric Miralles Moya, architect, born February 12 1955; died July 3 2000

He had earlier visited Edinburgh as a teenager, to learn English. But students only really listen to people who go beyond the academic and can actually manage to get an idea built successfully. In this, Miralles, for all his youth, could cut the mustard. Between 1974 and 1989, he was a rising star within the office of the Barcelona architects Helio Piñon and Albert Viaplana. There, he was involved in the design of the Plaça dels Països Catalans, the square in front of the main railway station, which drew the attention of the world's architects to the new approach to the design of public spaces in this city. He qualified in 1978 and, in 1983, set up his own office with Carme Pinós, his first wife, with whom he designed the cemetery for the town of Igualada. Completed in 1991, this project launched him into international fame. It was there that he was buried yesterday. These early works were more on the edge of architecture - as well as the Igualada cemetery, for example, there had been Barcelona's Olympic archery area and the pergola in the Olympic village - before he moved on to design his first buildings in 1990. These were a sports hall in Huesca and a gymnasium in Alicante. Although they both fitted beautifully into the landscape, they were somewhat chaotic, and wilfully aggressive in the abuse of structure. For a time, it might have seemed that Miralles was becoming trapped by his own ingenious and mysterious drawings. Fortunately, stimulated by competition successes (he won the bid for the Scottish parliament against four other teams), his later works showed an increasingly masterly control of his almost casual compositions. He was in the process of marrying his lyrical and poetic imagination to the representational character of institutional buildings, such as the Scottish parliament, the extension to the town hall in Utrecht, the school of architecture in Venice and the headquarters for the gas company in Barcelona. However, it is easy to understand that Miralles's heart was particularly in a project just round the corner from where he lived in the old medieval quarter of Barcelona. This was a project that the mayor had asked him to undertake - to replace the old market of Santa Caterina and its immediate surroundings. It was a challenge to find within the culture of our time an answer to the medieval street structure of the city. Fortunately, like the Scottish parliament, the design is far advanced, and his office will be able to finish the details. Yet, there will inevitably be something missing - the humour perhaps, which was an integral part of Miralles himself. Personally, I shall miss our casual encounters in the early morning, when we met cycling to work - our offices were almost next door to each other. We used to exchange brief comments on our respective projects. He was sometimes accompanied by his second wife and partner since 1993, Benedetta Tagliabue, and their children, Caterina, aged six, and a boy, Domènec, aged three. He was extremely fond of his family and had many friends, and, as a natural master, many pupils, who will continue to be inspired by his free approach to his art. Professor Andrew Macmillan writes: Enric Miralles and I first met in the early 1990s, when he came to talk about his work to us at the Mackintosh school of architecture in Glasgow. He stayed on to look at the students' work, and to inspire them - and he came again and again. He enjoyed architecture, he lived at his most intense through it. He reminded me of Pavarotti, who stops and smiles radiantly when he knows he has done well, pleased with himself and sharing his pleasure. With Enric, you were with a mind that was never at rest, a man with poetic insight into the stimuli that produce form and meaning in architecture. I remember walking in the rain along the Crinan canal during one of his visits, when we came across a fish-shaped puddle. Look, he said, in my next cemetery I will make one, a permanent puddle. At that time, he had just completed two brilliant cemeteries near Barcelona - the Spaniards still take death seriously. In discussion, his deep interest in art, in the depiction of light and space, his readings in philosophy, his encyclopedic knowledge of architectural sources, historical and contemporary, revealed how profoundly his own work was based. His presentation to the selection panel seeking an architect for the new Scottish parliament building was always stimulating, challenging and, above all, poetic, with unexpected twists and yet astonishingly practical at the same time. As a Catalan, he had a sympathy with Scotland - he liked the land and its people. He wanted to give of his best to make its forum, its first significant public building, special - to the place, to the people, to its enlightened traditions. He wanted to make it a building of today, looking forward not back. His sudden death is shocking, a cutting-off of a unique talent. Fortunately, architects work in teams, buildings are complex, and the personal involvement which is implicit in an atelier like that Enric operated and inspired - and that includes the new Scottish partners - means that dedicated, involved people can and will finish the parliament building. I hope Enric will be remembered for it.  Enric Miralles Moya, architect, born February 12 1955; died July 3 2000

webTitle: Ethical advice for Tony Blair - and his German guru

fields.headline: Ethical advice for Tony Blair - and his German guru
fields.trailText: Why won't Hans Küng (Letters, July 4) grant to the Guardian the same right that he himself demands from the Catholic church: the right of dissent? The global ethics that Prof Küng repeatedly calls for has to be built upon civil liberties, not a lurch towards the rightwing agenda on law and order. Research into CCTVs (and weren't these supposed to prevent loutish behaviour?) shows that it is the poor, the vulnerable and the ethnic minorities who are targeted by a Get Tough regime.
fields.body:
Why won't Hans Küng (Letters, July 4) grant to the Guardian the same right that he himself demands from the Catholic church: the right of dissent? The global ethics that Prof Küng repeatedly calls for has to be built upon civil liberties, not a lurch towards the rightwing agenda on law and order. Research into CCTVs (and weren't these supposed to prevent loutish behaviour?) shows that it is the poor, the vulnerable and the ethnic minorities who are targeted by a Get Tough regime.

And unlike Prof Küng, Tony Blair has not recognised that global ethics require a global economics that turns us away from the ideology of free market flexibility and deregulation.

Those who stress the importance of ethics often fall into the trap of imagining that the mantra of "rights imply responsibility" is sufficient. But duties correlate to powers, not rights. A right, by itself, empowers nobody. It is because they ignore this that New Labour end up loading duties on the poorest and and ask very little of the wealthiest.

Tony Blair is the worst kind of egalitarian: one who identifies equality between unequals. Surely Hans Küng sees that a global ethics has to start from a different premise?

Dr Tony Fitzpatrick
University of Nottingham
tony.fitzpatrick@ nottingham.ac.uk

While Mark Seddon (Comment, July 4) is right in his view that Tony Blair has failed to inspire affection in his party, Simon McKeown (Letters, July 4) perhaps makes a more telling point when he highlights the effect of changes in Labour's policy-making mechanisms.

Perhaps we should not be surprised that this leadership seems increasingly remote from its core support as it has stripped out the mechanisms for real dialogue and debate within, and across, the party. Focus groups have their place but no party, as the Tories discovered to their cost, can afford to lose the passionate support of those who are their ambassadors at a local and community level.

At last week's Local Government Association conference, Labour's private sessions were devoted, almost exclusively, to campaigning and the selection of candidates. Delegates wanted time and space to discuss, with ministers, the issues that concern their local communities. Until Blair, and his advisors, learn to appreciate the importance of genuine dialogue they will continue to face real difficulties with Labour members and Labour voters.

Cllr Andy Howell
Birmingham

Barbara Follett wasn't at a local "government" conference (Ex-ministers join spin fray, July 4) but at a local Labour party conference. And it wasn't an "outburst" but in the context of local activists debating the state of the party, including some appropriate criticism of Blair and his government. I, for one, reflected what I had heard while canvassing in May: that plenty of people don't like either.

John Quill
Watford
johnq@care4free.net

webTitle: Turkish leaders find EU reforms hard to swallow

fields.headline: Turkish leaders find EU reforms hard to swallow
fields.standfirst: Ankara has far to go before membership talks can start
fields.trailText: More than six months after it became a formal candidate for joining the European Union, Turkey has made little progress towards the wide-ranging reforms needed before membership negotiations can begin.
fields.body:
More than six months after it became a formal candidate for joining the European Union, Turkey has made little progress towards the wide-ranging reforms needed before membership negotiations can begin.

European diplomats in Ankara accept that the Turks face a huge task which cannot be completed overnight, but are disappointed that virtually nothing has been done so far.

"The European commission needs to tell them that this is a serious business", one EU diplomat said. "The Turks cannot pick and choose."

Turkey is by far the largest and most complex of the countries seeking membership. Before it can start negotiations it has to meet what are known as the Copenhagen criteria: broad political and economic standards set by EU members.

On the positive side, an intense debate has begun on some of the most sensitive issues , such as human rights and freedom of expression. In the past few weeks the role of the military in society, a topic previously off-limits, has been openly discussed.

The president, Ahmet Necdet Sezer, urged parliament last week to consider rapid reforms to democratise the constitution, which was created in the aftermath of a military coup 20 years ago.

But for all the talk, precious little has been achieved. A lack of political leadership on Europe and a bureaucratic struggle about the scope of reforms have left Turkish politicians' predictions that the process could be completed quickly looking hollow.

"There are powerful forces in this society which are extremely suspicious of Europe," the political commentator Semih Idiz of Star newspaper said. "They can slow the process right down, and that's exactly what has happened."

In recent weeks reports have been leaked to the media which speak of "subjective and exaggerated demands" from the EU and reforms which would "destroy national unity".

As always, the Kurdish issue will be one of the most difficult to resolve. It is hard to imagine Turkey beginning EU membership negotiations as long as bans on teaching or broadcasting in Kurdish remain in place. But equally, it would be difficult for the powerful military establishment to accept a complete change of policy towards the Kurds.

One possible compromise would be to promote reform under the umbrella of "individual" rather than "minority" rights. But it will not be easy. There is still a fear of granting concessions to Europe, and a strong body of opinion which regards negotiations as a process in which there is a winner and a loser.

But most Turks believe they would win by joining the EU. Membership has been a strategic goal of the establishment for many years, and polls suggest that a large majority of voters are in favour. But that could change.

"Just imagine trying to sell the idea of pooled sovereignty here," said an EU diplomat. "It would make the debate in London look like a tea party."

So it is perhaps inevitable that Turkey - a country with as many ties to the Middle East as to Europe - will have to go through a period of intense soul-searching on the path towards the EU.

A long wait could also be beneficial for the rest of Europe. Enlargement is already producing issues which EU members are struggling to deal with.

The immediate task in the coming months is for the European commission to draw up a series of documents, including an "accession partnership" which is supposed to set goals for a candidate country.

Much of the work to be done in Turkey involves detailed economic and technical issues, but political problems will continue to grab the headlines.

"Presentation will be the key ingredient", said another EU observer in Ankara. "If we come up with a blueprint for changing Turkish society it will go down here like a lead balloon."

webTitle: Animals die so that humans live

fields.headline: Animals die so that humans live
fields.trailText: The use of animals in medical research is a necessary step in developing safe and effective medicines for treating human diseases (Scientists predict big rise in animal tests, July 4).
fields.body:
The use of animals in medical research is a necessary step in developing safe and effective medicines for treating human diseases (Scientists predict big rise in animal tests, July 4).

Genetics has allowed the creation of better, more precise mouse "models" for many serious human conditions, including cancer, cystic fibrosis and muscular dystrophy. This speeds up research and ensures that trials in humans of promising treatments can begin sooner. Research using animals is the means, not the end, and most scientists are eager to see the animal phase of their work end, because it means that they can move on to work with people.

The predicted rise in the number of animals used should be seen as good news, because it means that science has advanced to the point where animal work is necessary and because it means that we are closer to the development of treatments for a wide range of diseases where, in most cases no effective intervention exists today.

Excessive restrictions on animal experiments means that disease will remain untreatable for longer and people will continue to suffer from the effects of potentially avoidable ill health and disability. The choice is as stark and as simple as that.

Alastair Kent
Director, Genetic Interest Group
mail@gig.org.uk

The human genome project will certainly change the way medicine is practiced and the way medical research is conducted. But it will not change the way lobbyists spread propaganda for their clients.

The human genome project will change the way physicians treat humans. If ever a discovery highlighted how little society now needs animals to model human disease, the human genome project has done just that. In earlier times, when genes were unheard of, scientists experimented on animals because animals were similar to humans.

With the advent of modern technology and increasing knowledge, we now know that the differences between humans and animals that exist on the cellular level outweigh the similarities on the superficial level.

Disease occurs on the cellular level. Humans suffer from diseases that have uniquely human manifestations. Monkeys are immune to herpes B while humans die from it. Humans' diet can result in clogged arteries while dogs can eat anything without having to worry about a bypass operation.

We live in the 21st century, not the 19th. The only people calling for more animal experimentation, in light of the knowledge that has come from the human genome project, are those who will profit financially from more animal experimentation. Consider the source.

Dr Ray Greek
Americans For Medical Advancement
AFMA@curedisease.com
Susan Green
Europeans For Medical Advancement
EFMA@btinternet.com

Certainly there are misgivings about the relevance of animal models in some situations and few can argue with the proposition that there are effective rules and regulations that limit suffering and harm wherever possible, and ensure that there are good reasons for prosecuting experimental strategies in animals.

However, there must also be recognition of the benefits that animal experimentation have provided man, and other animals.

Those who seek a complete ban on animal experimentation must, however, recognise the consequences for future health care and veterinary medicine. Furthermore, all who hold this position must presumably also accept that, in order to prevent a charge of hypocrisy, they should also refuse to benefit from any of the past advances based upon animal experimentation. This will include a refusal to benefit from all surgical procedures, all medicines, all cosmetics and all household cleaners. I wonder how many might then change their minds?

Prof Peter A Hall
Riyadh, Saudi Arabia

It is always interesting to read how those with vested interests are quick to adopt "spin" techniques to ensure that their research budgets and salaries are not affected by achievements such as the human genome project.

Given the controversy surrounding the vivisection industry and the importance of human health, why does the government continue to resist pressure from medical and scientific professionals to establish a public judicial inquiry into the value of the animal model in human medicine?

Catherine Neill
London

So, a faction of the scientific community are effectively threatening to take their work abroad if the government does not ease what they call the "bureaucracy" of the 1986 Animal (Scientific Procedures) Act. Are they seriously suggesting that our already inadequate standards with regards to animal welfare should be reduced to match those abroad?

Just as some researchers prey on public fears about disease, we now see them preying on the concerns of government to protect the future of British industry. This is nothing more than an attempt to blackmail the government into relaxing controls.

Jan Creamer
Director, National Anti-Vivisection Society

fields.headline: Secrets of the manly
fields.trailText: Ekow Eshun's analysis (Why manliness will get a modern leader nowhere, July 4) reminds me of Shere Hite's research, which seemed to prove that boys brought up by single mothers had an easier relationship with women as adults. It is worth remembering that the Charlton brothers, two of the most sportsmanlike of English footballers, were taught the game by their mother.

What neither of us enjoys is the cleaning, which is much more time consuming and far less rewarding. No one has ever praised my dust free skirting boards.

Cambridge
ehb102@lineone.net

As the Zimbabwean elections were conducted on the basis of one person one vote, and the actual voting was acknowledged by international observers to be generally free and fair, I can readily believe the assurances of Margaret McDonagh (Letters, July 4) that she and Millbank had nothing to do with them.

London

Manchester

Kieran Cooper

fields.headline: Greece penalised for toxic waste
fields.trailText: Greece's fledgling green credentials were in tatters last night after it was ordered to pay a daily fine of £14,000 for refusing to shut down a waste-disposal plant spewing toxic rubbish into a ravine 200 metres from the Mediterranean Sea.
fields.body:
Greece's fledgling green credentials were in tatters last night after it was ordered to pay a daily fine of £14,000 for refusing to shut down a waste-disposal plant spewing toxic rubbish into a ravine 200 metres from the Mediterranean Sea.

The ruling of the European court of justice in Luxembourg has far-reaching consequences for other European Union countries, for it is the first time that the court has fined an EU member-state for refusing to comply with one of its judgments.

"We are stepping into new territory here. This is a landmark ruling and one of the most important judgements of the year," a court official said.

The decision is also a sign that the court is ready to get tough with countries which flout EU law, and that is likely to give a glimmer of hope to UK farmers relying on it to overturn France's ban on British beef.

The court ordered Greece to close the plant, on the island of Crete, in 1992.

But opposition from the local authorities, who are loath to build a new plant near Chania, the local town, has prevented the order being obeyed.

The ruling is highly embarrassing to the Greek government, since the court found that waste from military bases, hospitals and local industry was still "thrown in an uncontrolled manner" into a ravine just 200 metres from the Mediterranean Sea.

The rubbish is constantly on fire and, every time it rains waste residues are swept into the sea and soak into the ground, damaging the environment.

Greek officials admitted yesterday that the ruling was likely to damage their country's environmental credentials, but were at pains to pin the blame on the local authorities in Crete.

"They are like the Sardinians and the Sicilians," one official said.

He claimed that the Cretan authorities had repeatedly refused to bow to pressure from Athens, but would now have no choice but to fall into line.

"It is an embarrassment for the country but it is something we're trying to improve," the official said. We will have to comply with the decision and we will be paying the fine. The fine is quite steep so we'll have to get our act together very quickly."

Tourists should not, he added, be put off from visiting Crete,for it was still safe to swim in the Mediterranean.

But the European commission, which brought the case against Greece, took a stronger line yesterday and argued that the matter was extremely serious.

"It is very serious because it is about waste and toxic waste and ultimately the consumer's health," a commission spokeswoman, Pia Ahrenkilde, said.

The court's decision was a landmark ruling, Ms Ahrenkilde added. It would serve as a deterrent against other countries which might be thinking of ignoring EU law.

The ruling is highly embarrassing to the Greek government, since the court found that waste from military bases, hospitals and local industry was still "thrown in an uncontrolled manner" into a ravine just 200 metres from the Mediterranean Sea. The rubbish is constantly on fire and, every time it rains waste residues are swept into the sea and soak into the ground, damaging the environment. Greek officials admitted yesterday that the ruling was likely to damage their country's environmental credentials, but were at pains to pin the blame on the local authorities in Crete. "They are like the Sardinians and the Sicilians," one official said. He claimed that the Cretan authorities had repeatedly refused to bow to pressure from Athens, but would now have no choice but to fall into line. "It is an embarrassment for the country but it is something we're trying to improve," the official said. We will have to comply with the decision and we will be paying the fine. The fine is quite steep so we'll have to get our act together very quickly." Tourists should not, he added, be put off from visiting Crete,for it was still safe to swim in the Mediterranean. But the European commission, which brought the case against Greece, took a stronger line yesterday and argued that the matter was extremely serious. "It is very serious because it is about waste and toxic waste and ultimately the consumer's health," a commission spokeswoman, Pia Ahrenkilde, said. The court's decision was a landmark ruling, Ms Ahrenkilde added. It would serve as a deterrent against other countries which might be thinking of ignoring EU law.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
 What a chatty fellow is Roger Liddle, co-author with O'Mandy Mandelson of the Blair Revolution and now Mr Tony's key adviser on Europe policy. Last Friday, at a BBC dinner party (Roger's wife is a senior manager there), Roger merrily chirruped to guests not only about his own importance (he answers to no one but the PM) but almost anything else. Roger himself flew to Germany to set up the meeting with Gerhard Schröder, he said - one arranged solely for the PM to tell the German chancellor to keep patience because Britain will unquestionably be joining the euro. Wow. As for Mr T's spot fines idea, this was Alastair Campbell's idea, said Rog, to deflect criticism of Mr T being weak on Europe. And when asked about rumours of rifts between Mr Tony and Gordon Brown, Roger almost spat out his wine. Not get on? he spluttered, that's the understatement of the century. They loathe each other...and it's a nightmare for people like him because the whole government is split into two camps. Roger wasn't coming to the phone to discuss his remarks. Perhaps he's done so much talking lately that he's lost his voice?

 When US phone companies Bell Atlantic and GTE merged to form Verizon, the new corporate giant cutely registered a swath of internet addresses - not just Verizon.com etc, but likely rude variants such as VerizonSucks.com and VerizonShits.com. It listed 700 names in total...but not enough. 2600, a strangely named but enterprising computing magazine, has registered VerizonReallySucks.com. Verizon then threatened the tiny mag with a breach of copyright writ. In a tough, no-nonsense counterstrike, 2600 registered VerizonShouldSpendMoreTimeFixingItsNetworkAndLessMoneyOnLawyers.com. And some people say these internet folks are all humourless nerds.

 More on the transcripts doctored by Clare Bomber Short's office after her interview with the Ecologist's Simon Restallack. Among the various idiotic or contentious remarks excised was one in response to Simon suggesting developing countries should be discouraged from developing oil resources and encouraged to use non-fossil fuel. "So the poorest countries in the world who have got oil are not supposed to use it and use the proceeds well in order to develop their economies," said Bomber, scathingly, describing this as "a bundle of prejudice, half-informed prejudices." Excellent. It is also official government policy. No wonder they removed it in what Bomber's delightful press chief Beverley Warmington describes as a "cock up". Of course. By the way, when Simon asked for the original tape, Beverly said that, due to another cock up, the tape had been wiped. Aha.

 My colleague John Vidal recalls interviewing Ms Short recently, and asking some questions she didn't like. "You don't know Africa," ranted the Bomber, "you've never lived in Africa." Well, John replied, I was born there, and lived in Nigeria for 12 years. "Er, well," said Bomber of the Nile, "you don't visit villages, you don't. . ."

 A strange email arrives, from Cosmopolitan magazine. "Dear Everyone," writes Andy Freidlander, "Do any of you know any good looking men who's [sic] girlfriends will vouch for the fact that they are good in the sack and who will be photographed nude?" A very exciting prospect. The email has also circulated between New Labour weenies - and there's nothing like a spotty four-eyes who spends his life sucking up to junior ministers to turn a woman on, is there?

 Hats off to my colleague Richard Adams, who trounced more than 50 members of the lobby and the Downing Street press office to win the Euro 2000 prediction competition. Godric Smith, Alastair Campbell's replacement, came 16th. Award-winning Peter Riddell of the Times was 31st.

webTitle: Drink advice service confronts sex abuse

fields.headline: Drink advice service confronts sex abuse
fields.standfirst: AA acts on rising reports of attacks by volunteers
fields.trailText: Vulnerable alcoholics seeking help for their addiction are being subjected to sexual and other abuse at the hands of long-serving volunteers from the world's largest alcohol support group.
fields.body:
Vulnerable alcoholics seeking help for their addiction are being subjected to sexual and other abuse at the hands of long-serving volunteers from the world's largest alcohol support group.

An internal memorandum circulated to every Alcoholics Anonymous group in the country reveals that volunteer members are increasingly being investigated by police forces examining allegations of sexual abuse.

It is impossible to quantify the allegations since AA is committed to anonymity and will not be drawn on any aspect of its work. But the document makes it clear the group's general service board has known of the problem for some time and feels it must be tackled at a national level.

According to the memo, leaked to the Glasgow-based Herald newspaper, within AA "there is a small minority of men and women who operate with sick but hidden agendas, and, no matter what they may say, they seek self-gratification often at the expense of other members or potential members".

Public exposure of the memo is embarrassing to AA, but the document itself was being interpreted yesterday as an attempt by the group to confront the ills which have long dogged other voluntary organisations.

A senior alcohol addiction worker said: "It came as a bit of a shock to me and I have never picked up on these allegations before. AA [is] in a difficult position: we all put checks and balances in place, but it is very difficult to protect people entirely from abuse of position because the people involved are invariably clever."

It is understood the chair of AA's York-based general services board drafted the memo after being made aware of the rising number of police investigations. It was issued as a consultation document to autonomous groups across the country and the board is hoping to find new ways of framing guidance to prevent further abuse.

Abusers within the organisation are said to have exploited their positions as "sponsors", taking advantage of the vulnerable when they are at their lowest ebb. Contact is usually made through telephone helplines and then continued in the home.

AA has guidelines governing who is eligible to become a sponsor or answer helplines and make home visits. But the memo reveals these have been broken, with some taking on the role with neither the appropriate experience nor duration of sobriety. The document says: "There appears to be a growing number of cases around the country of police (and other agency involvement) in allegations of unlawful sexual conduct by AA members."

It warns that the organisation has the "potential to become a breeding ground for predatory behaviour".

Although AA holds its creed of anonymity sacrosanct, there is admission of a general acknowledgement of abuse within AA, and that the organisation will be unable to duck exposure of such abuse. The organisation says it will not protect members from the law.

A spokeswoman for AA yesterday confirmed the leaked document was genuine, but refused to comment further.

webTitle: Opec in turmoil as Saudis drive down prices

fields.headline: Opec in turmoil as Saudis drive down prices
fields.trailText: Opec was thrown into turmoil yesterday by a Saudi decision to turn on the taps and force down oil prices.
fields.body:
Opec was thrown into turmoil yesterday by a Saudi decision to turn on the taps and force down oil prices. The surprise move by the desert kingdom was seen as a sign of its willingness to please Washington at the cost of alienating its Middle East neighbours.

Fearing that high oil prices could cause inflation and slow down economic growth, the United States has been pressing for action.

But the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries, representing the producers of 40% of the world's oil, offered only a modest increase in production, and that failed to move the markets.

On Monday Saudi Arabia - the world's biggest oil producer and the only country capable of shifting prices single-handedly - came to the rescue, announcing that it would "very soon" increase production by 500,000 barrels a day unless crude prices - currently about $30 (£20) a barrel - came down.

Yesterday Kuwait and Qatar complained that they had not been consulted, and Iran accused the kingdom of violating agreements. The Iraqi oil minister, Lieutenant-General Amer Mohammed Rashid, denounced the Saudis for giving in to pressure from the US, where petrol prices have become an issue in the presidential election.

The Venezuelan president of Opec, Ali Rodriguez, also joined the fray. "Before Saudi Arabia takes any decision it is essential to hold consultations. Until now we have always taken decisions by consensus," he said

In the US, Vice-President Al Gore immediately welcomed the Saudi move, saying: "I want to call on the big oil companies to let that Saudi output increase pass through in the form of price reductions to the people who are filling their cars."

Although oil producers have been enjoying a revenue bonanza recently, Opec regards $25 a barrel as a more reasonable level. Over-high prices can cause inflation and, in the long term, are bad for producers because they encourage customers to economise on oil or switch to alternatives.

Saudi Arabia has a reserve capacity of 2.5m barrels a day. Half of this can be restarted quickly, though the other half would take several months.

But Roger Diwan of the Washington consultancy Petroleum Finance Corporation says Saudi Arabia's actual production levels may be less important than the psychological effect on the market.

"What matters is the announcement," he said. "The Saudis are trying to force oil traders to start betting prices down. Their aim is to show traders the trend, because betting against Saudi Arabia is not a good idea."

Oil prices fell from around $25 a barrel in 1997 to under $10 in 1999, mainly as a result of the crisis in Asia's "tiger" economies and mild winters in the northern hemisphere.

Since last year, they have risen rapidly, partly because of collective action by Opec. But the rise has continued beyond Opec's target range of $22 to $28.

The Iranians, in particular, blame the US for the most recent increases, saying they are due to factors in the American market rather than a shortage of global production.

Refinery bottlenecks and anti-pollution regulations requiring different types of petrol have pushed up prices at filling stations.

Meanwhile, stockpiles of oil acquired at low prices have been reduced to almost nothing, because companies risk losing money if they replenish them now and prices subsequently fall.

One result of this, according to industry analysts, is that at present consumers have no cushion against a disruption of supplies from less dependable sources such as Iraq, Nigeria, Colombia and Angola.

Because of UN sanctions, Iraq does have an Opec quota, but it exports just under 2m barrels a day through the oil-for-food programme. The bulk of this goes to the US and Europe.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Austria to vote on EU sanctions
fields.body:
Austria to vote on EU sanctions

Austria upped the stakes in its response to EU sanctions yesterday, announcing a national referendum despite repeated pleas from Brussels.

Its 14 EU partners imposed an unprecedented quarantine in February when the chancellor, Wolfgang Schüssel, formed a government with the far-right Freedom party.

Voters will be asked: "Should the federal government...ensure by all possible means that the unfairly imposed sanctions on Austria be lifted immediately?"
Ian Black, Brussels

Five injured in Fiji shootings

Five people were wounded when Fijian troops started a 15-minute firefight with rebels outside parliament yesterday, raising the tension in the hostage crisis.

A military spokesman said the incident was the result of two inexperienced soldiers straying too close to the parliament, where the rebels are holding the deposed prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry, and 26 other politicians.

The shooting occurred shortly after the new indigenous Fijian prime minister, Laisenia Qarase, was sworn in.
Reuters, Suva

Ivory Coast unrest quelled

Ivory Coast's military ruler, General Robert Guei, said yesterday that the junta was in control after army unrest and that junior soldiers had been manipulated by politicians.

"These are young people manipulated by politicians. Some got a bit heated," he said after shooting in Abidjan. Military sources linked the unrest to a dispute over allowances.
Reuters, Abidjan

No sanctuary for whales

A proposal for a South Pacific whale sanctuary covering 4.7m square miles failed to gain enough support at the International Whaling Commission meeting yesterday.

The plan, which needed to win 75% of the votes, was opposed by 11 countries, including Japan and Norway. South Pacific whale species include the sperm and humpback.
AP, Adelaide

webTitle: NYPD carpets nine for park rampage assaults

fields.headline: NYPD carpets nine for park rampage assaults
fields.trailText: New York city police and victims' lawyers were squabbling yesterday about a decision to discipline nine officers, six of them supervisors, for failing to do their job properly when a gang rampaged in Central Park and sexually assaulted nearly 60 women.
fields.body:
New York city police and victims' lawyers were squabbling yesterday about a decision to discipline nine officers, six of them supervisors, for failing to do their job properly when a gang rampaged in Central Park and sexually assaulted nearly 60 women.

The attacks, in which women were sprayed with water and beer and some had their clothes torn off, happened in one of the city's most visible locations after the Puerto Rican Day parade nearly a month ago. Twenty-nine men have been arrested and another 17 are being sought.

A police department inquiry confirmed that some officers had failed to respond to reports of assaults and that the planning for the aftermath of the parade, watched by about a million people, was flawed.

None of the officers is likely to be dismissed. Two senior officers in charge of the operation will be given letters of instruction noting its shortcomings, and three civilian dispatchers will be disciplined for improper handling of calls.

The inquiry found that two officers failed to take women's complaints seriously.

"I think this is a disgrace," said Susan Karten, lawyer for one of the victims, who included a 14-year-old girl, three British tourists and a French couple on their honeymoon. "Admitting they did wrong is a good step, but I would like to have seen more accountability at the top. I don't think a letter of instruction in someone's file makes the city any safer."

John Driscoll, president of the Captains' Endowment Association, which represents senior officers, said: "This wasn't an investigation, it was a witch-hunt.

"These people worked a long, hard day and the department is offering them up to pander to the politicians, the community and the media."

fields.headline: Branding bridges the great divide
fields.standfirst: News Analysis Sweden and Denmark follow the trend of nations joining to create business regions
fields.trailText: Øresund - the California of Scandinavia. Well, not quite yet, perhaps. But with the help of a fresh image resembling a cross between quirky cartoon character eyes and smooth pebbles propping each other up, the "new" region this week embarked on a campaign to win increased investment and visitors.
fields.body:
Øresund - the California of Scandinavia. Well, not quite yet, perhaps. But with the help of a fresh image resembling a cross between quirky cartoon character eyes and smooth pebbles propping each other up, the "new" region this week embarked on a campaign to win increased investment and visitors.

This is no ordinary drive for regional investment and awareness. It is being waged by an area which spans two countries, two languages and two cultures which have fought bitter wars against each other over the centuries but are now united by an elegant 10 mile bridge and tunnel.

If the delicate branding exercise, launched this week, is successful, in five years or so Øresund should be an area that is ingrained in consciousness of the world's businesses and tourists.

It takes its name from the body of water, which in English would be known as a sound, that until last week had divided the Danish capital Copenhagen from Sweden's third city, Malmo for the best part of 7,000 years.

Who might come here? It is already the home to four of the world's five biggest hearing aid manufacturers and, with a population of 3m - the highest population concentration in Scandinavia - as well as a highly educated workforce, wants to build on its presence in fast-growing, people intensive industries such as biotechnology, media and IT.

"We would like to get our growth rate higher than the average in Denmark and Sweden which would be about 5% of GNP each year," said Jacob Vestergaard, chief executive officer of Øresund's identity committee.

"We had two brands called Denmark and Sweden. This a little bit different. We'd like to have one and one equal to three."

The advertising agency Wolff Olins, which created the brand and launched it this week, believes that if it is successful other regions which span national boundaries could also be enticed to embark on similar exercises.

"Supranational bodies such as the European Union will put more of a role on exercises such as this," said Robert Jones, consultant director at Wolff Olins.

Another region which could be a prime candidate for the rebranding treatment is Kent and the north coast of France, like Øresund once separated by water and now united by a tunnel.

"It's a big issue in Kent. Ten French businesses open in Ashford every week," said Mr Jones. Other areas divided by national borders, such as Italy and Slovenia and SaarLorLux, the patch of land bordering Luxembourg with Saarbrucken in Germany and Lorraine in France, might also fit the bill.

Øresund is, in many ways, the test-bed for any future cross-border regional branding exercises. It is a rare example of a cross-border campaign; most other branding exercises have focused on countries or cities, such as Portugal or Hull.

According to Wolff Olins, devising a brand for a city or country is already more complicated than inventing one for a product where only consumers need to be satisfied by a name or identity.

Corporate brands, particularly when companies are merging, are more complicated because shareholders, managers and workers alike need to feel content, while with a city, a set of local characteristics have to be encapsulated.

The issue with cross-border brands, say advertisers, is the need to unite people of different cultures as well as to get the correct message across to the outside world.

In the case of Øresund, the catalyst was the new £1.8bn bridge and tunnel which united land masses in Denmark and Sweden that, until a bitter battle 1658, was part of the Danish empire. The original project was to brand the bridge, not the separate areas it was uniting.

As part of the year-long exercise to create a brand for the region, Wolff Olins devised an entirely new name - Eko was one example - while one of the early logos was a cliché Viking hat with a face; another was a play on the English translation of the body of water, sound.

After researching the idea in Asia and the US, Øresund was the final version, even though few people outside Scandinavia had heard of it and found it difficult to pronounce. Measuring the success of such branding exercises is difficult. One example cited by Wolff Olins is that of Portugal, which 10 years or so after it embarked on its branding exercise, is now attracting tourists to areas other than the Algarve.

For Øresund, an image like California is a goal, portraying one style but allowing individual cities - in the way San Francisco and Los Angeles are able - to retain their own identities.

It is the man and woman in the street who might be the first to know if other regions are embarking on a new branding exercise, however. Watch out for the clipboard wielding researchers canvassing opinions on Lilash, the new region uniting Ashford with Lille.

This is no ordinary drive for regional investment and awareness. It is being waged by an area which spans two countries, two languages and two cultures which have fought bitter wars against each other over the centuries but are now united by an elegant 10 mile bridge and tunnel. If the delicate branding exercise, launched this week, is successful, in five years or so Øresund should be an area that is ingrained in consciousness of the world's businesses and tourists. It takes its name from the body of water, which in English would be known as a sound, that until last week had divided the Danish capital Copenhagen from Sweden's third city, Malmo for the best part of 7,000 years. Who might come here? It is already the home to four of the world's five biggest hearing aid manufacturers and, with a population of 3m - the highest population concentration in Scandinavia - as well as a highly educated workforce, wants to build on its presence in fast-growing, people intensive industries such as biotechnology, media and IT. "We would like to get our growth rate higher than the average in Denmark and Sweden which would be about 5% of GNP each year," said Jacob Vestergaard, chief executive officer of Øresund's identity committee. "We had two brands called Denmark and Sweden. This a little bit different. We'd like to have one and one equal to three." The advertising agency Wolff Olins, which created the brand and launched it this week, believes that if it is successful other regions which span national boundaries could also be enticed to embark on similar exercises. "Supranational bodies such as the European Union will put more of a role on exercises such as this," said Robert Jones, consultant director at Wolff Olins. Another region which could be a prime candidate for the rebranding treatment is Kent and the north coast of France, like Øresund once separated by water and now united by a tunnel. "It's a big issue in Kent. Ten French businesses open in Ashford every week," said Mr Jones. Other areas divided by national borders, such as Italy and Slovenia and SaarLorLux, the patch of land bordering Luxembourg with Saarbrucken in Germany and Lorraine in France, might also fit the bill. Øresund is, in many ways, the test-bed for any future cross-border regional branding exercises. It is a rare example of a cross-border campaign; most other branding exercises have focused on countries or cities, such as Portugal or Hull. According to Wolff Olins, devising a brand for a city or country is already more complicated than inventing one for a product where only consumers need to be satisfied by a name or identity. Corporate brands, particularly when companies are merging, are more complicated because shareholders, managers and workers alike need to feel content, while with a city, a set of local characteristics have to be encapsulated. The issue with cross-border brands, say advertisers, is the need to unite people of different cultures as well as to get the correct message across to the outside world. In the case of Øresund, the catalyst was the new £1.8bn bridge and tunnel which united land masses in Denmark and Sweden that, until a bitter battle 1658, was part of the Danish empire. The original project was to brand the bridge, not the separate areas it was uniting. As part of the year-long exercise to create a brand for the region, Wolff Olins devised an entirely new name - Eko was one example - while one of the early logos was a cliché Viking hat with a face; another was a play on the English translation of the body of water, sound. After researching the idea in Asia and the US, Øresund was the final version, even though few people outside Scandinavia had heard of it and found it difficult to pronounce. Measuring the success of such branding exercises is difficult. One example cited by Wolff Olins is that of Portugal, which 10 years or so after it embarked on its branding exercise, is now attracting tourists to areas other than the Algarve. For Øresund, an image like California is a goal, portraying one style but allowing individual cities - in the way San Francisco and Los Angeles are able - to retain their own identities. It is the man and woman in the street who might be the first to know if other regions are embarking on a new branding exercise, however. Watch out for the clipboard wielding researchers canvassing opinions on Lilash, the new region uniting Ashford with Lille.

webTitle: Easy path through EU's green frontier

fields.headline: Easy path through EU's green frontier
fields.trailText: The tragedy of the 58 Chinese immigrants who suffocated while being smuggled to Britain a fortnight ago is forcing the authorities to step up the policing of the permeable Czech border.
fields.byline: Kate Connolly on the Czech-German border
fields.body:
The tragedy of the 58 Chinese immigrants who suffocated while being smuggled to Britain a fortnight ago is forcing the authorities to step up the policing of the permeable Czech border.

In response to the international pressure since it was revealed that the Chinese trekked through the Czech Republic, there have been emergency meetings between the authorities on both sides of the Czech and German frontiers, resulting in proposals to upgrade equipment, increase staffing and make significant policy changes.

Desperately under-financed and poorly staffed, the Czech border patrols have been given temporary use of the latest human detection equipment by their German counterparts. they are bringing carbon dioxide detectors and thermal cameras into play in their effort to clamp down on what Czech officials say is an increasingly disturbing trend in mass human smuggling.

Officials are also introducing "shifting" patrols which will move along the border randomly in an effort to foil smugglers who rely on dodging predictable policing.

Since communism collapsed in 1989 the Czech Republic, which boasts more borders with western countries than any country in the former eastern bloc, has found itself labelled the major transit post between east and west on the human smuggling route.

As the top contender for European Union entry, the it has been warned by Brussels that demonstrating that it can keep the eastern edge of the EU tightly sealed is a prerequisite for joining the union.

Between January 1 and the end of May, 14,000 people from Asia and eastern Europe were caught attempting to cross the border illegally. Most of them had paid underground "travel agents", sometimes including police officers, tens of thousands of dollars to courier them. The police estimate that in the same period five times that number got through undetected.

At the border town of Cinovec, which through which 600 trucks pass each day, guards said they had been ordered by a transport ministry emergency directive to be more vigilant on the long "green lines"- the easily penetrated swaths of border forest and scrubland where 90% of the illegal refugees cross on foot, on motorbikes, or in jeeps that smash through rusty metal posts.

The smugglers often drop them near the green line before driving through an official border crossing, where an empty lorry arouses little suspicion.

Customs officials at Cinovec have intercepted three truckloads of people in the past six weeks. At the end of May six Chinese were found in an Avia truck, standing in 30cm spaces behind false wooden walls, according to Captain Bohumil Vitner.

Last week 20 Afghans were discovered clambering into the back of a lorry waiting to be taken by train into Germany.

The Czechs are insufficiently armed to fight the cause. Poorly paid, they have walkie-talkies, basic computer systems and telephones to keep them in constant touch with their German colleagues. In stark contrast, the Germans have more people, hi-tech thermal equipment, heat sensors, and one of the latest weapons, the £2,000 carbon dioxide detector which the Zinnowald border police lent to the Czechs after the Dover tragedy.

"We let drivers know what we're doing and hope they'll spread the message and it'll act as a deterrent," Capt Vitner said.

Vlastimil Schlecta laughed when asked the difference between controlling the borders now and a decade ago. When he was head of border guards who policed Czechoslovakia's eastern edge under communism, problems were few.

"Then, everything was focused on keeping people in, and for every 15km [9 miles] stretch there were 60 guards. Now we have just 15, and it's a nightmare, like fighting windmills," he said. If extra troops were needed for a football match they were pulled from the border police, so low was their status.

Other senior officials also bemoan the fact that the penalties for smuggling are so low. "Under communism punishment was by execution," said Josef Lech, a guard at Cinovec. "Now it's just two years in jail or a fine."

The Prague office of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees said that almost all migrants caught at the border used the Czech Republic as a base from which to continue their attempts to get into the west. The number of asylum cases in the Czech Republic rose from 1,417 in 1995 to more than 9,000 last year.

Marzia Ahmad, a 28-year old teacher from Afghanistan, is aware of the dangers, having experienced them first hand. Five days ago she and her family, including a four-month-old baby girl, were picked up after two months on the road from their home in war-torn Kabul.

Her description of the journey, in broken English, included men dressed in balaclavas and time spent in underground cells.

"We didn't have enough to eat and drink, so my milk dried up. Just before we got caught they pushed us out into the jungle and and kicked us to walk faster before driving off."
